metadata.title: ACVIM ABSTRACTS 5 WARMUP EXERCISE ALTERS ENERGY METABOLISM AND MUSCLE GLYCOGENOLYSIS DURING SUBSEQUENT SPRINT EXERCISE IN HORSES 6 EFFECT OF DIET AND EXERCISE INTENSITY ON CREATINE KINASE ACTIVITY IN THOROUGHBRED HORSES WITH RE- CURRENT EXERTIONAL RHABDOMYOLYSIS (RER). 8 SEVERITY CLASSIFICATION OF COWS WITH ACUTE CO- LIFORM MASTITIS BASED ON SYSTEMIC DISEASE SIGNS AND ASSOCIATED CLINICOPATHOLOGIC DATA

abstract.text: This study examined the effects of three different warm-up protocols on energy metabolism and muscle glycogenolysis during subsequent high intensity exercise. Our hypotheses were: 1) prior warmup exercise would increase aerobic energy production and decrease the rate of muscle glycogen degradation and the anaerobic contribution to energy production during subsequent sprint exercise, and 2) higher intensity warmup exercise would further enhance the aerobic energy contribution to total energy expenditure. Six fit Standardbred horses exercised at 115% VO 2max until fatigued (sprint exercise [SPR]), after each of three protocols: 1) no warm-up (NoWU); 2) 10 min of trotting at 50% VO 2max (LoWU); and 3) 7 min at 50% VO 2max followed by 45s intervals at 80, 90, and 100% VO 2max (HiWU). Respiratory gas exchange (VO 2 , VCO 2 ) and accumulated O 2 deficit (AOD) were measured during warmup and SPR. Mixed venous blood samples were obtained before and after warmup, and post SPR. Middle gluteal muscle samples for measurement of metabolite concentrations (ATP, PCr, G-6-P, muscle lactate [La mu ], glycogen) and calculation of the rate of ATP provision from anaerobic pathways were collected before and immediately after SPR.

When SPR was preceded by a warmup, peak VO 2 was higher (PϽ0.05) and AOD, expressed per min of exercise, was lower (PϽ0.05) than in NoWU. Following warmup exercise, net rate of muscle glycogen degradation was lower (LoWU: 40%; HiWU: 20%) and post SPR increases in G-6-P and decreases in PCr were significantly (PϽ0.05) diminished when compared to NoWU. Rates of blood and muscle lactate accumulation and the rate of anaerobic ATP provision during SPR, calculated from changes in ATP, PCr, and La mu , were significantly lower (PϽ0.05) in LoWU and HiWU than in NoWU. Mean run time in LoWU (173 Ϯ 10s) was greater (PϽ0.01) than in HiWU (142 Ϯ 11s) and NoWU (124 Ϯ 4s). We conclude that warmup was associated with an augmentation of the aerobic energy contribution to total energy expenditure, a decreased rate of glycogenolysis, lower O 2 deficit per min of exercise, and longer runtime to fatigue during subsequent sprint exercise, with no additional benefit from a high vs. a low intensity warmup. and *Kentucky Equine Research Inc., 3910 Delaney Ferry Rd., Versailles, KY 40383.

Diets high in carbohydrate (CHO) have anecdotally been reported to predispose horses to exertional rhabdomyolysis, purportedly by increasing muscle glycogen content leading to excessive breakdown of glycogen and severe lactic acidosis. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of 3 diets with variable soluble CHO and fat content and the effect of variable exercise intensity (gallop, canter, or trot) on plasma CK and plasma lactate (PL) concentration in TB horses with RER. Five TB with RER and 3 healthy TB were used. Diagnosis was established by the intermittent occurrence of exercise associated muscle cramping accompanied by elevated CK and abnormal caffeine contracture tests. Diets were formulated to meet (21.4 Mcal DE/day for low CHO and fat diets) or exceed daily requirements (28.8 Mcal DE/day for high CHO diet). Diets were fed in a crossover design for 3 week blocks. Horses exercised on a treadmill Mon. through Fri. Max speed on Mon. and Fri. was 11 m/s (6% slope), on Tue. and Thu. 9 m/s and on Wed. 4.5 m/s. Venous blood was obtained before, after and 4 h after exercise. Data was analyzed using an analysis of variance. RER horses had higher pre, but not post exercise, PL compared to controls. PL and CK were not correlated in RER horses (r 2 ϭ 0.01). There was no effect of diet or exercise intensity on CK in controls. RER horses consuming the high CHO diet had a greater increase in CK compared to the low CHO or fat diets (mean Ϯ sem,High CHO 561 Ϯ 109 U/l, low CHO 95 Ϯ 109 U/l, pϭ 0.002, fat 273 Ϯ 106 U/l, pϭ 0.06). RER horses exercised at the trot or canter had significantly greater increases in CK compared to galloped RER horses (Canter 384 Ϯ 96 U/l, Trot 439 Ϯ 126 U/l, Gallop 106 Ϯ 97 U/l, pϭ 0.04). RER horses fed the high CHO diet and trotted had the greatest post exercise CK (1226 Ϯ 168 U/l). Therefore, in TB horses susceptible to RER, diets high in CHO, formulated to exceed daily requirements, increase episodes of rhabdomyolysis. However rhabdomyolysis was not associated with high PL and occurred at speeds below the lactate threshold.

The purpose of this study was to assess the signalment, history, clinical and laboratory findings, and outcome of beef cattle with left (LDA) or right (RDA) displaced abomasum or abomasal volvulus (AV), and to compare them to similar reported characteristics dairy cattle, especially those used as prognostic indicators. Data were obtained for all cases of LDA, RDA, and AV in beef cattle admitted to the TAMU-VTH from 1/1/88 to 11/1/98. Odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals for breed and sex were computed. There were 14 AV's, 4 RDA's and 1 LDA. The LDA occurred in a 13-mon-old Brahman bull presented for abdominal distension of 3 days' and the bull survived. There were 7 Brahmans, 5 crossbreeds, 3 Beefmasters, 2 Brangus and 1 Santa Gertrudis with RDA or AV. Twelve were males. The median age was 10 mon(range, 1 to 72 mon) . Brahman cattle were more likely to develop RDA or AV than were other beef cattle (OR ϭ8.4 ; CI 95 ϭ 3.8-18.5). Males were more likely to develop RDA or AV than were females (OR ϭ3.6; CI 95 ϭ 1.4-9.0). Abdominal distention was observed in 11, heart rate Ն100 bpm in 14, and the abomasum was palpable on all of which a rectal examination was performed. Leukocytosis (7/10), neutrophilia (7/10), hyperglycemia (9/9), azotemia (9/9), hypochloremia (12/13) and hypokalemia (8/13) were frequent laboratory findings. Twelve of 18 survived, but 3 had ruptured abomasa at surgery. The duration of signs before examination in beef cattle was longer(median duration ϭ 3 days), but the survival rate in those without abomasal rupture was similar to that of dairy cattle. Beef cattle appear to have more frequent and severe clinical and clinicopathological abnormalities, specifically tachycardia, azotemia, hypochloremia, and hyperglycemia. Prognostic indicators recommended for dairy cattle may not be useful for beef cattle.

body_text.text: PORT H.C. Schott II, C.L. Coursen, S.W. Eberhart, R.F. Nachreiner, K.R. Refsal, S.L. Ewart, and J. V. Marteniuk. College of Veterinary Medicine, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI. During 1997-98, 67 Michigan horses were confirmed to have equine Cushings disease on the basis of characteristic clinical signs and the results of either a dexamethasone suppression test (DST), a thyrotropin (TRH) stimulaton test, or an elevated serum insulin concentration (Ͼ300 pmol/l). Presenting complaints included hirsuitism, hyperhidrosis, and muscle wasting. A substantial number (52%) had chronic laminitis as the major clinical problem. Changes in endocrine test results were compared after 6 months in horses that were either untreated (NT) or treated with pergolide (P, 2 ug/kg PO, q 24 h) or cyproheptidine (C, 1.2 mg/kg 3/4 PO, q 24 h). Ten horses had died or were euthanatized within the first 6 months with 70% attributable to complications of Cushings disease. As of the start of 1999, 6 month evaluations had been completed for 19 horses and were pending for 19 horses. 19 horses failed to remain on treatment for 6 months or had incomplete follow-up testing. Preliminary results (Table) support that treatment of equine Cushings disease warrants pursuit and that reversal of abnormal endocrine test results (DST/TRH) appears to be better with pergolide (6/9 ϭ 67%) than with cyproheptidine (2/6 ϭ 33%). In addition to being more problematic in terms of sample collection and handling when used under field conditions, preliminary results suggest that measurement of plasma ACTH concentration may be the least reliable diagnostic test for equine Cushings disease. Equine RAO is characterized by the development of clinical signs of airway obstruction and an airspace neutrophilia following exposure of susceptible horses to mouldy forage. We investigated the functional state of blood and airspace neutrophils (PMN) from RAO susceptible horses after a 5 h hay/straw challenge.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Venous blood and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) were collected 10 d before and 5 and 24 h and 4, 7 and 14 d after the initiation of the challenge. Respiratory burst activity of purified blood PMN and mixed BALF cells was measured by luminol (produced from PMN only) and lucigenin-dependent chemiluminescence (DCL) both basally and in response to the formylpeptide fMLP Ϫ 1M, Zymosan Activated Plasma Ϫ 10% (ZAP) and phorbol myristate acetate Ϫ 100ng/ml (PMA). Equine neutrophil elastase (ENE) was measured in BALF supernatant as a marker of PMN degranulation, by ELISA and its functional activity measured by cleavage of the chromogenic substrate N-methoxy-ALA-ALA-PRO-VAL p-Nitroanilide. Challenge induced a significant increase in absolute and differential BALF PMN counts at 5 and 24 h.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Basal lucigenin-and luminol-DCL of blood PMN were significantly increased (pϽ0.05) at 24 h after challenge. fMLP-stimulated lucigenin-DCL was increased (pϽ0.05) at 24 h consistent with a primed response. Basal BALF cell lucigeninand luminol-DCL was unchanged following challenge, but fMLP, ZAP and PMA induced luminol-DCL of BALF cells was significantly increased (pϽ0.05) at 5 and 24 h in direct correlation with the increased proportion of PMN.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Concentrations of ENE in BALF measured by ELISA were significantly elevated (pϽ0.05) compared to baseline (median: 3.6 ng/ml; range, 1.2-4.6) at 5 h (55.3; 4.9-360.3), 24 h (35.6; 9.6-15.8) and 4 d (14.7; 5.4-29. 3) after challenge but no functional ENE activity was detectable at any timepoint, consistent with functional inhibition by antiproteases.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: These results suggest that blood and BALF PMN are significantly primed in vivo for an enhanced respiratory burst following hay/straw challenge and that on recruitment to the airspaces PMN degranulate. The interaction between reactive oxygen species, proteases and antiproteases in the microenvironment of the pulmonary epithelium may play a role in the pathogenesis of equine RAO. Exercise-induced pulmonary hemorrhage (EIPH) occurs frequently in racehorses. Exercising horses develop severe pulmonary capillary hypertension, and the ensuing high transmural pulmonary capillary pressure contributes to the stress failure of pulmonary capillaries, resulting in EIPH. Nitric oxide (NO) is an endogenous vasodilator substance, which plays an important role in modulating the pulmonary vascular tone. Thus, in the present study, we investigated whether IV administration of nitroglycerin-a known NO donor, would attenuate the exercise-induced pulmonary capillary hypertension, and thereby, affect the incidence of EIPH in strenuously exercising racehorses. Five healthy, sound, exercise-trained Thoroughbred horses were studied at rest and during incremental treadmill exercise performed at 6, 8 and 14.2m/s on a 5% uphill grade in the control (no medications) and nitroglycerin (20g/kg/min, IV) experiments. Galloping at 14.2m/s on a 5% uphill grade elicited maximal heart rate (212 Ϯ 2 beats/min), and the horses could not sustain this workload for Ͼ90s. The nitroglycerin dosage for our experiments was selected based on separate trials in standing horses where it was demonstrated that maximal pulmonary/systemic hemodynamic effects of IV nitroglycerin are elicited at 5g/kg/min, and that increasing the dose 4-fold (to 20g/kg/min) did not cause any ill effects. In control experiments, exercise resulted in a significant (PϽ0.05) progressive increase in right atrial as well as pulmonary arterial, capillary and wedge pressures, and all horses experienced EIPH. Nitroglycerin infusion significantly (PϽ0.05) decreased the right atrial and pulmonary vascular pressures of standing horses while heart rate increased significantly. In the nitroglycerin-infusion experiments, exercise at 6 and 8m/s also resulted in a progressive significant (PϽ0.05) rise in the right atrial as well as pulmonary arterial, capillary and wedge pressures, but these values were found to be significantly (PϽ0.05) less than in the control experiments. However, this did not occur during galloping at 14.2m/s on a 5% uphill grade, when right atrial and pulmonary arterial, capillary and wedge pressures approached values observed in the control experiments, and all horses experienced EIPH. Thus, while IV nitroglycerin significantly attenuated the exercise-induced pulmonary capillary hypertension at sub-maximal workloads, attenuation did not occur during high-intensity exertion and the incidence of EIPH remained unaffected. The objective of this study was to examine the effects of glucose infusion on glucose kinetics in horses during exercise. We hypothesized that increased blood glucose availability would suppress the exercise-induced increment in hepatic glucose production (HGP) but increase whole-body disposal of blood glucose. In random order, 6 Standardbred horses completed two exercise trials consisting of running on a treadmill for 90 min at 34 Ϯ 1% of peak oxygen uptake. In one trial (Glu) glucose was infused for the duration of exercise at a mean rate of 34.9 Ϯ 1.1 mol/kg/min, while in the other trial (Con) an equivalent volume of saline was infused. In both trials, a primed constant-rate infusion of the stable isotopically-labeled tracer [6,6-2 H]glucose was given for measurement of glucose kinetics. Blood samples for determination of plasma glucose concentrations and isotopic enrichment (GCMS analysis) were collected at regular intervals. The rates of appearance (R a ) and disappearance (R d ) of glucose were determined by using a one-pool non-steady-state kinetic model. In Con, glucose R a was assumed to reflect HGP, whereas in Glu HGP was calculated as the difference between the measured total R a and the rate of glucose infusion.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: In Glu, plasma glucose increased progressively during exercise (rest: 4.9 Ϯ 0.3 mM; 90 min exercise: 8.2 Ϯ 1.2 mM), whereas plasma glucose in Con was unchanged. In Con, HGP increased from 6.3 Ϯ 1.5 mol/kg/min at rest to 29.6 Ϯ 2.5 mol/kg/min after 90 min of exercise. In Glu, there was complete suppression of the increase in HGP during the first 45 min of exercise. Although HGP increased during the remainder of exercise in Glu, values were 50-60% lower when compared to Con. During exercise, glucose R d increased in both trials. However, between 30 and 90 min of exercise, values were 50-75% higher (PϽ0.001) in Glu than in Con. These results indicate that: 1) exogenous glucose infusion suppresses the exercise-associated increase in HGP in horses during low-intensity exercise; and 2) increased glucose availability enhances utilization of plasma glucose during exercise, as reflected by the higher values for glucose R d in Glu. Importantly, these data demonstrate the utility of the stable-isotope tracer method for determination of glucose flux in horses during exercise. Multiple logistic regression models available in the literature to predict outcome of cows with a definitive diagnosis of right abomasal displacement or abomasal volvulus (RDA/AV) were evaluated using data from the veterinary teaching hospital (VTH) of the FMV Saint-Hyacinthe. A retrospective study was conducted on the medical records of cows admitted to the VTH from 1989 to 1994 with RDA/AV (nϭ295). It was followed by a prospective study conducted on 131 RDA/AV cases admitted to the VTH from 1995 to 1998.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: A hundred of these cows were considered non-productive (NP) when discharged while 325 were considered productive (P). We applied the published models (Constable et al JAVMA 198:2077 -2085 and Gröhn et al AJVR 51: 1895 -1899 to every cows. The predicted outcome was categorized either as P or NP and compared to the real outcome. The total correct classification rate (TCCR), sensitivity (Se), specificity (Sp), negative predictive value (NPV) and positive predictive value (PPV) of each model to predict NP were calculated. *Only the AV cases were included for validation of models of Constable et al. Prevalence of NP in this group was higher than in Constable et al's population. These models were less effective in our population than originally published. The models of Gröhn et al were as effective in our population, despite a lower NP prevalence in our study. A low PPV restricts their common use in our VTH. Internal potassium (Kϩ) balance has been evaluated by Fenwick in relation with hypocalcemia (Fenwick et al Austr.Vet.J. 60: 313-314.1983 ). Two types of cattle have been described with respect to red blood cell K concentration (RBCK) (Christinaz et al. J.Physiol. 224: 391-406.1972 ): high RBCK (average ϭ 80 mmol/L of erythrocytes (ER)) and low RBCK (average ϭ 20 mmol/L of ER), the most prevalent phenotype. A distinct syndrome of dairy cattle has been associated with hypokalemia. A first objective of this study was to develop a practical method of measurement for both internal and external Kϩ balances in dairy cows. A second objective was to study the internal and external Kϩ balances variation due to the lactation period and during the day.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Nineteen cows were randomly selected from the University herd with respect to the lactation group and number. Four cows were obtained from the early lactation (EL) group (11 to 30 days in milk (DIM)), 4 from the peak (P) lactation group (31 to 90 DIM), 4 from the late lactation (LL) group (225 or more DIM), 4 from the dry cows (D) group and 3 from the freshly calved (FC) group (1 to 10 DIM). Serum, heparinized blood, urine and milk were collected at 7 moments of the day. Kalemia (SK), RBCK, fractional urinary clearance of potassium (FeK) and milk Kϩ concentration (MLK) were measured.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Mean SK was 4.6 mmol/L (Ϯ 0.3). Mean RBCK was 21.6 mmol/L of ER (Ϯ 3.3). Average FeK was 80.1 mmol/L (Ϯ 33.9). Mean MLK was 43.6 mmol / L (Ϯ 12.3). Mean ingested K (IK) was 293 g / cow (Ϯ 53 g). There were significant variations during the day for RBCK, FeK and MLK. The mean MLK of LL (30.5 mmol / L) was lower than mean MLK (48.3 mmol / L) of the other groups (pϭ0.03). Ingested Kϩ was statistically correlated with FeK (pϭ0.005). There was no correlation between IK and MLK. Thus, this method of evaluation of the potassium status of dairy cows appears feasible. However, due to variations during the day, it is important to collect samples at the same moment every day, when long term Kϩ balance evolution is to be considered. Inflammation or ischemic damage to bowel may alter motility in affected bowel or even in ''normal'' bowel adjacent to affected areas. The purpose of this research was to evaluate the effects of short-term ischemia on the activity and responses of adjacent small intestine (SI).
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Jejunal samples were taken from 9 ponies at sites proximal and distal to SI made ischemic for 60-90 minutes. General activity patterns, responses to electrical field stimulation (EFS)-induced neuronal depolarization, and responses to norepinephrine (NE) were compared to the responses of a section of SI taken prior to ischemic insult.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: Both proximal and distal segments had evidence of decreased contractility. Contraction frequency was decreased in longitudinal muscle taken from sites proximal and distal to the ischemic SI, as compared to normal SI from the same horse. Distal sections had lower contraction frequency than proximal sections. Circular muscle strips were also affected, but to a lesser degree. The contractile response to EFS was less in proximal and distal longitudinal muscle strips kept at low tension as compared to normal SI. At high tension, distal sections relaxed less in response to EFS than did normal SI. In response to NE, proximal and distal longitudinal muscle strips were less contractile initially and proximal strips did not relax as much as controls during the second phase. Proximal circular muscle strips had a prolonged relaxation response to NE.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: The results indicate even short term ischemia can significantly affect the adjacent ''normal'' bowel. Discrepancies between proximal and distal SI motility patterns and alterations in the response to NE would be of particular concern in postoperative patients and could lead to clinical ileus or slowed transit. If similar changes occurred with enteritis or peritonitis, abnormal transit or absorption could result. Gastric ulcers are common in performance horses. The purpose of this study was to determine the efficacy of omeprazole paste in treating gastric ulcers and to determine a dosage regimen to prevent recurrence of gastric ulcers in Thoroughbred horses in race training. In a multicentre clinical study, 100 Thoroughbred horses with endoscopically verified gastric ulcers induced by race training were used. At each trial site, replicates of four horses were formed on approximately Day 2 based primarily on baseline gastric ulcer scores and secondarily on sex. Within replicates, one horse was randomly allocated to a control group, sham dosed with an empty syringe, and the other three horses received omeprazole orally at 4 mg/kg bwt once daily for 28 days. Following endoscopy on Day 27, omeprazole-treated horses were again blocked primarily based on gastric ulcer score and secondarily on sex. Within blocks of three, horses were randomly allocated to sham dosing with an empty syringe, or to treatment with omeprazole at 2.0 mg/kg once daily, or 4.0 mg/kg once daily for 30 days. Original sham dosed horses continued as controls for 57 days.
body_text.section: THE MICHIGAN CUSHINGS PROJECT: A PRELIMINARY RE-

body_text.text: At Day 27 (after 28 daily doses) gastric ulcers were completely healed in 77% of omeprazole treated horses, compared to 4% in controls, and the severity of the ulcers was reduced from baseline in 92% of treated horses, compared to 32% of controls (PϽ0.01). After 30 additional daily doses, ulcer scores were reduced or unchanged in 84% and 88% of horses treated with 2 or 4 mg/kg/day, respectively, compared to 16% for controls (PϽ0.01). There was no significant (PϽ0.20) difference in the change in ulcer scores between horses treated with omeprazole at either 2 or 4 mg/kg/day for that additional 30 daily dose period.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: These results clearly demonstrate that omeprazole paste, administered at 4 mg/ kg bwt once daily for 28 days, was effective in healing gastric ulcers in Thoroughbred race horses in training, while 2 mg/kg bwt once daily effectively prevented recurrence of gastric ulcers. Intravenous lidocaine has been used for the treatment of postoperative ileus (POI) in people. The purpose of our study was to investigate its usefulness in the treatment of equine POI and proximal duodenitis-jejunitis (PDJ). A doubleblinded multicenter study was undertaken. Horses with a diagnosis of POI or PDJ and Ն20 liters of reflux or refluxing Ͼ12 hours were given lidocaine or a saline placebo (bolus of 1.3 mg/kg followed by 0.05 mg/kg/minute for 24 hours). Comparisons were made in terms of reflux volume, physical parameters, pain, complications, and days hospitalized. Comparisons were also made between data collected before, during and after lidocaine therapy on trial horses and other horses given lidocaine in a non-blinded fashion.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: Significantly more cases receiving lidocaine stopped refluxing during the lidocaine infusion or within 6 hours of discontinuing the lidocaine than did saline controls. 63% of POI cases and 50% of PDJ horses stopped refluxing within 6 hours of discontinuing the iv drip. 59% stopped refluxing during the infusion. By 12 hours after treatment, 79% of treated horses had stopped refluxing. All lidocaine-treated cases had significantly less reflux during the infusion than prior to treatment. No significant differences were detected in heart rate, respiratory rate, or temperature. POI cases treated with lidocaine were discharged 4 days earlier than either PDJ cases or saline controls. Side effects included muscle fasciculations, ataxia, delayed detection of laminitis pain, and potentially increased incisional infection rates.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: In summary, lidocaine is an inexpensive motility modifier that appears to be both relatively safe and at least moderately effective for the treatment of equine ileus. However, the results suggest it does not simply act by inhibiting increased sympathetic bowel tone, as has been theorized.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of erythromycin lactobionate (EM) on myoelectric activity (MA) of the ileum, cecum and pelvic flexure of horses during the post-operative(PO) period and the post-recovery(PR) period (Ն 8 days PO). In 8 mature horses, 16 bipolar electrodes were implanted into the ileum(4), cecum(6) and pelvic flexure(6), and the jejunum was rubbed vigorously to mimic surgical trauma. At approximately 4, 16, and 24 hr PO, and during the PR period, 0.5 mg/kg EM was administered IV and MA was recorded. Recordings were evaluated by visual observation and by computer. Ratios of activity indices for 5-and 15-min segments before and after EM were compared using a generalized linear models approach and Duncan's multiple range test. During the PO period, decreased MA and alteration of the normal motility patterns of the gut were most pronounced in the cecum and least pronounced in the ileum. MA was essentially absent in the cecum 4 hr PO. The activity index was significantly greater following EM in the ileum during all PO sessions, but not during the PR session, in the cecum only during the PR session, and in the pelvic flexure during the PO and the PR sessions. During one 15-min period following EM for each region of the intestine, the activity index was decreased compared to before EM.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: Intravenous EM has an effect on MA of equine large and small intestine, and could be useful as a prokinetic drug for horses. The prokinetic effect of EM is not the same for different regions of the intestine nor is it the same during the PO period compared to the PR period. Because the effects EM administered during the PO period are not always the same as those administered after recovery, caution must be exercised when extrapolating the results of prokinetic studies carried out in normal animals to those with PO ileus or other dysmotilities. This study was designed to evaluate the control mechanisms of normal equine jejunal activity, particularly in regards to the neurotransmitters acetylcholine (ACH), norepinephrine (NE), substance P (SP), and nitric oxide (NO). Samples of normal jejunum, oriented in the plane of either the longitudinal (LM) or circular muscle (CM), were evaluated in vitro for their response to the neurotransmitters and for evidence of release of the neurotransmitters following electrical field stimulation (EFS). Samples were also evaluated histochemically for markers for ACH, SP, and NO.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF OMEPRAZOLE PASTE FOR TREATMENT

body_text.text: ACH contracted all muscle strips. Atropine altered EFS responses in a manner that suggested ACH may contract LM and low tension CM but that ACH can relax high tension CM.
NE produced a transient contractile response in LM and relaxed CM. During EFS, the response to adrenergic blockade indicated that NE relaxed LM and high tension CM, but contracted low tension LM.

SP increased the tone of all muscle strips. From EFS studies in the presence of a neurokinin-1 receptor blocker, it appeared that SP could either contract or relax jejunal muscle, depending upon muscle and stimulation parameters. SPlike immunoreactivity was present within the myenteric plexus and was partially colocalized with choline acetyltransferase-like immunoreactivity.

Sodium nitroprusside decreased the tone of high tension LM. NO synthase inhibitors altered the EFS response such that NO appeared to relax CM and high tension LM but contracted low tension LM. NADPH-diaphorase activity was demonstrated within the myenteric plexus.

These results suggest all 4 agents may function within the equine jejunum but that different situations and types of stimulation may alter the type of neurotransmitter release and corresponding muscle activity. Equine protozoal myeloencephalitis (EPM) is an emerging disease of critical importance to all horse industries. The disease is caused by the apicomplexan protozoan, Sarcocystis neurona; however, to date, S. neurona infection of horses has not been induced using molecularly-characterized sporocysts. We report here the induction of such infection in previously naïve horses.

Six horses were purchased and acclimated to an opossum-proof sand lot and a complete pelleted diet. Horses were negative by western blot for serum S. neurona IgG. Sporocysts were recovered from opossums (Didelphis virginiana pigra) and were categorized on the basis of 6 different genomic DNA sequences. Only sporocysts identified in this manner as S. neurona were used to challenge horses. Horses received either 1 or 6 consecutive daily doses of 5 ϫ 10 5 sporocysts by nasogastric tube and were then subjected to serial neurologic examination and sampling of blood and CSF. At 4 months, the challenged horses were necropsied.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: Horses challenged with a single dose of S. neurona seroconverted (N ϭ 2) and became western blot-positive in CSF. Seroconversion occurred between 19 and 26 days after challenge and antibodies were present in the CSF by 40 days. These horses did not develop convincing signs of neurologic disease. Contemporaneous unchallenged horses neither seroconverted nor displayed neurologic signs. Multiple sequential blinded samples submitted for western blot testing showed a very high degree of within-horse correlation. Horses challenged with 6 daily doses of S. neurona (N ϭ 2) developed unequivocal neurologic signs including limb weakness and ataxia. Findings on histopathologic examination of the CNS of horses given multiple doses were typical of EPM but no organism was identified or recovered.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: Characterized S. neurona sporocysts can induce clinical neurologic disease and seroconversion when administered by nasogastric tube to naïve horses. Clostridium difficile is associated with watery diarrhea and hemorrhagic, necrotizing enterocolitis in neonatal foals. The purpose of this study was to characterize isolates of C. difficile obtained from Thoroughbred foals with enterocolitis on a breeding farm over a two year period. Fourteen foals developed diarrhea between the age of 1 and 20 days. Fecal samples were cultured on cefoxitin-cycloserine-fructose (for C. difficile) as well as XLT4 agar plates and in selenite enrichment broth (for Salmonellae). An immunoassay was utilized to detect the presence of toxin A (Enterotoxin) in fecal samples. The presence of toxin A and B genes in cultured C. difficile isolates was evaluated by utilizing PCR. Genetic finger-printing of strains was performed using PCR. Antibiotic susceptibility testing was performed utilizing the Etest method.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: All 14 fecal samples were culture positive for C. difficile, and negative for Salmonellae. Toxin A was detected in 6/11 fecal samples tested. All 14 isolates of C. difficile were positive for the presence of toxin A and B genes. Five distinct strains were identified. Eight of 12 isolates tested for metronidazole susceptibility were determined to be resistant. Nine of 9 isolates were considered sensitive to vancomycin. All eight metronidazole-resistant isolates were of one strain type.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: This report describes the presence of toxin genes in and toxin production by C. difficile isolates cultured from 14 foals with diarrhea. These findings point to a diversity of strain types on one farm, however these strains were grouped with respect to time and antimicrobial susceptibility patterns. The finding of metronidazole resistance is interesting considering its paucity in isolates cultured from human patients with C. difficile enterocolitis. We have previously demonstrated that hemagglutinin (HA) gene DNA vaccination with or without IL-6 DNA coadministration, and influenza virus infection, all generate protective, but different, immune responses in horses. A study was performed to investigate the regional immunoregulatory mechanisms associated with these different immune responses.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: Horses were vaccinated with IL-6/HA DNA (Group1) or HA DNA only (Group 2) on three occasions using the PowderJect-XR gene gun. Group 3 horses were infected with influenza virus and Group 4 were controls. Nasal and serum antibody isotype responses were studied in all horses, and protection from challenge infection was studied in a subset of Groups 1 & 2. Animals from each group were euthanized; 14 days after the third vaccination (Groups 1& 2) or influenza infection (Group 3). Influenza virus-specific lymphoproliferative responses were determined in peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBLs) and lymph node lymphocytes (LNLs). The IL-2, IL-4 and IFN-␥ mRNA production in these lymphocyte populations was also measured by QRT-PCR.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: DNA vaccination prevented clinical disease and controlled viral shedding in both Groups 1 & 2, and was associated with IgGa and IgGb responses. Primary influenza virus infection (Group 3) produced identical IgG sub-isotype responses, but also generated a nasal IgA response. DNA vaccination was associated with lymphoproliferative responses in PBLs and inguinal LNLs, while influenza virus infection was associated with responses in PBLs, and hilar LNLs. The inguinal LNL lymphoproliferative responses in IL-6/HA DNA vaccinates (Group 2) were higher than in the HA DNA vaccinates (Group 1). Examination of cytokine production profiles indicates that these protective immune responses subsequent to DNA vaccination, or infection, are associated with different regional regulatory mechanisms. Our ability to design novel strategies to prevent infectious disease in the young calf is restricted by our limited understanding of how non-immunoglobulin maternal factors contribute to the immune system of the newborn. There is indirect evidence in cattle that maternal immune cells and antigen-specific immune cell responses are transferred to the calf. The aim of this study was to provide definitive genetic evidence for the transfer of cells from the cow to the newborn calf. This was achieved by using a sensitive and specific PCR-based assay to search calf immune tissues for maternal cells. The non-inherited allele of the bovine MHC BoLA-DRB3 gene was selected as a genetic marker for maternal cells since this is a highly polymorphic gene and therefore likely to be different between dam and calf. Genomic DNA was isolated from the PBMCs of ten Holstein cow-calf pairs. The BoLA-DRB3 genotype of each individual was determined using a technique combining PCR, denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis and automated sequencing. Four cow-calf pairs in which the non-inherited maternal BoLA-DRB3 allele (NIMDA) differed from the calf BoLA-DRB3 alleles were selected for study. Calves were fed 2 liters of fresh colostrum from their dam within 6 hours of birth, and maintained on commercial milk replacer. Calves were euthanized at 48-60 hours of age and multiple tissues collected at necropsy. Enriched lymphocyte populations were harvested from the intestinal epithelium, lamina propria, and Peyer's patches. The cow and calf BoLA-DRB3 alleles were aligned and PCR NIMDA-specific primers designed. Using these primers the maternal allele was successfully amplified from intraepithelial lymphocytes (2/4 calves), Peyer's patch (3/4 calves), mesenteric lymph node (2/4 calves), spleen (2/4 calves), and precolostral PBMCs (3/4 calves). The distribution of the NIM-DA varied between calves. Further studies using NIMDA-specific primers and NIMDA-specific DNA probes for in situ PCR on tissue sections of intestine and lymph nodes showed a homogeneous population of NIMDA-positive cells scattered throughout lymph node cortices and Peyer's patches. No positive cells were observed in sections using control primers and probes. These findings provide evidence for the transfer of maternal cells from the cow to the newborn calf. The presence of viable maternal immune cells in calf lymphoid tissues would suggest a role in calf immune system function or development. Clostridium difficile is associated with enterocolitis in adult horses and foals. Difficulty in isolating this organism through culture has likely led to it being overlooked in many cases. C.difficile exerts its effects through the production of exotoxins, but since non-toxigenic strains occur, definitive diagnosis requires identification of either toxins in feces, or the ability of isolates to produce toxins. This study evaluates the association of C.difficile with equine enterocolitis and examines the discepancy between bacterial culture and toxin identification.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: Anaerobic culture of fecal samples for C.difficile was performed using cycloserine-cefoxitin fructose agar (CCFA) on all cases of colitis involving foals and adult horses at the Ontario Veterinary College from March to December 1998. The organism was identified by colonial and Gram stain morphology, plus the production of l-proline-aminopeptidase. An ELISA was used to detect the presence of Toxin A and/or Toxin B in fecal samples. Normal horses and foals were also sampled.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: 24 cases of colitis in adult horses were sampled. C.difficile toxins were identified in 7 (29%), but C.difficile was only isolated from 2 of these. A nontoxigenic strain of C.difficile was isolated from one animal. 13 cases of enterocolitis in foals were sampled. C.difficile enterocolitis was diagnosed in 4 (31%) by ELISA and C.difficile was isolated from 3 of these. One non-toxigenic strain was isolated.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: C.difficile was not isolated from 259 adults and 37 foals with normal feces. C.difficile toxin was only detected in feces of 1 of 58 normal adults (1.7%) and 0 of 10 normal foals.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: To evaluate the discrepancies between bacterial culture and toxin assays in diagnosis, six fecal samples from which C.difficile was isolated were stored at 4 0 C and cultured daily. Survival time under these conditions varied from less than one to 46 days. The persistence of toxins was evaluated as well. 3 toxin positive fecal samples stored at 4 0 C were repeatedly tested and toxin was detected for greater than 30 days. Further, 4 toxigenic strains were grown in cooked meat broth (CMB) medium to induce toxin production. Toxin persisted in CMB and in feces stored at 4 0 C for greater than 30 days. The variability in survival of the organism when compared to the persistence of toxin and the rarity of toxin in healthy horses suggests that a diagnosis of C.difficile enterocolitis can be made in the absence of successful culture of the organism. Although the term laminitis indicates an inflammatory process, there are, to our knowledge, no previous reports of the involvement of inflammatory mediators in the onset of equine laminitis. In fact, the role of inflammation in early laminitis has been questioned due to the paucity of white blood cells in the laminitic digit. We investigated the gene expression of the pivotal inflammatory cytokine interleukin-1 beta (IL-1b) by cellular components of the palmar digital vasculature and laminar tissue in the early stages of laminitis. Horses were anesthetized 2-3 hours after administration of black walnut extract (BW, nϭ5) or placebo (nϭ3); the time point was dictated by the onset of neutropenia in the BW horses. Hemodynamic measurements were performed in one front foot while the digital vessels and laminar tissue in the opposite foot were fixed via formalin perfusion prior to tissue collection. In situ hybridization using equine-specific riboprobes for IL-1b was performed. Whereas no IL-1b message was apparent in control laminar tissues, there was marked IL-1b expression by endothelial cells of laminar capillaries in laminitic equine digits. No expression of IL-1b was noted in the palmar digital vessels, nor in the digital arterioles or venules. These results suggest a role of inflammation in the early laminitic disease process. Importantly, we have demonstrated gene expression of IL-1b by cell components of the laminar capillary wall, suggesting that the inflammatory process may be a local phenomenon within the laminitic digit.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL CHALLENGE OF HORSES WITH CHAR

body_text.text: AND AVIRULENT RHODOCOCCUS EQUI. S. Giguère and J.F. Prescott. Ontario Veterinary College, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: The virulence of R. equi for foals relies on the presence of a 85-or 90-kb plasmid. Immunocompetent mice infected with virulent R. equi develop a type 1 immune response characterized by the production of interferon (INF)-␥ and rapidly clear the infection. In contrast, induction of a type 2 response characterized by the production of interleukin (IL)-4 leads to the development of a severe pneumonia. We hypothesized that the 85-kb plasmid of R. equi mediates virulence by modulating the cytokine response of infected foals.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: Eight 3-week old pony foals were infected intrabronchially with virulent R. equi strain 103 containing an 85-kb plasmid (103ϩ), 8 foals were infected with the plasmid cured derivative (103-), and 6 control foals received only saline. Half of the foals in each group were euthanized at 3 days postinfection and the remaining half at 14 days postinfection. After euthanasia, CD4ϩ T helper lymphocytes were purified from the bronchial lymph nodes (BLN) using immunomagnetic separation. Messenger RNA (mRNA) expression for IL-1␣, IL-1␤, IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-10, IL-12 p35, IL-12 p40, INF-␥, TNF-␣ and ␤-actin was measured quantitatively using reverse transcription-competitive PCR.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: All foals infected with 103ϩ had lesions ranging from mild to moderate consolidation of the cranioventral lung lobes on day 3 to severe pyogranulomatous pneumonia on day 14, whereas the foals of the other groups showed no gross lesions. All the foals infected with R. equi developed a type 1 immune response characterized by strong IL-2 and INF-␥ mRNA expression. IL-1␣, IL-1␤, IL-4, IL-5, IL-12 p40 and TNF-␣ mRNA expression was not detected. In general, foals infected with 103ϩ produced higher IL-2 and IL-6 mRNA expression than those infected with 103-or the controls. IL-10 mRNA expression was similar in the 2 groups of R. equi infected foals but could not be detected in the controls. IL-12 p35 mRNA expression was considerably higher in 103ϩ infected foals when compared to those infected with 103-but was not detected in the controls. On day 3, mean INF-␥ mRNA expression was slightly higher in 103ϩ than in 103-infected foals. In contrast, on day 14 when strain 103-was completely cleared from the lungs, mean INF-␥ mRNA expression was significantly (P Ͻ 0.01) greater in 103-infected foals. Despite a significant increase in bacterial numbers between day 3 and day 14 in 103ϩ infected foals, INF-␥ mRNA expression did not change in this group.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: These results suggest a role for plasmid encoded products in downregulating INF-␥ production as part of the pathogenesis of R. equi infection in foals. Introduction of DNA encoding a single antigen stimulates a highly specific immune response to the expressed protein. In the case of antigens for which cloned genes are available, this enables direct vaccination without the need for purification of recombinant protein. This approach offers considerable advantages for generating monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) to recently cloned molecules, including equine cytokines. There are currently few monoclonal antibodies recognizing equine cytokines, and the availability of these reagents would provide a potent and novel means of characterizing equine immune responses. A study was performed to generate mABs to equine interleukin 2 (eq IL-2), employing biolistic DNA vaccination techniques to immunize mice. The eq IL-2 gene was subcloned into a suitable plasmid vector, coated onto gold beads, and administered percutaneously to the abdominal skin of Balb/c mice using a PowderJect-XR gene gun; 7.5g of plasmid DNA was given to each mouse on three occasions. Mice with the greatest immune response to eq IL-2 were selected by ELISA using supernatant from a Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cell line expressing recombinant equine IL-2 (rEq IL-2) as the capture antigen. Fusion of splenocytes to NS-1 myeloma cells was performed. A paired ELISA was developed to select hybridomas. CHO cell supernatants were used as capture antigens to identify hybridomas. Positive hybridomas were cloned twice by limiting dilution. Functional assays were performed by evaluating the ability of anti-eq IL-2 mABs to block ConA-stimulated lymphocyte proliferations. Antibody specificity was confirmed with immunoblot assays and by affinity purification of equine IL-2. Development of eq IL-2 ELISA and ELISPOT detection systems was also undertaken. Overall this approach to mAb production, and these specific anti-IL-2 reagents, represent potent tools for examining equine immune responses. Viable larvae of infective L3 stage Haemonchus contortus were utilized to generate cell populations for in-vitro propagation in a tissue culture environment. A variety of laboratory strategies were applied to validate the identify of H. contortus-derived cell populations including biochemical profile analysis for detecting the expression of phosphorylhydrolase, and aminopeptidase-M (ApM, zinc-metaloprotease) like activity utilizing enzyme-specific substrates (e.g. nitrophenylphosphate (pNPP), leucine-para-nitroanaline (leucine-pNA)). Significance of these experimental finding are directly related to the known expression of both phosphorylhydrolase, and ApM like biochemical activity by cell types populating the luminal surface of the nematode digestive system.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: Immunoprotective properties of antigenic fractions expressed by H. contortusderived cell populations was assessed by administering two IM injections of detergent solubilized protein (100 ug) to healthy sheep (nϭ8) at 14-day intervals. Animals were then challenged per-os with infective L3 stage H. contortus larvae (nϭ10,000). Compared to negative reference controls, vaccinated sheep displayed reduction in abomasal parasite burders. Applying polyclonal primary antibody harvested from immunoprotected sheep, a spectrum of detergent solubilized antigens expressed by intact H. contortus larvae were recognized. Similarly, immunohistochemical analysis utilizing ovine polyclonal antibody recognized antigens expressed by anatomical structures consistent with the digestive system of H. contortus. The objective of the study was to compare antibody levels to BVDV measured by virus neutralization (VN) and ELISA. Forty-seven cattle entering a feedlot vaccine trial were tested for BVDV antibodies, by ELISA and by VN for type I (NADL strain) and type II BVDV (NVSL 125 strain). Also, a subgroup of samples (7) showing a greater type II than type I BVDV titer were also VN tested using the Oregon and Singer strains. The ELISA was performed at Biovet, using the procedure provided by the manufacturer (BioX). VN testing was performed at the Animal Health Laboratory of the University of Guelph. A correlation coefficient was computed between ELISA result and the log-transformed VN titer.
body_text.section: CYTOKINE PROFILE OF FOALS INFECTED WITH VIRULENT

body_text.text: By ELISA, 18 samples were positive and 29 samples were negative. All samples negative on the ELISA had VN titer Յ 1:3 for type I (NADL) and type II BVDV. Correlation coefficient was high between ELISA result and VN titers for each strain, ranging from 0.81 to 0.95. All samples with ELISA results Ն 0.89 had at least one VN titer Ն 1:256. If, on these samples, VN had only been performed on one strain, titers may have been as low as 1:32. Moreover, we did not find that VN was useful in differentiating between type I and type II BVDV, as the same differences were observed between various type I strains as between type I and type II strains. An increasing number of horses are diagnosed with EPM, based on clinical neurological signs and CSF Western blot analysis. Clinical signs in some horses are inapparent to mild, whereas other horses have severe neurologic signs which may result in prolonged treatment. The purpose of this study was to determine whether use immunoglobulin concentrations (IgG, IgM) produced in the CSF can be used to evaluate the immune response to EPM infection. In order to screen for humoral response, total IgG and IgM levels were determined.

Horses, used in the study, were divided into three groups: control (nϭ5, CSF EPM Western blot negative animals), I (nϭ5, CSF EPM Western blot positive that improved with treatment), and S (nϭ5, CSF EPM Western blot positive that either deteriorated or stayed static after treatment). CSF samples were tested in all of the horses at Day 0, prior to treatment with ponazuril, Day 28, after 28 days of treatment (5-10mg/kg ponazuril (toltrazuril sulfone), PO, Q24hr), and Day 120, 3 months after the cessation of treatment. CSF IgM and IgG concentrations were determined by ELISA.

All horses in the study were showing clinical signs for greater than 1 month duration at the time of testing. In all groups of horses, total IgG and IgM levels correlated, such that increases or decreases in total IgG corresponded with changes in IgM, respectively. The control group had lower total CSF IgG and IgM concentrations when compared to EPM positive animals. Horses which showed a marked improvement in clinical signs (Group I) showed more significant changes in IgM and possibly IgG concentrations than horses which did not improve (Group S). Comparisons of average IgG and IgM levels between groups was difficult because of the range of baseline averages between horses. Impending death in calves with diarrhea and dehydration has been associated with acidemia, hyperkalemia, bradycardia, and cardiac arrhythmias. A decrease in heart rate (HR) of 8 beats per minute (bpm) has been reported for each 1 mEq/L increase in serum or plasma potassium concentration ([K ϩ ]) in a small number of calves with diarrhea (Ann Rech veter 1973; 4:99-111) , but no relationship was found in a larger data set (3rd International Symposium on Neonatal Diarrhea, 1980:375-381) . The purpose of this study was to further examine the relationship between HR and [K ϩ ] in calves.

Data was obtained from 4 studies involving calves less than 21 days of age that were healthy (n ϭ 62), or had naturally-acquired (n ϭ 36) or experimentallyinduced (n ϭ 62) diarrhea and dehydration. The normal HR and [K ϩ ] for healthy calves were 111 Ϯ 20 bpm (mean Ϯ SD), and 4.8 Ϯ 0.4 mEq/L, respectively. For calves with diarrhea and dehydration, HR ranged from 46 to 180 beats/min, serum [K ϩ ] from 1.9 to 11.9 mEq/L, and venous blood pH from 6.73 to 7.46. Linear regression using dummy variable coding of 419 data points from 98 calves indicated that when [K ϩ ] Ͻ8.0 mEq/L, HR increased linearly with [K ϩ ], such that: HR ϭ 107 ϩ 3.5[K ϩ ] (R 2 ϭ 0.83). Of 16 calves with diarrhea and HR Յ70 bpm (below the 95% confidence interval for normal HR), 10 had [K ϩ ] Ͻ5.5 mEq/L and 6 had [K ϩ ] Ͼ9.5. We conclude that a weak association between HR and [K ϩ ] exists in calves with diarrhea, and that bradycardia (HR Յ70 bpm) is of minimal value in predicting the presence of hyperkalemia. German shepherd dogs (GSD) are predisposed to enteropathies such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), but to date the aetiology of these conditions is unknown. Both IBD and SIBO may be the result of local immune dysregulation. The aim of the present study was to examine cytokine mRNA expression in the intestinal mucosa of GSDs with enteropathies.

Biopsies of duodenal mucosa were taken from GSDs with small intestinal enteropathies (group 1, nϭ16) and control dogs (group 2, nϭ12), either during endoscopy or immediately post mortem. Cytokine mRNA expression, for interleukin (IL) -2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, IL-12p40, Interferon (IFN) -gamma, Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) -alpha and transforming growth factor (TGF) -beta, was determined by semi-quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction. Results were expressed relative to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase mRNA expression within the same sample.

IL-2, IL-5, IL-12p40, IFN-gamma TNF-alpha and TGF-beta mRNA expression in group 1 dogs was significantly greater than in group 2 dogs (pϽ0.01 for all). IL-4 and IL-10 mRNA was only detected in three and 24 respectively of all 28 samples, with no significant differences between groups. Further there were no significant differences between group 1 dogs subclassified as IBD or SIBO. Cytokine mRNA expression was reassessed after treatment with antibiotics, in 5 group 1 dogs with SIBO. Both TNF-alpha and TGF-beta mRNA expression declined significantly from pre-treatment values.

This study demonstrates that GSDs with IBD and SIBO have increased expression of mRNA for a variety of cytokines, suggesting heightened mucosal immune responses in both conditions. Feline pancreatitis is a notoriously difficult disorder to diagnose antemortem; lack of a sensitive and specific test, along with clinical and clinicopathologic presentation that may mimic other disease states contribute to the problem. Serum amylase and lipase are unreliable indicators of pancreatic disease in the cat. Histopathologic examination, is considered the ''gold-standard'' for antemortem diagnosis of feline pancreatitis. Preliminary findings and clinical impression have indicated that a radioimmunoassay for trypsin-like immunoreactivity in feline serum (fTLI) might be useful for the antemortem diagnosis of pancreatitis.

In this prospective study, 30 cats with clinical signs consistent with pancreatitis, including lethargy, anorexia, vomiting or abdominal pain, underwent surgical biopsy of the pancreas in addition to other routine diagnostic tests. Blood samples were drawn from fasted cats on the morning of their biopsies and serum fTLI concentrations were determined by species-specific radioimmunoassay. Haematologic and serum biochemical analyses were performed by standard automated laboratory methods. Pancreatic biopsies were categorized into 4 groups on the basis of histopathology as being either a normal pancreas (nϭ10); mild (nϭ7), moderate (nϭ6) or severe (nϭ7) pancreatitis. Pancreatic biopsies were compared with serum fTLI concentration, and haematologic and serum biochemical findings, using the Kruskal-Wallis nonparametric analysis of variance (AN-OVA) test. There was no significant difference between the 4 histopathologic groups with respect to the fTLI values (pϭ0.41). Median fTLI concentrations were 51g/L (range 18-Ͼ200g/L) for cats with a normal pancreas; 136g/L (range 12-Ͼ200g/L) for cats with mild pancreatitis; 110g/L (range 28-Ͼ200g/L) for cats with moderate pancreatitis, and 32g/L (range 24-86g/L) for cats with severe pancreatitis. There were no significant differences in any of the haematologic or biochemical parameters measured among the four histopathologic groups (pϾ0.05).We conclude that in cats that present with signs compatible with pancreatitis, serum fTLI is poorly associated with the severity of inflammation as judged by pancreatic histopathology. Although feline inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a well-recognized clinical syndrome, it is still poorly understood. We examined cats with naturally occurring IBD to further characterize this syndrome.

Eleven cats consecutively diagnosed with IBD between June 1998 and September 1998 comprised the study population. All had histologic lesions compatible with lymphocytic-plasmacytic enteritis and/or gastritis. Endoscopic biopsies of gastric mucosa were tested for urease activity and evaluated by cytology for the presence of spiral organisms consistent with Helicobacter spp. Fecal cytology was evaluated for the presence of spore-forming rods, spirochetes, and leukocytes. Fecal material was cultured for Salmonella spp. and Campylobacter jejuni. We assessed feces also for Cryptosporidium parvum using IFA and PCR; for Giardia by ELISA and IFA; for C. perfringens enterotoxin by ELISA; for enteric viruses by electron microscopy; and for enteric parasites by zinc sulfate flotation. In addition, serum was collected for feline trypsin-like immunoreactivity (fTLI), cobalamin, and folate concentration determinations. Sera were assayed for C. parvum and Toxoplasma gondii antibodies by ELISA.

All fecal cultures and electron microscopy results were negative. In all cats, Giardia ELISA and IFA were negative and no parasitic ova were found by zinc sulfate flotation. One cat was positive for C. perfringens enterotoxin, but sporeforming rods were not observed from fecal cytology. While C. parvum oocysts were not detected in feces of any cat, serum antibodies were detected in 6/11 (5 of 6 were positive for IgA). One C. parvum seropositive cat was also positive for T. gondii IgM. All other cats had negative T. gondii serology. Helicobacter spp. was identified in 6/11 cats (54%). Serum fTLI (85 Ϯ56g/L) was elevated in 8/11 (73%) while serum cobalamin (466 Ϯ407ng/L) was decreased in 6/11. Serum folate concentrations were normal in all cats.

Detection of infectious agents was uncommon. The presence of C. parvum antibodies suggests present or prior infection. Elevated serum fTLI concentrations suggest concurrent pancreatitis. Decreased serum cobalamin concentrations may indicate decreased ileal absorption. Further study of cats with IBD is required to determine the significance of elevated fTLI, decreased cobalamin, and exposure to C. parvum. The effect of reduced frequency of administration of misoprostol on its ability to prevent aspirin-induced gastric injury was evaluated. Twenty-four randomsource dogs were divided into 4 groups which received aspirin and misoprostol as follows: Group I, 25 mg/kg aspirin PO TID and placebo PO TID; Group II, 25 mg/kg aspirin PO TID and misoprostol 3 ug/kg PO TID; Group III, 25 mg/ kg aspirin PO TID, misoprostol 3 ug/kg PO BID and placebo PO QD; and Group IV, 25 mg/kg aspirin PO TID, misoprostol 3 ug/kg PO QD and placebo PO BID for 28 days. Groups were stratified for Helicobacter status based on results of 'CLO test'. Gastroscopy was performed on days 9, 5, 14 and 28. Each region of the stomach was evaluated separately and visible lesions were scored on a scale of 1 (submucosal hemorrhage) to 11 (perforating ulcer). Median total score for each group was compared at each day using a Kruskal-Wallis test. Median total score within each group between days was compared using a Kruskal-Wallis test.

No difference in total score was identified between Group I and IV on any day. Significant differences in total score (p Յ 0.05) were found between Groups II and III compared to Groups I and IV on day 5. Significant difference was observed on Day 14 between the total score of Group III and Group IV, but not between Group III and Group I. Group III had a significantly lower score (p Յ 0.05) than Groups I, II and IV on day 28. Study indicated that misoprostol 3 ug/kg PO BID dosing may be as effective as misoprostol 3 ug/kg PO TID dosing at preventing aspirin-induced gastric injury. Gastric erosions were present in all dogs receiving misoprostol in the study. The lack of efficacy of TID dosing on days 14 and 28 may be related to higher salicylate concentrations in Group II dogs or individual variation within the small study population. Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated hypersensitivity to luminal-derived antigens may play a causative role in canine idiopathic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study aimed to characterize the IgE-related immune response of the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) in healthy and IBD-affected dogs.

Tissue specimens from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and mesenteric lymph node (mln) of 9 control and 20 diseased dogs were investigated. In situ hybridization for mRNA specific for IgE and interleukin-4 (IL-4), the key cytokine for isotype switching to IgE, and immunohistochemistry for IgE-protein and two mast cell markers, tryptase and chymase, were performed on consecutive sections. Counts of positive cells (ϩ) were expressed per mm 2 and statistically analyzed. Histopathology revealed increased numbers of plasma cells in the GI mucosa of diseased dogs. Nevertheless, IgE mRNAϩ cells were rarely detected (median, 0 cells/0.3mm 2 ; range, 0-130). Most IgE mRNAϩ cells were found in mlns (healthy/diseased: median, 13/8 cells/mm 2 ; range, 0-130/0-63). The signal pattern of IL-4 mRNA was similar to that of IgE mRNA. In contrast to IgE mRNA, cells expressing IgE on their surface were located throughout the GI mucosa; diseased dogs displayed more IgEϩ cells than controls (healthy/diseased: median, 5/40 cells/0.3mm 2 ; range, 0-202/0-468; pϭ0.0001). Total mast cell numbers did not differ between controls and diseased dogs, nor was there a shift in their subtypes.

Thus, local IgE synthesis as assessed by IgE mRNA does not occur to a significant degree in the GALT of either healthy or IBD-affected dogs but rather in associated mlns. The increased number of IgE protein-bearing cells in dogs with IBD may offer new perspectives in regard to causative and therapeutic interventions. In man, a serum albumin:effusion albumin (SA-EA) gradient Ն 1.1 discriminates the presence of portal hypertension. A prospective study of dogs with hepatoportal disease and other conditions associated with transudative abdominal effusions was done to examine their SA-EA gradients. Dogs (nϭ56) presenting consecutively to our hospital over 24 months had simultaneous sampling of ascites and serum. Cytologic evaluation and refractometer fluid protein concentration were done immediately to establish inclusion criteria. Samples were centrifuged within 1 hour, supernatant or sera separated and stored frozen at Ϫ70 C until thawed for batched analyses. Albumin was determined using the bromocresol green method. Total protein was determined using an automated biuret reaction. Each dog underwent appropriate diagnostic tests to elucidate conditions causing their effusion (e.g. CBC, chemistry profile, urinalysis, bile acids, coagulation assessments, abdominal ultrasonography, thoracic radiography, echocardiography, colorectal scintigraphy, and/or visceral biopsies). A definitive diagnosis was determined in each case. Significant differences were tested using nonparametric methods and an ␣ of 0.05. Twenty-nine dogs had hepatoportal disease (Grp 1) including: cirrhosis/fibrosis (nϭ25), congenital portosystemic shunts (postsurgical portal hypertension, enteritis, nϭ3), and portal thromboembolism (nϭ1). Twenty-seven dogs had miscellaneous disorders (Grp 2): malignancy (nϭ7), congestive heart failure (nϭ5), pancreatitis (nϭ5), protein losing enteropathy (nϭ3), thromboembolism (nϭ2), protein losing nephropathy (nϭ2) and one each with fluid overload, vena cava compression, and bile duct rupture.

Results: Significantly greater median values for age, weight, RBC MCV, concentrations of fibrinogen, albumin, and creatinine, amylase activity, and fluid nucleated cell count, RBC count and albumin concentration, occurred in Grp 2. Significantly greater values for the partial thromboplastin time occurred in Grp 1. The median SA-EA gradients were similar in each group: 1.4 (0.7-3.1) in Grp 1 and 1.30 (0.80-3.30) in Grp 2. In dogs with hepatoportal disorders, 26/ 29 had an SA-EA gradient Ն 1.1; 14/29 had a serum albumin Ͻ 2.0 gm/dl, 19/ 29 a fluid albumin Յ 0.2 gm/dl, and 27/29 fluid total protein Ͻ 2.5 gm/dl. In dogs with other disorders, 19/27 had an SA-EA gradient Ն1.1; 5/27 a serum albumin Ͻ 2.0 gm/dl, 6/27 a fluid albumin Յ 0.2 gm/dl, and 13/27 fluid total protein Ͻ 2.5 gm/dl. As in man, portal hypertension indicated by an SA-EA gradient Ն 1.1, seemingly is a common factor in formation of transudative abdominal effusions. OF AN ENZYME-LINKED IMMUNO SORBENT ASSAY FOR THE MEASURE-MENT OF FELINE TRYPSIN-LIKE IMMUNOREACTIVITY IN Serum feline trypsin-like immunoreactivity (fTLI) has been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of various exocrine pancreatic disorders in cats. Serum fTLI is markedly subnormal in cats with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Also, cats with pancreatitis often have elevated serum fTLI concentrations. To date radioimmunoassay was the only method available to determine fTLI in serum. The goal of this project was to develop and validate an enzyme-linked immuno sorbent assay (ELISA) for quantitative analysis of fTLI in cat serum.

ref_spans.text: OF AN ENZYME-LINKED IMMUNO SORBENT ASSAY FOR THE MEASURE-MENT OF FELINE TRYPSIN-LIKE IMMUNOREACTIVITY IN

body_text.text: A capture sandwich ELISA was developed using feline trypsin (purified from feline pancreata) and antiserum against feline trypsin raised in New Zealand White rabbits and purified by affinity chromatography using immobilized feline trypsin. The captured trypsin was identified using the same purified polyclonal antiserum after bioatinilation, a commercially available streptavidin-labeled horseradish peroxidase preparation, and a horseradish peroxidase substrate. The assay was validated by determination of sensitivity, linearity, accuracy, precision, and reproducibility. The linearity of the assay was determined by evaluating dilutional parallelism. Five serum samples with serum fTLI concentrations ranging from 6.4 to 136.6g/l were diluted 1/2, 1/4, and 1/8. Accuracy of the assay was tested by spiking five different serum samples with feline trypsin solutions in concentrations of 7. 81, 15.63, 31.25, and 62 .5g/l. Precision and reproducibility were evaluated by determining intra-assay and inter-assay variability of five different serum samples, respectively. A reference range for serum fTLI by ELISA was determined by measuring serum fTLI in serum samples from 63 clinically healthy cats.

The sensitivity of this assay was determined to be 1.23 g/l. Observed to expected ratios for dilutional parallelism ranged from 78.5 to 140.8% for the five different serum samples. Observed to expected ratios for spiking recoveries of the five samples ranged from 82.0 to 101.8%. Intra-assay variability of five different samples ranged from 9.9 to 11.1% and inter-assay variability ranged from 10.2 to 21.7%. The reference range (mean Ϯ2SD) for serum fTLI in healthy cats measured by ELISA was determined to be 12g/l to 82g/l.

We conclude that the fTLI ELISA described here is sufficiently sensitive, linear, accurate, precise, and reproducible for clinical application in the diagnosis of pancreatic disorders in cats. The goal of this study was to develop a method for the simultaneous separation and quantification of 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose (methylglucose), L-rhamnose (rhamnose), D(ϩ)xylose (xylose), sucrose, and lactulose in dog urine by high pressure anion exchange liquid chromatography and pulsed amperometric detection. The method was validated by determination of dilutional parallelism, spiking recovery, intra-assay variability (nϭ10), and inter-assay variability (nϭ10) using three different samples.

At a flow rate of 1ml/min the 5 sugars were separated using a NaOH gradient (0-15min: 0.004M NaOH, 15-16min: continuously increasing from 0.004M to 0.02M NaOH, 16-17.5min: continuously increasing from 0.02M to 0.078M NaOH, 17.5-24min: 0.078M NaOH, 24-27min: continuously increasing from 0.078M NaOH to 0.198M NaOH, and 27min: 0.198M NaOH). Approximate elution times were 14.5min for methylglucose, 15.8min for rhamnose, 22.7min for xylose, 23.8min for sucrose, and 30.1min for lactulose. Observed to expected ratios for all 5 sugars and all 3 samples were 77.6 to 106.9% (94.0 Ϯ8.5%; mean ϮSD) for a 1/2 dilution, 85.2 to 121.4% (100.0 Ϯ9.5%) for a 1/4 dilution, and 91.6 to 163.7% (108.1 Ϯ17.8%) for a 1/8 dilution of the three different samples. Also, observed to expected ratios for all 5 sugars and all 3 samples were 87.8 to 116.1% (102.3 Ϯ6.4%) when a standard solution containing 100mg/l of methylglucose, rhamnose, xylose, and sucrose and 50mg/l of lactulose was added to each sample, 85.5 to 104.0% (97.5 Ϯ5.7%) when the standard solution in a dilution of 1/2 was added, 89.3 to 111.3% (99.9 Ϯ5.8%) when the standard solution in a dilution of 1/4 was added, 89.7 to 110.0% (99.6 Ϯ5.5%) when the standard solution in a dilution of 1/8 was added, and 96.6 to 116.7% (103.0 Ϯ5.5%) when the standard solution in a dilution of 1/16 was added. The intraassay coefficients of variation were 1.6, 3.4, and 4.7% for methylglucose, 1.6, 2.0, and 3.6% for rhamnose, 2.7, 1.4, and 1.1% for xylose, 9.8, 3.4, and 4 .0% for sucrose, and 3.2, 3.3, and 3.3% for lactulose. Finally, the inter-assay coefficients of variation were 3.2, 5.7, and 4.2% for methylglucose, 4.3, 5.4, and 6.4% for rhamnose, 3.3, 5.0, and 4.2% for xylose, 9.4, 9.9, and 9 .4% for sucrose, and 6.1, 4.9, and 2.7% for lactulose.

We conclude that the method described here to simultaneously separate and quantify methylglucose, rhamnose, xylose, sucrose, and lactulose in canine urine is linear, accurate, precise, and reproducible. Recovery of inert sugars in urine can be used as a marker for gastrointestinal permeability and mucosal function. A test solution containing a mixture of inert sugars is given orally and urinary recoveries of these inert sugars are determined.

The urinary bladders of seven healthy research dogs were completely emptied immediately prior to oral administration of 100ml of a solution containing 1.0g of 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose (methylglucose), 2.5g of L-rhamnose (rhamnose), 2.5g of D(ϩ)xylose (xylose), and 2.5g of lactulose. Urine samples were collected every 2hrs for 12hrs. Urinary recoveries of the inert sugars were determined by high pressure anion exchange liquid chromatography and pulsed amperometric detection. The percent of recovery (%R) of total recovery (R) after 12hrs was calculated for each sugar and time-point.
The mean %R for all 4 inert sugars exceeded 86% at 6hrs with a standard deviation of Յ 8.1% and 94% at 8hrs with a SD Յ 2.4%.

We conclude that cumulative urine collection for 6 or 8 hours after an oral dose of a solution containing methylglucose, rhamnose, xylose, and lactulose is sufficient for estimation of urinary recovery of these 4 inert sugars in healthy dogs. Urinary recoveries of inert sugars can be used as markers for gastrointestinal permeability and mucosal function. Traditionally, L-rhamnose (rhamnose) and lactulose have been utilized for these studies in dogs. Recently, D(ϩ)xylose (xylose) and 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose (methylglucose) have been added for intestinal permeability and mucosal function testing. Finally, sucrose has been used separately for gastric permeability testing. The objective of this project was to evaluate whether the simultaneous use of 2, 4, or 5 of these sugars would lead to alterations in the urinary recovery of any one of the other sugars within an 8 hour sampling period.

Seven healthy research dogs were enrolled into this study. The bladders of the dogs were catheterized and completely emptied prior to oral administration of 100ml of a solution of either 2 (2.5g rhamnose, 2.5g lactulose), 4 (1g methylglucose, 2.5g rhamnose, 2.5g xylose, 2.5g lactulose), or 5 (1g methylglucose, 2.5g rhamnose, 2.5g xylose, 10g sucrose, 2.5g lactulose) sugars. Urine produced over the subsequent 8 hours was collected and urinary recoveries determined by high pressure anion exchange liquid chromatography and pulsed amperometric detection. Urinary recoveries of rhamnose and lactulose were compared between the 2-, 4-, and 5-sugar tests using repeated measures of variance, while urinary recoveries of methylglucose and xylose between the 4-and the 5-sugar tests were compared using a paired two-sided t-test.

The urinary recovery of sucrose in the 5-sugar test was 1.1 Ϯ1.8% (mean ϮSD). For rhamnose there was no significant difference (pϭ0.14) between urinary recoveries in the 2 (27.9 Ϯ4.4%), 4 (26.2 Ϯ6.2%), and 5 (33.6 Ϯ8.5%) sugar tests. Also, there was no significant difference (pϭ0.69) between urinary recoveries of lactulose in the 2 (3.7 Ϯ2.6%), 4 (4.7 Ϯ4.7%), or 5 (5.9 Ϯ5.9%) sugar tests. Finally, there was no significant difference between urinary recoveries of xylose (pϭ0.52) in the 4 (28.8 Ϯ7.2%) and 5 (31.3 Ϯ8.0%) sugar tests or between urinary recoveries of methylglucose (pϭ0.24) in the 4 (66.0 Ϯ18.6%) and 5 (79.0 Ϯ18.8%) sugar tests.

We conclude that in healthy dogs intestinal permeability of rhamnose and lactulose within 8 hours of oral application are not altered by concurrent administration of xylose, methylglucose, and sucrose. Furthermore, we conclude that within 8 hours of oral administration intestinal permeability of rhamnose, xylose, and lactulose and mucosal absorption of methylglucose are not altered by concurrent administration of sucrose to healthy dogs. A state, known as ''leaky gut'' syndrome, can exist where the tight junctions between small intestinal epithelial cells widen enabling compounds to diffuse between the enterocytes. Many studies have used ''non-metabolizable'' markers to quantify the extent of passive absorption in the small intestine. However, the potential exists for these markers to be fermented in the small intestine by resident bacteria. Fermentation as indicated by the production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), would result in the breakdown and disappearance of these markers. Therefore, this study was conducted to determine the potential ability of intestinal bacteria to ferment these ''inert'' markers.

Feces represent a diverse source of intestinal bacteria that are relatively easy to obtain. As such, feces collected from 3 dogs, were used as the enteric bacteria inoculum source to conduct an in vitro fermentation of the following substrates: beet pulp (positive control), alpha-cellulose (negative control), mannitol, L-rhamnose, lactulose, D-xylose, melibiose, raffinose, stachyose, cellobiose, 3-O-methylglucose, and polyethylene glycol (PEG). Each substrate was anaerobically incubated with enteric bacteria inoculum and growth media for 6, 12, and 24 h.

When data were pooled across all fermentation times and donors, total average short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) concentrations (avg 12.65 mmol/g OM) were highest (p Ͻ 0.05) for melibiose, D-xylose, stachyose, lactulose, raffinose, L-rhamnose, and mannitol. Fermentation of cellobiose and beet pulp resulted in moderate levels of total SCFA (avg 3.39 mmol/g OM), with minimal detection of SCFA (avg 0.01 mmol/g OM) from 3-O-methylglucose, PEG, and alpha-cellulose. Acetate concentrations were highest (p Ͻ 0.05) for raffinose, stachyose, and melibiose, with propionate production being higher (p Ͻ 0.05) for mannitol, lactulose, D-xylose, and L-rhamnose. Butyrate production was highest (p Ͻ 0.05) for cellobiose and lactulose. With the exception of 3-O-methylglucose, PEG, and alpha-cellulose, fermentation increased (p Ͻ 0.05) as fermentation time increased from 6 to 24 h. Results indicated that 3-O-methylglucose and PEG were virtually non-fermentable by intestinal bacteria, further validating their use as inert markers. Results further revealed substantial fermentation of the remaining markers, which may result in bias interpretation of data from previous intestinal permeability studies. The purpose of this retrospective study was to characterize imaging findings in cats with confirmed upper gastrointestinal inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and to relate these findings to clinical signs and histologic changes. Medical records for 33 cats with a clinical and histopathologic diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal IBD were reviewed for signalment, clinical signs, clinicopathologic findings, radiographic and ultrasonographic findings, and results of endoscopic examination. Histologic findings were reviewed and characterized by severity and type of inflammatory infiltrate.

All cats had one or more clinical signs (e.g. vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss, and anorexia) consistent with IBD. Lymphocytic-plasmacytic infiltrates of increasing cellularity were observed in histologic sections from cats with mild, moderate and severe IBD. Crypt distortion, villous blunting and fusion, and fibrosis were more commonly seen in moderate to severe IBD. Clinicopathologic findings included anemia, leukocytosis or leukopenia, hypocholesterolemia, and hyper-or hypoproteinemia in some, but not all cats. No survey radiographic abnormalities were found in 9 cats with mild, moderate, or severe IBD. One of 3 cats had abnormalities in a contrast study. In 13/17 (76%) cats, abdominal ultrasonography revealed several intestinal abnormalities (e.g., poor wall layer definition, focal thickening) and enlarged abnormal mesenteric lymph nodes with hypoechoic changes consistent with a diagnosis of IBD.
