Ultrasonographic abnormalities were consistently associated with histologic abnormalities. Endoscopic observation revealed findings (e.g., erythema, plaques, mucosal friability) consistent with inflammation in 9/18 (50%) cats. Abnormal endoscopic findings were not always associated with histologic abnormalities.

Clinical signs and ultrasonographic findings appeared to have the best correlation with histologic grade in feline IBD. Radiography was not sensitive in detecting intestinal inflammation, but ultrasonography detected abnormalities in most cases. Endoscopy was useful in detecting inflammation, although many cases had normal endoscopic findings. In feline upper gastrointestinal IBD, abdominal ultrasonography identified more abnormalities than upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and should be considered in the medical investigation of feline IBD. Colonoscopy is commonly performed in dogs with signs of large bowel disease. In humans, the overall rate of complications is about 0.1% and mortality rates between 0.008% and 0.02% have been reported. Complications in dogs are believed to be rare, but no studies are available to support this contention. The purpose of this study was to characterize the type and frequency of complications associated with performing colonoscopy in dogs with signs of large bowel disease.

Medical records from 301 dogs that had 349 colonoscopic procedures performed between April 1984 and June 1998 were retrospectively reviewed. Preparation consisted of withholding food for 24 hours, administering multiple warm water enemas, and in 285 cases, giving Golytely. All dogs were examined while under inhalant gas general anesthesia using flexible gastroscopes by staff clinicians or by house officers strictly supervised by staff clinicians.

The median age was 6 years. There were 190 males and 159 females of 72 different pure breeds. There were 52 mixed breed dogs. Clinical signs were present for a median of 14 weeks prior to colonoscopy. The most common indications for colonoscopy were chronic large bowel diarrhea (142), chronic mixed bowel diarrhea (65), hematochezia (61), and tenesmus or dyschezia (28). Colonoscopy was performed by an experienced senior clinician in 109 (31.3%) procedures.

Serious complications occurred in only 2 procedures (0.6%), and consisted of one case each of colonic perforation and rectal hemorrhage after biopsy with a rigid forceps. Both dogs survived. Vomiting was associated with Golytely administration in 15 procedures (5.3%). Minor transient complications were noted after 7 procedures (0.2%) and included lethargy, pain, pyrexia, vomiting, diarrhea, premature ventricular contractions, and acute vestibular disease. Some of these complications could have been related to the underlying disease or to other diagnostic procedures performed.

In this study, complications associated with colonoscopy were uncommon (6.9% of procedures) and when they occurred were usually minor and transient, despite the lack of endoscopic experience of many of the clinicians. Colonoscopy appears to be a safe procedure. Apoptotic cell death accompanies cholestatic hepatic disease. Since cholestatic disorders are associated with increased serum and tissue bile acid concentrations and bile acids are known hepatotoxins, it is likely that bile acids contribute to the ongoing pathology in many chronic hepatopathies. We and others have demonstrated that hydrophobic bile acids induce apoptosis in primary rat hepatocyte cultures and have used this in vitro model to study the mechanisms associated with bile acid induced hepatotoxicity. Since hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) has been shown to protect neuronal and gastric epithelial cells from apoptosis, we explored the role of HGF in modulating bile acid induced hepatocyte apoptosis. Rat hepatocytes were isolated by collagenase perfusion and plated on cover slips or tissue culture flasks coated with Type I collagen in Minimal Eagles Medium supplemented with 10 % fetal calf serum. Four hours after plating, experiments were initiated by adding 50 um glycochenodeoxycholate (GCDC) and hepatocytes evaluated by Hoechst staining for morphologic evidence of apoptosis (chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation). The effect of hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) and epidermal growth factor (EGF) on GCDC induced apoptosis was evaluated by pretreating cultures for 15 minutes with 50 ng/ml of HGF or EGF prior to the addition of the bile acid. Treatment with GCDC alone induced apoptosis in 29.7Ϯ 3.2 % of hepatocytes. HGF significantly reduced the amount of GCDC induced apoptosis by 60.2 Ϯ 7.8 % while EGF had little effect (19.1 Ϯ 8.9% reduction in apoptosis). The protective effect of HGF was prevented in the presence of 50 uM wortmannin, an inhibitor of phosphoinositol-3-OH kinase. HGF mediated cytoprotection was accompanied by phosphosphorylation of protein kinase B (PKB) as determined on immunblots of cell extracts with phosphospecific antibodies. Pretreatment with 50 uM wortmannin prevented HGF mediated activation of PKB. HGF mediated protection against bile acid induced apoptosis in rat hepataocytes may involve sequential activation of PI3K and PKB. Since HGF is produced by nonparenchymal cells in the liver, we hypothesize that it exerts a paracrine effect on hepatocytes to promote cell survival. The effects of a gastrostomy tube (G-tube) on gastric emptying were evaluated utilizing scintigraphy in 13 cats (complete block design). In order to differentiate between administration route (ingestion vs infusion) and the presence of the gastrostomy tube (present or not present), gastric emptying was compared between three combinations: 1) no G-tube, food ingested; 2) G-tube present, food infused; 3) G-tube present, food ingested. Thirteen cats were accommodated to a commercial canned diet (CNM-CV Purina Inc.) for 2 weeks. The diet was labeled with 99m Tc-disofenin. After ingestion, gastric images were taken at 12 intervals for 5 hours.

Gastric emptying was not significantly affected by either the presence of the G-tube or the route of administration of food into the stomach. Canine pancreatic lipase (cPL) is required for our ongoing studies of canine lipases, but to our knowledge is not available commercially. The purification of cPL from canine pancreatic juice, but not from pancreatic tissue, has been reported previously. Given the logistic difficulties associated with collection of pancreatic juice in dogs the objective of this project was to purify cPL from dog pancreas.

Dog pancreata were collected from research dogs that were sacrificed for unrelated research projects after humane euthanasia. After removal of gross fat pancreatic tissue was sliced in small cubes and crushed in 100ml acetone using a Polytron, and filtered through a Buchner funnel. In order to completely remove all fat this procedure was repeated a total of 8 times, using acetone and a chloroform butanol mixture. The final extract was resuspended in approximately 50ml of ethyl ether, and filtered in the Buchner funnel to dryness. Five grams of the delipified pancreatic extract were further purified by extracting the enzymes in a tris-buffer containing two different protease inhibitors, benzamindine and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. After centrifugation the supernatant was saved and further purified by anion exchange chromatography on a mono-Q column, gel-filtration on a Sephacryl S-100 column, and cation exchange chromatography on a Source-S column using a NaCl gradient.
The table shows protein yield, specific lipolytic activity per mg protein, and total lipolytic activity after each purification step for a typical purification.

Canine pancreatic lipase was successfully purified from canine pancreatic tissue. The purified product showed a single band on sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with a molecular weight of approximately 50,700. The identity of the product was confirmed by N-terminal amino acid sequencing of the first 25 amino acid residues which showed the sequence Lys-Glu-Val-X-Phe-Pro-Arg-Leu-Gly-X-Phe-Ser-Asp-Asp-Ser-Pro-Trp-Ala-Gly-Ile-Val-Glu-Arg-Pro-Leu. Twenty of 23 identified amino acid residues matched corresponding residues of porcine pancreatic lipase.

We conclude that using the described protocol canine pancreatic lipase can be successfully purified from canine pancreatic tissue. Bromide (Br) is a binary compound of the element bromine and other common cations, in this case potassium (KBr). It is an adjunctive treatment for dogs with epilepsy, particularly those that are refractory to phenobarbital. Bromide is no longer manufactured by pharmaceutical companies in the United States and must be obtained as a reagent grade chemical from chemical supply companies. Since Br is a salt of hydrobromic acid (Hϩ Br-), it should remain stable indefinitely. However there are no data on the stability of Br in solution over time nor on the effects of storage conditions (refrigerator vs. room temperature; clear plastic container vs. brown glass).

Eight different one liter KBr solutions were made by weighing 250 gm of KBr powder and adding enough distilled water to make a one liter solution. Four solutions were put into clear plastic containers and 4 were put into brown glass containers. Two of each container types were placed in a refrigerator (4ЊC) for 1 year, and two were kept at room temperature (25ЊC) for 1 year. To assimilate daily dosing conditions, a small portion was removed daily from one container type under the two different storage conditions. The concentration of KBr was measured in each container at monthly intervals using ion exchange high performance liquid chromatography(Dionex Model 4000 HP2C).

The physical condition of the bromide did not change over a 12 month period, nor were there significant changes in the Br concentration of each container. We concluded that Br was stable in solution over a 1 year period and that it does not matter if Br is stored in clear or brown containers, plastic or glass containers, or if it is stored at room or refrigerator temperatures. If some patients are manifesting poor seizure control, it not likely because of instability of Br and the types of storage conditions described here. Phenobarbital (PB) is the drug of choice for control of canine epilepsy. It induces hepatic enzymes and can be hepatotoxic and/or decrease T4 in some dogs. At times, PB needs to be discontinued but it is unknown how long liver enzyme induction and decreases in T4 persist following discontinuation. The purpose of this study was to characterize changes in total T4 (TT4), free T4 (FT4), liver enzymes (ALT, ALP, GGT), albumin, TSH and cholesterol following discontinuation of long-term PB administration in normal dogs.

Twelve normal dogs were administered PB at a dose of 4.4-6.6 mg/kg PO BID for 27 weeks. Following discontinuation of PB (week 27), blood was collected for analysis at varying intervals for 10 weeks. Results were compared to those from the end of the PB trial.

Comparison to pre-treatment values showed serum ALT, ALP, TSH and cholesterol to be significantly higher at week 27, while TT4 and FT4 were significantly lower. GGT and albumin were unchanged. Serum ALT, ALP, and cholesterol were significantly decreased from week 27 by weeks 5, 1, and 2, respectively, post withdrawal. Serum GGT was significantly increased above week 27 at week 1 post withdrawal and remained above baseline until week 9. Serum albumin was significantly increased from week 27 at weeks 2 and 5-9 post withdrawal. Serum TSH was not significantly different from week 27 at any time during the post withdrawal period. Serum TT4 was significantly increased from week 27 at weeks 1, 2, and 4-10 post withdrawal. Serum FT4 was significantly increased above week 27 at weeks 5-8 post withdrawal.

This study documents that changes in liver enzymes (ALT, ALP, GGT) and cholesterol induced by PB resolve 1-5 weeks after withdrawal of the drug in normal dogs treated for 27 weeks. Therefore, it can be recommended that liver parameters be evaluated at least 6 weeks after discontinuation of PB, and significantly abnormal findings should lead the clinician to re-evaluate the dog for hepatotoxicity or other primary liver disease. In addition, TT4 and FT4 decreases resolved 1 and 5 weeks after withdrawal, respectively. In dogs with suspected hypothyroidism, it is recommended that thyroid values be evaluated at least 6 weeks following cessation of PB. Feline hyperesthesia syndrome is a commonly recognized but poorly understood disorder characterized by paroxysmal agitation, focal spasms of the thoracolumbar epaxial muscles, vocalization, biting of the caudal trunk and pelvic limbs, and exaggerated tail movements. Pharmacological therapy including prednisone, amitriptyline, phenobarbital, carnitine, and coenzyme-Q 10 is often unrewarding. Five cats with compatible signs underwent a battery of tests which included a complete neurological examination, a CBC, biochemistry profile, spinal radiographs, electromyography (EMG), and histological, histochemical, and immunocytochemical evaluation of fresh frozen muscle biopsy specimens. Infectious disease screening tests (FeLV, FIV, Toxoplasma gondii (nϭ4) and Feline syncytia-forming virus (FSV) (nϭ1), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis (nϭ3) and electroencephalography (nϭ1) were performed. Four of five cats had a chronic, intermittent to progressive clinical course over a 1 to 2 year period before presentation. All cats were between 5 and 8 years of age with no apparent sex predilection. No neurological deficits were detected in any of the cats; however, zones of apparent hyperpathia were present in thoracolumbar epaxial muscles in 4 cats. Hematological and biochemical parameters were within normal limits with the exception of elevated globulin levels in 2 cats. Spinal radiographs were normal in all cats. Spontaneous EMG activity was found in a multifocal distribution within thoracolumbar epaxial muscles. The majority of spontaneous activity was found in the mid-thoracic segments and consisted of fibrillation potentials, positive sharp waves, complex repetitive discharges, and trains of giant motor unit potentials. No abnormalities were found in appendicular muscles. Infectious disease testing, CSF analysis, and electroencephalography were unremarkable in those cats tested with the exception of a positive FSV titer (1: 16) in 1 cat. Epaxial muscle biopsies (5/5) contained numerous rimmed vacuoles, the contents of which were positively labeled with monoclonal antibodies against paired helical filaments and ␤-amyloid. Vacuoles were not observed in muscles from 10 unaffected cats. The rimmed vacuoles and antibody labeling patterns are similar to that described in inclusion body myositis/myopathy in humans. Dogs in status epilepticus often need to be heavily sedated or anesthetized to halt seizure activity. Such measures preclude the administration of oral anticonvulsants. In those patients already receiving an adequate dose of phenobarbital, the ability to safely and effectively administer a loading dose of potassium bromide (KBr) intrarectally may allow for improved short and long-term seizure control. The purpose of this study was to determine the peak drug concentrations and bioavailability of an intrarectal KBr loading dose in dogs, as well as to evaluate the safety and potential side-effects of a 24-hour intrarectal loading protocol. Four normal adult female-spayed hound dogs, weighing an average of 22.3 kg (range: 19.1-26 kg), were used in a two-way crossover design. Each dog was administered a loading dose (600 mg/kg) of sterile KBr solution (concentration 250 mg/ml) over 24 hours, via six intrarectal (IR) boluses (100 mg/ kg, q 4h). Serum samples for bromide and potassium (K ϩ ) concentrations were obtained every 2 hours during the loading period, and weekly thereafter for bromide, until the concentrations were below the limit of quantitation. At this point, two dogs were re-loaded over 24 hours as a continuous rate intravenous infusion. The gold chloride method was used to determine serum bromide concentrations. The average serum bromide concentration after IR loading was 0.92 mg/ml (range: 0.81-1.11 mg/ml), and after IV loading was 1.18 mg/ml (range: 1.13-1.22 mg/ml). The average peak serum K ϩ concentration during KBr loading was 5.87 mEq/L (range: 5.5-6.8 mEq/L) and 5.7 mEq/L (range: 5.6-5.8 mEq/ L) for IR and IV loading, respectively (normal range: 3.5-5.5 mEq/L). Mean half-life (t 1/2 ) of IR KBr was 488.8 hours, or 20.4 days. A side-effect of both IR and IV KBr loading was mild sedation, and of IR loading was transient diarrhea. Preliminary bioavailability (F) of intrarectally administered bromide was calculated in 2 dogs (FϭAUC {rectal}/ AUC {intravenous}) to be 57.7 %. Results indicate that KBr is well absorbed rectally and that a 24-hour intrarectal loading protocol is safe to administer in normal dogs. Periodic monitoring of serum phenobarbital (PB) concentrations (PBC) in epileptic dogs is important because seizure control correlates best with serum PBC and not dosage. It has been recommended that serum PBC be measured at either trough (zero hour) or peak (three to six hours post dosing) times, but this can be inconvenient due to the difficulty in scheduling around a set dosing interval. The purpose of this study was to evaluate trough and peak serum PBC in epileptic dogs to determine whether there are significant differences in serum PBC occurring throughout a dosing interval.

Fourteen epileptic dogs receiving PB on a B.I.D. schedule for a minimum of three weeks were entered in this study. No dog had received any known cytochrome P450-inducing or inhibiting drugs within three months prior to the study. Blood samples were collected after a 12 hour fast prior to PB dosing (trough), and three and six hours post dosing. All serum PBC were determined using a fluorescence polarization immunoassay validated for dog serum. For each dog, trough, three hour and six hour serum PBC were compared using an analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by a Fisher's LSD test. Trough and both peak concentrations for each dog were also compared to determine whether drug concentrations were in different therapeutic categories which were defined, for the purposes of this study, as subtherapeutic (Ͻ15 ug/ml), low therapeutic (16-25 ug/ml), mid therapeutic (26-35 ug/ml), high therapeutic (36-45 ug/ml), and supratherapeutic (Ͼ45 ug/ml).

The duration of treatment ranged from one to 120 months with a median of 19 months. The median dose was 6.0 mg/kg/day with a range of 2 to 10.9 mg/ kg/day. There was no statistically significant difference among mean trough, three hour and six hour PBC. In addition, for 13 of 14 dogs (93%), the serum PBC were in the same therapeutic category at both peak and trough samples. One dog, which was receiving the highest dose of PB per day (10.9 mg/kg/day), had a trough and six hour PBC in the mid therapeutic range but a three hour PBC in the high therapeutic range.

To date, this ongoing study suggests that there is no significant difference in trough and peak serum PBC in epileptic dogs. Therefore, coordination of timing of blood samples, which is inconvenient for both clients and clinicians, is probable unnecessary when evaluating serum PBC in most dogs. The one dog receiving the highest daily dose of PB had a wider daily variation in PBC, and we are currently evaluating additional dogs to determine whether a higher daily dose is associated with greater variations in serum PBC. The purpose of this report is to discuss the results of computed tomography(CT)-guided brain biopsy in 50 dogs, with respect to the diagnostic yield of the procedure and post-operative clinical complications.

CT-guided stereotactic brain biopsies were done in 50 dogs with clinical signs of cerebral dysfunction that had lesions evident on brain imaging (CT or magnetic resonance imaging [MRI] ). Dogs were presented to the University of California-Davis Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital between November 1996 and September 1998. One to four core biopsy samples of the imaged lesion were obtained from each dog. Crush preparations for immediate histological interpretation were prepared from each core sample. The remainder of each core sample was formalin fixed.

In 22 dogs the neuropathologic diagnosis from stereotactic biopsy (including both crush preparations and paraffin sections) was compared with that made from tissue obtained from subsequent surgical resection or at necropsy.
After the biopsy procedure, 41 dogs were closely monitored for clinical signs of complications, seven dogs were taken immediately for craniotomy, and two dogs were euthanatized.

The final diagnosis was in agreement with the stereotactic biopsy diagnosis in 20 of 22 dogs. In 17 other dogs without follow-up, stereotactic brain biopsy provided a diagnosis of a specific primary brain tumor.

Of the 41 dogs available for evaluation of postoperative complications, 36 recovered without apparent complications. Of the remaining five dogs, complications included transient epistaxis (1 dog), transient exacerbation of cerebellar signs (1 dog), obtundation progressing to coma (1 dog), and intractable seizures (2 dogs). The last three dogs all had large primary brain tumors, and had received high doses of phenobarbital and glucocorticoids prior to biopsy.

Results of this study suggest that CT-guided stereotactic brain biopsy provides an accurate histopathological diagnosis of the majority of brain lesions detected by CT or MRI, with a low complication rate. Inherited canine motor neuron disease (Hereditary Canine Spinal Muscular Atrophy) (HCSMA) was first identified in Brittany Spaniels in 1979. The pathological and clinical features of the disease are similar to the human disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and have been well described, but biochemical data on a large number of affected animals has not been reported. This retrospective study characterize the pattern of laboratory findings and relevant histopathological changes in a large number of dogs with inherited HCSMA. We reviewed medical records of 54 affected dogs (January 1993-December 1998) including 43 affected adult dogs (mean age 5.6 years) heterozygous (HTZs) for HCSMA and 11 affected ho ozygote (HMZs) pup (mean age 13 wks). Laboratory data included complete blood counts, serum chemistries, CSF analysis, T3 and T4 measurements, urinalysis, and necropsy findings. Serum levels of vitamin E were measured in 7 HMZs and 14 HTZs. Except for the the clinical signs of HCSMA, all animals were normal on physical examination, were ambulatory and were able to eat and drink. A mild regenerative anemia was identified in 43% of the HTZs and 77% of the HMZs. Other abnormalities included increases (2.6-fold) in AST (SGOT), and ALP in ϳ15% of the HTZs. Hypoglobulinemia and hypoalbuminemia were present in ϳ32% of the HTZs. Serum levels of vitamin E in the HMZs were significantly lower (Pϭ0.001) than the HTZs or the age matched controls. Histologically, the livers of both HTZs and HMZs were generally unremarkable except for only rare, micronodular inflammatory foci. A few crypts were mildly dilated in the small intestine of several HTZs. Denervation muscle atrophy was present in all dogs; focal muscle necrosis was observed in several older HTZs.

The hematologic data were not compatible with RBC destruction; there was no evidence of blood loss. We interpreted the anemia as reduced erythropoiesis, possibly related to chronic disease. The mild liver lesions may be associated with the elevation in AST (SGOT) and ALP. Additional sources of increased AST could include skeletal muscle and RBCs. The cause of low serum levels of albumin and immunoglobulins is unclear, because there was no significant intestinal pathology, renal protein loss, or nutritional deficit. Low levels of the antioxidant vitamin E in HCSMA are consistent with similar findings reported in equine motor neuron disease, and suggest a role for oxidant injury in HCSMA. The significance of the abnormal laboratory findings in a limited number of dogs with HCSMA warrant further study to elucidate their potential association with the disease process. Fourteen miniature wirehaired dachshunds (MWHD) were evaluated for repetitive muscle contractions (twitching), seizures and hypnic jerks. Age of onset ranged from 6 to 13 years of age (median 7 years) and 5 males and 9 females were affected. Neurological examination was normal except for the observed twitching, and neither muscle atrophy, weakness or exercise intolerance were evident. Twitching occurred spontaneously (11/14) and could be elicited by sudden movements in the visual field (14/14), sudden changes in light intensity (10/ 14), and sudden noise (7/14). The seizures included impaired consciousness, extended or paddling limbs, foaming at the mouth, vocalizing and urinating. Occasionally the seizures followed a violent train of twitching (3/12). Hypnic jerks occurred at rest or when asleep. Laboratory evaluations including complete blood counts, serum chemistry profiles, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis were within normal limits.

In humans, histological and ultrastructural evaluation of muscle biopsy specimens has proven valuable in establishing a diagnosis in cases of progressive myoclonic epilepsy. Fresh frozen and formalin fixed biopsies from the triceps and vastus lateralis muscles were evaluated from 7 affected dogs. In muscles from 5 of 7 dogs, intense periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant inclusions (polyglucosan bodies) were present beneath the sarcolemma and between myofibrils. Ultrastructurally, glycogen particles, dense granular material and filamentous aggregates were present in subsarcolemmal spaces. A peripheral nerve specimen was available from one dog and showed similar polyglucosan bodies in the axoplasm of myelinated fibers. Filamentous accumulations of PAS positive, diastase resistant material may be associated with phosphofructokinase deficiency, branching enzyme deficiency, polyglucosan body disease, polysaccharide storage myopathy, and Lafora disease. The clinical presentation of progressive myoclonic epilepsy with the absence of muscle weakness, the lack of hypoglycemia or liver disease, and the presence of polyglucosan bodies within the muscle biopsies is consistent with a diagnosis of Lafora disease in the MWHD. The underlying metabolic abnormality in Lafora disease is as yet unknown. The clinical presentation, muscle immunohistochemistry, and immunophenotype of invading myocytotoxic T lymphocytes were evaluated in 7 young Newfoundlands with a newly recognized breed associated polymyositis. Age of disease onset, sex distribution of affected dogs, frequency of specific clinical signs, and serum biochemical abnormalities were collectively evaluated. Fresh frozen muscle biopsies were examined with histochemical stains as well as with the immunoreagent SPA-HRPO. In situ immunophenotyping of T lymphocytes was evaluated using monoclonal antibodies against canine lymphocyte CD4 and CD8 antigens in frozen muscle biopsy sections.

The Newfoundlands (4 males and 3 females) ranged in age from 6 months to 5 years of age at the time of disease onset. The most common presenting sign was exercise-induced weakness (7/7 dogs). Other common findings included generalized appendicular and masticatory muscle atrophy (5/7 dogs); dysphagia (4/7 dogs); regurgitation (4/7 dogs); and voice change/respiratory stridor (4/7 dogs). Generalized muscle pain was not a feature in any of the dogs.

Biochemical analysis revealed variable elevations in CK ranging from normal (3/7) to 5867, 6620, 8830, and 17598 IU/L in the remaining 4 dogs. Other abnormalities included hypercholesterolemia (3/7) and hypothyroidism (2/5). Concurrent immune mediated myasthenia gravis was not present in any of the 6 dogs that were tested.

Muscle histopathology was similar in all but one case, consisting of multifocal areas of lymphocytic, plasmacytic infiltration in an endomysial distribution. There was cellular invasion of non-necrotic myofibers. The one exception demonstrated predominantly degenerative changes (myonecrosis and fibrosis). All cases had prominent sarcolemmal labeling either within the serum or directly on the dog's muscle biopsy, a finding rarely observed in other causes of polymyositis and in masticatory myositis. Immunophenotyping of the invading lymphocytes revealed primarily CD8ϩ cells with less prominent labeling for CD4ϩ lymphocytes.

These findings are identical to those associated with human familial polymyositis. It is postulated that interactions between ICAM-1 (on targeted myofibers) and LFA-1 (expressed on the invading CD8ϩ lymphocytes) allows these T cells to selectively migrate into inflamed muscle and adhere to MHC-1 positive myofibers. The above sarcolemmal staining strongly suggests an immune-mediated etiology against a component of the sarcolemmal membrane itself. Myelography is currently the preferred means of diagnosing canine intervertebral disc disease. However, myelograms can cause worsening of neurological signs and seizures. The aim of this study was to describe the computed tomographic (CT) appearance of acute intervertebral disc herniations in dogs, and to compare the relative accuracy of myelography and CT at localizing herniated disc material. Twenty dogs with acute intervertebral disc herniations causing paraparesis were used. The dogs were imaged using a third generation CT scanner. Based on the neurological examination, transverse scans were acquired at 3mm intervals between T10 and L4, or L3 and S3. Following the CT scans, lumbar myelograms were performed by subarachnoid injection of iohexol. Hemilaminectomies were then performed to decompress the spinal cord based on the CT and myelographic appearance. The CT scans and myelograms were randomized and 6 clinicians with differing levels of clinical experience identified the position of herniated disc material in each case. The CT and myelographic findings were compared with the surgical findings.

On transverse CT images, the normal spinal cord was delineated by epidural fat over the disc spaces. Herniated disc material was clearly visible in the vertebral canal as a heterogeneous hyperattenuating mass. For the 6 reviewers, CT was 90% and myelography was 88% accurate at identifying the major site of disc herniation. Lateralization of disc material was correctly predicted in 96% of dogs with CT and 92% of dogs with myelography. We conclude that acutely herniated mineralized disc material is easily identifiable on CT scans. Moreover, CT is slightly more accurate than myelography at localizing the disc material when assessed by observers of differing clinical experience.
(GE Sytec SRi)(Omnipaque, Nycomed) The breeds of dog represented included 14 dachshunds, 3 cross breeds, 1 toy poodle, 1 cocker spaniel and 1 peekapoo.

The full extent of disc herniation was predicted in 84% of the cases with CT and 80% of the cases with myelography. In some animals, the subarachnoid space was characterized by increased attenuation cranial and caudal to the site of disc herniation. This was identififed as hemorrhage at surgery. The purpose of this study is to report the technique and results of transarticular process pinning for initial vertebral alignment and stabilization, prior to fixation with vertebral body pins and polymethylmethacrylate cement (PMMA), in thoracolumbar and lumbosacral vertebral column fracture/luxations. Eighteen dogs were examined at times varying from hours to days post-trauma, with signs localized to the thoracolumbar or lumbosacral spinal cord. All but three had non-ambulatory paraparesis; four were paraplegic. Lateral projections only were done during plain radiography and myelography. Survey vertebral radiographs confirmed a fracture/luxation in all dogs. Additional fractures were identified in nine dogs: four of the pelvis and/or pelvic limb long bones, and five of the caudal vertebrae.

Routine dissection of epaxial musculature was done with the dogs in sternal recumbency. Manual traction and reduction was done by means of bone holding forceps, and the articular processes aligned. A Kirschner wire of appropriate size was driven through the aligned articular processes in a medial to ventrolateral direction. This was done bilaterally in nine dogs, and unilaterally in nine, due to the presence of either fractured processes or planned hemilaminectomy. The K-wires were cut and crimped. Further stabilization involved placement of vertebral body pins and PMMA. Steinmann pins were used in seven dogs, and negative threaded pins in two dogs. In nine dogs, positive threaded pins were used. The bent ends of the trans-articular process K-wires were incorporated in the PMMA. Closure was routine, and post-operative radiographs were obtained in all dogs.

Two months post-operatively, six dogs were ambulatory with minimal gait abnormalities, six dogs were ambulatory with mild neurological deficits, and one dog was ambulatory with marked neurological deficits. Three dogs were lost to follow-up. Two dogs were euthanatized.

The technique of trans-articular process pinning facilitates vertebral alignment and stabilization. The technique effectively maintains reduction and stability of the vertebral fracture-luxation, reducing the potential of spinal trauma during manipulation and placement of vertebral body pins. Reduction is also maintained during the critical phase of PMMA placement and polymerization. Inborn errors of metabolism are caused by genetic defects resulting in abnormal synthesis, metabolism, transport or storage of biochemical compounds. In people, over 100 neurometabolic disorders have been identified, most of which are inborn errors of organic acid (OA) or amino acid (AA) metabolism. Although quantification of urinary OA is optimal for diagnosis of most metabolic disorders, determination of CSF OA and AA may be necessary for diagnosis of neurodegenerative disorders involving abnormalities of CNS oxidative metabolism. Ratios of lactate to pyruvate and 3-OH butyrate to acetoacetate have been used for evaluation of the redox couple NADϩ/NADH in the blood. Elevated blood alanine concentration is also an indicator of disordered pyruvate metabolism. The object of this study was to establish reference ranges for CSF OA and AA (including alanine), and CSF lactate/pyruvate and 3-OHbutyrate/acetoacetate ratios in healthy dogs under general anesthesia and 10 minutes after death.

Ten healthy dogs, as determined by physical and neurological examinations, CBC and a biochemistry panel, were used. All dogs were anesthetized, and CSF drawn from the cerebellomedullary cistern. An aliquot of the CSF was immediately frozen on dry ice for OA and AA determination; total RBC and WBC counts, WBC differential count, and total protein were determined on a 2nd aliquot. The dogs were then euthanatized and a 2nd CSF sample drawn for the same analyses. The brain and spinal cord from each dog was removed and examined for gross and histologic abnormalities. Four dogs were identified with microscopic inflammatory CNS lesions despite having normal clinical pathologic data, including CSF analyses, and were eliminated from the study. For the 6 remaining dogs, CSF OA concentration was determined by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry; CSF AA concentration was determined by quantitative column chromatography.

All 18 AA and 29 of 31 OA assayed were detectable in the CSF. No significant difference was found between the OA and AA levels of the dogs under anesthesia and following euthanasia. The lactate/pyruvate ratios differed significantly from the ratios of a group of clinically normal dogs studied at the University of Georgia, and substantially from the ratios reported for canine blood. The 3-OH butyrate/acetoacetate ratios and alanine levels were not significantly different from those of the University of Georgia dogs. Therefore, 3-OH butyrate/acetoacetate ratios and alanine concentration may be more reliable than lactate/pyruvate ratios in detecting disorders of CNS metabolism in the dog. The purpose of this study is to determine if Degenerative Myelopathy (DM) of German Shepherd dogs could be caused by a defect in the gene that encodes the canine hepatic alpha (␣) tocopherol transfer protein (␣TTP). This protein is responsible for the binding and transfer of ␣tocopherol between biological membranes and for maintaining plasma Vitamin E levels and it has been detected solely in hepatocytes. There is conflicting evidence in the literature regarding Vitamin E levels in dogs with DM; levels have been low in serum or tissue in some studies but have been normal in others. We decided to determine whether or not a genetic defect might cause impaired utilization of ␣tocopherol in liver cells of dogs with DM, similar to that seen in humans with familial Ataxia with Vitamin E Deficiency (AVED). This disease is caused by defects in the human ␣TTP gene and there are distinct similarities in clinical signs and progression to DM. The ␣TTP mRNA is expressed at high levels in liver and at low levels in lung, retina, heart, kidney, skin and other tissues. We therefore isolated total RNA from the liver of a normal dog. The RNA was reverse transcribed and then amplified using degenerate primers. Primer selection was based on the cDNA sequences for human and rat ␣TTP. Products were sequenced directly in both directions. We were able to identify about 600 base pairs of the 3' end of the canine ␣TTP coding region, which represents 72 % of the whole protein. The homology of the determined amino acid sequence for canine ␣TTP was 95 % between dog and human and 90 % between dog and rat. Almost all genetic defects causing AVED in humans lie within the region for which we now have sequence data for canine ␣TTP. We are now conducting reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and sequence analysis of canine ␣TTP on liver RNA isolated from 10 dogs with histologically confirmed DM. Glutamate is the most abundant excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system (CNS). However, excessive extracellular levels of glutamate are neurotoxic, and glutamate is incriminated as a mediator of secondary tissue damage following acute CNS injury. The aim of this study was to measure the concentration of glutamate in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from dogs with acute and chronic compressive thoracolumbar spinal cord injuries due to intervertebral disc herniation. CSF samples were taken from the cerebellomedullary cistern (CMC) and lumbar subarachnoid space from 8 normal dogs, 13 dogs with acute spinal cord injuries and 11 dogs with chronic spinal cord compression. The samples were frozen at Ϫ80ЊC for subsequent high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis of glutamate concentration. HPLC was performed on derivatized CSF samples using ultraviolet detection. CSF glutamate concentrations in dogs with spinal cord injuries were compared with those of the normal dogs using the Wilcoxon Signed Rank test.

The results demonstrated that focal spinal cord injuries do not affect the glutamate concentration in CSF taken from the CMC. However, dogs with severe, acute thoracolumbar disc herniations had significantly elevated glutamate concentrations in their lumbar CSF when compared with the control dogs (pϽ0.01). Moreover, the severity of their clinical signs was directly related to the glutamate concentration (r s ϭ0.6, pϭ0.011). Dogs with chronic compressive thoracolumbar lesions also had significantly elevated lumbar CSF glutamate concentrations when compared to the control dogs (pϽ0.01). These results suggest that excitotoxicity may play a role in both acute and chronic canine spinal cord compression. Therapeutic strategies to counter excitotoxic damage may therefore be useful in the management of such conditions and to correlate the glutamate concentration with injury severity. The purpose of this report is to describe the clinical signs, radiographic and pathological findings, and treatment of two dogs with extradural spinal synovial cysts. Affected dogs were a German short-haired pointer mixed breed dog (dog 1, female, 10 years-of-age) and a Mastiff (dog 2, neutered male, 1.5 years-ofage).

In both dogs, physical and neurological examinations confirmed the presence of progressively worsening spinal cord dysfunction (thoracolumbar in dog 1 and cervical in dog 2) of at least four months duration. Results of a complete blood count, serum biochemical tests, urinalysis, thoracic radiography, and abdominal ultrasound were unremarkable. Plain spinal radiographs, lumbar cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, and lumbar myelography were done in both dogs. Results of CSF analysis in both dogs revealed an albuminocytologic dissociation. Myelography of dog 1 demonstrated a right-sided extradural lesion compressing the spinal cord at T13-L1, and in dog 2 a bilateral extradural spinal cord compression was evident at C5-6 and C6-7.
body_text.section: EXTRADURAL SPINAL SYNOVIAL CYSTS IN TWO DOGS

body_text.text: Each dog was treated by means of surgical decompression (hemilaminectomy in dog 1 and dorsal laminectomy in dog 2), and extradural cystic mass removal. Histopathological examination of the excised material confirmed a solitary synovial cyst in dog 1, and multiple synovial cysts in dog 2. Both dogs are clinically normal eighteen months (dog 1) and two years (dog 2) following completion of surgery.
body_text.section: EXTRADURAL SPINAL SYNOVIAL CYSTS IN TWO DOGS

body_text.text: Solitary or multiple synovial cysts should be considered as a possible cause of extradural spinal cord compression in dogs. Synovial cysts result most likely from degenerative changes of the vertebral column, however trauma may be a causative factor. It appears that surgical decompression by means of laminectomy and synovial cyst excision provide satisfactory long-term return to normal neurological function in dogs. The center of pressure (COP) is a point on the ground that represents the centroid of force distribution an a force plate. The location of the COP is mapped by force plate analysis. In human beings, movements of COP (postural sway) are affected by certain neurological diseases. The objective of this pilot study was to measure and compare the COP movements in normal horses and in horses with neurological disease.
body_text.section: EXTRADURAL SPINAL SYNOVIAL CYSTS IN TWO DOGS

body_text.text: The subjects were 6 normal horses and 5 horses with cervical stenotic myelopathy. The horses stood with both fore hooves or both hind hooves placed squarely on an in-ground force plate. For each condition, movements of the COP were recorded during four 10 second periods using a sampling rate of 2,000 Hz. The variables calculated for each 10 second period were the average radius of the COP path, average velocity of COP movement, and mediolateral and craniocaudal range of COP motion. The results were also displayed as a stabilogram, which plots the craniocaudal movements against the mediolateral movements of COP. Comparisons between the normal and neurological groups were made using ANOVA (pϽ0.05). All COP variables were significantly greater in the neurological group than in the normal group suggesting a deficit in balance.
body_text.section: CENTER OF PRESSURE ANALYSIS IN NORMAL

body_text.text: The results of this pilot study suggest that COP analysis is a potentially valuable, non-invasive diagnostic tool in horses with neurological disease and in monitoring their response to therapy.
body_text.section: CENTER OF PRESSURE ANALYSIS IN NORMAL

body_text.text: Feldman, WJ Hornoff, and TG Nyland. School of Veterinary Medicine, UC Davis.
body_text.section: ULTRASOUND GUIDED PERCUTANEOUS ETHANOL INJEC-TION (PEI) FOR THE TREATMENT OF PRIMARY HYPER-PARA-THYROIDISM IN 8 DOGS RE Goldstein, CD Long, EC

body_text.text: For inclusion in this prospective study, each dog must have had persistent hypercalcemia, increased serum ionized calcium concentrations, low-normal to low serum phosphorus concentrations, normal or increased serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentrations, undetectable serum PTH related protein concentrations, and a solitary parathyroid mass visualized ultrasonographically with a 10MHz transducer. Eight dogs (4-16 years of age) met the above criteria and were included in the study. The ranges of their serum concentrations evaluated included calcium (13.2-14.6 mg/dl, reference range: 9.9-11.4 mg/dl); ionized calcium (1.45-1.85 nmol/l, reference range: 1.12-1.35 nmol/l); phosphorus (1.6-3.2 mg/dl, reference range: 3.0-5.5 mg/dl); and PTH (4.9-19.5 pmol/dl, reference range: 2-13 pmol/dl). The parathyroid masses were 0.06-0.14 cm 3 in volume. Each dog was sedated with propofol for approximately 10 minutes to prevent movement during the injection procedure. With ultrasound guidance, a 27 gauge needle was inserted into the parathyroid mass. Ethanol (96%) was slowly injected until diffusion throughout the mass was observed or a volume of ½ of the calculated mass volume was achieved.
body_text.section: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPTH) is a well defined condition in dogs.

body_text.text: Serum total and ionized calcium concentrations decreased to normal or subnormal values within 48 hours of the injection procedure in 6/8 dogs. One of the other 2 dog was then re-injected resulting in normalization of the calcium concentrations, the other dog's calcium concentrations normalized within 5 days of the initial injection. Serum PTH and phosphorus concentrations returned to within the normal range in all dogs within 24 hours of the injection (the second injection in the dog that received 2). Five dogs were hypocalcemic 2-5 days post injection. One dog required transient calcium and vitamin D supplementation. No dog displayed any adverse reactions to the injections or any other side effects. All dogs were closely monitored for 6-12 months. Chemistry panels including PTH concentrations remained within normal limits in 7 of 8 dogs for the duration of the study, as well as complete resolution of the clinical signs associated with hypercalcemia. Increased calcium concentrations were present at 1 and 2 months post injection in 1 dog and the owners elected to surgically remove the still present parathyroid mass. We conclude that ultrasound guided PEI therapy appears to be a safe and efficacious alternative to surgical therapy for PHPTH in most dogs. PEI therapy has been used extensively in the last 10 years for the treatment of solitary thyroid adenomas as well as for other endocrine and non-endocrine tumors in humans. Four 11-15 year old neutered domestic shorthair cats (2 male) with hyperthyroidism were included in a prospective study to evaluate PEI therapy for the treatment of unilateral hyperthyroidism in cats. All cats had increased serum thyroxin (T 4 ) concentrations (4.0, 5.2, 7.0, and 8.4 g/dl, reference range: 1.1-3.9 g/dl), a palpable thyroid nodule and clinical signs consistent with hyperthyroidism. Unilateral disease was diagnosed based on nuclear scintigraphy with unilateral uptake of pertechnetate ( 99m Tc). An enlarged solitary thyroid mass was identified ultrasonographically in all 4 cats using a 10MHz transducer. One cat had a mass with a cystic appearance. The thyroid mass volumes were 0.20, 0.33, 0.74, and 0.84 cm 3 . Intravenous propofol sedation was utilized to prevent movement during the injection procedure which lasted approximately 10 minutes. A 27 gauge needle was inserted into the thyroid mass with ultrasound guidance. Ethanol (96%) was slowly injected until diffusion throughout the mass was observed or a volume of ½ of the calculated mass volume was achieved. All 4 cats received a single injection.
body_text.section: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPTH) is a well defined condition in dogs.

body_text.text: Serum T 4 and free T 4 concentrations became normal or subnormal in all cats within 48 hours of the injection. These values remained below or within the reference range for the duration of the 6 month study. All clinical signs of hyperthyroidism were reported by the owners to have resolved within one week of the treatment. No cats exhibited clinical signs of hypothyroidism or required thyroid supplementation. Repeat nuclear scintigraphy performed in all cats 3 months after the injection procedure was normal in 1 cat and showed evidence of faint residual increased 99m Tc uptake in 3 cats. No severe biochemical or clinical complications were observed as a result of the injection or during the study. A transient voice change was noted by the owners of 2 out of the 4 cats. This occurred within a few days of the injection and resolved 6-8 weeks later.
body_text.section: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPTH) is a well defined condition in dogs.

body_text.text: In conclusion, PEI therapy may be an efficacious and safe therapy for the treatment of unilateral hyperthyroidism in cats. The pharmacokinetics of troglitazone was characterized in healthy cats following single dose IV and oral administration of the drug. Five healthy adult cats (4.5 Ϯ 0.1 kg) were studied after IV (5 mg/kg) and oral (40 mg/kg) administration of troglitazone using a paired, randomized cross-over design. Blood and urine samples were collected following drug administration and plasma and urine troglitazone concentrations were determined by high performance liquid chromatography.
body_text.section: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPTH) is a well defined condition in dogs.

body_text.text: Area-moment analysis was used to calculate pharmacokinetic parameters for troglitazone. Following IV administration, the terminal phase half-life of troglitazone was 1.1 Ϯ 0.1 h. Troglitazone distributed to a small central compartment of 0.15 Ϯ 0.09 L/kg which approximated blood volume. Steady-state volume of distribution was 0.23 Ϯ 0.15 L/kg. Mean total clearance of troglitazone was 0.33 Ϯ 0.04 L/h/kg. Absorption of troglitazone was rapid following oral administration with a first-order absorption rate constant of 0.70 Ϯ 0.52 h Ϫ1 . Peak plasma troglitazone concentrations of 2.8 Ϯ 0.8 mg/L were obtained at 1.1 Ϯ 0.6 h following oral administration. The oral bioavailability of troglitazone was low averaging 7 Ϯ 3%.

The general disposition pattern of troglitazone is similar to that reported for humans and other animals with some exceptions. Total clearance, half-life, bioavailability and elimination of troglitazone by non-renal clearance mechanisms is comparable to that reported in human and animal studies. However, steadystate volume of distribution was somewhat lower in cats. PEI has been used successfully, with few adverse effects, for the treatment of people with solitary thyroid adenomas as well as for those with primary hyperparathyroidism and a variety of non-endocrine tumors. The ethanol injection causes necrosis of the tissue. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of PEI for the treatment of bilateral hyperthyroidism in cats. Six cats (4 female), between the ages of 11 and 16 years (median 11 years) were included in the study. For inclusion, each cat must have met the following criteria: clinical signs typical of hyperthyroidism, increased serum total (tT4) and free T4 (fT4), bilateral thyroid enlargement demonstrated with radioactive pertechnetate scan and cervical ultrasound, no previous treatment and no concurrent illness unrelated to the hyperthyroidism. The tT4 concentrations were 3.1, 6.0, 6.9, 9.4, 9.4, 15.4 (ref. range 0.8-2.6 ) and the volume of the larger thyroid lobe in each cat was 0.2, 0.4, 0.3, 0.4, 0.7, 0.2 cm 3 , respectively (normalϭ0.06cm 3 ). Each cat was anesthetized (15-25 min) while a 27 gauge needle was directed into both thyroid lobes (1 cat) or the larger thyroid lobe (5 cats) with ultrasound guidance. 100% ethanol was slowly injected until there was visual evidence of complete infiltration (target dose-½ thyroid volume). tT4 and fT4 were monitored daily for 5 days, then every 2 weeks. Ionized calcium was also monitored daily for 5 days following the injection and results remained within the reference range. The first cat died within 12 hours of having both thyroid lobes injected, thus the remaining 5 cats had only the larger lobe treated initially. tT4 and fT4 decreased into the reference range within 72 hours post-injection in all cats. At the time of writing this report, 4 of 5 cats remain euthyroid (2 cats at 6 weeks, 1 cat at 4 weeks, 1 cat at 2 weeks). Recurrence of hyperthyroidism (T4ϭ5.0, fT4ϭ4.16, bilateral 99 T c uptake) occurred in one cat 2 weeks post injection. Injection of the contralateral lobe did not result in permanent euthyroidism and failure of the initial injection is suspected. Transient dysphonia (2/5 cats), Horner's Syndrome (2/5 cats) and mild gagging (2/5 cats) were noted, each sign dissipating within 2-4 weeks. A transient laryngeal paralysis that resolved after 2 weeks, was detected with ultrasound in one cat. These preliminary results suggest that staged PEI may be safe and effective for the treatment of bilateral hyperthyroidism in cats. This study describes a population of cats with a histologic diagnosis of thyroid adenomatous hyperplasia (TAH) with normal serum thyroxine concentrations and the absence of clinical hyperthyroidism.

Medical records from the Veterinary Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania were searched from 1988 to 1998 for all cats with a complete necropsy and a post mortem diagnosis of TAH and euthyroxinemia. Exclusion criteria included cats with a serum thyroxine level greater than 3.5ug/dl, a previous diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, treatment with antithyroid medication, 131 I therapy or thyroidectomy. Medical records were reviewed for presenting complaint, medical history, clinical signs, complete blood count, serum chemistry, urine analysis, coagulation screen, serum thyroxine (T 4 ) concentration, imaging studies, necropsy diagnosis and histopathology.

Twenty six cats with TAH and normal or low T 4 concentration were identified. The average serum T 4 concentration was 1.65 ug/dl (range: 0.2-3.3 ug/dl, normal 1-3.5 ug/dl). Four cats had more than one serum T 4 measured ranging from 2 months to 4.5 years after the first concentration was drawn. The average of the second measurement was 1.3 ug/dl (0.6-2.1 ug/dl). The average age at necropsy was 14.25 years (7-20.5). Castrated males and spayed females were equally represented. 60% of cats had a normal body weight. Signs typical of feline hyperthyroidism such as polyphagia, hyperactivity, tachycardia, regurgitation, increased nail growth, avoiding heat, or increased fecal volume were not reported in any of these cats. Clinical abnormalities included anorexia (77%), muscle weakness (65%), weight loss (54%), vomiting (46%), dyspnea (42%), PU/PD (38%), a palpable thyroid gland (38%), mentation changes (27%), gallop rhythm (15%), diarrhea (15%), pulmonary crackles (12%), and alopecia (8%). One cat had a cardiac murmur. The cats were necropsied after euthanasia (88%) or spontaneous death (12%). Post mortem findings varied considerably and included chylothorax, diabetes mellitus, dirofilariasis, heart disease, hepatic lipidosis, neoplasia, or renal disease with no prevalence of any one disease. Because of the strong association between hyperthyroidism and cardiac disease, cats were carefully evaluated for cardiac changes. 81% had cardiac disease at necropsy, including myocardial fibrosis (38%), hyaline arteriopathy (38%), endocardial fibrosis (19%) and myocarditis (12%). Only one had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We conclude that thyroid adenomatous hyperplasia may occur in euthyroid cats. A role for dietary fiber in the treatment of diabetes mellitus is well accepted. However, the long-term benefits of soluble fiber versus insoluble fiber remain incompletely characterized. The purpose of this study was to compare the effects of three commercial diets, one with increased amounts of soluble fiber (HSF), one composed principally of insoluble fiber (HIF), and one low in fiber (LF), on the glycemic control of dogs with naturally occurring insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.

Six dogs with diabetes mellitus were identified and determined to be free of concurrent disease. All dogs were well regulated with NPH insulin administered at 12-hour intervals. Low plasma C-peptide concentrations in all dogs were consistent with endogenous insulinopenia. A blinded, crossover study was designed with dogs randomly assigned to a sequence of three diets. Daily food intake was divided into two equal meals fed at 12-hour intervals and caloric intake was held consistent throughout the study. Each diet was fed exclusively for 4 weeks with a one-week transition period between diets. Body weight, insulin dose, and concentrations of serum fructosamine, albumin, and 10-hour serial blood glucose concentrations were determined following each 4-week period.

There were no significant differences in body weight, insulin dosage per kilogram of body weight, or serum albumin concentration between diets. Mean glucose concentration (mg/dl) was lower (pՅ0.05) for HIF (217) when compared to LF (336) and also tended to be lower when compared to HSF (312). Fructosamine concentrations were lower for HIF when compared to HSF and LF, and mean minimum and maximum glucose concentrations tended to be lower for HIF (163, 280) when compared to LF (250, 403) and HSF (247, 374) but these trends did not reach statistical significance.

In conclusion, when compared with diets higher in soluble fiber or low in fiber, a diet containing principally insoluble fiber may improve glycemic control in dogs with naturally occurring insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
HYPOTHYROID HORSES. B. A. Breuhaus. College of Veterinary Medicine, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC.
body_text.section: THYROID STIMULATING HORMONE IN EUTHYROID AND

body_text.text: The following study was performed to measure resting thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and TSH response to thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) in normal and hypothyroid horses. Blood was drawn from nine clinically normal horses and assayed for resting concentrations of TSH, total thyroxine (TT4), free thyroxine (fT4), total tri-iodothyronine (TT3), and free tri-iodothyronine (fT3). TSH and thyroid hormone responses were measured after administration of TRH and the horses then were placed on propylthiouracil (PTU), 4 mg/kg PO daily in their feed, for 6 weeks. Resting concentrations of TSH and thyroid hormones were measured weekly. TRH response tests were repeated at the end of the PTU administration period.
body_text.section: THYROID STIMULATING HORMONE IN EUTHYROID AND

body_text.text: Mean resting concentrations of TSH, TT4, fT4, TT3, and fT3 (mean Ϯ standard deviation) were 0.45 Ϯ 0.28 ng/ml, 21 Ϯ 9 nmol/L, 13 Ϯ 3 pmol/L, 1.2 Ϯ 0.7 nmol/L, and 3.1 Ϯ 1.6 pmol/L, respectively. After administration of TRH, TSH peaked at 45 minutes (0.89 Ϯ 0.5 ng/ml). TT3 and fT3 peaked at 2 hours (2.8 Ϯ 0.9 nmol/L and 7.4 Ϯ 3.2 pmol/L) and TT4 and fT4 peaked at 4 hours (42 Ϯ 13 nmol/L and 25 Ϯ 6 pmol/L). During PTU administration, TSH rose steadily to reach 1.34 ng/ml by the 6 th week. TT4, fT4, TT3, and fT3 decreased to 5 Ϯ 6 nmol/L, 6 Ϯ 5 pmol/L, 0.3 Ϯ 0.4 nmol/L, and 0.8 Ϯ 1.0 pmol/L, respectively. After PTU administration, TSH response was exaggerated (peak 3.64 ng/ml) and thyroid hormone response was delayed and blunted. TT4 increased from 5 Ϯ 6 to 19 Ϯ 16 nmol/L and fT4 increased from 6 Ϯ 5 to 12 Ϯ 8 nmol/L at 6 hours. TT3 increased from 0.3 Ϯ 0.4 to 0.8 Ϯ 0.8 nmol/L at 4 hours and fT3 increased from 0.8 Ϯ 1.0 to 1.8 Ϯ 2.1 pmol/L at 2 hours.
body_text.section: THYROID STIMULATING HORMONE IN EUTHYROID AND

body_text.text: The data suggest that measurement of TSH in conjunction with thyroid hormones, either at rest or in response to TRH, may be useful in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism in horses. Calcipotriene is a vitamin D analog that is used topically for the treatment of psoriasis in humans. The accidental ingestion of calcipotriene has been associated with life-threatening hypercalcemia in dogs. Traditional treatment of hypercalcemia from vitamin D and its analogs using steroids, diuretics, and fluids, with or without salmon calcitonin, can be prolonged and labor intensive. The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of pamidronate disodium, a diphosphonate, in the treatment of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia in dogs.
body_text.section: THYROID STIMULATING HORMONE IN EUTHYROID AND

body_text.text: Data on pamidronate treatment (7 cases) was collected from referring veterinarians treating calcipotriene toxicoses. Pamidronate disodium (1.3-2 mg/kg) was administered to dogs that had developed hypercalcemia (Ͼ12.5 mg/dl) and hyperphosphatemia (Ͼ6.5 mg/dl) secondary to accidental ingestion of calcipotriene. Serum calcium, phosphorus, BUN, creatinine, and clinical status were monitored prior to and following treatment with pamidronate. Monitoring of calcium and phosphorus continued a month or more following calcipotriene ingestion.

Before treatment with pamidronate, serum calcium, phosphorus, BUN, and creatinine levels were above normal laboratory ranges, and dogs showed clinical signs of vomiting, gagging, depression, and anorexia. In addition, the calcium and phosphorus product (Ca x P) was indicative of the potential for tissue calcification and renal failure. Average laboratory values are given in the table.

In most cases, significant reduction of serum calcium and phosphorus was seen within 24-48 hours of a single treatment. Usually, calcium and phosphorus levels stayed normal and clinical signs resolved throughout the remainder of time the dogs were monitored. The data suggests that pamidronate disodium is a useful adjunct in the treatment of hypercalcemia secondary to ingestion of calcipotriene in dogs. The objective of this report is to describe the clinical syndrome seen with ingestions of calcipotriene in dogs. Data from over 50 cases of accidental canine Dovonex (calcipotriene) exposures was collected over the phone from animal owners and veterinarians. Dovonex contains 0.005% calcipotriene, a potent vitamin D 3 analogue, and is used for the treatment of psoriasis in humans. Rodent studies appear to greatly underestimate the toxicity of calcipotriene to dogs. Our data suggests that ingestions of 40-60 g calcipotriene/kg body weight or greater have resulted in severe hypercalcemia (Ͼ16 mg/dl), and calcium x phosphorus products of Ͼ130. Approximately 50% of cases developed serum calcium concentrations of Ͼ14 mg/dl, 30% had phosphorus concentrations between 7.4 and 12.3 mg/dl, and 30% had BUN concentrations between 45-148 mg/dl. The onset of clinical signs occurs within 24-72 hours and includes depression, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea, and weakness. Elevations in BUN and creatinine occur by 72 hours. 20% of dogs either died or were euthanized. Hyperphosphatemia and hypercalcemia develop by 12-24 hours and can last for weeks. Calcium x phosphorus products above 60, and the long elimination half-life of vitamin D 3 metabolites promote soft tissue mineralization, especially in the GI tract, kidney, or vascular tissue.

Calcipotriene is a structural analogue of calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D 3 , and readily binds to natural vitamin D 3 receptors. Hypercalcemia occurs due to increased intestinal absorption of calcium, increased bone resorption of calcium, and decreased renal excretion of calcium. Treatment requires aggressive decontamination and is aimed at reducing serum calcium and phosphorus concentrations. The prolonged half-life of calcipotriene necessitates monitoring and treatment for weeks. Dovonex exposure should be considered as a differential in cases of acute, severe hypercalcemia. The nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug carprofen and thyroxine (T4) are highly bound by serum proteins. We postulated that carprofen would influence thyroid fuynction tests in dogs. For this study, 21 healthy dogs, 13 males and 8 females, weighing from 14-43 kg, were treated with 2.2-3.3 mg/kg q12h of carprofen (Rimadyl) orally. Serum samples were drawn before and at 2 and 5 weeks of treatment. Serum total T4 (TT4) and TSH were measured by immunoassay. Free T4 (FT4) was measured by modified equilibrium dialysis (Nichols). The following results were obtained: Carprofen caused mild but significant depression of serum TT4 and TSH, with 4 dogs falling below the normal range (11 nM) and 3 having undetectable TSH values. Although there was a trend for FT4 to fall and FFT4 to rise, these changes were not significant. We propose the following mechanism: 1) carprofen initially displaced T4 from serum and cellular binding sites resulting in an initial elevation of FT4; 2) TSH secretion was inhibited by negative feedback; 3) T4 secretion was reduced until FT4 returned to pretreatment values. TSH remained low possibly because the pituitary intracellular FT4 remained elevated despite a normal serum FT4. In summary, dogs on carprofen therapy should ideally be assessed for hypothyroidism with FT4 by dialysis and TSH measurements.
WITH DIABETES MELLITUS. Rebecka S. Hess, H. Mark Saunders, Thomas J. Van Winkle, and Cynthia R. Ward. School of Veterinary Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF CONCURRENT DISORDERS IN DOGS

body_text.text: The goal of the study was to characterize concurrent disorders in dogs with diabetes mellitus. To this end, a retrospective study was performed. Medical records were reviewed in detail. A low dose dexamethasone suppression (LDDS) test was considered consistent with a diagnosis of hyperadrenocorticism (HAC) if the 8 hour cortisol concentration was greater than 1 g/dl, and an ACTH stimulation test was considered consistent with a diagnosis of HAC if the 2 hour cortisol concentration was greater or equal 22 g/dl. A TSH stimulation test was considered consistent with a diagnosis of hypothyroidism if the basal serum T 4 was Ͻ1.5 g/dl and the increase after stimulation was less than twofold with an absolute increase of Ͻ2 g/dl. Acute pancreatitis was diagnosed based on clinical signs and histopathology or ultrasonography. A hypoechoic pancreas with hyperechoic peripancreatic mesentery was considered consistent with a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF CONCURRENT DISORDERS IN DOGS

body_text.text: The study included 221 dogs with diabetes mellitus. Over 50% of dogs had normal complete blood counts. Abnormal changes in the chemistry screen included hypochloremia (127 dogs, 57%) and increased serum ALT concentration (163 dogs, 74%) and serum ALKP activity (188 dogs, 85%). Venous pH and ionized calcium were measured in 121 and 87 dogs respectively, and were abnormally low in 56 (25%) and 41 (18%) dogs, respectively. Lipemia was observed in 92 (42%) dogs. Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and prothrombin time (PT) were measured in 42 dogs, and were prolonged in 8 (4%) and 3 (1%) dogs, respectively. Results of urinalyses showed that 174 dogs (79%) had glucosuria, 165 (75%) had hypersthenuria, 108 (49%) had proteinuria, 91 (41%) had hemoglobinuria, 75 (34%) had ketonuria, and 65 (29%) had bilirubinuria. Aerobic urine culture was performed in 159 dogs (72%); 34 dogs (21%) had aerobic bacterial growth. E. Coli was the most common genera of bacteria cultured (14 dogs, 41%). Hyperadrenocorticism was diagnosed in 53 dogs (24%) based on clinical signs and a LDDS test (45 dogs) or an ACTH stimulation test (12 dogs). Eight dogs (4%) were diagnosed as hypothyroid based on a TSH stimulation test (7 dogs) or low T 4 and high TSH concentrations (1 dog). Acute pancreatitis was diagnosed in 30 dogs (14%) based on ultrasonography (27 dogs) or necropsy (5 dogs). We conclude that dogs with diabetes mellitus have many concurrent disorders including HAC, urinary tract infection, acute pancreatitis, and hypothyroidism. The goal of this study was to evaluate the glycemic response to insulin treatment in dogs with diabetes mellitus. To this end, a retrospective study was performed. Insulin treatment was reviewed based on data obtained prior to referral, at the time of initial examination, and at the time of clinical control of diabetes mellitus. Insulin treatment was characterized by determining the type and dose of insulin, the range of blood glucose concentration during insulin treatment, the time of blood glucose nadir, and the insulin duration of action. Insulin duration of action was defined as the number of hours after insulin administration in which blood glucose concentration remained below 200 mg/dl. Results are presented as mean Ϯ SD.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF CONCURRENT DISORDERS IN DOGS

body_text.text: Two hundred and twenty one dogs with diabetes mellitus were examined between 1993 and 1998. Of these dogs, 127 were treated with insulin prior to referral, mostly with NPH insulin (79 dogs, 62%). Prior to referral, 69 dogs (54%) were treated with once daily insulin, 57 dogs (45%) were treated with twice daily insulin, and 1 dog (1%) was treated with regular insulin every 2 hours. Dogs were treated with a mean insulin dose of 1.2Ϯ0.8 IU/kg and a range of 0.1-5.3 IU/kg. The mean minimum blood glucose concentration prior to referral was 153Ϯ152 mg/dl and the mean maximum blood glucose concentration was 297Ϯ187 mg/dl. At the time of initial examination, 195 dogs had a blood glucose curve performed, and most dogs (155, 79%) were given NPH insulin. The majority of dogs (141, 72%) were treated with twice daily insulin, 34 dogs (17%) were treated with once daily insulin, the mean insulin dose was 0.7Ϯ0.6 IU/kg, and the range was 0.1-6.9 IU/kg. The mean minimum blood glucose concentration at the time of initial examination was 168Ϯ101 mg/dl and the mean maximum blood glucose concentration was 382Ϯ133 mg/dl. Mean blood glucose nadir was observed 6.0Ϯ4.1 hours after insulin administration, and insulin duration of action was 11.1Ϯ4.3 hours. At the time of clinical control of diabetes mellitus, 83 dogs had a glucose curve performed. The mean insulin dose was 0.7Ϯ0.3 IU/kg, the range was 0.2-1.6 IU/kg, the mean minimum blood glucose concentration was 158Ϯ94 mg/dl, the mean maximum blood glucose concentration was 304Ϯ111 mg/dl, the mean blood glucose nadir was observed 5.3Ϯ3.7 hours after insulin administration, and insulin duration of action was 10.2Ϯ4.6 hours. Once clinical control was achieved, only 5 dogs (6%) had an insulin duration of action greater than 12 hours. We conclude that although 54% of diabetic dogs were treated with once daily insulin prior to referral, most dogs (94%) require twice daily insulin treatment. The effect of age on glucose tolerance and body composition have gone unreported to date in the domestic cat and was the purpose of this study.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF CONCURRENT DISORDERS IN DOGS

body_text.text: Twenty young (1.04 Ϯ 0.05 y; Y) and twenty old (8.43 Ϯ 0.42 y; O) cats were fed a baseline diet for 60-d. Cats were weighed weekly and feed intakes were adjusted to maintain body weight. Before and after the dietary period, glucose (GTT) and insulin (ITT) tolerance tests were conducted and body composition was determined by dual energy X-ray absorptiometry. Young cats had significantly lower fasted body weights (3.65 Ϯ 0.08 kg vs 4.10 Ϯ 0.08 kg, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.001), total body fat (1106 Ϯ 60 g vs 1389 Ϯ 59 g, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.001), percent body fat (28.9 Ϯ 1.4% vs 34.2 Ϯ 1.4%, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.01), total lean body mass (2463 Ϯ 43 g vs 2644 Ϯ 44 g, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.01), higher percent lean mass (68 Ϯ 1 % vs 65 Ϯ 1 %, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.05), lower total body lean mass ϩ bone mineral content (2495 Ϯ 45 g vs 2688 Ϯ 45 g, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.01) and total body bone mineral content (32.5 Ϯ 2.2 g vs 44.8 Ϯ 2.2 g, Y and O cats respectively, pϽ0.01). The GTT showed that young cats had higher glucose effectiveness (0.014 Ϯ 0.001 min Ϫ1 vs 0.007 Ϯ 0.001 min Ϫ1 , Y and O cats, respectively, pϽ0.003) and glucose concentration at tϭ0 estimated by extrapolating the prediction of the glucose kinetics model to the moment of injection (thus cardiovascular mixing is not included) (393 Ϯ 12 mg/dl vs 351 Ϯ 13 mg/dl, Y and O cats, respectively, pϽ0.03). The ITT showed that old cats had a significantly greater area above the glucose curve and under baseline compared with young cats (Ϫ2419 Ϯ 246 mg*h/dl vs Ϫ3147 Ϯ 246 mg*h/dl, Y and O cats, respectively, pϽ0.05).
body_text.section: THE EFFECTS OF AGE ON GLUCOSE TOLERANCE

body_text.text: This study is, to the best of our knowledge, the first to show age-related differences in body composition in cats. Glucose homeostasis in cats is subject to vary with advancing age, as reported in other species. Whether this is due to age-related changes in body composition is unknown, but should be taken into consideration in future clinical studies which compare glucose metabolism between young and old cats. The purpose of this study was to determine the efficacy of once daily insulin therapy using protamine zinc analine insulin (PZI) alone compared with PZI and oral vanadium. Thirteen cats with naturally-occurring diabetes mellitus were randomly assigned to receive once daily injections of PZI alone or PZI combined with 45 mg vanadium dipicolinate orally for 16 weeks in a parallel study design. A thorough physical examination, CBC, serum biochemical analysis, serum thyroxine concentration, urinalysis and tests for FeLV and FIV was performed on each cat. Emaciated, ketotic, dehydrated, or debilitated cats were excluded from entry into the study.
body_text.section: THE EFFECTS OF AGE ON GLUCOSE TOLERANCE

body_text.text: All cats were randomly assigned to receive PZI alone (1-3 units q 24 hrs SQ initially) or PZI plus oral vanadium (45 mg q 24 hr PO). Every cat was fully evaluated before and at 4, 8, 12, and 16 weeks after entry into the study by a complete history, physical examination, body weight, serial blood glucose curves, serum fructosamine, serum biochemistry profile and urinalysis. Insulin dosage was adjusted based on clinical signs, serum fructosamine and serial blood glucose curves. Pre and post treatment values for serum fructosamine, fasting blood glucose (FBG), body weight, and insulin dose were compared using a Student's t-test.
body_text.section: THE EFFECTS OF AGE ON GLUCOSE TOLERANCE

body_text.text: All were domestic shorthaired cats; 3 were spayed females and 10 were male neutered cats. The median age of the cats was 10 years. Median insulin dose was higher (5 U) in the cats treated with PZI alone compared with cats treated with PZI and oral vanadium (3U). Signs of diabetes mellitus, such as polydipsia, polyuria, resolved in the PZI and vanadium treated cats and these cats experienced only mild weight loss (0.25 lbs) during therapy. Side effects included mild anorexia and vomiting which resolved upon temporary withdrawal of the vanadium. Clinical signs improved but did not resolve and weight loss (0.75 lbs) was more pronounced in cats treated with PZI alone compared with the vanadium treated group.
body_text.section: THE EFFECTS OF AGE ON GLUCOSE TOLERANCE

body_text.text: The mean change in serum fructosamine was greater, but not statistically different, in the vanadium treated group (191Ϯ 95 mg/dl) compared with those cats treated with PZI alone (54Ϯ43 mg/dl). Oral vanadium compounds appear to be a viable adjunct therapy when combined with long-acting insulin (PZI) in cats suffering from diabetes mellitus. Thrombocytopenia is a rare but well recognized side effect of methimazole (Tapazole) treatment in cats. Methimazole has also been implicated in producing a bleeding tendency in cats with a normal platelet count. Because of that, some have recommended not using methimazole to make cats euthyroid prior to surgery, in the belief that this bleeding tendency would increase the bleeding associated with surgery and therefore surgical risk. In this study, we investigated for hemostatic abnormalities caused by the administration of methimazole to cats with hyperthyroidism. Thirteen hyperthyroid cats were evaluated before and again after 3-4 weeks after treatment with methimazole (5-15 mg/day). Parameters evaluated included serum total and free T4, platelet count, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, thrombin clotting time, and buccal mucosal bleeding time. After treatment, the median serum concentrations of total and free T4 fell to within reference range. Median platelet count was normal before treatment and increased slightly after treatment but the change was not significant; no cat became thrombocytopenic. All coagulation parameters were normal in all cats, both before treatment and after methimazole administration. The pretreatment buccal mucosal bleeding times (range, 30-90 sec) was similar to the feline reference range (60-120 sec). After treatment, buccal mucosal bleeding times tended to increase slightly (range, 45-65 sec), but the values did not rise above reference range limits and the change was not significant.
body_text.section: THE EFFECTS OF AGE ON GLUCOSE TOLERANCE

body_text.text: In conclusion, results of this study failed to identify a subclinical bleeding tendency in hyperthyroid cats treated with methimazole. The drug does indeed cause thrombocytopenia in a few cats and may produce an undefined bleeding tendency in other cats (even less commonly); but methimazole does not appear to induce a bleeding tendency in all cats treated. However, if a bleed tendency associated with methimazole is suspected, determination of a buccal mucosal bleeding time prior to surgery may be justified. Two commercially available L-thyroxine products (HϭHeska, DϭDaniels) were compared. Oral dosages were given at 22 ug/kg b.i.d. and IV at 10 ug/kg to 6 radio-thyroidectomized male beagles. Oral medication was given for a minimum of 2 weeks prior to obtaining samples. Repeatability of serum TT4 concentrations over a 5 day period was also determined at times 0, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hrs after dosing. Total thyroxine was assayed using an RIA validated for canine serum. Data analyses were performed using model independent approaches by computer (PC NonLin) and manual methods. IV kinetic analyses found T 1/2 beta (terminal T1/2) to be 19.9Ϯ8.4 hrs, Volume of distribution at steady state (Vss) to be 0.44Ϯ0.11 L/kg, and total body clearance (Cl) to be 0.018Ϯ0.007 L/hr/kg. Oral kinetic analyses revealed no significant differences between H and D with the exception of Cmax (PϽ0.05, See table). Relative bioavailability based on AUC (H/D) was 0.87 with no significant difference found between products. Comparison of coefficient of variance for repeatability of L-thyroxine concentrations between H and D indicated no significant differences. This study was designed to evaluate the accuracy of available glucose measuring devices as commonly used in dogs. Comparisons were made between blood glucose results obtained from each device and those obtained on the same sample using a standard dry chemistry laboratory unit (Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics vitros 500) as the gold standard via a simple linear regression. To estimate the difference between glucose values obtained from each device and from dry chemistry, 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for the median difference were calculated.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME
