body_text.text: Venous samples were assayed according to manufacturers' directions using systems including iSTAT (Heska Sensor Devices), Glucometer Encore (Miles Inc; Enc), ExacTech R.S.G. (MediSense, Inc; RSG), Glucometer Elite (Miles Inc; Elite), Glucometer 3 (Miles Inc; Gf3), and Accu-Chek Easy (Boehringer Mannheim Corp; Esy). Samples (n ϭ 110; glucose range 41 mg/dl Ϫ 596 mg/dl) were collected in lithium heparin tubes and assayed within 10 minutes. In each case the device (m) significantly predicted the dry chemistry value (y), but R2 values varied. Overall, R2 and linear equation for each device were: iSTAT R2 ϭ 0.99; y ϭ m1.03-5.5; Enc R2 ϭ 0.98; y ϭ m1.18 ϩ 2.30; RSG R2 ϭ 0.87; y ϭ m1.06 ϩ 66.68; Elite R2 ϭ 0.95; y ϭ m1.11 ϩ 19.68; Gf3 R2 ϭ 0.87; y ϭ m0.80 ϩ 18.53; Esy R2 ϭ 0.92; y ϭ m0.96 ϩ 7.21. The samples were divided into 3 subsets based on glucose values. R2 values were much lower for all devices in the subset where glucose was Ͻ100 mg/dl. Individual results often varied markedly from the dry chemistry value. Median differences between dry chemistry and the devices ranged from Ϫ7 mg/dl (95% CI:(Ϫ23,2)) for Gf3 to 63 mg/dl (95% CI:(55,69)) for RSG.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Although all devices were able to predict the dry chemistry glucose values, some provided closer estimates than others, with the iSTAT providing excellent accuracy. The accuracy of each device was less at lower blood glucose values, which is unfortunately the very range where accuracy is most important. All of the devices had occasional readings markedly different than the dry chemistry unit, which could have led to clinically inappropriate treatment choices. The purpose of this study was to determine the adequacy of digoxin dosing in dogs with naturally occurring heart disease at the onset of treatment and during chronic therapy as reflected by serum digoxin concentrations (D conc ) measured 6 to 8 hours after the morning dose. We also examined the relationship of D conc to the prescribed digoxin dose and to body size, BUN, serum creatinine and potassium concentrations, and to a variety of other clinical parameters. Additionally, we evaluated the utility of serum digoxin measurements for the evaluation of suspected digoxin intoxication and for the purpose of re-dosing.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: In 66 dogs in which oral digoxin was initiated 7-10 days prior to sampling, D conc was Ն 0.9 ng/ml and Յ 2.5 ng/ml in 44 dogs (66.7%). The D conc was Ͻ 0.9 ng/ml in 18 dogs (27.3%), and it was Ͼ 2.5 ng/ml in 4 dogs (6.0%). Of 62 serum samples obtained from 47 dogs treated chronically (Ͼ 1 month) with oral digoxin, the D conc was Ն 0.9 ng/ml and Յ 2.5 ng/ml in 42 samples (67.7%) from 28 dogs. The D conc was Ͻ 0.9 ng/ml in 8 samples (12.9%) from 8 dogs, and it was Ͼ 2.5 ng/ml in 12 samples (19.3%) from 11 dogs. Of 21 serum samples obtained from 17 dogs because of suspected digoxin intoxication, the D conc was Ͼ 2.5 ng/ml in 10 samples (47.6%). The D conc was Ն 0.9 ng/ml and Յ 2.5 ng/ ml in 9 samples (42.9%), and Ͻ 0.9 ng/ml in 2 samples (9.5%). A D conc Ն 0.9 ng/ml and Յ 2.5 ng/ml was achieved 11/12 dogs re-dosed due to suspected digoxin toxicity and in 3/7 dogs with sub-therapeutic D conc.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Signs of digoxin intoxication and high D conc (Ͼ 2.5 ng/ml) were significantly associated with high BUN and serum creatinine concentrations and with the concurrent administration of other cardiac medications (ACE inhibitors and diuretics).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: In conclusion, clinical signs of digoxin toxicity and high D conc can largely be avoided during oral digitalization when the initial dose is 0.003 to 0.004 mg/kg twice daily. Digitalis intoxication, often erroneously suspected when serum digoxin levels are in or below the accepted therapeutic range, develops most commonly in dogs on chronic therapy that are receiving multiple cardiac medications. The efficacy of ecadotril (ECAD), a neutral endopeptidase inhibitor, was examined in dogs with moderate heart failure (HF) (left ventricular ejection fraction, LV EFϭ30%-40%) produced by multiple intracoronary microembolizations. Dogs were randomized to 3 months oral therapy with ECAD (100 mg once daily, nϭ5) or to placebo (PL, nϭ4). LV EF, LV end-systolic volume (ESV), end-diastolic volume (EDV), and plasma norepinephrine (PNE) concentrations were measured before (PRE) and after 3 months of therapy (POST) and the results shown in the table.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: In PL treated dogs, EDV, ESV, and PNE increased and EF decreased significantly after 3 months of treatment. In contrast, therapy with ECAD preserved, ESV, EDV and EF and did not elicit a significant rise in PNE. Conclusion: Longterm oral therapy with ECAD prevents or, at the very least, attenuates progressive LV systolic dysfunction and LV chamber dilation in dogs with experimentallyinduced HF. The purpose of this study was to assess the effects of systemic hypertension (HT) on echocardiographic and radiographic cardiovascular variables in cats compared to a healthy population of geriatric cats. Secondary objectives were to determine if there were any relationships between these findings and age or systolic blood pressure (SBP).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Group 1 consisted of 15 healthy cats over 8 years of age with normal SBP, and no evidence of cardiovascular disease on physical exam, ECG or echocardiogram. Group 2 consisted of 15 hypertensive cats (SBPϾ180mmHg based on an average of 4 measurements taken at 3 different times within 24 hours). Echocardiographic evaluation in each cat included standard 2-D, M-mode, Doppler measures, as well as four different aortic root dimensions. Fifteen objective variables were measured and two subjective scores determined from right lateral and dorsoventral radiographic views.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: LV wall thickness tended to be greater in the HT group but still within accepted clinical limits of normal. Significant differences between groups were found in all of the aortic root measures (except annulus). The ratio of proximal ascending aorta to annulus was also significantly different between group 1 and 2 (1.05:1 Ϯ 0.09 vs 1.33:1 Ϯ 0.13, respectively). A ratio of 1.2:1 or greater was found in 14 of 15 HT cats. There was a significant positive correlation between this ratio and SBP measure. Of the 17 radiographic parameters, only aortic undulation score was considered significant (0.06 Ϯ 0.2 vs 0.8 Ϯ 1.1), however, there was no correlation between the degree of SBP elevation and aortic undulation score. There was a significant positive relationship between age and some measures indicating horizontal inclination of the cardiac silhouette.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: In summary, measures of the aortic root demonstrate aortic dilation in hypertensive cats. Furthermore, the presence of a wavy aorta is more pronounced in hypertensive compared to healthy older cats. In a previous study, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibition failed to reduce the LV chamber or cardiomyocyte remodeling which invariably occurs with chronic volume overload hypertrophy induced by mitral regurgitation (MR) in dogs. Whether the failure to prevent LV remodeling with ACE inhibition was due to incomplete prevention of myocardial angiotensin-II (ANG II) formation and subsequent activation of the ANG II type-1 (AT 1 ) receptor remained unclear. We tested the hypothesis that specific AT 1 receptor antagonism would influence LV and cardiomyocyte remodeling and function with chronic MR..
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Six normal adult mongrel dogs (NL) were compared to 13 dogs with chronic MR, 6 untreated (MR) and 7 treated with the AT 1 receptor antagonist irbesartan (MRI-I). Systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance increased two-fold in chronic MR and normalized in MRϩI dogs as LV stroke volume improved significantly. LV end-diastolic dimension/wall thickness ratio increased in MR and MRϩI (7.3Ϯ0.3 and 7.1Ϯ0.3) compared to NLs (3.6Ϯ0.3, pϽ.05) as resting cardiomyocyte length increased in both MR. and MRϩI vs. NLs (164Ϯ1.0 and 174Ϯ0.8 vs. 139Ϯ0.6um, pϽ0.05). Velocity of isolated cardiomyocyte contractile shortening decreased in MR vs.NLs (60Ϯ1 vs 71Ϯ1 um/sec, pϽO.O5) and improved in MRϩI (69Ϯ1 um/sec, pϽ0.05 compared to MR.). LV ACE activity and ANG II levels increased two-fold in MR dogs (pϽ0.05) and normalized in MRϩI dogs.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: AT 1 receptor blockade in chronic MR improved forward stroke volume and systemic vascular resistance but failed to prevent LV chamber remodeling and cardiomyocyte lengthening, suggesting that ANG II activation of the AT 1 receptor does not significantly contribute to LV and myocyte remodeling in chronic MR. The normalization of cardiac ACE activity and ANG II levels with AT 1 receptor antagonism may have contributed to improved cardiomyocyte contractile function. The objective of this study was to determine the effect of chronic ACE-inhibition with enalapril on renal function in dogs with compensated mitral regurgitation (MR).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Blood samples from 116 dogs involved in a study of the efficacy of enalapril in delaying the onset of heart failure in naturally-occuring MR in client-owned dogs were evaluated. Serum creatinine concentrations (Cr) were determined at the outset of the study, and at 2 weeks and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after institution of either enalapril or placebo in a randomized, double-blinded fashion. Without breaking the code, Cr were compared between groups 1 (enalapril or placebo) and 2 (opposite of group 1) at each time point. In addition, the percentage of dogs in which Cr rose more than 35% from baseline values and the change in Cr from baseline to 6 and 12 months' therapy were compared between groups 1 and 2.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: There were no differences between groups 1 and 2 in any of the parameters evaluated. No dogs from either group became azotemic during the study and none dropped out of the study due to worsening azotemia.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: We conclude that chronic enalapril therapy of up to 12 months' duration does not appear to have a deleterious effect on renal function, based on Cr in dogs with MR, prior to the onset of heart failure. Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a primary myocardial disease that is inherited in at least 20% of affected human beings. Causative mutations in both the actin gene and dystrophin gene have been identified. DCM has also been demonstated to be familial in some breeds of dogs including Doberman Pinschers, Boxers and Newfoundlands, although causative mutations have not been identified.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: The purpose of this study was to evaluate DNA from Doberman Pinschers with DCM for the presence of mutations within the cardiac actin gene. DNA was extracted from 16 Doberman Pinschers with DCM. The diagnosis of DCM was based upon echocardiographic documentation of left ventricular dilation and systolic myocardial dysfunction (%SFϽ 20%) in the absence of congenital heart disease, or clinically significant acquired valvular dysfunction. DNA from 10 control dogs with normal echocardiograms was also extracted and analyzed. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and Single Stranded Conformational Polymorphism (SSCP) techniques were used for mutation analysis. PCR primers were developed using the published human sequences of the major actin exons. PCR conditions were optimized for canine products and PCR was performed to develop a product for SSCP analysis. SSCP was used to evaluate each exon for evidence of mutations. Molecular analysis did not reveal any mutations or polymorphisms within the exons of the actin gene in dogs with dilated cardiomyopathy. We conclude that mutations within the exons of the cardiac actin gene are unlikely to be the cause for inherited dilated cardiomyopathy within this breed of dog. In people, reduced plasma concentrations of B vitamins and subsequent hyperhomocysteinemia are risk factors for thrombotic disease. The purpose of this study was to determine whether plasma B vitamin and homocysteine concentrations play a role in the pathogenesis of feline cardiomyopathy and arterial thromboembolism (ATE). Fasting plasma concentrations of homocysteine and vitamins B 6 , B 12 , and folate were measured in 29 cats with ATE and cardiomyopathy [ATE group; diagnosed by typical physical examination findings of ATE and either an echocardiogram (echo), necropsy, or both], 27 cats with cardiomyopathy and no history of ATE (CM group; diagnosed by echo), and 29 healthy cats (based on a normal physical examination and echo). Mean vitamin B 12 concentration was significantly lower in ATE cats (866Ϯ367 pg/ml) and CM cats (939Ϯ389 pg/ml) compared to healthy controls (1650Ϯ700 pg/ml; pϽ0.001). In addition, mean vitamin B 6 concentration was significantly lower in ATE cats (3247Ϯ1215 pmol/ml) and CM cats (3200Ϯ906 pmol/ml) compared to healthy cats (4380Ϯ1302 pmol/ml; pϭ0.005). No differences were found between groups in folate or homocysteine concentrations. There was a negative correlation between vitamins B 6 (pϽ0.005), B 12 (pϽ0.001), and folate (pϭ0.059) and echocardiographic left atrial size. Although homocysteine and B vitamin concentrations were not correlated with medication type or dosage, they were correlated negatively with age. Multivariate analysis revealed that vitamin B 12 concentration was the only significant predictor of left atrial size. The results of this study suggest that, although homocysteine and B vitamins do not appear to play a role in ATE, B vitamin concentrations appear to be altered in feline cardiomyopathy and may play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. Percutaneous occlusion of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is an established therapeutic modality in human medicine. Small case reports and abstracts have suggested that this technique is applicable in dogs with PDA. Transarterial ductal occlusion was attempted in 43 dogs between January 1994 and December 1998. Three of the dogs had undergone unsuccessful attempts at surgical correction prior to attempted occlusion. There were 36 females and 7 males with a mean age of 13Ϯ 16 months and a mean weight of 7.6 Ϯ.5.8 (range 2.1-25) kg. Following selective angiography and morphologic classification of ductal anatomy, occlusion was performed using 1-7 standard 0.038 Gianturco vascular occlusion coils (Cook Inc., Bloomington, Indiana).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Occlusion was accomplished in 37 of the 43 dogs (86%). The minimal ductal diameter of the dogs that could not be occluded was significantly greater (5.4 Ϯ 2.5mm) than that of the dogs that could be occluded (2.5Ϯ 0.9mm). Additionally 4 of the 6 dogs that could not be occluded had type III ductal morphology. All three dogs which had previously undergone surgery were successfully occluded. Two dogs required a second procedure. Twenty two dogs had complete occlusion based on post-deployment angiography. The remaining 15 dogs had trivial residual flow. Complications included pulmonary embolization (4), partial aortic deployment (1), aortic embolization (4) and arterial hemmorrhage with hematoma formation (1). Coils in the pulmonary artery were left in place. All coils that embolized into the aorta were retrieved witout complication using a Nitinol gooseneck snare catheter (MicroVena, Inc). There were no fatalities. We conclude that percuatneous tranarterial ductal occlusion using Gianturco vascular occlusion coils is a viable therapy for PDA in dogs. The structure and function of the heart are determined by the interaction between the extracellular matrix (ECM), specific cell receptors (integrins), the cytoskeleton and intrinsic genetic regulation of cell function. Structurally, integrins mediate the attachment of the cardiac myocyte to the ECM and transmit the mechanical contraction force from the actin cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix. Integrins also transfer mechanical and chemical information from the extracellular matrix into the cells and modulate cell phenotype-specific expression and gene transcription. We tested the hypothesis that the interaction between myocardial integrins and the ECM is altered during the ventricular remodeling which occurs in volume overload associated with mitral regurgitation.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Ten dogs with experimental mitral regurgitation (MR) induced by percutaneous chordae tendinae rupture were studied for 2 weeks (2, MR-2wk), 1 month (4, MR-1m) or six months (4, MR-6m) and were compared to normal dogs (3, N) and dogs with chronic spontaneous mitral insufficiency (3, MR-CS). Hemodynamics at baseline, induction and sacrifice and echocardiograms at baseline and sacrifice were evaluated. Cardiac myocytes were isolated at sacrifice and in vitro adhesion of viable myocytes to collagen I, collagen IV, laminin, and fibronectin were assayed. Adhesion to each substrate was similar and collagen I is used for illustration.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: A significant increase in myocyte adhesion to collagen I (A-C1) was noted in MR-2wk compared to N and MR-CS (40% vs 16% & 18%, respectively). In MR-1m, A-C1 in each dog was not significantly different from N and MR-CS. In MR-6m, 2 dogs had significant increase in A-C1 (48%) and 2 dogs had A-C1 consistent with N and MR-CS (19%). Echocardiographically, the MR-6m showed the greatest increase in mass and left ventricular diameter. Hemodynamic data indicated more severe disease in MR as compared to MR-CS. One of the MR-6m with increased A-C1 had clinical pulmonary edema and marked increased Pa wedge pressures, PVR, and LA/Aortic ratio compared to other MR-6m and MR-CS, but SV, SVR, and EF consistent with MR-CS. Increased cardiac myocyte adhesion was noted at the initiation of MR (MR-2wk) when transmural wall stress is high and collagen remodeling is most active. This suggests that the integrin activity is highest at the initial stress of MR and may normalize in compensated chronic MR. Familial Dysrhythmia of Boxer dogs (FDBD) is an inherited disease characterized by syncope and sudden death. The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence of ventricular dysrhythmias in asymptomatic boxer dogs.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Ambulatory ECGs were obtained in 143 boxer dogs using three-channel Holter monitoring recorders and analyzed with a Delmar Holter analysis system using prospective, user-interaction. All dogs were free of historical or clinical evidence of arrhythmia or syncope, and all recordings were Ͼ20 hours in duration. Age, gender, number and grade of ventricular extrasystoles were determined. Dysrhythmias were graded as follows: 0ϭno dysrhythmia, 1ϭsingle uniform ventricular premature complexes (VPCs), 2ϭcouplets, bigeminy, trigeminy, or multiform, 3ϭtriplets, RonT, or ventricular tachycardia.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Eighty females (56%) and 63 males (44%) with a median age of 4 years (6 months to 12 years) were examined. The number of VPCs ranged from zero to 62,622. The median number of VPCs was 10. Of the 143 dogs, 24(17%) had zero VPCs, 63(44%) had Ͼ0 and Ͻ 50, 28(19.5%) had Ͼ50 and Ͻ500, and 28(19.5%) had Ͼ500. Of the 119 dogs with ventricular ectopy, 47(40%) were grade 1, 42(35%) were grade 2,and 30(25%) were grade 3, with a median of grade 2. Dogs were divided into 3 age groups: Ͻ3 yrs, Ն3 and Յ6 yrs, and Ͼ6 yrs. VPC number and grade were significantly different among age groups, with both number and grade increasing with age. VPC number and grade were not significantly different with respect to gender. There was a strong correlation between VPC number and grade.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: Results of this study indicate that some asymptomatic boxer dogs have frequent ventricular dysrhythmias of variable grade. Routine ambulatory ECG monitoring may be an important diagnostic modality in asymptomatic boxer dogs, especially those with a family history of FDBD. The tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) / serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) clomipramine (CLO) can increase heart rate, slow intracardiac conduction and increase intra-ocular pressure (IOP) in man. It is therefore recommended to use CLO with caution in humans with cardiovascular disease or glaucoma. The purpose of the study was to test whether the same precautions are necessary in dogs.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF METHIMAZOLE ON HEMOSTATIC PARAME

body_text.text: The ECG and heart rate of dogs were recorded telemetrically. The IOP was measured by tonometry. In Part I, dogs (nϭ8) received placebo or 20 mg/kg CLO PO in a two-way cross-over. In Part II, dogs received 4 or 12 mg/kg CLO PO in a two-way cross-over and the response compared to the pretreatment period. CLO had no effect on heart rate or cardiac rhythm at 4 mg/kg. At dosages of 12 and 20 mg/kg, CLO produced a non statistically significant bradycardia, and changes to the cardiac rhythm (sino-atrial block, second degree atrio-ventricular block and ventricular escape beats) were noted in Յ4% of recordings. The changes to the cardiac rhythm always occurred during periods of low heart rate and are a normal ''physiological'' response in dogs to a slowing of the heart rate. The observed cardiovascular actions of CLO should have no adverse effects in most dogs with congestive heart failure and might even be beneficial in some cases. CLO did not produce any of the potentially dangerous stimulatory effects (tachycardia and arrhythmias) described with TCAs in man. CLO had no effect on the IOP in dogs.

Few precautions should be needed with CLO in dogs with either cardiovascular disease or glaucoma. Further trials are recommended in dogs with severe bradycardia or decompensated congestive heart failure. Indications for myocardial biopsies include, myocarditis, doxorubicin cardiotoxicity, cardiomyopathies, neoplasia, amyloidosis, and glycogen storage disease. Myocardial biopsies are traditionally done via a transvenous endomyocardial technique. In veterinary medicine, this usually requires general anesthesia. Because of inherent difficulties with the procedure, risk of general anesthesia, and owner reluctance to consent to the procedure, endomyocardial biopsies are infrequently performed in veterinary medicine. The purpose of this study was to develop an alternative myocardial biopsy method that could be done on an outpatient basis.

A Bard Monopty biopsy needle (20 gauge) was selected for the procedure. The length of needle penetration was 11 mm. Full thickness sample biopsies were taken from the apical regions of the left and right ventricular free walls of a cadaver heart. With outflow occlude, the left and right ventricular cavities were filled with saline under high pressure to assess potential leakage from the biopsy sites. Minimal saline leakage occurred. With owners informed consent, ultrasound-guided biopsies were taken from the hearts of three dogs with evidence of clinical disease. Multiple biopsies (2-3) were taken from each dog. The biopsy sites chosen were in the apical regions (two from the right side and one from the left). The dogs were lightly sedated with ketamine and diazepam and monitored with continuous ECG. Post-biopsy the dogs were assessed for hemorrhage. pneumothorax and arrhythmia. Myocardial samples were successfully recovered from all three dogs. Transient ventricular arrythmias were seen in all dogs at the moment of biopsy. There were no significant post-op complications.

In conclusion, ultrasound-guide myocardial biopsies may be a safe, effective alternative to transvenous endomyocardial biopsies. Boxers are afflicted with an inherited ventricular arrhythmia (VA) that causes syncope and sudden death. The purpose of this study was to determine the morphology of spontaneous VA in Boxers using 12 lead ECGs and to compare this morphology to pace mapping in dogs of similar somatotypic conformation. A standardized 12 lead ECG was recorded from 22 Boxers with spontaneous VA. Pace mapping was performed in 7 other dogs under general anesthesia. The left ventricle (LV) was accessed via the femoral artery and the right ventricle (RV) was accessed via the femoral and jugular veins using 8.5Fr introducers. The distal two electrodes of a steerable 7Fr quadrapolar electrophysiologic catheter (1-mm interelectrode spacing) were used for pacing. The following 7 intracardiac sites were paced from the LV: apex, mid-septum, outflow tract, caudal basilar region below mitral valve; and from the RV: apex, mid-septum, and outflow tract (RVOT). The pacing cycle length was constant at 333 ms for 30 seconds. Twelve lead ECGs were recorded. The amplitude of the positive and negative deflections of the premature QRS complexes were measured in the Boxers to determine the polarity of each lead during VA. Similarly, measurements from all pacing sites in all leads were done to determine the site that most closely templated the most common morphology of the VA from the Boxers. Of the 22 VA from the Boxers, a positive QRS morphology was present in 18 (82%) dogs in the caudal leads (II, III, aVF) and 19 (86%) dogs in the left precordial leads (V2-V6). Lead I was positive in 12 (55%) and V1 was positive in 15 (68%). The terminal and delayed forces in V1 were negative in 9 of 22 (41%) dogs with positive caudal leads. The transition lead (earliest precordial lead with R/S ratio Ͼ 1) was V2 in 6 of 22 (27%) dogs and V3 in 1 dog with positive caudal leads. The paced sites that approximated the spontaneous VA were the RV mid-septum and RVOT. Circumferential pace mapping in 2 dogs did not allow further regionalization in the RVOT to the septum or free wall. In conclusion, spontaneous VA in the Boxer predominately has a positive morphology in leads that correspond to a site of origin from the basilar RV. Although specific mapping in the Boxer is required to identify the site of VA origin, these findings suggest that exploration of the basilar RV for disease is required. While elevated plasma homocysteine (hyperhomocysteinemia) is now recognized as an independent risk factor in human thrombovascular diseases, this has not been evaluated in cats. Therefore, we investigated whether plasma homocysteine concentrations were altered in cardiomyopathic cats with congestive heart failure and thromboembolism.

Fasting venous whole blood samples were collected from 30 sequentially admitted cats with cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure (CHF). Plasma was promptly prepared and frozen (Ϫ70ЊC) for homocysteine analysis by mass spectometry. Twelve of these 30 cats (9(, 3&) had only CHF (6 with 3 mol/L) averaged 6.4mmol/L higher than normal cats (pϭ0.22). While plasma homocysteine was higher in cats who had CHF with TE than with CHF only, this was not significant. Left atrial dimension and LA:Ao ratio were larger in cats who had CHF and TE vs CHF alone (pϽ0.01). Cardiac dimensions did not correlate with plasma homocysteine concentrations. There were no statistically significant associations between plasma homocysteine concentrations, age, weight, or gender.

Thus, hyperhomocysteinemia was detected in cats who had CHF and arterial thromboembolim. This may represent an acquired deficiency, a nutritional defect, or a unique genetic susceptibility. The purpose of this study was to determine the changes, if any, in plasma volume and/or neuroendocrine levels in renal hypertensive cats. Previous studies have demonstrated that hyperaldosteronism is a frequent finding suggesting variable activation of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone system. There are many other neuroendocrine variables that are involved in vascular resistance and plasma volume control, which need to be evaluated to better ascertain overall cause and effect scenarios. It is important to interpret neuroendocrine status with respect to plasma volume and renal handling of electrolytes which should have predictable changes. These interactions have not been addressed by previous studies.

Eighteen normotensive (control) cats and 4 renal hypertensive cats were compared with respect to plasma volume (PV), plasma renin (PRA), aldosterone (ALD), atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), epinephrine (E), norepinephrine (NE), fractional excretion of electrolytes and urine protein to creatinine ratio. Plasma volume was determined by I-125 labeled albumin. The means for the control (C) and hypertensive (H) cats were as follows: Age-yrs (4.4C, 13.3H), weightkg (4.59C, 5.17H), systolic blood pressure-mmHg (136.4C, 224.0H), BUN-mg/ dl (25.7C, 37.1H), creatinine-mg/dl (1.2C, 2.2H), PRA-ng/ml/hr (1.25C, 0.03H), ANP-pg/ml (332.9C, 427.2H), ALD-pg/ml (102.4C, 107.0H), E-pg/ ml (266.0C, 134.8H), NE-pg/ml (389.4C, 600.3H) and PV-ml/kg (29.34C, 33.06H). There were no significant changes in plasma volume or neuroendocrine levels between groups.

In conclusion, there were no significant changes in plasma volume or neuroendocrine levels in these renal hypertensive cats. In addition, all hypertensive cats had normal aldosterone levels, which is in direct contradistinction from previous studies. The number of cats in this study was very small and a larger population is needed to support these findings. The efficacy and practicality of the cardiac event recorder in identifying or eliminating transient cardiac arrhythmias as the cause of syncope in clinical patients was investigated. In a prospective study, 37 dogs were evaluated. Inclusion criteria included 1) history of one or more episodes of syncope within the preceding 14 days, 2) no evidence of systemic disease that could result in syncope, and 3) a negative routine electrocardiogram performed at the time of presentation. A King of Hearts cardiac event recorder was used and the monitoring duration was 7 (nϭ32) to 14 (nϭ5) days. Owners completed an activity log of the date and time that any clinical signs occurred, the activity of the patient at the time of clinical signs, and a brief description of the episode.

When used for a period of 7 to 14 days, the cardiac event recorder demonstrated the culpability of cardiac arrhythmias in 17 (45.9%) dogs. Clinical signs did not occur in 20 (54.1%) dogs during the recording period. Cardiac arrhythmias were demon-strated to be the cause of syncope in 10 (58.8%) of 17 cases exhibiting clinical signs during the recording period. Cardiac arrhythmias were ruled out as the cause of syncope in 7 (41.2%) of these cases. None of the dogs were encumbered by the unit which weighs 100 gm. It is concluded that the cardiac event recorder is an effective and practical diagnostic tool in the assessment of dogs with a recent history of syncope and in the detection of transient cardiac arrhythmias. The purpose of the study was to determine whether tubulointerstitial or glomerular abnormalities have a greater negative impact on renal function.

body_text.text: Renal tissue from 39 dogs who had serum creatinine measured within 24 to 36 hours of death or euthanasia was examined using quantitative morphometric techniques. Measurements included relative volume fractions of tubules, interstitium, glomeruli, and capillaries, in addition to glomerular area, glomerular capillary tuft area, Bowman's space area, Bowman's capsule harmonic mean thickness, and volume weighted mean volume of the glomerulus. Regression analysis was performed to determine if there was a significant correlation between these measurements and serum creatinine concentration.

body_text.text: Renal diseases identified included chronic interstitial nephritis (18), glomerulonephritis (11), amyloidosis (3), nephrocalcinosis (1), and granulomatous nephritis (1). Normal renal tissue from five dogs was also examined. Serum creatinine measurements ranged from 52 umol/L (0.6 mg/dl) to 1205 umol/L (13.6 mg/dl). Statistically significant (P Յ 0.05) correlations with serum creatinine concentration were identified for interstitial volume fraction (r 2 ϭ 0.34, r ϭ 0.58), tubular volume fraction (r 2 ϭ Ϫ0.31, r ϭ Ϫ0.56), glomerular area (r 2 ϭ 0.16, r ϭ 0.4), Bowman's space area (r 2 ϭ 0.26, r ϭ 0.51), Bowman's capsule harmonic mean thickness (r 2 ϭ 0.20, r ϭ 0.45), and volume weighted mean volume of the glomerulus (r 2 ϭ 0.11, r ϭ 0.33).
body_text.section: DIAGNOSTIC UTILITY OF THE CARDIAC EVENT RECORD-ER IN THE EVALUATION OF DOGS WITH SYNCOPE AND

body_text.text: Based on the measurements performed in this study, tubular and interstitial abnormalities have a greater negative impact on renal function than do glomerular abnormalities. This is similar to findings in human beings with renal disease. The implication is that therapy directed at preserving tubular function and normal interstitial architecture will have greater positive effect on renal function than therapy directed at the glomerulus. Ingestion of proteins of animal origin result in an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). Recent studies in rats and humans indicate that such renal responses are absent or blunted when vegetable protein, and particularly soy protein is ingested. Renal damage in remnant kidney rats has been ameliorated when soy protein has been substituted for casein, and altered hemodynamic responses have been proposed as one possible mechanism.
body_text.section: DIAGNOSTIC UTILITY OF THE CARDIAC EVENT RECORD-ER IN THE EVALUATION OF DOGS WITH SYNCOPE AND

body_text.text: We examined effects of protein meals on GFR and RPF of both normal and remnant kidney dogs to determine if protein source influenced the magnitude of protein effects. In 4 normal dogs casein, soy meal, semipurified soy flakes, and purified soy protein were tested. In 7 remnant kidney dogs casein, purified soy protein, and liver were tested. For each test, the dog was fasted for 16 hours, baseline measurements of GFR (exogenous creatinine clearance) and RPF (PAH clearance) were made, dogs were fed an amount of test protein consumed with a normal meal, and measurements (GFR, RPF) were continued for 4 or 5 hourly collection periods after feeding.
body_text.section: DIAGNOSTIC UTILITY OF THE CARDIAC EVENT RECORD-ER IN THE EVALUATION OF DOGS WITH SYNCOPE AND

body_text.text: Similar increases in GFR and RPF occurred regardless of protein source in both normal and remnant kidney dogs. Responses expressed as percent of baseline values were less in remnant kidney dogs than in normal dogs, particularly for RPF.
body_text.section: DIAGNOSTIC UTILITY OF THE CARDIAC EVENT RECORD-ER IN THE EVALUATION OF DOGS WITH SYNCOPE AND

body_text.text: We conclude that protein source was not a significant factor in postprandial renal hemodynamic responses in either normal or remnant kidney dogs. However, a renoprotective effects of soy protein in dogs is not excluded by our study since in other species other mechanisms with potential for imparting renoprotection have been described.

body_text.text: INDEX OF NATURALLY OCCURRING CANINE CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE J.E.Bauer 1 , R.C. Crocker 1 , D.Senior 2 , L. Nagode 3 , J.Rawlings 4 P.Markwell 4,,, 1 Texas A&M Univ., 2 Louisiana State Univ., 3 The Ohio State Univ., 4 Waltham Centre for Pet Nutrition.
body_text.section: URINE PGE 2 /CREATININE AS AN EARLY DIAGNOSTIC

body_text.text: Early stages of chronic renal failure (CRF) are characterized by balanced effects between renal injury and renal compensations. In the early stages renal function is adequate and thus rarely recognized. Serum creatinine measurements are frequently used diagnostically but patients with high normal values (1.3-2.0 mg/dl) may have early renal failure and be overlooked. By the time clinical disease occurs loss of renal functional mass may be so extensive that end-stage uremia rapidly develops. Thus, earlier indices of CRF would allow diet or other therapies to be instituted prior to generalized progression. Thirty dogs with naturally occurring CRF and 16 age-matched control dogs were evaluated as part of a two-center study. The CRF dogs were subdivided into early vs moderate CRF based on serum creatinine concentrations (Cr) and glomerular filtration rates (GFR). Sera and free-catch urine samples were obtained after withholding food overnight. Serum biochemistry profiles, concentrations of parathyroid hormone (PTH), and calcitriol, and urine concentrations of microprotein, creatinine, and eicosanoids (PGE 2 and TxB 2 ), were analyzed. Comparisons were performed using Kruskal-Wallis ANOVA at pϽ0.05. Calcitriol and albumin concentrations were not significantly different in any group. Serum calcium, phosphorus, and PTH concentrations were different only between control and moderate CRF dogs. However, urine PGE 2 /Creatinine, (PG/Cr) urine protein/creatinine (Pr/Cr) ratios, and BUN were different from controls in both CRF dog groups. Most notable was a Ͼ4-fold decrease in urine PG/Cr in affected dogs in both the mild (1084 pg/mg)and moderate (666 pg/mg) CRF groups (controlϭ4374 pg/mg). Regression analysis indicated strong inverse correlation (r 2 ϭ0.54, pϽ0.0001)between log(urine PG/Cr) and Cr. An inverse correlation between log(GFR) and Cr and direct relationship between log(urine PG/Cr) and GFR were also found. Correlations with BUN or urine Pr/Cr were not strong due to high variability. Strong correlation between urine PG/Cr and dogs with early CRF along with large numerical differences between normal and affected dogs suggests this measurement may help identify geriatric and canine populations with early CRF. Previous studies in our laboratory demonstrated that cats with partial nephrectomy exhibit glomerular hypertension (Am J Physiol 269:R1008, 1995), an adaptive change that has been associated with progressive renal injury in laboratory rodents and dogs. In human beings (N Engl J Med 334:939, 1996) , laboratory rodents (J Clin Invest 77:1993 , 1986 , and diabetic dogs (Kidney Int 46:161, 1994) , a renoprotective effect of inhibition of converting enzyme has been causally linked to reductions in glomerular capillary pressure. We tested the hypothesis that treatment with the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor, benazepril, would lower glomerular capillary pressure in cats with induced chronic renal insufficiency.
body_text.section: URINE PGE 2 /CREATININE AS AN EARLY DIAGNOSTIC

body_text.text: Following reduction in renal mass, thirty-two cats were randomly divided into four groups (nϭ8 each) on the basis of urinary inulin clearance (glomerular filtration rate, GFR). Each group then received once daily oral dosing with benazepril as follows: Group 1 (0 mg/kg); Group 2 (0.25-0.50 mg/kg); Group 3 (0.50-1.00 mg/kg); and Group 4 (1.00-2.00 mg/kg) for 6 months. The cats were studied by radiotelemetric blood pressure implants, renal clearance, and renal micropuncture techniques. Data were analyzed by ANOVA using a model incorporating treatment effect (and time effect where repeated measurements were made).
body_text.section: URINE PGE 2 /CREATININE AS AN EARLY DIAGNOSTIC

body_text.text: Compared to group 1, the glomerular capillary pressure was significantly lower in groups 2-4, systolic arterial blood pressure was significantly lower in groups 2 and 3, mean and diastolic arterial blood pressure were significantly lower in group 3, renal plasma flow was significantly higher in group 4, and GFR was significantly higher in groups 3 and 4. We conclude that benazepril treatment reduced glomerular capillary pressure and systemic arterial blood pressure while sustaining or increasing renal plasma flow and GFR in cats with chronic renal insufficiency. A blinded, multicenter, prospective clinical trial assessed the effects of enalapril (EN) versus standard care in dogs with naturally occurring, idiopathic glomerulonephropathy (GN). Twenty-nine adult dogs with membranous (16) and membranoproliferative (13) GN were identified for study. Dogs were randomly assigned to receive either EN (0.5 mg/kg PO 12-24 h) (nϭ16) or placebo (nϭ14) for six months (one dog was treated first with the placebo and then with EN). All dogs were treated with low-dose aspirin (0.5-5 mg/kg PO 12-24h) and fed Hills k/d diet. At baseline there was no difference in serum creatinine (SrCr), systolic blood pressure (SBP), or glomerular histologic grade between groups, however the urine protein/creatinine ratio (UP/C) was greater in the EN treatment group compared with the placebo treatment group (8.7Ϯ4.4 vs. 4.7Ϯ2.3).
body_text.section: URINE PGE 2 /CREATININE AS AN EARLY DIAGNOSTIC

body_text.text: After six months of treatment the change in UP/C from baseline was significantly different between groups (EN ϭ Ϫ4.2Ϯ1.4 vs. 1.9Ϯ0.9 in the placebo group). When data were adjusted for changes in GFR (UP/C x SrCr) a similar significant reduction was noted (Ϫ6.3Ϯ10.5 vs 8.3Ϯ10.1). The change in SBP after six months of treatment was also significantly different between groups (EN ϭ Ϫ16.7Ϯ7.0 vs 6.8Ϯ6.8 mmHg in the placebo group). Response to treatment was categorized as a) improvement (Ն 50% reduction in UP/C with stable SrCr) (assigned a value of 2), b) no progression (Ͻ 50% reduction in UP/C with stable SrCr) (value of 1), and c) progression (Ͼ 50% increase in UP/C and/or SrCr or euthanasia due to renal failure) (value of 0). Response to treatment was significantly better in the EN treated dogs (1.4Ϯ0.8) compared with the placebo treated dogs (0.3Ϯ0.5). These results suggest that EN treatment is beneficial in dogs with naturally occurring idiopathic GN. Systemic arterial hypertension is thought to be a common complicating factor in feline chronic renal failure (CRF). If this is translated into glomerular capillary hypertension, it may contribute to progressive loss of functioning nephrons. The aim of this study was to determine the incidence of hypertension in cases of feline CRF and to compare urine protein excretion in hypertensive and normotensive cats with similar degrees of renal dysfunction.

Fifty two cats with a diagnosis of stable CRF were entered into the study. Systolic arterial blood pressure (SABP) was measured using an indirect Doppler technique. Hypertension was diagnosed as SABP Ն175 mmHg which was persistent or associated with ocular lesions. Spot urine samples were collected by cystocentesis and urine protein to creatinine ratio measured. Normotensive cats over 12 years of age were paired with hypertensive cats of similar body weight and plasma creatinine concentration and compared using the Wilcoxon signed rank test.

Fifteen of the 52 cats with CRF had SABP of Ն175 mmHg giving an incidence of 28.8% for hypertension associated with CRF. All the cats with hypertension were 12 years of age or older, compared with only 19 of the 37 normotensive cats. These data show that systemic hypertension occurs in 29% of our feline CRF population with a tendency to occur in older animals. Hypertension was associated with greater urinary protein loss suggesting systemic hypertension may be reflected in raised glomerular capillary pressure. The high osmolality of normal feline urine is an important defence mechanism preventing bacterial colonization of the urinary tract. Cats with chronic renal failure (CRF) lack the ability to concentrate urine and may be more susceptible to bacterial urinary tract infection (UTI). The aims of this study were to assess the incidence and prevalence of UTI in cats with CRF and to identify the number of cats in which UTI recurred following treatment.

Thirty six cats with a diagnosis of stable CRF where urine samples had been collected by cystocentesis on 4 or more occasions (1 to 2 months between each sampling), were included in the study. A complete urinalysis was performed, including microscopic urine sediment examination and quantitative bacterial cultures. Blood samples were collected and the plasma creatinine concentration assayed. Data are expressed as mean Ϯ SD and cats with and without UTI were compared using an unpaired Student's t test.

A total of 268 urine samples (mean of 7.4 samples per cat) were analysed, 22 of which contained significant numbers of bacteria, giving a prevalence of UTI of 8.2%. Eleven of the 36 cats with stable CRF had significant bacteriuria on one or more occasions giving an incidence of 30.5%. Recurrent episodes of UTI occurred in six cats. In all cases, the bacteria cultured were identified as E coli. Comparing cats with UTIs to those where no UTI was detected, the two groups did not differ significantly in age (14.1 Ϯ 3.2 compared to 11.4 Ϯ 5.8) or urine specific gravity (1.015 Ϯ 0.003 compared to 1.017 Ϯ 0.004). Females were over-represented in the UTI group (8 of 11 or 73%) and under represented in the group with no evidence of UTIs (7 of 25 or 28%).

These data suggest that UTIs are very common in female cats with stable CRF. Recurrent episodes of UTI may be a factor in the progression of CRF but any association between bacterial UTI and progressive deterioration in renal function is difficult to prove as, once detected, UTIs were promptly treated with appropriate antibacterial drugs in these cases of CRF. The objective of this study was to validate a cocktail kinetic approach for the simultaneous measurement of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) in the dog.

Six healthy Beagle dogs were randomly assigned in a three-period cross-over study of intravenous bolus administration of iohexol (64.7 mg/kg), PAH (10 mg/ kg) and an iohexol/PAH mixture. A one-mL blood sample was obtained before, then 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 and 45 minutes, and 1, 1.5, 2, 3.5, 6 and 8 hours after the administration. PAH and iohexol were determined simultaneously by a validated HPLC method. Data were analysed using non compartmental and bicompartmental approaches.

Two stereoisomers, exo-iohexol (quantitatively the most important) and endoiohexol, were identified. The limits of quantification for the endo-, exo-iohexol and PAH assay methods were 2, 9 and 1 g/mL, respectively. The accuracy values for PAH and iohexol were 6.3 %, 1.8 % and 1.3 % respectively. No metabolites of PAH were detected. The total plasma clearance values for PAH and exo-iohexol were 13 Ϯ 2.3 mL/kg/min and 2.9 Ϯ 0.3 mL/kg/min, respectively. No significant effect of coadministration of PAH and iohexol was observed on the clearance of either drug.

In conclusion, this approach allows an easy simultaneous determination of GFR and ERPF in experimental studies. Non compartimental approach should be also recommended for the calculation of ERPF and GFR. General anesthesia (GA) and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been reported to cause renal dysfunction in dogs. Renal function was investigated in 26 normal, healthy dogs undergoing GA for student performed ovariohysterectomies. Due to the inexperience of the students, the procedure was usually protracted. The dogs were given one of 3 NSAIDs: ketorolac (0.5 mg/ kg), ketoprofen (1 mg/kg), or carprofen (4 mg/kg). All dogs were over 5 kg, healthy, and were presented for routine ovariohysterectomies at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Academic Hospital. All dogs were premedicated with acetyl promazine (0.05 mg/kg subcutaneously), and a NSAIDs, induced with thiopentone (10-15 mg/kg), and maintained on 2% halothane. None of the dogs were given intra-venous fluids during the surgery.

Renal function was assessed prior to surgery, 24, and 48 hours post surgery. Renal function and integrity was evaluated using serum urea and creatinine, fractional clearance of sodium (FC Na ), urine enzymes (GGT and ALP) and urinalysis.

The duration of the GA ranged from 1½-4 hours, with an average of 2 hours. There was no change over time in urine specific gravity, serum urea and creatinine, urine enzyme activity, and urine enzyme activity expressed as a ratio to creatinine that were indicative of renal dysfunction. The only statistically significant change was a decrease in FC Na 24 and 48 hours post surgery. A few dogs showed increases in renal tubular epithelial cells on urine sediment examination and concurrent increase in urine enzyme activity, 24 and 48 hours post surgery. However, this was neither a statistically nor a clinically significant finding.

It was concluded that renal function and integrity remained unaffected in this sample of 26 anesthetised healthy dogs that were given NSAIDs without concurrent intra-venous fluids. Benazepril is an ACE inhibitor which has been used to treat chronic heart failure in dogs. Aged dogs, which tend to suffer from heart disease, often also have renal insufficiency. Benazepril may be a suitable drug to use in these dogs as its active metabolite, benazeprilat, is excreted via both biliary and urinary routes. In this study, pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) parameters for benazepril were tested in dogs with experimental renal insufficiency.

Dogs received either no treatment (control) or a normal dose (0.5 mg/kg, nϭ5) or a 20-fold overdose (10 mg/kg, nϭ4) of benazepril PO SID for 15 consecutive days both before and after surgery. Reduction of renal mass to ¼ of normal was achieved via right-side nephrectomy and ligation of the branches of the left renal artery. Plasma concentrations of benazepril and benazeprilat were measured by a GCMS method.

The 1/4 th kidney model resulted in increases in BUN to 30 mg/dL and plasma creatinine to 2.0 mg/dL and reductions in RPF by 37% and GFR by 30%. Treatment with either dose of benazepril produced no significant change in these parameters. Concentrations of benazeprilat, assessed by AUC(0→24h) values, were not different pre and post-surgery. Plasma ACE values were reduced with benazepril to a similar extent pre and post-surgery. Benazepril was well tolerated in all dogs.

It is concluded that this model of renal insufficiency did not lead to any significant changes in the PKs or PDs of benazepril, administered at both a normal dose and with a 20-fold overdose. Benazepril appears to have a high safety margin, and no dose adjustment should be needed, in dogs with renal insufficency. This may be due to the dual biliary and urinary excretion of its active metabolite. Products containing extracts of the saw palmetto plant, Serenoa repens, are available as over the counter therapy for prostatic hyperplasia in men. The goal of this study was to evaluate the effect of Serenoa repens on canine prostatic hyperplasia and to assess whether the doses administered had any adverse effects. Twenty mature dogs with prostatic hyperplasia were assigned to 3 groups based on prostatic volume/kg body weight. All dogs were treated orally 3 times a day for 91 days: 8 dogs received 1500 mg/day; 6 dogs received 300 mg/day; and 6 dogs received canned dog food meatballs without medication. Dogs were observed at least 3 times a day for abnormal clinical signs. A CBC, serum biochemical profile, urinalysis, urine culture, abdominal radiography, prostatic ultrasonography, semen evaluation and culture, and serum testosterone concentrations were performed before therapy and at the midpoint and end of therapy. At the termination of treatment, necropsies were performed. Individuals conducting and interpreting the test results were blinded as to the treatment groups of the dogs. Treatment did not affect prostatic weight, prostatic volume, or prostatic histologic scores for hyperplasia. No significant differences were found in semen characteristics, caudal abdominal radiographs, prostatic ultrasound, or serum testosterone concentrations between groups. No beneficial or adverse effects related to treatment with Serenoa repens were found. Renal insufficiency was induced experimentally in 5 cats by 7/8 nephrectomy. As compared to pretreatment, the nephrectomised cats had statisically significant (pϽ0.01) increases in plasma urea and creatinine and reductions in creatinine clearance (assessed via creatinine clearance). Systolic, diastolic and mean blood pressure, measured telemetrically, and plasma levels of plasma renin, angiotensin I and II and aldosterone were also increased significantly (pϽ0.05). Benazepril administered at a dose of 2.5mg PO for 2 weeks produced significant (pϽ0.05) reductions in angiotensin II, aldosterone and all three blood pressure parameters.

A total of 11 cats with chronic renal failure including proteinuria received benazepril (0.25-1 mg/kg PO SID) or no ACE inhibitor (control) for 12 to 24 weeks. As compared to the control group, the benazepril treated cats had lower plasma urea and creatinine values.
There were no changes in urine protein values in the control group (nϭ5) during the trial whereas all benazepril treated cats (nϭ6) showed marked reductions in urine protein values during treatment.

It is concluded that the ACE inhibitor benazepril may be useful in the treatment of chronic renal failure in cats. The purposes of this study were to evaluate blood pressure, renal function and the renin angiotensin aldosterone system in cats with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), and to evaluate the response of these parameters to amlodipine. Four adult cats with ADPKD and four age-matched, healthy control cats were studied. All cats were instrumented with a radiotelemetry device for 24-hour hemodynamic monitoring. Renal function was assessed by measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR), effective renal plasma flow (ERPF), renal blood flow (RBF), filtration fraction (FF), blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr). GFR was determined by 3H inulin clearance and RBF by 14C-tetraethylammonium bromide clearance. Plasma renin activity (PRA), aldosterone (Aldo), and atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) were measured. All evaluations were performed at baseline and repeated after 7 days of amlodipine therapy at a dose of 0.625mg/cat. At baseline, control cats had significantly higher median systolic, mean, and diastolic pressures (pϽ0.0001) compared to ADPKD cats. Amlodipine decreased median systolic, mean, and diastolic blood pressures (pϽ0.0001) in both ADPKD and control cats. Peak amlodipine effect usually occurred within 3 hours of administration. Renal function was not different between ADPKD and control cats at baseline other than a mild increased BUN concentration in one ADPKD cat. Amlodipine did not lead to significant changes in any renal function tests. ADPKD cats had significantly higher PRA (pϭ0.0286) and Aldo concentrations (pϭ0.0286) at baseline. Amplodipine did not cause significant changes in evaluated hormones, and no difference was noted between ADPKD and control cats.

Hypertension was not documented ADPKD cats. Amlodipine successfully reduced blood pressure in normotensive cats and did not adversely affect renal function. ADPKD cats may have overactivity of the RAAS. Dogs with renal disease may develop systemic hypertension (SHT). In human medicine, treatment of SHT is considered once systolic blood pressure (SBP) values exceed 140 mmHg because of an increasing risk of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular complications. In veterinary medicine, SHT is numerically defined as SBP greater than 2 standard deviations from a normotensive population of dogs. Recognized consequences of SHT in humans include hypertensive retinopathy, cardiomyopathy, encephalopathy, and enhanced progression of renal failure. The purpose of this prospective study was to evaluate the prevalence of SHT in 42 dogs with chronic renal failure (CRF), the incidence of end-organ damage in relation to blood pressure, and the impact of SHT on mortality in renal failure-hypertensive (RFH) and renal failure-non-hypertensive (RFNH) populations. Blood pressures were measured using oscillometric techniques and care was taken to avoid stress-induced hypertension.

Hypertensive dogs (SBPϾ160 mmHg) were divided into two groups: group 1 having SBPϭ160-180 mmHg and group 2 having SBPϾ180 mmHg. Eight of 42 dogs (19.0%) were included in group 1 and twelve (12/42; 28.6%) were included in group 2. None of the dogs in group 1 developed recognized clinical consequences of hypertension. In group 2 dogs, hypertensive retinopathies were recognized in 4/12 (33.3%). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy was recognized in 1 dog (1/12; 8.3%). Rapid progression of renal failure was seen in (6/12; 50%) of the cases. Findings consistent with hypertensive encephalopathy were suspected in 3/12 dogs (25%). Percent of dogs alive after 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months were 58.3%, 22.2%, 11.1%, 11.1% and 0% (RFH dogs) and 100%, 95.8%, 76.5%, 60%, and 50% (RFNH dogs), respectively.

The preliminary results of this study indicate a systolic blood pressure of 160-180 mmHg seems to be benign and appears not to influence the progression of CRF. However, some animals with normal or mildly elevated blood pressure may develop higher pressure values. Sustained hypertension (Ͼ180 mmHg) is common in dogs with CRF and may lead to important clinical consequences. Clinical recognition of hypertension in CRF is important as SHT appears to significantly decrease survival time in CRF patients. A double blind, crossover, placebo controlled study was done in intact adult dogs (nϭ8) to determine if SAMe, an important methyl and GSH donor, can attenuate adverse effects of high dose chronic prednisone (Pred) therapy. A pilot study in 4 adult dogs, determined that co-administration of Pred (1-3 mg/ kg/ day) and SAMe (20 mg/kg/day minimum dose) did not affect bioavailability or pharmacokinetics of either substance (24 hrs, 21 to 42 days).

A loading dose of Pred (4 mg/kg for 5 days) was followed by 2.2 mg/kg PO SID for 12 weeks. Dogs received either SAMe (20 mg/kg minimum dose) or an identical appearing Placebo (Pla), on an empty stomach, in two divided doses/ day. Crossover occurred on day 43. Blood and urine samples, ICG clearance, and liver biopsies were collected on day 0 and designated intervals thereafter. Parameters evaluated included: CBC, biochemistry profiles, glucocorticoid induced alkaline phosphatase (G-ALP) activity, and concentrations of haptoglobin, total bile acids, RBC TBARs, and blood GSH and GSSG. Samples were collected after a 12-hr fast and before treatments. Tissues (days: 0, 42, 84) were stained with H & E and PAS. Morphometry was done using NIH freeware. Differences within and between groups were tested using a paired T test and two sample T test; respectively.

Morphologic changes in liver suggest that SAMe-Pred does not alter vacuolation, glycogen accumulation, or cell size heterogeneity. Pla-Pred significantly increased ALP and G-ALP (days 28 & 42), bile acids (fractional change, day 42), and decreased TBARs (days 7-42), GSH (fractional change, days 14-42), and GSSG (7-42 days). SAMe-Pred significantly increased ALP and G-ALP (day 28), and decreased TBARs (days 7-42), GSH (fractional change, days 14-42), and GSSG (day 42). On inspection, bile acids and % ICG retentions were lower and ICG clearance and GSH higher in SAMe-Pred intervals.

Despite the small number of dogs and expected large individual variation in response to glucocorticoids, Pred significantly reduced RBC GSH, GSSG and TBARs in all dogs. SAMe modified the influence of Pred on GSSG and (on inspection) GSH. We conclude that oral administration of the nutraceutical SAMe may improve hepatocellular handling of organic anions (e.g. bile acids, ICG), attenuate ALP and G-ALP induction, and beneficially alter glutathione stores/metabolism in dogs given chronic high dose glucocorticoid therapy. We examined the medical records of in 14 dogs with ultrasonographically identified gallbladder (GB) mucoceles and recorded the clinical, biochemical and histological findings and treatment outcome. In all dogs abdominal ultrasound revealed an enlarged GB with either a kiwi or stellate like bile pattern. Eight breeds were represented with an increased incidence in Cocker Spaniels (4/14). Body weight and age ranged from 6 to 36 kg (median:12 kg) and 4 to 17 years (median: 9.5 yrs), respectively. Clinical signs included: vomiting (12/14), anorexia (11/14), lethargy (9/14), polyuria/polydipsia (5/14), diarrhea (2/14) and a history of diabetes mellitus (2/14). Physical exam findings included: abdominal pain (6/13), icterus (6/13), hyperthermia (4/13) and a palpable abdominal mass (1/13). Serum biochemical evaluation showed increased alkaline phosphatase (13/14, median 11.6X, range 1-55X), alanine aminotransferase (11/14, median 6.5X, range 1-101X), ␥-glutamyl transpeptidase (11/13, median 4.7X, range 1-66.7X) and bilirubin (11/13, median 7.6X, range 1-74X). GB histopathology in 10/14 dogs confirmed the presence of a mucocele and identified mucosal hyperplasia (10/10), mural necrosis (9/10) and suppurative cholecystitis (5/10). Three dogs without GB biopsies had macroscopic evidence of a mucocele and GB wall necrosis. Surgery was done in 10 dogs (9 cholecystectomies and 1 cholecystotomy). Acute GB rupture was identified in 3 dogs and a previous rupture suspected in 4 dogs on histopathology and/or by the presence of GB wall adhesions at surgery. Aerobic bacterial cultures of bile were positive in 6/ 9 dogs. Four dogs died in the immediate post-operative period from bile peritonitis (2), pneumonia(1) and an unrelated cardiomyopathy (1). The other 6 dogs were alive and well at least 2 months post-operatively. Two dogs died of GB rupture pior to surgical intervention. One dog was euthanized due to chronic renal failure. One dog treated medically (choleretics and antibiotics) was asymptomatic for 1 year. Identification of the characteristic kiwi or stellate pattern to bile in the GB accurately identified the presence of a GB mucocele. In dogs with biochemical evidence of hepatobiliary disease, GB mucoceles were frequently associated with mural necrosis (12/13) and/or cholecystitis (9/13). These findings suggest that when GB mucoceles are identified by ultrasound, a combination of surgery (cholecystectomy) and medical treatment (antibiotics) should be contemplated. Fine needle aspiration with cytology has been frequently advocated as a diagnostic tool for the evaluation of liver disease. The correlation of cytology to histopathology, however has not been evaluated in dogs and cats with liver disease. This retrospective study was performed to determine the diagnostic accuracy of hepatic cytology when compared to the histologic diagnosis.

Thirty-three cases were evaluated. Thirty-two cases (7 cats, 25 dogs) having both liver cytology and histopathology performed within 24 hours of each other were included in this study. One case had an inadequate cytologic sample for evaluation. Liver cytology samples were obtained via ultrasound guidance and histopathologic samples were obtained either via ultrasound, laparoscopy, surgery or at necropsy. All cytologic and histologic samples were reviewed by one investigator (VG and BP respectively) for the predominant diagnostic features. The results were compared and the correlation of cytology to histopathology was graded as correlation, partial correlation where cytology revealed part but not all of the diagnosis, or no correlation. A 2X2 contingency table analysis was utilized to determine correlation versus partial or no correlation.

The results indicate only 9 cases (28%) were correlated. Seven cases (22%) had partial correlation and 16 cases (50%) had no correlation. The lack of correlation between the cytologic and histopathologic diagnosis was significant (PϽ0.001). Correlation was found in 0 of 3 cases of lipidosis, 2 of 6 cases of vacuolar degeneration, 3 of 11cases of hepatitis, 4 of 9 cases of neoplasia and 0 of 3 other conditions.

In summary, the results of this preliminary study found the cytologic diagnosis to have a poor correlation with the histopathologic diagnosis in dogs and cats with liver disease. The greatest correlation was observed in cases of hepatic neoplasia (44%). Unexpected hepatotoxicity was associated with the administration of stanozolol (Winstrol-V; 1-4 mg/cat/day PO) in 16/21 cats enrolled in two separate studies. One study was evaluating the effects of stanozolol in a colony of 18 research cats (12 healthy, 6 with naturally occurring chronic renal failure), and the other study was evaluating the clinical response of client-owned cats with severe gingivitis/stomatitis to stanozolol. The cats in the chronic renal failure study (RF) were divided into two groups and received stanozolol (25 mg IM on day one, followed by 2 mg stanozolol PO q12h) or placebo for four weeks, followed by a two-week washout period, after which the groups were reversed. In the gingivitis-stomatitis study (GS), cats were administered 1 mg stanozolol PO q24h. Most cats in the RF study stopped eating or had a significantly reduced food intake within 7-10 days of initiating stanozolol administration. Serum alanine transaminase (ALT) activity was significantly elevated in 14/18 RF cats when tested during and up to two weeks after stanozolol administration. Serum alkaline phosphatase activity (SAP) was mildly increased in only 3 cats. Four cats in the RF study had ALT Ͼ1000 U/L after only two weeks of stanozolol administration and were removed from the study. All 4 of these cats had coagulopathies consistent with vitamin-K antagonism, and 3 were hyperbilirubinemic. Administration of vitamin K resolved the coagulopathy in 3 cats within 48 hours. All cats survived and liver enzymes were normal in all cats tested more than 4 weeks after discontinuing stanozolol. In the GS cats, 2/3 developed evidence of severe hepatic failure 2-3 months after initiating stanozolol therapy. Anorexia was present for one week and one month, respectively, when the cats presented for reevaluation. Both cats were hyperbilirubinemic, and coagulopathies were present in both. Serum ALT was elevated in one cat, but normal in the other. SAP was elevated in both cats. The cat with the most severe hyperbilirubinemia did not survive. Histopathologic evaluation of liver biopsies from 3 cats in the RF study and both cats in the GS study demonstrated severe, diffuse, centrilobular hepatic lipidosis and cholestasis, without evidence of significant hepatocellular necrosis. The use of stanozolol in cats is not recommended until additional toxicity studies can be performed.

THE CAT. S. Tasker 1 , P. Cripps 2 and A. Mackin 3 . University of Edinburgh, Scotland 1 ; University of Liverpool, England 2 ; and Mississippi State University, MS 3 . Counting platelets in cats is frequently inaccurate and susceptible to procedural errors. The purpose of our study was to determine the relationship between 'gold standard' hemacytometer manual platelet counts and other methods of counting feline platelets, namely estimation of platelet numbers from examination of either a stained blood smear or a commercially-available supravital stain and proprietary slide (Zynocyte, MA), platelet counting using several different bench top centrifuge-type hematology analyzers (QBC VetAutroread, Idexx, ME; VS/2000, Zynocyte, MA), and automated platelet counts performed in an external laboratory using a standard impedance-based analyzer (Baker System 9110ϩ, Biochem Immunosystems, PA). The effects on Baker counts of using two different anticoagulants (EDTA and sodium citrate) for stored and transported samples were also determined.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF METHODS OF PLATELET COUNTING IN

body_text.text: Hemacytometer platelet counts were performed on venous blood taken from 49 sick cats (9 with thrombocytopenia and 40 with platelet numbers within normal range), and compared with counts obtained by other methods via Pearson correlation coefficients and Least Squares regression analysis. Baker counts were performed a median of 2 hours after sample collection; all other counts were done immediately after collection. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of time between sampling and analysis for Baker counts. For all of the above analyses, statistical significance was taken as PϽ0.05. For each counting method, sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic accuracy for differentiating low from normal platelet counts was also determined.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF METHODS OF PLATELET COUNTING IN

body_text.text: All of the platelet counting methods evaluated had correlation (r) values of under 0.8. Correlation (r) values obtained: blood smear 0.776, Baker EDTA 0.579, Baker citrate (corrected for citrate dilution) 0.629, QBC 0.538, VS/2000 0.505, Zynocyte slide 0.329. Platelet clumping precluded calculation of platelet numbers in 9 out of 49 blood smears, all of which had adequate hemacytometer counts. Time between collection and counting had no effect on Baker platelet counts obtained with both EDTA and citrate samples. Sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic accuracy respectively for each method were: blood smear 67%, 93%, 88%; Baker EDTA 100%, 16%, 33%; Baker citrate 100%, 38%, 49%; QBC 44%, 97%, 88%; VS/ 2000 100%, 40%, 51%; and Zynocyte slide 43%, 66%, 62%.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF METHODS OF PLATELET COUNTING IN

body_text.text: In conclusion, no counting method was found to consistently obtain reliable results. Based on our results, we recommend that stained blood smear platelet estimations or, ideally, hemacytometer counts are performed when analyzer counts are abnormal or inconsistent with clinical findings. Citrate is preferable to EDTA as an anticoagulant for samples stored and transported for later platelet counting by hematology analyzer.

body_text.text: TREATMENT OF CANINE VON WILLEBRAND DISEASE M. Brooks and J. Catalfamo. Comparative Coagulation Section, Diagnostic Laboratory, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

The efficacy of cryoprecipitate (cryo) for surgical prophylaxis and correction of the bleeding tendency caused by canine von Willebrand disease (vWD) was investigated. Six vWD-affected dogs, (nϭ2 type 1, nϭ2 type 2, nϭ2 type 3) were evaluated over a 4 year period. Cryo was prepared by thawing canine fresh frozen plasma at 4 C, and the % yield and potency (U/ml) of factor VIII and von Willebrand factor (vWF) in representative cryo units was determined. In a series of infusion studies, response to cryo was monitored in type 2 and 3 vWD dogs through serial measurement of their plasma vWF concentration (vWF:Ag), factor VIII coagulant activity (fVIII:C), and determination of buccal bleeding time (BT). Cryo was given pre and post-operatively (nϭ3 castration, nϭ2 cruciate repair, nϭ5 dentistry) and clinical response to dose (UvWF/kg) was evaluated by monitoring Hct, vWF:Ag, and observation of the surgical wound. In a retrospective review, the cryo dose (UvWF/kg) to control bleeding from cutaneous or mucosal sites (nϭ18 events for 5 dogs) was tallied. Signs of fever, vomiting, diarrhea, urticaria, dyspnea, or hemolysis within 24 h. of cryo transfusion were recorded for each dog.

At study entry, all dogs had history of 1 or more episodes of abnormal bleeding and had marked prolongation of BT (Ͼ12 minutes). Cryo units (nϭ15) had median vWF yield of 42%, potency of 4.96 UvWF/ml, and ratio of vWF:fVIII of 1.1. Cryo dose correlated with post-infusion plasma vWF:Ag (rϭ0.89), but not with factor VIII:C (rϭ0.13). In response to a single cryo infusion (12 UvWF/ kg), plasma vWF:Ag peaked at ½ h., and returned to baseline at 24 h. post infusion. Shortening of BT was readily demonstrated in type 1 and 2 vWD dogs at a dosage range of 5.6 to 11.5 UvWF/kg. Transfusion of up to 22 UvWF/kg did not shorten BT in type 3 vWD dogs. Preoperative dosages of 14 to 30 UvWF/ kg induced plasma vWF:Ag response of 19 to 63%, sufficient for normal intraoperative hemostasis in all dogs. Postoperative transfusion to sustain plasma vWF:Ag Ն10% maintained hemostasis for 48 hr post-op. In most cases, dosages of 5.5 to 9 UvWF/kg were sufficient to stop cutaneous or mucosal bleeds. No adverse reactions were observed after cryo transfusion. These studies indicate that cryo is safe and highly effective for treating vWD. The BT is useful for diagnosis but does not accurately predict surgical hemostasis, and BT response differs for vWD subtypes. Optimizing treatment regimens to balance cost and efficacy will require specific measurement of vWF to determine cryo potency and patient response. Crotalus viridis viridis, the prairie rattlesnake, is the only species of poisonous snake present in northeastern Colorado and a common cause of envenomation. This study was performed to define clinically relevant variables and to identify optimal treatment modalities.

Canine snakebite cases diagnosed at the Colorado State University Veterinary Teaching Hospital from 1989 to 1998 were identified by medical record review. Objective measures of outcome included mortality, days hospitalized, cost, and laboratory abnormalities. A multivariate regression analysis was performed to test for significant effects on outcome of clinical variables and treatments.

One hundred cases of canine snakebite were identified; the majority occurred between May and September. The majority of the dogs were 3 mo-12 yrs of age (median 3.7 yrs) and were bitten on the head (78/96) in the late afternoon. There was no sex predilection. The median time to presentation was 1 hour (range 15 min-13 hrs). Swelling at the bite was the primary finding. Principal initial laboratory findings were thrombocytopenia (44/50), leukocytosis (37/70), echinocytosis (48/52), and prolonged activated clotting time (8/86); thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis and prolonged activated clotting times progressed over 24 hrs in some dogs. Ninety four dogs were hospitalized; 48 were discharged the following day. Antibiotics (87 dogs), intravenous crystalloid fluid therapy (84 dogs), glucocorticoids (83 dogs), antihistamines (55 dogs) and antivenin (23 dogs) were the most common treatments. One dog died. Smaller dogs were hospitalized longer than larger dogs. Antivenin had no significant effect on days hospitalized but was associated with a higher platelet count after treatment and a higher total hospital bill.

The bites of the prairie rattlesnake are associated with significant morbidity but low mortality. Antivenin use and dosage should be reassessed for dogs bitten by this species of rattlesnake. We reviewed 50 cases of confirmed feline heartworm disease (FHWD) seen at North Carolina State University from 1985 through 1997.

The M:F was 28:22 (56% males; no evidence of male over-representation compared to the hospital reference population of 8400 cats [4474:3926, 57% male]). The mean age was 6.35 (SDϭ4.4; 1-19 years. Forty-two cats were domestic (84%), with 31 DSH and 11 DLH. There was no difference between proportions of exotic and domestic cats, compared to the control population. FHWD was diagnosed less often in the 4th quarter of the year. There is no evidence of increasing prevalence from 1985-1997. Owners reported 13 of 48 cats (27%) to be housed totally indoors, 33 (69%) indoors and outdoors, and 2 (4%) totally outdoors. Presenting signs included dyspnea (24 cats, 48%), cough (19 cats, 38% and sudden death (5 cats, 10%). Vomiting was reported in 19 cats (38%), with frequent vomiting being noted in 8 (16%). Only 1 of 8 cats (13%) was microfilaria-positive. ELISA was positive for antigen in 37 of 43 cats (86%) and for antibodies in 19 of 22 cats (86%). Three cats (14%) with FHWD were antibody negative. Heartworms were detected in 14 of 33 cats (42%) by echocardiography. Eosinophilia was detected in 43% (18/42) of cats with FHWD, significantly more often than in the control population. Thoracic radiographs (nϭ41) showed 76% (31/41) to have pulmonary artery enlargement. Pulmonary parenchymal abnormalities (Ϯ hyperinflation) were recognized in 76% (31/41), with a bronchointerstitial pattern being most common. Median survival for 48 cats was 1.5 years; in cats living beyond the day of presentation, it was 4 years. Survival of 11 cats treated with sodium caparsolate was not significantly different from those not receiving adulticide. The relationship of Helicobacter felis a bacterium observed in the stomachs of cats, to gastric disease is unclear. The objective of this study was to determine if H. felis infection alters gastric morphology, cytokine expression, and secretory function in cats. Five SPF, Helicobacter free cats were studied before and for one year after inoculation with H. felis (ATCC 49179). Four SPF, uninfected cats served as controls.

All five H. felis inoculated cats became colonized as determined by urease activity, histopathology, PCR, culture and transmission electron microscopy of serial gastric biopsies. Uninoculated cats remained Helicobacter free. The body and cardia were more heavily colonized than the pyloric antrum. Mild gastric inflammation was detected in infected and uninfected cats, but was more extensive in infected cats. There was a weak correlation (Tau .311, P ϭ0.02) between colonization density and the degree of inflammation. No upregulation of mucosal IL-1a, IL-1b or TNF-a was detected by RT-PCR in any cat. Lymphoid follicles and atrophy were observed almost exclusively in the pylorus of infected cats. Gradual seroconversion (IgG) was observed in 4/5 infected cats, with ELISA values peaking at 4-15x baseline. There was no correlation between seroconversion and the number of organisms observed, the degree of gastric inflammation, or the number of lymphoid follicles. The gastric secretory axis, assessed by fasting plasma gastrin and pentagastrin stimulated gastric acid secretion was similar in both infected and uninfected cats.
