body_text.text: These findings suggest that H. felis infection induces mild gastric inflammation and marked lymphoid follicle hyperplasia, but does not perturb gastric secretory function in cats. The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of canine lyophilized IgG in the treatment of dogs naturally infected with canine parvovirus. Forty-three dogs that presented consecutively to Auburn University for treatment of severe parvoviral enteritis were admitted to the study and randomly assigned to either the Conventional Treatment group (Group 1-Nϭ22) or the IgG group (Group 2-Nϭ21). All dogs received identical treatment (lactated Ringers solution 6.6 ml/kg/day, enrofloxacin 5 mg/kg IV q 12 h, ampicillin 22 mg/kg IV q 8 h, metoclopramide 1 mg/kg/24 h CRI, and potassium chloride 4 mEq/L) until signs of gastroenteritis subsided. Dogs in Group 2 were also given lyophilized canine IgG (mean dosage 163 mg/kg) on the first day of hospitalization. Partial parenteral nutrition (PPN) was given to dogs on fluids Ͼ5 days and hetastarch or plasma (22 ml/kg) was administered if serum albumin dropped below 1.0 g/dl or peripheral edema developed. There was no difference between Groups 1 and 2 for neutrophil count (1684/L vs 2331/L), lymphocyte count (1354/L vs 1548/L), age (13.5 wks vs 16 wks), and body weight (9.2 kg vs 10.6 kg). Hospitalization time (4 days vs 7 days) and # hours on IV fluids (77 h vs 137 h) were significantly decreased (p Ͻ.01) in Group 2 vs Group 1. Dogs in Group 2 began eating after 68 h (2.8 d) and exhibited a firm stool by 74 h (3.1 d), whereas dogs in Group 1 did not begin eating until 134 h (5.6 d) and developed a firm stool after 148 h (6.2 d). There was no difference in survival rate (Group 1: 18/22, 82%; Group 2: 19/21, 90%). In Group 1, 7 dogs received PPN, 6 dogs received hetastarch, and 2 dogs received plasma; additional therapy was not administered to any of the dogs in Group 2. In conclusion, dogs receiving lyophilized IgG as adjunctive therapy for CPV enteritis had decreased hospitalization time, reduced severity of disease, and reduced cost of treatment compared to dogs treated with conventional therapy alone.

body_text.text: A previous study showed that 8% of cats within the United States had Cryptosporidium parvum IgG in serum suggesting that exposure to this pathogen was common. The purpose of this study was to determine the duration of oocyst shedding and the temporal serum C. parvum specific IgA, IgM, and IgG responses in experimentally inoculated cats.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: Eight adult cats were shown to be seronegative for C. parvum specific IgG and oocysts on 2 separate dates prior to being inoculated orally with 1 x 10 6 C. parvum oocysts. Thin fecal smears were made of each cat's feces daily until 30 days post-infection (PI) and then twice weekly until day 85. Starting day 85, methylprednisolone acetate was administered at 20 mg/kg, IM, weekly for 3 weeks. Fecal smears were then made daily from days 85-115 and then twice weekly until the termination of the experiment on day 140. An immunoflourescent antibody assay (Merifluor Cincinnati, Ohio) was applied to each thin fecal smear to aid in detection of C. parvum oocysts. Sera were collected weekly and were assayed in ELISA for detection of C. parvum-specific IgA, IgM, and IgG.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: All cats shed oocysts with a prepatent period of 5 to 9 days. All cats were subclinically infected, but oocysts were shed intermittently for 2 to 23 days. When methylprednisolone acetate was administered, oocysts had not been detected in the feces of any cat for between 55 to 77 days. Diarrhea developed and oocysts were found in the feces of all cats following the third methylprednisolone acetate injection. All 8 cats developed detectable serum IgM, IgG, and IgA levels PI. On day 140, 7 of 8 cats were seropositive for IgM and all 8 cats were seropositive for IgG and IgA. In general, magnitude of serum IgA responses was greater than IgM or IgG.

body_text.text: This study suggests cats can be chronically infected with C. parvum and have detectable levels of serum antibodies for months after infection. Toxoplasma gondii infection of cats is common but usually subclinical; ocular inflammation is one manifestation of disease. The purpose of this study was to determine whether clinical ocular toxoplasmosis occurs in kittens infected transplacentally or in the neonatal period.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: Young adult, pregnant queens (n ϭ 3) were purchased and shown to be seronegative for T. gondii IgM and IgG, FIV antibodies, coronavirus antibodies, and FeLV p27 antigen. Queen 1 was inoculated orally with 300 T. gondii tissue cysts and queened 3 healthy kittens 17 days later. Queens 2 and 3 were inoculated orally with 1000 T. gondii tissue cysts and queened 5 kittens each, 1 and 8 days later, respectively. Only 1 kitten from Queen 3 survived.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: All 3 queens seroconverted but ocular lesions were not detected. Ocular lesions developed in 6 of 9 surviving kittens. Bilateral, multifocal, progressive lesions of the tapetal choroid and retina developed in 1 kitten from Queen 1, 66 days after birth. In 2 kittens from Queen 2, anterior uveitis, characterized by mild flare, cells, and small keratic precipitates, was detected at 50 days after birth in 1 kitten and 72 days in the other. The anterior uveitis had resolved by day 56 and 77, respectively. Bilateral, multifocal, lesions of the tapetal choroid and retina were also detected on day 50 and 62, respectively in these kittens. Chorioretinal lesions but not anterior uveitis were detected day 66 in 2 additional kittens from Queen 2 and day 80 in the kitten from Queen 3. At the time of abstract submission, active chorioretinal lesions in the kitten from Queen 1 were present 97 days after initial detection. Chorioretinal lesions in 4 kittens from Queen 2 resolved, leaving mild tapetal color change or areas of hyperreflectivity 14 (1), 50 (2), and 56 (1) days after initial detection; lesions in the Queen 3 kitten are static but have not resolved after 40 days. Trichomonads are rarely seen in the feces of cats with diarrhea. When identified, trichomonads are regarded as dubious pathogens; relegated to simple overgrowth of indiginous fauna. We observed large numbers of trichomonads, resistant to antimicrobial therapy, in feces from cats with uncomplicated large bowel diarrhea.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: Diarrhea with concurrent trichomonas infection was diagnosed in 32 cats during a 20 month period. Signalment, origin, clinicopathologic findings, and prior treatments were recorded. Trichomonads were seen in fresh feces examined in saline at 40X magnification or after culture of feces in Modified Diamonds Me-dia@37ЊC. Fecal samples from 20 healthy indoor cats and 100 feral cats were examined to determine the prevalence of trichomonas in geographically comparable populations.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: Cats with trichomonas ranged in age from 3mos-13yrs with 75% Ͻ1 yr of age at the time of diagnosis. The origin of 30 cats was traced to a multiple-cat environment (cattery or adoption agency). Two cats developed diarrhea after addition of an infected kitten into the home. Cats were native to North Carolina(26), Virginia(3), Connecticut(2), or Tennessee(1). Duration of diarrhea ranged from 2days to 3yrs, was large-bowel consistency, malodorous, and often dribbled from an inflamed anus. Further evaluation of diarrhea included a CBC(4), chemistry profile(3), UA(3), FeLV/FIV test(26), fecal flotation (19), Giardia antigen test (14), Auramine-O stained smear for Cryptosporidium (14), Gram-stained smear for Clostridia(12), colonic mucosal biopsy(2), FIP or Toxo titer(2), and abdominal ultrasound exam(1). Coexisting enteric infection was documented (Isospora(3), Toxascaris, Giardia, or Giardia and Cryptosporidium) in only 6 cats. Colonic mucosal biopsy revealed marked lymphoplasmacytic colitis, typhlitis, and enteritis(1), and mild lymphoplasmacytic colitis(1). Treatments included paromomycin(25), fenbendazole (19), metronidazole (17), furazolidone(15), pyrantel pamoate(15), sulfadimethoxine(15), albendazole(6), trimethoprim sulfadiazine(4), tylosin(3), enrofloxacin(3), amoxicillin(2), clindamycin(2), and erythromycin(2). Resolution of diarrhea correlated with disappearance of trichomonads during treatment of many cats, however organisms and diarrhea after discontinuation of treatment was prevalent. Trichomonads were not recovered from the feces of any feral or indoor cats.

body_text.text: Trichomonas may be a causal agent of diarrhea in cats. Using the described techniques, trichomonads were not part of the indiginous fauna of healthy domestic or feral cats. Feline heartworm (HW) infection is a growing concern for veterinarians in HW endemic areas. The purpose of this study was to determine the prevalence of HW in cats in a HW endemic region and to compare the performance of currently available serologic tests against a necropsy gold standard. 330 adult cats (46% male, 54% female) euthanized at a local animal control facility were examined within 2 hours of death. Blood was collected from the vena cava for serologic testing, and the heart and lungs were dissected for the presence of HW. Serum was assayed for FeLV antigen (ag), FIV antibody (ab), and for HW ag and ab.
body_text.section: CRYPTOSPORIDIUM PARVUM OOCYST SHEDDING AND SERUM ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN EXPERIMENTALLY IN-FECTED CATS. C.A. McReynolds and M.R. Lappin. College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.

body_text.text: Adult HW (n ϭ 1-4) were identified in 19 (6%) cats. HW infection was not correlated with FeLV or FIV, but male cats were slightly over represented. Ag tests detected 68-79% of HW and were highly specific. Four of six cats with false-negative ag results on 1 or more tests had only a single male worm. Ab tests detected 32-89% of HW. False positives were more common (10-23%) with ab than ag tests. Negative ab tests occurred in some ag-positive cats with HW identified at necropsy.

body_text.text: Feline HW in this region is as common as FeLV (6%) The gastrointestinal tract is the most common anatomic location of lymphoma in cats, with most descriptions of gastrointestinal lymphoma being poorly differentiated (lymphoblastic or immunoblastic). The purpose of this study is to describe the clinical features of cats with well differentiated lymphocytic gastrointestinal lymphoma, and to determine response to therapy and prognostic factors. Sixty-five cats with gastrointestinal lymphoma were evaluated at the Veterinary Specialty Hospital of San Diego (VSHSD) between 1988 and 1996. Of these, 39 cats were determined to have well differentiated lymphocytic lymphoma. Cats with a histologic diagnosis with biopsy obtained endoscopically (97%) or surgically (3%) were considered for study. All biopsies were reviewed by a single pathologist (JLC). The most common clinical signs were vomiting (87%), weight loss (79%), anorexia (53%), diarrhea (53%), and lethargy (47%). Nine percent had neither vomiting nor diarrhea. An abdominal mass was palpated in 26% of cats while 32% had thickened gastrointestinal loops. Twenty-six cats were treated, 23 of whom were given prednisone and chlorambucil. Fourteen (61%) achieved complete remission (CR). The disease-free interval (DFI) of those who achieved CR ranged from 5.75 to 24 months (median 15.5 months, 6 cats still in CR). The overall survival ranged from 0.33 to 25 months (median 12 months), and the median survival of those who achieved CR was 17.5 months. There was no significant difference in DFI or survival due to age, sex, breed, palpable abdominal mass, retroviral status, hypoalbuminemia, or localization of tumor. In conclusion, cats with well differentiated lymphocytic gastrointestinal lymphoma treated with a relatively simple protocol have a higher CR rate and overall survival times than in cats previously reported with poorly differentiated gastrointestinal lymphoma treated with more complex protocols. Endoscopic biopsy was highly useful for obtaining a diagnosis, and may result in early detection of gastrointestinal lymphoma in cats. Due to the limited accessibility of the nervous system, the treatment of brain tumors via gene therapy offers unique possibilities. Previous studies using stereotactic injections of viral vectors only induced focal transduction. Since viral particle size permits blood brain barrier passage, we hypothesized that delivery of an adenoviral vector by selective arterial catherization would permit significant tumor transduction in vivo with minimal side effects to the patient.

body_text.text: Six dogs with the diagnosis of intracranial neoplasm were entered in this study in accordance with the Biosafety and Research Animal Resources Center guidelines. Fluoroscopy guided carotid catheterization through the right femoral artery was performed under anesthesia, and 20 ul of 5x 10 10 adenovirus (human adenovirus type 5 with an E1 deletion) carrying the ␤-galactosidase gene (LacZ marker) was injected selectively at the tumor level. After five days of isolation, surgery was performed and tumor, brain and skin samples were obtained to assess the extent of transduction using X-gal staining. Complete blood count and serum chemistries were collected prior to injection and surgery, and two weeks post surgery. Euthanasia was performed in two patients due to post-operative complications. Tissue transduction was assessed postmortem in both cases.

The tumors were histopathologically indentified as meningioma (5) and choroid plexus carcinoma (1) and were located in the forebrain (3), midbrain (1) and caudal fossa (2). Selective transduction of the neoplasms was identified in four of six dogs. In one dog, both the neoplasm and brain tissue were transduced, and no transduction was noted in the neoplasm of another dog. One dog underwent a second craniotomy four months after diagnosis to remove the remaining neoplasm. Expression of the X-gal staining was still present in the neoplasm only.

We have demonstrated that fluoroscopy guided selective intra-arterial injection of adenoviral vectors for gene therapy of spontaneous occurring canine intracranial neoplasms is possible, effective, safe, and more diffuse and extensive than that previously documented with stereotactic viral vector delivery. We are now in an excellent position to assess the effect of specific genes in vivo on canine neoplasms, and begin therapeutic clinical trials for dogs with brain cancer. Cutaneous lymphoma comprises 3 to 8% of all lymphoma reported in dogs and is generally classified as epitheliotropic (usually T-cell) or nonepitheliotropic (usually B-cell). Historically, the treatment of cutaneous lymphoma has been unrewarding. Few reports of long term remissions or survival times exist. The optimal chemotherapeutic protocol is unknown.

Recently, the alkylating agent, lomustine (CCNU), was reported to be a useful rescue agent in dogs with refractory multicentric lymphoma. The lipophilic nature of the drug and ease of administration make it an attractive agent for the treatment of cutaneous lymphoma. The purpose of this pilot study was to determine if lomustine is useful in the treatment of cutaneous lymphoma in dogs.
body_text.section: PILOT STUDY ON THE USE OF LOMUSTINE (CCNU) FOR

body_text.text: Seven dogs with cutaneous lymphoma (5 epitheliotropic and 2 nonepitheliotropic) were evaluated. All dogs were diagnosed by histologic evaluation of biopsies. Two dogs had all lesions surgically excised prior to treatment. Five dogs had nonresectable disease. All dogs received lomustine at a dose of 50 mg/ m 2 PO q 21 days until relapse. Complete remissions were achieved in all dogs and ranged from 2 to 15 months. The 2 dogs whose lesions were surgically excised prior to chemotherapy had the longest remissions (7 and 15 months). The two dogs with nonepitheliotropic lymphoma had the shortest remissions (2 and 3 months). Two dogs died of unrelated disease while still in complete remission.

body_text.text: Lomustine appears to have activity against cutaneous lymphoma, especially the epitheliotropic form. Alterations in cisplatin accumulation in cells resulting in resistance is multifactorial. A decrease in drug influx, an increase drug efflux, or modifications in ion transport mechanisms have been observed in cisplatin resistant cell lines by others. The objective of research was to investigate the HCO 3 Ϫ /Cl Ϫ exchange inhibitor SITS (4-acetamido-4Ј; isothiocyanostilbene-2,2Ј-disulfonic acid). Our hypothesis to be tested was that a high intracellular chloride ion concentration (via SITS exposure) lowers the concentration of the cytotoxic aquated cisplatin species resulting in cisplatin resistance. Using a canine osteosarcoma cell line established in our laboratory, we exposed cells to cisplatin with or without concomitant exposure to SITS. Cell survival was determined using the Cell Titer 96 AQ ueous One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay. In COS31 cisplatin sensitive cells cultured in the presence of SITS in chloride-containing medium, sensitivity to cisplatin significantly decreased after only one exposure to cisplatin. At fixed concentrations of cisplatin, sensitivity to cisplatin significantly decreased as the concentration of SITS exposure increased. Cisplatin undergoes activation to its toxic form when the chloride ligands are replaced by water, thereby forming a charged electrophile, which reacts with DNA and other nucleophilic sites. It has been proposed that a high extracellular chloride concentration favors the native form of cisplatin and a low chloride concentration within the cell shifts the equilibrium to the aquated cytotoxic form of cisplatin. The data presented indicates that inhibiting HCO 3 -/Clexchange with SITS leads to a dose-dependent form of cisplatin resistance. Our laboratory findings would suggest that the level of one ion or inhibiting an ion transport system could lead to a cascade of effects within the cell, which may ultimately lead to drug resistance.

body_text.text: TREATMENT FOR RELAPSING CANINE LYMPHOMA. Hahn KA, Nolan ML. University of Tennessee-Knoxville. L-asparaginase is an enzyme that inhibits protein synthesis by the depletion of sources of L-asparagine, which is necessary for transformed lymphoid cells to proliferate. Canine lymphoma is a predominantly B-cell tumor with widespread disease; without treatment, dogs with lymphoma usually survive 1-2 months. Previously untreated dogs with lymphoma will respond to L-asparaginase therapy. A prospective study evaluated the use of L-asparaginase as single agent therapy in dogs with lymphoma that relapsed following single agent Adriamycin chemotherapy (30 mg/m 2 , five 3 week cycles). Dogs were given 10,000 IU/m 2 (5,000 IU/ml) as an intramuscular injection 15 minutes following premedication (Benadryl, 1 mg/kg) once every 4 weeks. Dogs achieving either a partial response (PR) or complete response (CR) following treatment initiation were continued on L-asparaginase every 4 weeks thereafter until relapse. Eighteen dogs were treated. Eleven dogs (61.1%) achieved a complete remission (CR) with a median time to relapse of 24 weeks, four dogs (22.2%) achieved a partial remission (PR) with a median time to progressive disease (PD) of 6 weeks, and three dogs (16.7%) did not respond (NR) to therapy. The asparaginase was well tolerated and no toxicoses were observed (allergic reactions, urticarial reactions). Others have reported that more than 90% of dogs with previously untreated lymphoma achieve a CR or PR with L-asparaginase therapy with a median time to relapse of 30 weeks. In our study, 83.3% achieved a CR or PR using Lasparaginase therapy with an overall median time to relapse of 21 weeks. We concluded that single agent L-asparaginase should be considered in the treatment of dogs with relapsing lymphoma. The major cause of treatment failure in cancer patients is tumour invasion and metastasis. The inability of local therapy to eradicate metastatic cancer presents a challenge in the therapy of residual or metastatic disease. Laser immunotherapy is a novel cancer treatment utilizing local selective chromophore-enhanced photothermal laser treatment to reduce tumour burden and expose tumour antigens while the immunoadjuvant concomitantly stimulates a systemic anti-tumour immune response against the remaining cells of the tumour. Laser immunotherapy employs: (1) an infrared laser (805 nm); (2) a photosensitizer (indocyanine green [ICG]); and (3) an immunoadjuvant (glycated chitosan gel [GCG] ). The purpose of this study was to investigate immunotherapy for the treatment of metastatic cancer (e.g. feline vaccinosarcoma) utilizing the Dunning R3327-MatLu rat prostatic cancer model. Twenty-five (3 groups) Copenhagen rats were injected subcutaneously in the left flank with 10 6 MatLu cells. Laser immunotherapy was performed on day 13 (Group I ϭ early) or on day 33 (Group II ϭlate) with intratumour injection (200 L) of the photosensitizer (0.25% ICG) and immunoadjuvant (1% GCG) solution followed by noninvasive laser irradiation (10 minutes at 2W). Group III was an untreated control. Rats were sacrificed and necropsied on day 42.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF SINGLE AGENT L-ASPARAGINASE AS

body_text.text: Rats treated with laser immunotherapy early (Group I) had significantly fewer mean (ϮSE) metastases (2.13 Ϯ 1.85) than the controls (7.0 Ϯ 3.15) (pϽ0.05). Similarly, Group I had significantly less mean primary tumour volume (124.9 Ϯ 33.7 mm 3 ) than the controls (274.5 Ϯ 38.8 mm 3 ) (pϽ0.05). Rats treated later (Group II) did not have significantly fewer metastases (3.29 Ϯ 1.52) or less primary tumour volume (245.8 Ϯ 30.0 mm 3 ) than controls (pϾ0.28).

body_text.text: This study demonstrated the efficacy of laser immunotherapy as an adjunctive therapy for the control of metastatic cancer if given early. In future, further studies are needed to elucidate the mechanism of action of laser immunotherapy. The precise mechanisms of sarcoma formation at sites of previous injections in cats are not known. Carcinogenesis is a multistage process that is associated with gain-of-function or loss-of function of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes (TSGs). Expression of the TSG p53 and the oncogenes mdm-2 and c-kit are altered commonly in soft-tissue sarcomas in human beings.
body_text.section: EFFICACY OF SINGLE AGENT L-ASPARAGINASE AS

body_text.text: In order to define possible mechanisms of tumorigenesis at injection sites, we evaluated the expression of c-kit, p53, and mdm-2 by immunohistochemical methods in 102 archived injection-site sarcomas. We also compared the expression of these genes between tumors with different histologic characteristics.
body_text.section: EXPRESSION OF TUMOR SUPPRESSOR GENES AND ON

body_text.text: Most of the tumors, independent of histologic type, had positive staining for either c-KIT (74%) or P53 (72%). Fifty-one percent of the tumors had positive staining for both. Nearly half (47%) of the tumors had positive staining for MDM-2. Tumors with positive staining for both mdm-2 and p53 (36%) had more anaplastic features than the other tumors. The high prevalence of positive staining for P53 and c-KIT suggest that expression of these genes may be involved in development of sarcomas at injection sites. (17), anorexia (14), weight loss (10), dyspnea (8), vomiting (6) and coughing (3). Eight cats were receiving oral prednisone at the time of admission. Physical exam findings included depression (21), dyspnea (16), dehydration (13), hypothermia (8), and icterus (5). Common clinicopathologic abnormalities included anemia (58%), neutrophilia (56%), thrombocytopenia (47%), hyponatremia (78%), hypocalcemia (73%), hypoalbuminemia (54%), elevated BUN (54%), elevated bilirubin (52%), hypokalemia (48%), hyperglycemia (48%), elevated ALT (32%) and ALP (20%), acidosis (17%), and elevated creatinine (17%). In 6 cats, PT and PTT were measured and were elevated in 2 and 6 cats, respectively. Antithrombin III was low in the 1 cat in which it was measured. Thoracic radiographs were available for review in 14 cats and common findings included pleural effusion (8), uneven vascular diameter between lung lobes (7), noncircumscribed pulmonary consolidations (6), enlargement and blunting of caudal pulmonary arteries (5), oligemia in the periphery of 1 or more lung lobes (4), atelectasis (3), and single well-demarcated thoracic masses (3). One cat had a normal thoracic radiograph. PTE was suspected antemortem in only 4 cats. Histologic lesions were classified according to the location of the thrombus (venous, 8; capillary, 9; arterial, 20) ; distribution (focal, 6; multifocal, 14; diffuse, 9); and chronicity (peracute, 1; acute, 13; subacute, 7; chronic, 8). Underlying conditions identified at necropsy included cardiac disease (18), neoplasia (10), DIC (5), protein-losing enteropathy (4), protein-losing nephropathy (4) , IMHA (2), sepsis (2), and trauma (1). Two cats had long term (Ͼ30 days) dialysis catheters placed and in both, blood clots were visualized antemortem at the tip of the catheter or in the right atrium. Diseases that may have predisposed cats to developing PTE were identified in 14 cats (47%). PTE was the direct cause of death in 4 cats, a contributor to death in 17 cats, and an incidental finding in 8 cats. The cysteinyl leukotrienes (LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4) are inflammatory mediators derived from the lipoxygenation of arachidonic acid. LTC4 and LTD4 within the lung can increase mucous secretion, increase vascular permeability, impair mucociliary clearance, and cause bronchoconstriction. Leukotrienes have been suggested to be important mediators in many forms of bronchial asthma in people. Agents that inhibit lipoxygenase or block the leukotriene receptors have been recently added to the therapeutic options available for human asthmatics. LTE4 is the stable end product of both LTC4 and LTD4 metabolism. LTE4 is excreted in the urine and urine levels may be used as an indicator of lipoxygenase activity in the patient. The potential ex vivo generation of mediators in urine samples from urinary tract disease patients remains a poorly defined area. Studies in people have revealed substantially elevated urinary LTE4 levels in many types of asthmatic patients. A report of urinary LTE4 levels in a feline model has noted a 2-3 fold increase in urinary LTE4 following the induction of allergic bronchitis.
body_text.section: EXPRESSION OF TUMOR SUPPRESSOR GENES AND ON

body_text.text: The purpose of this pilot study was to obtain preliminary data investigating whether urinary LTE4 levels are elevated in feline patients with naturally-occurring bronchitis of presumed allergic etiology (''feline asthma'') when compared to a control population of normal cats and a separate population of cats with lower urinary tract disease (LUTD). Urine samples were collected via cystocentesis from cats with the clinical diagnosis of bronchitis (nϭ16), LUTD in the form of urinary tract infection or cystic calculi (nϭ6), and normal cats (nϭ4). Urinary LTE4 levels (pg/ml) were determined by use of a commercially available ELISA assay (Oxford Biomedical Research, Inc., Oxford, MI). Urinary LTE4 levels are referenced to urine creatinine concentration (mg/ml) measured using a modified kinetic Jaffe method. Mean urinary LTE4/creatinine (pg/mg) ratios (meanϮSD) for the bronchitic, normal, and LUTD-afflicted populations were 31.5 Ϯ 53.9, 33.8 Ϯ 13.5, and 57.7 Ϯ 98.9 respectively. No statistically significant difference (pϽ0.05) between the means was present. Our results suggest that the pathophysiology of feline allergic bronchitis may differ from human asthma and experimentally-induced feline eosinophilic lower airway disease in the degree of lipoxygenase activity contributing to clinical signs. Further study appears warranted before anti-leukotriene therapies could be recommended for treatment of this condition in cats.
body_text.section: URINARY LEUKOTRIENE E4 LEVELS IN CATS WITH AL

body_text.text: WITH ASTHMA. EA Rozanski, and AM Hoffman, Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine, North Grafton MA.
body_text.section: LUNG FUNCTION AND INHALED ALBUTEROL IN CATS

body_text.text: Lower airway diseases, such as asthma, are a common problem in cats. Clinical signs of asthma include coughing, wheezing and respiratory distress. These signs are believed to represent bronchoconstriction. If so, clinical signs should resolve following treatment with a beta-2 agonist. Barometeric whole-body plethysmography (BWBP) detects experimental bronchoconstriction in cats. The purposes of this study were to evaluate BWBP and to determine the effect of therapy with aerosol albuterol, in cats with naturally occurring asthma.
body_text.section: LUNG FUNCTION AND INHALED ALBUTEROL IN CATS

body_text.text: Eight cats with asthma were evaluated using BWBP. Pulmonary mechanics analyzer software (XA Biosystem, Buxco Electronics) was used to analyze the box pressure signals which were dynamically calibrated to the derivative of a known volume (pseudoflow signal). The following variables were computed: Peak inspiratory pseudo-flow (PIF), peak expiratory pseudo-flow (PEF), tidal volume (TV), end-inspiratory pause (EIP), end-expiratory pause (EEP), frequency (f), expiratory time (Te), inspiratory time (Ti), relaxation time (RT, time for box pressure to decay to 30% of total box pressure during expiration), Pause ([Te/Rt] Ϫ1), and enhanced pause (PENH-(Te/[0.3 xRT]-1 x PEF/[PIF x0.67]). Baseline measurements were made from all cats. Aerosol albuterol was then administered to 5 cats from a pressurized-metered dose inhaler, specially designed for cats, and the cats re-tested. Results from asthmatic cats were compared with a group of normal healthy cats and the effects of albuterol were assessed (with ␣ set at 0.05).
body_text.section: LUNG FUNCTION AND INHALED ALBUTEROL IN CATS

body_text.text: No differences between groups were detected in f, TV, PEF, PIF, EIP, Te or Ti. However, the values for EEP, Pause, PENH were significantly higher and the RT lower in the asthmatic cats. Therapy with albuterol resulted in significant improvement in Pause and PENH values. In conclusion, BWBP derived variables effectively characterized lower airway obstruction and its immediate reversal by treatment with a beta-2 agonist. Using BWBP, a rapid diagnosis of lower airway obstruction and its subsequent reversal may be made in cats with asthma. To our knowledge, mucociliary clearance rate (MCCR) has not been evaluated in the cat. The goal of this study was to develop a protocol for measuring MCCR cats, to determine MCCR in normal anesthetized cats and to determine the effect of theophylline on MCCR in cats.
body_text.section: LUNG FUNCTION AND INHALED ALBUTEROL IN CATS

body_text.text: Six normal adult cats were anesthetized with propofol and a droplet of the radionuclide 99m Technetium-macro aggregated albumin was placed endoscopically at the carina. Dynamic acquisition scintigraphic scanning was performed with the larynx as the end point. MCCR was calculated by dividing the distance the droplet travelled by the frame rate. Each cat was scanned six times; three times following placebo and three times following the administration of 25 mg/ kg per os of sustained release theophylline (Slo-bid). Serum theophylline levels were measured during scanning to assure therapeutic levels.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: MCCR in normal adult cats anesthetized with propofol was 2.22 Ϯ 0.28 cm/ min. MCCR in cats receiving theophylline was 2.18 Ϯ 0.35 cm/min. Theophylline administration did not significantly affect the MCCR.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: Theophylline has been demonstrated to increase MCCR in humans, horses, dogs and rats. This study determined MCCR in normal anesthetized cats and found that it was not influenced by the administration of theophylline. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) in dogs is generally performed through a bronchoscope, limiting accessibility to clinicians with specialized equipment. To increase availability of this procedure, a non-bronchoscopic technique was developed. A 122 cm, 16 FR Levin type polyvinyl stomach tube (Sherwood Medical Co., St. Louis, MO) was modified using sterile technique. The distal fenestrations were cut off and the end tapered. The proximal end was shortened by 40-55 cm. Nine dogs (9-26kg) were anesthetized by injection, placed in dorsal recumbency, and intubated. The BAL tube was passed through the tracheal tube into the airways until resistance was felt, then slightly retracted, rotated, and readvanced to insure a snug fit. Radiographs showed the tube to be in the right (7/ 9) or left (2/9) caudal lobe. A 25 ml bolus of saline was infused by syringe, followed by 5 ml of air. Suction was applied immediately using the same syringe. This procedure was repeated 4 times for a total volume of 125 ml. Fluid retrieved from boluses 2&3 and 4&5 were combined for analysis. Oxygen was provided for 10 min following BAL. Oxygen saturation was measured by pulse oximetry 1,3,5,10,15, and 20 min post-BAL. Thoracic radiographs were taken 48 hr post-BAL.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: Recovered fluid was consistent with BAL fluid obtained bronchoscopically. The mean recovery volume for all boluses combined was 84 ml(67%). Foam was visible in 42/45 specimens. Mean white cell counts were Ͼ300/l. Mean macrophage counts from boluses 1, 2&3, and 4&5 were 71%, 85%, and 88%, respectively.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: Oxygen saturation was Ն95% in 50/54 measurements. No clinical or radiographic signs of complications occurred.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: This technique is an effective, simple, inexpensive, and safe method for nonbronchoscopic BAL in dogs.
body_text.section: EFFECT OF THEOPHYLLINE ON MUCOCILIARY CLEAR

body_text.text: Schermerhorn, J. Pembleton-Corbett, B. Kornreich. NYSCVM, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.
body_text.section: PULMONARY THROMBOEMBOLISM IN CATS: 17 CASES. T.

body_text.text: All cats with pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) confirmed by necropsy over a 23 year period from 1975 to 1998 were included in this retrospective study. Affected cats were identified by a computer search of the NYSCVM database, using the hospital's diagnostic codes for the following conditions: pulmonary thromboembolism, lung infarction due to thrombosis, thrombosis of the pulmonary artery, and lung thrombosis. Twenty-eight cases were identified using these search parameters; of these, 17 cases were suitable for inclusion in the study. No sex predilection for was detected in affected cats (47% male vs. 53% female). The median age at the time of death was 11 years (range 10 months to 18 years; nϭ15). However, the age distribution was bimodal (peaks centered at 0-2 and 10-12 years of age). The median body weight was 3.8 kg. (range 2.3 to 5.2 kg.; nϭ15). PTE occurred in association with another disorder in most cats (95%). In ϳ75% of cases, PTE was associated with a common feline disorder: neoplasm (nϭ6), pancreatitis (nϭ2), anemia (nϭ2), cardiac disease (nϭ1), FIP (nϭ1), and hepatic lipidosis (nϭ1). Other disorders associated with PTE included: glomerular nephritis, pneumonia, and encephalitis. Respiratory distress that immediately preceded death was recorded in the medical record of 63% of cats with PTE. In cats with primary cardiac or pulmonary disease and in anemic cats, respiratory distress was usually attributed to progression of the known pathology; in the remaining cats that had dyspnea, the onset of respiratory distress was generally attributed to the complications of severe multisystemic illness. However, PTE was not suspected as the cause of dyspnea in any of the cats included in this study. In those cats with confirmed PTE but without significant cardiac or pulmonary disease, the clinical signs of PTE were similar to those reported for other species: an acute onset of tachypnea and dyspnea which fails to improve with oxygen therapy. Thoracic radiographs were normal or had non-specific changes such as prominent interstitial and alveolar markings, pulmonary edema, and vascular changes. We conclude that PTE occurs in the cat but is rare. In this study, PTE was found in association with a variety of common feline disorders and complicated the clinical management and, in some instances, directly caused the death of affected cats. It appears from the findings outlined here that the same criteria used to raise the clinical suspicion for PTE in the dog can also be applied to the cat.
body_text.section: PULMONARY THROMBOEMBOLISM IN CATS: 17 CASES. T.

body_text.text: HYDROGEN TESTING. L. Hansson 1 , J.M. Steiner 2 , D. A. Williams 2, 1 Regional Animal Hospital, Helsingborg, Sweden, 2 Texas A&M University.
body_text.section: REDUCING DILUTION OF BREATH SAMPLES FOR BREATH

body_text.text: Estimation of alveolar hydrogen concentration is important in breath hydrogen testing. Alveolar hydrogen concentration can be estimated by measuring the hydrogen concentration in the expiratory air and estimating the dilution of the alveolar air with room air. This is accomplished by measuring the CO 2 in the expiratory air and comparing it to the presumed alveolar CO 2 concentration of 5%. CO 2 concentrations in canine expired air were 2.29Ϯ0.02 (%, meanϮSD) in one report (Ludlow et al, JVIM, 9: 191, 1995) , but in an initial study of 155 samples from 7 dogs we observed CO 2 concentrations of 0.89Ϯ0.34. This degree of room air contamination limits the ability to correctly calculate alveolar hydrogen concentration. The objective of this study was to evaluate changes in the collection method that might reduce the contamination of breath samples with room air.
body_text.section: REDUCING DILUTION OF BREATH SAMPLES FOR BREATH

body_text.text: Breath samples from 10 healthy mix-breed experimental dogs were collected using both a snug-fitting and a loose-fitting standard anesthetic induction mask attached to a reservoir bag via a two-way non-rebreathing valve, and a modified, ''reduced dead space'' (RDS) snug-fitting system with a shorter valve adapter and foam lining the inner walls of the anesthetic mask. Samples from the reservoir bag were transferred by syringes and analyzed directly or transferred to vacuum transport tubes via a plastic syringe (S), via a three-way tube fill adapter with high (H) or medium (M) pressure manual expression, or via a three-way tube fill adapter with one opening plugged (P). H 2 and CO 2 were analyzed within three hours of sampling by electrochemical and thermal conductivity, respectively. Additional samples were saved in transport tubes at room temperature for analysis at 4 and 19 days post sampling.
body_text.section: REDUCING DILUTION OF BREATH SAMPLES FOR BREATH

body_text.text: Breath CO 2 concentration was significantly greater (pϭ0.032; nϭ7) with the snug fitting mask (2.01Ϯ0.76) compared to the loose fitting mask (1.19Ϯ0.76). Breath CO 2 concentration was also significantly greater (pϭ0.0034; nϭ10) with the RDS system (2.68Ϯ0.92) compared to the regular snug-fitting collection system. There was a significant difference (pϭ0.0007; nϭ9) of % CO 2 loss between the four different transfer methods (mean % CO 2 lossϮSD: 17.9Ϯ0.099 (S), 19.4Ϯ0.15 (H), 34.8Ϯ0.29 (M) and 5.3Ϯ0.063 (P)). There was no significant change (pϭ0.177 and pϭ0.074, respectively) of % CO 2 and H 2 concentrations after storage of breath samples in transport tubes for 4 or 19 days.
body_text.section: REDUCING DILUTION OF BREATH SAMPLES FOR BREATH

body_text.text: We conclude that reducing dead space in the collection system reduces the dilution of alveolar gases. Transfer to a transport tube via a three-way tube fill adapter with one opening plugged resulted in minimal loss of CO 2 , and both CO 2 and H 2 were stable in transport tubes for at least 19 days. This study evaluated the effect of coadministration of d-␣-tocopheryl polyethylene glycol-1000 succinate (TPGS), a water-soluble vitamin E, on the absorption kinetics of orally administered cyclosporin A (CsA, Sandimmune) in healthy dogs.
body_text.section: REDUCING DILUTION OF BREATH SAMPLES FOR BREATH

body_text.text: Four healthy, adult dogs were used in a randomized crossover study design. Each dog was given a single oral dose of CsA at 10 mg/kg: two dogs were given CsA alone and two dogs were given CsA thoroughly mixed with 10 IU/ kg TPGS. Blood samples were drawn via jugular catheter at 0, ½, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, and 24 hours post-administration. After a seven-day washout period, the procedure was repeated with each group receiving the alternate treatment. Whole blood CsA levels were determined by high-pressure liquid chromatography by an independent laboratory.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: Data were compiled into CsA alone and CsA/TPGS groups, and CsA concentration versus time graphs were created for each group. The areas under the concentration versus time curves (AUC), absorption rates (Kabs), half-lives (t½), maximum concentrations (Cmax) and times to maximum concentration (Tmax) were calculated. Group means were analyzed with paired t-tests. For the CsA/ TPGS group, AUC and Cmax means were significantly greater than CsA group means. No significant difference was found between group means for Kabs, t½, or Tmax. Significance was set at p Յ 0.05. Values are shown below as group mean Ϯ standard deviation.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: TPGS easily forms micelles at low concentrations and these micelles can enhance absorption of lipophilic substances such as CsA. In addition, TPGS has been shown to inhibit p-glycoprotein-mediated countertransport of substances from the blood into the intestinal lumen. The increased CsA bioavailability shown with TPGS coadministration is likely due to both these mechanisms. TPGS does not interfere with cytochrome P450, as previously used ''CsA sparing'' agents do, and has no reported adverse systemic effects. Coadministration of TPGS should safely enable significant CsA dose reduction. Resultant cost savings may make CsA therapy feasible for greater numbers of veterinary clients. The influence of food composition on cat urinary pH has been extensively studied whereas the relationship between urinary pH and meal frequency is poorly documented. The purpose of this study was to compare the effect of meal pattern and nature of food (dry vs. canned) on cat urinary pH.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: Eight spayed adult cats were successively adapted to 2 meal patterns (all day long (24h) or 1 hour meal (1h)), using 3 commercial maintenance dry cat foods (D) and two canned foods (C) for 2 weeks. The amounts of food offered were 90 g/day for the dry foods and 350 g/day for the canned food. After adaptation, urine samples were obtained by cystocenthesis just before (T0) and 3, 6 and 9 hours following renewal of the food. Cystocenthesis were performed twice on different days on each animal and for all time points. Urine pH was determined with an electrode on fresh urine sample. Significant (pϽ0.05) differences between feeding patterns, nature of foods and time points were assessed by repeated measure ANOVA.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: Results are summarized in the figure Figure: Urinary pH over time as a function of feeding pattern and food (dry (D: mean of 3 foods) versus canned (C: mean of 2 foods))(meanϮsem ; values at each time point with different superscript differ at pϭ0.05).
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: The present study shows that the nature of food (dry vs canned) as well as the feeding pattern influence post prandial urinary pH. Only all day long feeding of dry food minimizes the rise in urinary pH following renewal of the food.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF d-␣-TOCOPHERYL POLYETHYLENE GLY-

body_text.text: WEIGHT AND BODY COMPOSITION FOLLOWING GONAD-ECTOMY IN CATS. 1 P. Nguyen, 1 H. Dumon, 1 L. Martin, 2 V. Biourge, 2 R. Sergheraert. 1 Nantes National Veterinary School (Nantes, France) and 2 Royal Canin Research Center (Vannes, France). The gonadectomy may predispose to obesity by removal of hormones that stimulate behavior resulting in more physical activity or act as satiety factors. A high energy density level in the food has also been described as a factor predisposing to obesity in humans and laboratory animals. This study was conducted to compare the effects of dietary fat and energy density of the diet on body weight (BW) and body composition changes following gonadectomy in cats compared to intact controls.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: Twelve males and 12 females, 8-mo. old, short-hair cats were purchased from an inbred SPF colony and housed in 8 group cages of 3 animals of the same sex and initial BW. At 9 mo. of age, 2 groups of females (GF) and 2 groups of males (GM) were neutered whereas the 2 other groups of females were ligatured (EF) and the remaining 2 groups of males were left intact (EM). Half of the cats were fed ad libitum a low fat (LF), low energy (10.3 % fat, 3500 kcal ME /kg) complete balanced extruded diet and the other half a high fat (HF), high energy food (20.9 % fat, 4300 kcal ME/kg) so that to have 8 treatment groups based on sex (M/F), sexual status (neutered/intact) and diets (LF/HF). The ingredients used and the composition were similar between the two diets except for the starch, fat and dietary fiber contents.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: Food consumption for each group was measured daily. Individual BW and body condition scores were recorded weekly. After 26 week of feeding, body fat was determined after a single injection of labelled water (H 2 18 O).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: All cats gained BW, but males more than females, neutered animals more than intact ones, and cats fed the HF diet more than those consuming the LF one. Both neutering and fat led to higher energy intake, body weight gain, body condition score and body fat content. Reverse cholesterol transport (RCT) concerns cholesterol movements from peripheral cells via plasma towards the liver, the only organ in which elimination of cholesterol from the body is possible, by transformation into biliary acids. RCT is initiated by efflux of unesterified cholesterol from cells into HDL (containing apolipoprotein A-I) following by esterification in these lipoproteins (LP). Movements towards the liver involve two possible mechanisms: direct uptake of HDL (or HDL cholesteryl esters) and/or cholesteryl esters, or exchanges with VLDL and LDL (containing apolipoprotein B100) and uptake by the liver of these LP. Relative importance of these 2 are presumably different between species.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: Two men and two dogs received a 14 h perfusion of deuterated leucine (as endogenous marker of apolipoproteins A-I and B100, 10 mmol/kg/h) and of [1-2 13 C] acetate (as endogenous marker of cholesterol, 4 mmol/kg/h). Blood samples were collected every 15 minutes during the first two hours then hourly over 12h for men and 22h for dogs. VLDL, LDL and HDL were isolated by ultracentrifugation. Unesterified cholesterol and cholesteryl ester, apolipoproteins A-I and B100 were isolated in each LP fraction. The samples were analysed for isotopic enrichment using GC/MS for leucine and GC-C-IRMS for cholesterol. Results were analysed by compartmental modelisation using SAAM II program. The analysis required the development of an integrated model taking into account both turnover of apolipoproteins A-I and B100 and turnover of cholesterol in the various LP fractions.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: This protocol allowed us to quantify the different processes involved in RCT (LP secretion, cholesterol esterification and exchanges between LP, lipolysis, LP uptakes). In humans the RCT occures essentially (2/3) through the indirect pathway (via VLDL and LDL) whereas in dogs RCT occures exclusively by the way of direct uptake of both entire HDL (30%) and HDL cholesteryl ester (70%). These differences could explain in part the low prevalence of atherogenic lesions in the canine species compared to man. Our objective was to evaluate low density and very low density lipoprotein (LDLϩVLDL) oxidation in vitro as a measure of resistance to oxidative stress in exercising sled dogs. We hypothesized that antioxidant supplementation would mitigate the effect of exercise-induced oxidative stress, as measured by lag time and Vmax of LDLϩVLDL oxidation. Sixty-two sled dogs were randomly divided into 3 gender-, age-, and ability-matched groups: a sedentary group; an exercise group; and an exercise group supplemented daily for 5 weeks with 400 IU of vitamin E, 5 mg of ␤-carotene, and 20 mg of lutein. Exercise, preceded and followed by 72 h of rest, consisted of dogs running an average of 72.5 km a day for 3 consecutive days. Supplementation was blinded and placebo-controlled.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: Oxidation lag time, a measure of LDLϩVLDL antioxidant status, increased significantly during exercise and after 72 h of rest in the supplemented exercise group (mean Ϯ SE pre-exercise lag time ϭ 16.7 Ϯ2.7 min; day 1ϭ 29 Ϯ2.6; day 3 ϭ 27.8 Ϯ2.3; 72 h post-exercise ϭ 32.6 Ϯ3.6). Oxidation lag time was also prolonged after rest in the non-supplemented exercise group (pre-exercise ϭ 24.2 Ϯ2.7, 72 h post-exercise ϭ 41.8 Ϯ2.4, p Ͻ 0.01), but not during exercise (day 1 ϭ 30.7 Ϯ2.9; day 3 ϭ 28.9 Ϯ2.4). No significant effects of exercise or supplementation were found in the propagation rates (Vmax) of LDLϩVLDL oxidation. Exercise induced significant decreases in concentration of LDLϩVLDL cholesterol fractions in both supplemented and non-supplemented exercise groups. There was therefore no measurable effect of supplementation on plasma LDLϩVLDL concentration.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: These results demonstrate that dietary supplementation of canine endurance athletes with antioxidants delays LDLϩVLDL oxidation during exercise, suggesting that antioxidant administration increases resistance to exercise-induced oxidant stress. Furthermore, exercise followed by 72 h of rest increases LDLϩVLDL resistance to oxidation suggesting an effect of training on antioxidant capacity. In order to evaluate the beneficial effects of vitamin E supplementation in sled dogs participating in long distance races, 8 Alaskan Huskies were randomly supplemented with Vitamin E (E group, 1000 IU alpha-tocopherol/d) or placebo (P group) for 1 month before and during a 10 day race. Plasma antioxidant status (PAS), plasma VIT E, polyunsatured/satured fatty acid ratio (P/S), urinary creatinine and urinary Isoprostanes (IsP), were determined before and after a 10 consecutive day race. All dogs were fed similar high protein, high fat diets.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: In P group, post race values (mean Ϯ standard deviation) of PAS, P/S, VIT E, decreased significantly as compared to pre race values (1.52 Ϯ 0.28 vs 0.91 Ϯ 0.35 mmol/l ; 1.05 Ϯ 0.09 vs 0.98 Ϯ 0.08 ; 29.7 Ϯ 10.1 vs 24.5 Ϯ 13.4 mol/l, respectively). IsP levels increased from 102.9 Ϯ 11.2 to 261.2 Ϯ 37.6 pmol/mmol creatinine.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: In E group, only PAS post race value was significantly reduced from 1.45 Ϯ 0.37 to 1.12 Ϯ 0.31 mmol/l. Plasma VIT E and P/S levels were also reduced, but not significantly: 69.5 Ϯ 13.2 vs 57.8 Ϯ 17.6 mol/l and 1.06 Ϯ 0.11 vs 1.04 Ϯ 0,08. IsP levels increased from 111.2 Ϯ 20.7 to 184.7 Ϯ 26.3 pmol/ mmol creatinine.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: Endurance exercise induces significant changes in antioxydant status and lipid peroxidation markers which appear partly attenuated with vitamin E supplementation.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF DIETARY FAT AND ENERGY ON BODY

body_text.text: TESTING, SERUM TOTAL MAGNESIUM AND IONIZED MAGNESIUM CONCENTRATIONS IN HEALTHY ADULT BEAGLES FED 0.01% AND 0.1%Mg DIETS HS Allen*, LJ Barton*, A Guzik † , C Kirk ‡ , K Wedekind ‡ , and PR Fox*. *The Animal Medical Center, † Louisiana State Univ. ‡ Hill's Science and Technology Center.

We evaluated parenteral magnesium tolerance testing (PMTT), serum ionized magnesium (iMg), and total serum Mg (TMg) in 10 healthy adult beagles (4F, 6M) fed a Mg depleted diet (0.01% Mg) for 28 days, followed by a Mg repleted diet (0.1% Mg) for 14 days. PMTT (0.2mEq/kg Mg infused IV over 4 hours) was performed at three different intervals: at the end of depletion (day 28), at the end of repletion (day 42), and after a 48 hour fast following the repletion diet (day 44). Serum TMg and iMg were determined on days 0 (baseline), 7, 14, 21, 28 during the depletion trial. The effects of diets supplemented with saturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids on canine neutrophil membrane fluidity and phagocytosis was investigated. Forty adult dogs were divided into 4 groups (nϭ10) and a low fat basal diet was supplemented with either safflower oil (SFO), beef tallow (BT), linseed oil (LSO), or Menhaden fish oil (MHO) for 28 days at a dosage of 18 g oil per 100 g basal diet. The four diets had P/S ratios of 0.4, 0.98, 4.9, and 5.3 for BT, MHO, SFO and LSO respectively. The % Kcals from n-3 fatty acids was 0.3, 0.3, 8.9, and 19.6 for SFO, BT, MHO, and LSO respectively. Neutrophils were assayed for membrane fluidity and phagocytosis. Membrane fluidity was assessed using fluorescence polarization and calculated anisotropy. Phagocytosis was determined using flow cytometry and quantified as the percent cells that ingested 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, or Ͼ 4 fluorescent microspheres.

Statistical analyses revealed that membrane fluidity and phagocytosis is linearly correlated. The two n-3 treatment groups had significantly greater membrane fluidity compared to the SFO and BT groups and the SFO had increased membrane fluidity compared to the BT group. Analysis of the phagocytosis data revealed that there was no significant difference between the groups in the number of cells that ingested 1 or 2 beads. However, the LSO and MHO groups had significantly greater uptake of 3, 4, and Ͼ 4 beads. Strikingly, the MHO and LSO groups also had a significantly greater number of cells that participated in phagocytosis compared to the SFO and BT groups.

Diets containing 18 and 20 carbon n-3 fatty acids results in incorporation of 20 and 22 carbon n-3 fatty acids into the membrane resulting in an increase in fluidity. However, it required 2 X the amount of n-3 fatty acids in the LSO group to produce a similar response in membrane fluidity and phagocytosis as observed in the MHO treatment group. Diets containing 20 carbon n-3 fatty acids increase membrane fluidity even at a P/S ratio of 1.0. It is not the dietary P/S ratio or total PUFA, but rather the contribution of long chain n-3 fatty acids, which increases membrane fluidity and improve phagocytosis. It remains unclear what effect diets comprised of different n-3 sources (18 vs. 20 carbons) with the same n-6 /n-3 ratio have on neutrophil membrane composition and function. Therefore, we investigated the effects of diets containing either 18 or 20 carbon n-3 fatty acids on canine neutrophil superoxide and leukotriene (LTB) production and fatty acid composition. Forty adult dogs were divided into 4 groups (nϭ10) and a low fat basal diet was supplemented with either safflower oil (SFO), beef tallow (BT), linseed oil (LSO), or Menhaden fish oil (MHO) for 28 days at a dosage of 18 g oil per 100 g basal diet. Dietary fat provided 40.8 % of Kcals and the n-6/n-3 ratios of the diets were 101, 9.7, 0.38, and 0.34 for the SFO, BT, LSO and MHO groups respectively. Neutrophils were isolated from peripheral blood, stimulated and assayed for superoxide and LTB production. LTB 4 and LTB 5 were separated by HPLC and quantified by ELISA. Superoxide anion production was quantified and fatty acid analysis of neutrophil membranes was performed using GLC.

Statistical analyses (p Ͻ 0.05) revealed that MHO group had significantly less LTB 4 than the other three groups. The MHO group also had significantly greater LTB 5 than the other three groups. The LSO group also had significantly greater LTB 5 production than the SFO and BT groups. The LSO and MHO groups had significantly lower superoxide production compared to the SFO and BT groups. Fatty acid analysis revealed that the MHO group had significantly greater incorporation of long chain n-3 fatty acids (20:5, 22:5, and 22:6) into the neutrophil membrane. The LSO group also had significant, but to a lesser degree, incorporation of 20:5 and 22:5, but no 22:6 was observed. We conclude that 18 and 20 carbon n-3 fatty acid are differentially incorporated into the cell membrane at the same n-6/n-3 ratio, resulting in a differential reduction of pro-inflammatory mediators. Thus, it is the type (18 vs. 20 carbon) and amount of n-3 fatty acids and not simply the n-6/n-3 ratio that differentially modifies membrane composition and cellular function. Serum ferritin (an iron storage protein) levels are related to total body iron stores in both humans and dogs. Serum ferritin, in dogs, is usually assayed by species specific antibody-driven reactions. These assays are difficult to develop and not readily available. In this report we evaluate the measurement of serum ferritin, using a commercially available kit, in normal dogs and in dogs with microcytic, non-regenerative anemia.

Fifty healthy adult dogs of various breeds and both sexes, were sampled to determine the appropriate reference interval for canine serum ferritin. Ferritin was assayed by an immunoturbidimetric assay with polyclonal anti-human ferritin antibodies (Tina-quant [a] Ferritin, Boehringer M.), using Boehringer M./ Hitachi 911 instrumentation. The assay was previously validated for precision, linearity and recovery percentage. Thirty dogs with microcytic, non-regenerative anemia and low serum iron concentrations were also selected. In these cases history, physical findings and laboratory findings and clinical follow-up were used to differentiate between iron deficiency and anemia of chronic inflammation (ACI).

The reference interval assessed for ferritin in normal dogs was 80-120 ng/ml (mean ϭ 98 Ϯ 11). In the 30 cases of anemia, the ferritin concentration ranged from 20 to 730 ng/ml (mean ϭ 184 ng/ml). In the subgroup of anemic patients affected by true iron deficency (n ϭ 10), ferritin levels ranged from 20 to 77.5 ng/ml (mean ϭ 48 ng/ml). In the remaining dogs (n ϭ 20), affected by ACI, the serum ferritin levels ranged from 83.3 ng/ml to 730 (mean 504 ng/ml). An unexpected finding was that five additional dogs, affected by porto-systemic shunts and associated microcytic anemia, had both low serum iron and ferritin concentrations. This finding is in contrast to that reported by other investigators.

Canine serum ferritin can be detected by a simple and accurate method and can be utilized in the diagnosis and management of iron deficiency anemia. Moreover our reference range in normal dogs, is narrower than previously reported with other techniques. The importance of dietary fiber in maintenance of normal colonic health and treatment of colonic disease is becoming well accepted in dogs. However, the cat is an obligate carnivore that evolved on diets low in carbohydrates and fiber.

There have been few studies reported examining the effects of fiber on feline colonic function. This pilot study was conducted to determine if insoluble dietary fiber had an effect on fecal short chain fatty acid (SCFA) production, and if the presence of fiber altered fecal nitrogen excretion. Twelve neutered, healthy, adult, mixed breed cats were allocated into 2 dietary groups of 6 cats, fed individually in a randomized cross-over design. Cats were provided food based on individual caloric needs for weight maintenance. Body weight was monitored weekly and food consumption was recorded daily. Initially all cats were fed a maintanence diet (MD) (1% fiber) for 2 weeks, then cats were divided into the test groups and fed either a moderate fiber (MF) diet (9% insoluble fiber) or a high fiber (HF) diet (17% insoluble fiber) for 2 weeks. At the end of each period, feces were collected for 48 hr to determine fecal output, and after this, fecal samples were collected immediately upon defecation, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at Ϫ80ЊC until analyzed. Samples were extracted and analyzed for SCFA concentration by gas chromatography. Total fecal nitrogen was determined by the Leco Analysis System after converting the samples to vapor in a high temperature oven. The cats consumed all diets readily and maintained their body weights throughout the study. Cats consuming the MF & HF diets had significantly higher concentrations of acetate and propionate, but not butyrate or total SCFA than cats consuming MD. No differences were found between MF & HF, although cats consuming the HF diet tended to have a higher SCFA conc. As expected, cats consuming the HF diets also produced the most feces (P Ͻ 0.05) compared to the MF or MD cats. Fecal nitrogen (FN) values increased (P Ͻ 0.05) in the cats consuming diets containing more insoluble fiber, but were not significantly different between the MF and HF diets. The increase in FN correlated with: 1) the increase in fecal dry weight (p ϭ 0.009, r ϭ 0.472), 2) the total SCFA concentrations (p ϭ 0.0039, rϭ 0.417), and 3) the dietary protein concentration (p ϭ 0.0026, r ϭ 0.434). These data support previous in vitro work showing that the colonic microflora in cats can ferment insoluble fiber to SCFA, which may influence colonic health. Further, increased nitrogen in the feces of cats consuming insoluble fiber is important, because it may suggest reduced dietary protein digestibility. Alternatively, increased FN excretion could be due to the increased SCFA (and concurrent production of hydrogen, methane, carbon dioxide and water) that ''traps'' ammonia in the feces as ammonium ion. Each year a number of dogs participating in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race develop myopathies. The objective of this study was to determine the role of vitamin E in limiting the extent of this muscle damage by investigating the hypothesis that dogs with higher prerace plasma vitamin E concentrations would perform better and experience less muscle damage than dogs with lower vitamin E concentrations.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF INSOLUBLE DIETARY FIBER ON

body_text.text: Venous blood samples were collected from dogs participating in the 1998 Iditarod Race within 30 days of the start of the race (P) (nϭ751) and at the finish (F) after running 1159 miles (nϭ197). Blood was also collected from dogs that did not complete the race (nϭ158). Plasma was analyzed for vitamin E concentration and creatine kinase (CK) activity.

Prerace vitamin E concentrations varied from 7.7 ug/ml to 112 ug/ml. Median, 25% and 75% percentiles for prerace values were 24.9 ug/ml, 20.1 ug/ml and 31.8 ug/ml respectively. There was no significant difference between the median plasma vitamin E concentration of the dogs at each time (P: 24.9 ug/ml; R: 25.4 ug/ml; F: 24.3 ug/ml), (Pϭ0.17). There was no correlation between a dog's prerace plasma vitamin E concentration and either the finishing time (R 2 ϭ0.0003) or the distance it travelled, if it failed to complete the race (R 2 ϭ0.005).

The median plasma CK concentration of R-dogs (2229 iu/l) was significantly greater than F-dogs (715 iu/l), (PϽ0.001) and both R-and F-dogs had median CK values that were significantly greater than at time P; (PϽ0.001). R-dogs with plasma CK values Ͼ 10,000 iu/l (nϭ39), had median prerace plasma vitamin E concentrations that were similar to R-dogs with CK values that were Ͻ 10,000 iu/l (nϭ119): (24.8 iu/l vs. 24.3 iu/l), (Pϭ0.3). There was no association between a dog's prerace plasma vitamin E concentration and its CK activity when it retired (R 2 ϭ0.0006).

From these results, there does not appear to be any link between a dog's prerace plasma vitamin E concentration and its performance in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race or in the extent of muscle damage based on CK activity. Volatile fatty acids (VFAs) are the primary end products of anaerobic microbial fermentation in the mammalian gastrointestinal tract. They maintain intestinal mucosal integrity, promote intestinal fluid/electrolyte balance, influence carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, and provide metabolic energy. Because cats are carnivores with relatively short, nonvoluminous gastrointestinal tracts, it might be expected that VFA production would be less than in other species. Values have not been established in vivo for cats, so the purpose of our study was to measure VFAs in the gastrointestinal tracts of healthy adult cats fed a free-choice commercial dry cat food. The gastrointestinal tracts were removed en bloc from the cadavers of 14 random source cats immediately following euthanasia. The tracts were divided into 6 sections (stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, proximal colon, and distal colon), and the luminal contents collected, centrifuged and analyzed for acetate, proprionate, butyrate, isobutyrate, isovalerate, and valerate using gas chromatography. The pH in each segment and colonic osmolarity were also measured.

Mean total VFA concentrations ([Total VFA], mmol/L), total VFA amounts (Tot VFA, mol), and pH are reported below. Total VFA concentrations and the distribution of individual VFAs in the proximal and distal colon were comparable to those reported in the forestomach of ruminants and in the large intestines of other animals. Small intestinal VFA concentrations in the cats were higher than those found in other species; this is consistent with recent reports that normal cats harbor high numbers of small intestinal bacteria. Luminal pH varied throughout the intestines of the cats in a pattern similar to that reported in other species. Although VFA concentrations in the cats were high, the total VFA amounts were very low due to the small gastrointestinal tract volume, and little metabolic energy is probably provided by VFAs in cats. VFAs are likely to have local beneficial effects, however, as reported in other species. Conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) refers to a group of isomers of linoleic acid. In growing mice, rats, and chickens, consumption of CLA decreases body fat content 57-70%, 23%, and 22%, respectively. CLA supplementation to adult mice resulted in significantly less body fat (Ϫ46%) and more lean body mass (ϩ9%) when compared with non-supplemented mice. Therefore, CLA may be useful in weight reduction programs in cats or dogs. The purpose of our study was to evaluate the influence of CLA supplementation on body composition in healthy adult cats.

MATERIALS AND METHODS Twelve three-year-old cats (6 males and 6 females) were fed an adult maintenance diet (FM; Feline Maintenance, Hill's Pet Nutrition Inc, Topeka, KS) to maintain weight prior to the study. Following this period, body composition was determined by dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA; QDR 1000/W, Hologic Inc., Waltham, MA), and cats were assigned to one of two study groups based on body fat content. One group was fed FM supplemented with CLA (1%), and the other group was fed FM supplemented with sunflower oil (1%); diets were isoenergetic. Cats were fed to maintain body weight throughout the study. Food intake was measured daily, and body weight measured weekly. Body composition using DEXA was performed at 4 and 8 weeks.
RESULTS Food intake, body weight, percent lean body mass, and percent body fat did not differ significantly between groups during the study.

DISCUSSION CLA consumption by healthy adult cats did not apparently influence body composition. Several possible explanations exist. Cats have decreased delta-6-desaturase activity; therefore, they may metabolize CLA differently from other species. Adult cats were studied, and CLA consumption may influence body composition to a greater degree in growing animals. It is possible that consumption of a greater quantity of CLA or a longer study period may have resulted in changes in body composition. Lastly, a difference may have been observed if a greater number of cats had been studied. CONCLUSION Although CLA consumption by rats, mice, chickens, and human beings is associated with alteration in body composition (less adipose tissue and greater lean body mass), it did not influence body composition in these healthy adult cats. Bovine papillomavirus (BPV) DNA has been detected in the majority of sarcoids examined to date. These studies have focused on cases located primarily in the Northeast region of the United States, and Europe (primarily Switzerland). The majority of tumors in these studies have bovine papillomavirus type 1 (BPV-1) DNA found in them with a much smaller percentage having BPV-2 type DNA. In all studies to date viral DNA was detected in tumor tissue alone, and was absent from normal equine skin and other tissues tested.

The purpose of this study was to assess the prevalence of BPV-1 and BPV-2 DNA in tumor tissue and normal skin samples collected from horses living in the Western United States. The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to screen equine tissue samples for the presence of viral DNA. One hundred fifty four tissue samples from 60 horses were collected and analyzed for the presence of BPV-1 or BPV-2. Tissue samples were collected from tumors (sarcoids) and from normal skin at close and distant proximity to the tumor sites. Tissues were harvested, immediately fixed in 10% formaldehyde routinely processed and paraffin embedded. A 50-micron section was used for DNA extraction. Primers known to amplify a 280 base pair region of the E5 early gene of both BPV-1 and BPV-2 were used to detect viral DNA. Restriction enzyme cleavage patterns of the amplified fragment was then performed to determine papillomavirus types. Negative controls included three equine warts, skin from three unaffected horses, a cutaneous melanoma, cutaneous lymphoma, and a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. In addition, swabs were taken of the skin of one affected horse to determine if viral shedding from the tumor site could contaminate the surface of normal skin. A bovine fibropapilloma was used as a positive control. 91 out of 98 equine sarcoids were positive for bovine papillomaviral DNA. 7 of the positive samples were sequenced and shown to match 100% with expected sequence patterns for BPV-1 and BPV-2. Approximately 50% of the tumors examined in this study had restriction enzyme patterns consistent with BPV-2. Twenty-nine of the 43 samples of normal skin taken from affected horses were positive for papillomavirus DNA.

This represents the first report of the presence of viral DNA in normal skin samples from horses affected with equine sarcoids. There appears to be a large variation in the prevalence of viral subtypes in tumors from different geographic regions. Bovine papillomavirus (BPV) is one of a family of small DNA viruses. These viruses are capable of inducing epithelial or fibroepithelial tumor in several species including cows, horses, dogs, rabbits and man. Specifically, two of the bovine papillomavirus gene products are capable of inducing transformation in cultured fibroblasts. Viral DNA has been detected in the majority of equine sarcoids examined to date, and expression of viral genes is likely to be a factor in initiation of tumorigenesis in equine sarcoids.

The purpose of this study was to attempt to detect and quantify expression of the BPV transforming gene, E5, in equine sarcoids. Equine sarcoids and normal skin from affected and unaffected horses were collected and immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen before storage at Ϫ70C. After extraction, a known quantity of protein from each sample was incubated with agarose beads covalently coupled to S aureus Protein A (Immunopure Plus, Pierce) and an anti-E5 polyclonal antibody. Following incubation, samples were washed and bound protein eluted from the beads. Eluted proteins were electrophoresed on a 14% polyacrylamide gel and transferred to a PVDF membrane. A western blot technique using a chemilumenescence detection system was used to detect and quantify the E5 protein. The 7 kDa, E5 protein was detected in both positive controls and equine sarcoids, but not in normal skin from unaffected horses. A difference in the quantity of expression was detected between samples. This represents the first confirmation of expression of bovine papillomavirus transforming proteins in equine sarcoids.
NOVA SCOTIA DUCK TOLLING RETRIEVERS. Mark Rishniw. College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF AUSCULTABLE CARDIAC DISEASE IN

body_text.text: Pulmonic stenosis has been identified in 2 Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retrievers (NSDTR) in the last 2 years. A cardiac screening program was established by the NSDTR club to examine the prevalence of auscultable cardiac disease within the breed and determine if a breed predisposition could be identified.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF AUSCULTABLE CARDIAC DISEASE IN

body_text.text: 105 presumptively healthy NSDTR between 3 months and 10 years of age were independently screened by auscultation by 1 of 8 clinicians (7 cardiologists, 1 internist). 10/105 dogs had auscultable abnormalities: 6 had soft left-sided apical systolic murmurs, 3 had soft left-sided basilar systolic murmurs. One dog had an audible extra heart sound, but was not evaluated further. Complete 2D and Doppler echocardiographic examinations were performed on 6/9 dogs with murmurs. 4 of these dogs had mild mitral insufficiency (3/4 dogs were Ͼ5 years) and 2 had physiologic (flow) murmurs diagnosed by exclusion. Incidental mild pulmonic insufficiency was identified in 3 of the 6 dogs examined echocardiographically.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF AUSCULTABLE CARDIAC DISEASE IN

body_text.text: These data suggest that NSDTR have little auscultably detectable congenital cardiac disease. Mild (presumably acquired) mitral valve disease is occasionally detected in older dogs. Whether the breed is over-represented with respect to this lesion cannot be determined at this time. Prevalence of non-auscultable cardiac disease, such as cardiomyopathy, cannot be determined by this study. Percutaneous balloon pericardiotomy (PBC) has been performed in people and in a small number of dogs as a treatment for recurrent pericardial effusion with tamponade (PET). We have found this technique useful in the management of dogs with malignant PET.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF AUSCULTABLE CARDIAC DISEASE IN

body_text.text: Three dogs with inoperable intrapericardial neoplasia and PET were studied. Under general anesthesia, a 16G over the needle catheter was inserted into the pericardial sac (PS), percutaneously, at the right 5th intercostal space. Contrast material was injected to outline the PS and confirm the catheter location fluoroscopically. Using a 0.038in guide wire, the catheter was replaced with an 8.5Fr sheath introducing catheter (SIC) through which a 14mm, 4cm balloon dilating catheter (BDC) was placed into the PS. The SIC was removed and BDC positioned across the parietal pericardium. Three dilations, each of 3 minutes' duration, were performed and the BDC deflated and removed. In 1 (Dog 2), this was followed by a series of dilations culminating with a 20mm, 4cm BDC, placed (without SIC) over the guide wire.

There were no important complications (pain has been managed with a preoperative fentanyl patch and/or oxymorphone, PRN). No dog has had significant recurrence of effusion and each has been released 1 day post-procedure (PP). Dog 1 was euthanatized 41 weeks PP due to metastatic disease, without recurrence of PET. Dogs 2 and 3 are asymptomatic and free of pericardial effusion 42 and 10 weeks PP.

We conclude that percutaneous balloon pericardiotomy appears to be a safe, economical, and effective method for palliative treatment of recurrent PET and may be the preferred treatment in dogs with recurrent PET and limited life expectancy due to intrapericardial neoplasia. Human studies and animals models suggest an association exists between viral myocarditis and development of DCM. While many dogs with DCM belong to breeds with a recognized pattern of presumed heritable cardiomyopathy, a remaining subpopulation of dogs with DCM belongs to assorted, atypical dog breeds. Viral myocarditis may contribute to the development of cardiomyopathy in this latter group of dogs. The objective of this study was to perform DNA extraction and polymerase chain reaction analysis on paraffin-embedded archived myocardial samples from dogs of both populations to screen for canine parvovirus, adenovirus types 1 and 2, and herpesvirus.

Paraffin-embedded myocardial samples from 10 dogs of atypical breeds, 8 Doberman pinschers, 2 Boxers, and 3 Cocker spaniels with DCM (%FSϽ22%, increased LVIDd) were screened for viral genomic material by PCR analysis. DNA was extracted from the myocardium using a phenol-chloroform extraction technique following xylene dissolution of paraffin, and proteinase K digestion. Sets of PCR primers were designed for canine parvovirus, adenovirus types 1 and 2, and canine herpesvirus.
