DNA extracted from both viral cultures and paraffin-embedded tissues of dogs with a confirmed clinical diagnosis of viral infection with each agent were used as positive controls. Successful PCR amplification reaction conditions were established for all viral primer sets using the positive control DNA samples.

Canine parvovirus, adenovirus type 2, and herpesvirus viral nucleic acid were not amplified from any of the cardiomyopathic samples. Polymerase chain reaction analysis for canine adenovirus type 1 amplified a band of similar size from both the positive controls and one cardiomyopathic sample from a five month old German Shepherd. Sequence analysis of the product confirmed it to be canine adenovirus.

We conclude that canine parvovirus, adenovirus types 1 and 2, and herpesvirus are not commonly associated with clinical DCM in dogs. The techniques of DNA extraction and PCR analysis for viral genome may be successfully performed on archived paraffin-embedded myocardial samples in dogs. Similar studies may be warranted to evaluate for presence of genomic material from other canine viral agents, such as canine distemper virus, by modifying the technique to include a reverse-transcription PCR reaction. Rabbit coronavirus (RbCV) infection-induced myocarditis results in cardiac chamber dilatation and myocyte hypertrophy. We have shown that the gross, histopathologic, and morphometric changes of RbCV infection are accompanied by systolic left ventricular dysfunction and a constellation of ECG abnormalities including ventricular tachyarrhythmias and QT interval prolongation that suggest that infection enhances vulnerability to ventricular fibrillation. The mortality rate following RbCV infection is 60%, with sudden death (unexpected and unexplained death of a rabbit between 8 hour observation intervals) accounting for approximately half of those deaths. The purpose of this investigation was to clarify the pathophysiology of sudden death associated with RbCV infection.

Six male New Zealand White rabbits weighing 2.5-3.0 kg. were purchased from a commercial supplier. The animals were housed individually at 21ЊC with a standardized light-dark cycle and fed rabbit diet and water ad libitum. A radiotransmitter (TL11M2-C50-PXT, Data Sciences, Minneapolis, MN) was surgically implanted. This transmitter included 2 ECG leads, an intraarterial catheter secured in the femoral artery, and a temperature sensor. The relative strength of the transmitter's signal was used to calculate an index of the animal's physical activity. Data were recorded continuously for 60 seconds every 15 minutes, 24 hours per day.

Following a 10 day acclimation period, instrumented rabbits were innoculated with 0.2 ml. of 10 3 RID 50 coronavirus stock into the marginal ear vein. Pressure recording capability was lost in 2 of the 6 rabbits within 10 days of transmitter implant. Of the 6 infected rabbits, 3 died suddenly. Analysis of telemetry data revealed that sudden death in these rabbits was preceded by 1 to 4 hours of inactivity, progressive hypotension and sinus tachycardia. Terminally (within 1 hour of death), hypothermia, sinus bradycardia with dramatically decreased QRS voltages, and severe hypotension occurred.

We conclude that despite the presence of ventricular ectopy and QT prolongation caused by RbCV infection, sudden death appears to be the result of cardiogenic shock rather than ventricular arrhythmia. Absolute and relative heart size in normal cats was determined by correlating heart size and selected skeletal structures. This study used 100 cats considered cardiologically normal on radiography Ϯechocardiography. Results were subjected to statistical analysis.

Standardized measurements were made of the long and short axes of the heart, mid-thoracic vertebrae, and other structures in normal feline thoracic radiographs. The measurements were recorded in millimeters as well as the number of thoracic vertebral lengths spanned by each dimension beginning with T4 in the lateral radiograph. The long and short axis measurements of the heart expressed in vertebral lengths were added to yield vertebral heart size (VHS) comparable to a reported study in dogs.

The normal feline VHS was 7.5v Ϯ 0.3 SD in lateral radiographs. The long axis dimension correlated moderately with the length of 3 sternebrae from S2-4. The short axis dimension correlated well with the length of 3.2 vertebrae from T4-6. The short axis dimension in ventrodorsal and dorsoventral radiographs was 3.4v Ϯ 0.2 SD.

Heart size based upon body size is more reliable than absolute dimensions as an indicator of cardiomegaly. The VHS method is easy to use and encourages objective assessment of heart size. It is helpful in determining cardiomegaly, as well as in comparing heart size in sequential radiographs. A radiographic study of 100 normal adult dogs showed that a vertebral scale system for measuring heart size was applicable in various breeds of dogs with different chest shapes (1). The applicability of this method in puppies and growing dogs was not determined. The aims of the present study were to determine normal heart size in puppies at 3 months of age and assess relative changes in heart size with maturity.

Lateral and dorsoventral radiographs were made of 11 normal puppies at 3, 6, and 12 months of age. The lengths of the long and short axes of the heart were compared to the number of thoracic vertebrae beginning with T4. The values were then added to yield the vertebral heart size (VHS). The average VHS at 3 months was 10.1v; at 6 months it was 9.9v ; and at 12 months it was 10.0v. The differences in heart size between age groups were not significant.
This study indicates that the VHS method for determining heart size in immature dogs is useful and the values obtained are essentially the same as in adult dogs (9.7v).

1. Buchanan JW and Bucheler J. Vertebral scale system to measure canine heart size in radiographs. J Am Vet Med Assoc 1995; 206: 194-199 Clinical monitoring of digoxin plasma concentration is necessary because of both a large inter-animal variation in digoxin pharmacokinetics and the small ratio of toxic/therapeutic concentrations. Digoxin concentration data from clinical monitoring are used to adapt dose regimens. Hierarchical mixed effects modeling of data from clinical monitoring can be used to identify factors which are covariables for model parameters, possibly improving dose calculations and predictions.

We examined 161 cases of dogs receiving digoxin (32 prospective and 129 retrospective). Samples for digoxin analysis were taken at steady state, after known dose, dose interval and dose-to-sample interval. Covariables examined included plasma creatinine, serum potassium, body weight x (x ϭ 0.75, 1), body surface area, age and the formulation administered. Initial modeling identified 19 cases with markedly (5-10 fold) slower absorption: these cases were unique in that they had been admitted to hospital within hours prior to dosing. Using the remaining 142 cases, a one compartment open model for oral administration and multiple step-wise regression, the following potentially useful covariables were identified: Clearance ϭ f(Ln{Creatinine}, Age), Volume/F ϭ f(Serum Potassium, Formulation, Age) and Ka ϭ f(Weight).

The best model found enabled prediction of individual digoxin clearance as Cl ϭ [2.939-(1.159*creatinine)]*100 mL/h/kg (creatinine expressed as Ln[mg/ dlϩ1]) (r 2 ϭ 0.26) and V d /F ϭ 21.267-(1.773*K ϩ ) L/kg (K ϩ in mEq/L) (r 2 ϭ 0.64). Population mean parameters (cv%) were Cl ϭ 203.0 mL/h/kg (34%), V d / F ϭ 13.2 L/kg (21%) and k a ϭ 0.990 h Ϫ1 (51%). These parameters and regression equations could be used to aid dose calculations and the underlying model illustrates some reasons for individual departure from expected dose-concentration relationships. Nitrates are potentially beneficial in the treatment of heart failure because they may increase systemic venous capacitance and reduce ventricular filling pressures. Isosorbide mononitrate (ISMN) was evaluated in a randomized, blinded, and placebo-controlled study using 6 normal dogs (Ͻ 15 kg). Technetium-labeled red blood cells (RBCs) were used to follow changes in blood volume distribution between the thorax and the abdomen. Each dog was orally dosed with placebo, 2, 3, and 4 mg/kg ISMN on separate days with a two-week washout period between randomized dosings. On the day of each study, RBCs were labeled in vitro with technetium-99m and administered intravenously. Information obtained after labeling included measurement of blood pressure (BP), packed cell volume (PCV), and heart rate (HR), and scintigraphic imaging of the thorax and abdomen. The drug or placebo was administered followed by repeated measures of the aforementioned variables at 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180, 210, and 240 minutes. Plasma ISMN concentration was determined at 60 minutes. Scintigraphic counts were corrected for biological and physical decay. Regional counts were expressed as a percentage of the whole.

No differences were detected in BP (Pϭ0.61), PCV (Pϭ0.92), HR (Pϭ0.92), thoracic blood volume percentage (TBVP) (Pϭ0.34), or abdominal blood volume percentage (ABVP) (Pϭ0.34) between placebo and any dose of ISMN. Quadratic curves decreasing with time (primary decline within first 60 minutes) were noted at all doses of ISMN and placebo for HR (20 % decrease, PϽ0.0001), PCV (7 % decrease, PϽ0.0001), and TBVP (19% decrease, PϽ0.0001), as well as an increase over time (primary rise within first 60 minutes) for ABVP (9 % increase, PϽ0.0001). Blood pressure did not change (Pϭ0.38). Mean plasma ISMN concentration 60 minutes after dosing was 0 ng/ml with placebo, 1,248 ng/ml with ISMN 2 mg/kg, 2,105 ng/ml with ISMN 3 mg/kg, and 2,352 ng/ml with ISMN 4 mg/kg (minimum human therapeutic concentration ϭ 100 ng/ml).

The use of technetium labeled RBCs to document blood volume redistribution following oral administration of ISMN in normal dogs failed to detect a shift in blood volume from the thorax to the abdomen at the doses tested, compared to placebo, despite adequate absorption of the drug. The significant decrease in TBVP, HR, and PCV and the increase in ABVP across time for all doses and placebo can potentially be explained by acclimation to the environment and splenic sequestration of blood over the four hours.
ADULT DOGS. Mark Rishniw. College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF PULMONIC INSUFFICIENCY IN NORMAL

body_text.text: Mild pulmonic insufficiency (PI) is commonly identified by color Doppler echocardiography in adult dogs without recognizable pulmonic valve disease. It is usually found incidentally while evaluating other cardiac pathology and is generally not considered part of the pathologic processes (unless pulmonic stenosis, heartworm disease or pulmonary arterial hypertension exist). However, the prevalence of PI in normal adult dogs is unknown.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF PULMONIC INSUFFICIENCY IN NORMAL

body_text.text: 25 normal adult dogs between 9 months and 13 years of age were examined by color Doppler echocardiography for presence of PI. The pulmonic valve was imaged in a right-sided short-axis parasternal view in all cases, optimizing with zoom functions for the pulmonic valve where necessary. No dog had echocardiographic evidence of structural cardiac disease. Pulmonary artery pressures were not measured in any dog. The degree of PI was semi-quantified (trace, mild, moderate, severe) by examining the size of the color Doppler insufficiency jet. 23/25 (92%; 95%CI ϭ 73%-99%) dogs had evidence of PI: 16 dogs had trace PI, 5 had mild PI and 2 had moderate PI. Spectral Doppler of the insufficiency jets in the dogs with moderate PI showed peak and end-diastolic velocities Ͻ2.0m/s, consistent with normal pulmonary artery pressures.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF PULMONIC INSUFFICIENCY IN NORMAL

body_text.text: These data suggest that in normal adult dogs trace or mild PI is commonly detected by color Doppler echocardiographic evaluation of the pulmonic valve and moderate PI is observed occasionally. The prevalence of incidental PI in normal adult dogs is similar to that reported in normal adult humans. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a clinically important disease in both humans and domestic cats, manifested by cardiac hypertrophy and myocyte disarray which can result in heart failure and sudden death. The disease is familial in humans, resulting from mutations in genes that determine the structure and function of cardiac contractile proteins. Recent observations indicate that HCM in the cat is also familial, supporting the hypothesis that human and feline HCM share related molecular pathogenesis. We propose to test this hypothesis using complementary mutation screening of candidate genes and gene mapping approaches. Identification of the genetic basis of feline HCM is expected to provide a valuable natural model for pathogenetic investigations and therapeutic trials which should benefit both humans and cats.
body_text.section: PREVALENCE OF PULMONIC INSUFFICIENCY IN NORMAL

body_text.text: Neither cDNA nor genomic DNA sequences of the candidate sarcomeric genes have been published in the cat. Normal cDNA sequences were generated from control cats which were greater than 7 years of age and judged to have normal cardiac architecture by echocardiography or measurements at necropsy. Work was begun on ␤-cardiac myosin heavy-chain (␤-MHC), cardiac troponin-T (cTNT), and cardiac myosin binding protein-C (MYBPC) because mutations in these three genes are thought to contribute most to familial HCM in humans. Polymorphic markers are being tested in a family of Persian cats with a high incidence of HCM and an inheritance pattern strongly suggestive of autosomal dominant transmission. Direct mutation screening is conducted on samples from clinical HCM (confirmed by echocardiography or necropsy) cases with a familial history.

Sequence homology between cat and human is greater than 90% for all three genes investigated to date (cTNT, ␤-MHC and MYBPC). Direct sequencing of candidate genes for mutations in ten unrelated affected cats has revealed neutral polymorphisms (seven in cTNT, two in ␤-MHC and eight in MYBPC) that do not determine disease, but which result in restriction site polymorphisms and so are suitable for linkage analysis. Recently, we have identified several intronic polymorphic markers in both MYBPC and B-MHC genes. While these data continue to support the hypothesis that familial HCM in the cat may share a similar pathogenesis to that in humans, no disease associated mutations have been identified to date. Prognosis for dogs with subvalvular aortic stenosis (SAS) varies with lesion severity. Mild lesions may not compromise quality of life or longevity, but moderate to severe lesions often lead to syncope, exertional weakness, congestive heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. Doppler-derived peak left ventricular to aortic pressure gradient (PG) is the method most often used for quantifying severity of SAS. Gradients are often categorized as mild (PG Յ 50 mmHg), moderate (PG Ͼ 50 and Ͻ 100 mmHg), or severe (PG Ն 100 mmHg). The purpose of this study was to determine the change in PG in young Newfoundlands with SAS.

Medical records from all Newfoundlands with SAS evaluated between July 1988 and July 1998 were reviewed retrospectively to identify untreated dogs examined by Doppler echocardiography at least twice during the first year of life. Twenty-three dogs (13 female, 10 male) were identified. Age at the initial exam ranged from 2 to 7 mos (medianϭ4 mos), while age at the second exam ranged from 3 to 12 mos (medianϭ8 mos). The median PG increased from 56 mmHg (range, 25-210) at the first exam to 117 mmHg (range, 32-263) at the second exam. The median PG change from exam 1 to exam 2 was 48 mmHg ranging from a decrease of 60 mmHg to an increase of 123 mmHg. The PG increased by Ͼ25 mmHg in 15 dogs, decreased by Ͼ25 mmHg in 1 dog, and changed Ͻ25 mm Hg in 7 dogs. The increment in PG affected severity classification in 16 (70%) of the dogs. Three dogs changed from mild to moderate, 8 dogs from moderate to severe, and 5 dogs from mild to severe.

This study documents the progressive nature of SAS in some Newfoundlands during the first year of life. The degree of disease progression is sufficient in some dogs to affect prognosis and therapeutic decisions. The syndrome of gastric distention and volvulus (GDV) occurs commonly in large breed dogs and may prove fatal in approximately 20% of cases. Approximately 43% of these cases develop cardiac arrhythmias that may contribute to mortality. Most of these arrhythmias are ventricular in origin and ventricular fibrillation (VF) may be the mechanism of death. This study designed an iatrogenic model of gastric distention (GD) to investigate (1) the prevalence of ventricular arrhythmias (VA) during acute GD and its recovery, (2) if programmed electrical stimulation (PES) may uncover tendency to VF, (3) if the QTc of the electrocardiogram (ECG) predicts tendency to VF, and (4) if hemodynamic changes predate VF. Eleven healthy beagles, anesthetized with morphine and alpha-chloralose, and instrumented so that vascular pressures, cardiac output, and PES could be recorded, were used. Five were unperturbed, while acute gastric distention to a pressure of 30mmHg for 1.5 hours was produced in six others. The results were (1) No dogs with GD developed spontaneously occurring arrhythmias. (2) Ventricular fibrillation was produced in no dogs by conventional PES, but in all dogs (pϽ0.05) with GD and none of the controls, using accelerated ventricular pacing. (3) The QTc of the ECG did not change in dogs with GD, but it shortened in (pϽ0.05) in controls. (4) There were no hemodynamic changes that achieved statistical significance. In conclusion, dogs with acute GD have a tendency for VF which may be uncovered by a robust protocol of PES. There are no hemodynamic prodromata of VF. Future studies will be conducted using various specific autonomic probes to determine the putative mechanism for the vulnerability to arrhythmia with GD. Arterial thromboembolism is a common sequalae to cardiomyopathy in cats. A safe and effective method to prevent thrombus formation and subsequent embolization does not currently exist. Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) has been used in humans as long-term prophalaxis for individuals at risk of thromboembolic conditions. The purpose of this study was to document the effects of dalteparin sodium (Fragmin) on laboratory values in cats. In humans, the therapeutic range for anti-Xa is 0.3-0.7 IU/ml. Eight healthy cats were studied. Cats were divided into two groups randomly. Each cat had a normal physical examination and a CBC, platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and anti-Xa activity prior to study admission. Group 1 received a single subcutaneous injection of dalteparin sodium at 200 IU/kg once daily for 5 days, while Group 2 received 100 IU/kg once daily for 5 days. Blood samples were collected for analysis prior to study admission and then 4 hours after the final dose on the fifth day. One cat in Group 2 had additional samples for anti-Xa activity at 2, 8, 12 and 24 hours post-injection. Samples were processed using routine laboratory methods. Values were compared using a t-test with a p value of Ͻ0.05 considered significant.
No treatment effects were seen on the PT, CBC or platelet counts at any dose. For all cats, anti Xa-activity was not detected in baseline samples (Ͻ0.01 IU/ml)

Post aPTT Post Xa activity Therapy significantly affected the aPTT and anti-Xa activity in Group 1 (pϽ0.01) and the anti-Xa activity in Group 2 (pϽ0.01). The anti-Xa activity for the single cat in Group 2 demonstrated a loss of the therapeutic level between 4 and 8 hours after administration. No clinical signs of bleeding or other problems related to drug administration were detected in our cats.

The results of this study suggest further evaluation of dalteparin sodium in cats at clinical risk of thromboembolic disease is warranted. Our data supports an initial dose of 100 IU/kg, but further research is necessary to determine dose frequency and efficacy. Beta cell antibodies and insulin antibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of diabetes in human patients. Beta cell antibodies have also been found in about 50% of newly diagnosed diabetic dogs.

The objective of this study was to examine the role of these antibodies in feline diabetes. The serum of 15 newly diagnosed untreated diabetic cats and of 30 cats with diseases other than diabetes was examined for beta cell and insulin antibodies. For beta cell antibody testing purified beta cells from a radiationinduced transplantable rat insulinoma were used. Serum from cats in which antibeta cell antibodies were induced by injecting a purified beta cell suspension subcutaneously was used as positive control. Following incubation with test sera, fluorescein-labeled anti-cat immunoglobulins were used to visualize binding between the beta cells and cat gamma globulins. Each serum was tested on 2 different tumor preparations. For the detection of insulin antibodies, a charcoal separation method was used.

It was found that none of the diabetic cats and none of the cats with diseases other than diabetes had antibodies against beta cells or against endogenous insulin. It is concluded that immune-mediated processes are not causing diabetes in the cat. Further studies are needed to determine the etiology of feline diabetes.
MENTS BY CAPILLARY BLOOD SAMPLING. G. Wess and C. Reusch. Clinic for Small Animal Internal Medicine, University of Zurich, Switzerland.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: Serial blood glucose measurement is an integral part in the management of diabetes mellitus. However, hospitalization and difficult veni-puncture are often stressful for the animal and thus, concentration of blood glucose may not reflect the animal's status at home.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: The purpose of this study was two-fold: first, to develop a method for obtaining an adequate drop of capillary blood from the ear of dogs and cats to measure blood glucose concentration using a portable blood glucose meter (PBGM), and second, to evaluate two PBGMs using either capillary or venous blood.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: Capillary blood was collected using two different methods. The first method (group size: 40 adult dogs) consisted in prewarming the ear and used a lancing device (Softclix Pro). The second method (used in 40 adult dogs and 80 adult cats) employed a new commercial vacuum lancing device (Vaculance). The PBGMs used in this study were Glucotrend and Glucometer Elite. Capillary PBGM readings were compared with PBGM values, using venous blood and with those of a hexokinase reference method.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: Both methods of capillary blood sampling were fast, easy to perform and yielded an adequate amount of blood to reliable measure the glucose concentration. Sampling of capillary blood using the Vaculance device was tolerated very well in all animals. Using the Softclix method, a second person was required to hold the animal's head in a few cases. The Vaculance method was faster and easier to perform. Varying performance of the PBGM was found in different glycemic ranges. Both PBGM underestimated the reference values in most cases. The underestimations were small in the low, slightly higher in the normal and highest in the high glycemic range. Capillary glucose readings of Glucometer Elite were in most cases slightly lower, compared to the corresponding venous glucose values, whereas Glucotrend capillary glucose readings were overall slightly higher (and therefore closer to reference values) than Glucotrend venous glucose readings. 100% of estimations of both PBGM were within clinically acceptable zones.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: The measurement of capillary blood glucose using PBGM is cheap, clinically accurate, easy and fast to perform. These simple methods may allow the owners of diabetic patients to measure blood glucose at home and hence, it could serve as a new and important tool in the management of diabetic dogs and cats. Exertional rhabdomyolysis (ER) occurs most often in mares and is suggested to occur more frequently during estrus than diestrus. The effect of one week of 10 mg/day 17␤ estradiol or 200 mg/day progesterone on pre-and 4 hr postexercise serum CK activity and muscle glycogen concentrations was evaluated in ovariectomized mares fed either hay only or hay and 5 kg/day of grain. Ovariectomy was performed 1 month prior to the study on 5 normal Thoroughbreds (TB) and 2 mares (TB and Arabian) with a history of ER. Muscle glycogen was assayed from percutaneous gluteal biopsies taken before, during and after 30 min (4-8 m/s) of exercise.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: Post exercise CK activity was Ͻ 800 U/L in 5/6 TB horses for all exercise tests. Post-exercise CK in 1 ER mare was between 1000-5200 U/L in 4/6 tests and 3,800-138,000 U/L in 6/6 tests for the other ER mare. No clear association between change in CK and hormonal supplement was apparent in the 5 TB or 2 ER susceptible horses apart from a tendency to lower CK with estradiol in normal horses. Muscle glycogen concentrations on the hay-only diet were unaffected by estradiol supplementation but mean concentrations were 50-60 mg/ kg dw lower at all time points with progesterone supplementation. Feeding sweet feed had little effect on muscle glycogen concentrations with estradiol or no hormonal supplementation. However, mean muscle glycogen concentrations were restored to normal in grain fed mares on progesterone. In conclusion, ovariectomy or hormone supplementation did not prevent ER in susceptible horses. Estradiol did not induce greater changes in CK with exercise in either normal or ER susceptible horses. Supplementing mares with 200 mg of progesterone IM /day may reduce muscle glycogen concentrations if horses do not receive grain supplementation. The Syndrome of Inappropriate Secretion of Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH) is a rare disorder in dogs characterised by hypo-osmolality and persistent arginine vasopressin (AVP) production, in the absence of hypovolemia and/or hypotension. Polydipsia is the presenting clinical sign common to all previously reported cases of canine SIADH. Current management involves the restriction of the patient's water intake so that ongoing urinary and insensible losses induce a negative water balance and body fluid volume is restored toward normal. The dog in this case did not present with polydipsia so water restriction was not considered a practical therapeutic option.
body_text.section: NEW METHODS FOR SIMPLIFIED GLUCOSE MEASURE-

body_text.text: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the nonpeptide selective AVP V 2 receptor antagonist OPC-31260 in a dog with naturally occurring SIADH. Oral administration of OPC-31260 at a dose rate of 3 mg/kg resulted in marked aquaresis with a rise in urine output and a decline in urine specific gravity within one hour. Corresponding increases in the levels of plasma sodium, plasma osmolality, and plasma renin activity were recorded over a four hour period. The AVP level remained inappropriately elevated throughout the study. The results were similar when the trial procedure was repeated after a stabilisation period of twelve days. Long-term therapy with OPC-31260 at a dose of 3 mg/kg PO q 12 h resulted in good control of clinical signs with no deleterious effects detected during a three year follow-up period. Despite the sustained clinical benefits observed in this case, plasma sodium did not normalize with continued administration of the drug.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF AN ORAL VASOPRESSIN RECEPTOR ANTAG

body_text.text: We concluded that: 1) Treatment of a dog with naturally occurring SIADH with the AVP receptor antagonist OPC-31260 at a dose of 3 mg/kg PO q 12 h resulted in marked aquaresis and significant palliation of clinical signs with no discernible side effects detected over a three year period. 2) OPC-31260 appears to offer a feasible medical alternative to restriction of water intake for the treatment of dogs with SIADH. 3) Higher doses of OPC-31260 may be required in order to achieve and maintain normal plasma sodium in dogs with SIADH. Under physiologic conditions, a rise in intracellular free calcium ([Ca 2ϩ ] i ) is the trigger for insulin release from pancreatic ␤ cells. Norepinephrine (NE), a potent inhibitor of insulin release, acts in part by lowering [Ca 2ϩ ] i . We investigated the mechanisms by which NE lowers [Ca 2ϩ ] i using indo-1 microfluorimetry to measure [Ca 2ϩ ] i in single HIT-T15 cells, a hamster-derived ␤ cell line. The possibility that NE directly inhibits calcium influx via voltage-dependent Ca 2ϩ channels (VDCC) was tested using a depolarizing concentration of potassium chloride (KCL) to open VDCC. We found no effect of NE (10M) on [Ca 2ϩ ] i in the presence of 35 or 20 mM KCL or in cells depolarized by the incremental addition of 3 to 5 mM KCL. In the event that NE interacts with VDCC only in the presence of glucose (GLU), we depolarized cells using 20 mM KCL in the presence of diazoxide (DIAZ) and 10 mM GLU. Again, NE had no effect on [Ca 2ϩ ] i . We next examined the possibility that NE lowers [Ca 2ϩ ] i by direct activation of KATP channels. Activation of KATP channels indirectly lowers [Ca 2ϩ ] i by preventing VDCC from opening. In GLU-stimulated HIT cells, DIAZ The Burmese breed was reported to be overrepresented amongst cats with diabetes mellitus in Australia. The purpose of this study was to investigate whether there was evidence for a genetic aetiology amongst Burmese diabetic cats from New Zealand.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF AN ORAL VASOPRESSIN RECEPTOR ANTAG

body_text.text: Pedigrees were obtained for 336 Burmese cats. Of these, 17 cats were diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and 17 showed no evidence of diabetes. The remaining 302 cats were unobserved relatives of the affected individuals. All affected cats were born between 1974 and 1989, and where the age of onset was known, this was always above 10 years.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF AN ORAL VASOPRESSIN RECEPTOR ANTAG

body_text.text: Diabetic pedigrees were analyzed according to criteria by Nicholas (1987) for evidence of a genetic aetiology and type of inheritance. Evidence for a genetic aetiology was based on the finding that the prevalence of diabetes in some families was greater than in others. Thirty-five animals in the data had more than 10 descendants. Of these, 23 cats had more than 10% of all their offspring affected with diabetes. The highest proportion of affected progeny was 29%, and the lowest proportion of affected descendants was 0%. Males and females were both affected, suggesting that the gene or genes causing diabetes are autosomal rather than sex-linked. Of the 17 affected individuals, 16 were of known gender, of which 4 were female and 12 were male. The disorder showed few signs of dominant gene action: it was rarely seen in sequential generations and nearly always skipped at least one and often more generations; and apparently unaffected offspring from apparently unaffected parents sometimes produced affected progeny. Recessive inheritance of diabetes could not be disproved, nor, however, could it be supported conclusively.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF AN ORAL VASOPRESSIN RECEPTOR ANTAG

body_text.text: This study demonstrated that there is clear evidence of genetic aetiology with some cats having more than 10% of their offspring affected. The condition was not sex linked and was unlikely to be dominant, but the study was unable to prove recessive, polygenic or multifactional inheritance. The aim of this study was to compare a variety of clinical and clinicopathological parameters for monitoring insulin treated diabetic cats over a period of up to 12 months for each cat.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF AN ORAL VASOPRESSIN RECEPTOR ANTAG

body_text.text: Results from a total of 19 diabetic cats recorded over a treatment period ranging from 2 to 12 months are reported. Cats were treated with porcine lente insulin (Caninsulin) twice daily. Samples were taken at 4, 8, 12, 26, and 52 weeks of therapy. Parameters studied included 24 hour water intake in hospital, excluding water in food (W), blood glucose, fructosamine (Fr), betahydroxybutyrate (B-OH), cholesterol (Chol), and triglycerides blanked for free glycerol (TG). Serial blood glucose curves measurements were taken every 2 hours for 24 hours to obtain mean blood glucose (MBG), the standard deviation of blood glucose (SDBG), and the J index (J), which arithmetically combines the MBG and the SDBG into a single value. The parameters were correlated against each other in pairwise fashion using Pearson Product Moment correlation.

Parameters which were significantly correlated were MBG and Fr (nϭ45, pϭ0.003, coeffϭ0.439), W and Fr (nϭ42, pϭ0.037, coeffϭ0.323), pϭ0.010, coeffϭ0.384), MBG and W (nϭ42, pϭ0.0001, coeffϭ0.562), pϭ0.01, coeffϭ0.385), and W and J (nϭ42, pϭ0.001, coeffϭ0.511) . The values of Fr and J were not significantly correlated (nϭ45, pϭ0.151, coeffϭ0.218) despite both these values being well correlated to water intake.

It was concluded that the parameters MBG, J, W, and Fr were the most closely matching indicators of control in insulin-treated diabetic cats. Measurement of water intake over a 24 hour period correlates well to MBG and Fr, and provides a simple, cost effective indicator of diabetic control. The purpose of this study was to establish reference values for the glucose tolerance test, insulin tolerance test and insulin sensitivity test in clinically normal cats, and to determine the variability in the tests over a 6 week period.

Thirty-two clinically normal, non-obese cats (as determined by body weight and body mass index), were acclimatised for two weeks to the holding facilities and a standard diet (32%protein, 9.9% fat, 2.6% C.F., 6.7% ash, 8.0% moisture). An intravenous glucose tolerance test (0.5g of glucose /kg), insulin tolerance test (0.1U of regular human insulin/kg) and an insulin sensitivity test (0.3g of glucose/kg at 0-min, followed by 0.05U of regular human insulin/kg at 20-min) were performed on consecutive days in each cat via a jugular catheter. In eight cats, the tests were repeated after an interval of six weeks.

During the glucose tolerance test, the fasting plasma glucose concentration (mean Ϯ SD) was 71 Ϯ 14 mg/dl, fasting plasma insulin was 8.3 Ϯ 4.4 U/ ml, glucose half-life (T1/2) was 56.8 Ϯ 8.8 minutes and the glucose disappearance coefficient (K) was 1.25 Ϯ 0.2%/minute. During the insulin tolerance test the mean glucose disappearance coefficient (K itt ) was 3.83 Ϯ 1.67%/min. The mean insulin sensitivity index (determined by minimal modeling) was 2.98 Ϯ 1.84 x 10 Ϫ4 (min Ϫ1 /U/ml). There were no significant (PϽ0.05) differences in any of these values after an interval of six weeks. The coefficient of variation was low for most values but was moderate for S I (47%) and high for K itt (60%) possibly reflecting the marked changeability of in vivo insulin sensitivity which may occur as part of the maintenance of normal glucose tolerance.

We conclude that standardization of test protocols and establishment of a validated range of reference values for these tests will assist in the identification of cats with impaired glucose tolerance and insulin insensitivity. Sporadic reports in human medicine have linked furosemide to the development of glucose intolerance in normoglycemic patients and deterioration of glycemic control in diabetic patients. This study was designed to evaluate parameters of glucose homeostasis in normal (Part I; nϭ6) and diabetic (Part II; nϭ6) dogs receiving furosemide therapy. In Part I, glycemic parameters (fasting serum glucose and insulin concentrations, insulin sensitivity, and glucose effectiveness) were assessed in healthy beagles following acute and chronic furosemide administration. The acute trials evaluated the effects of intravenous furosemide administration (0 mg/kg (saline), 2 mg/kg, and 6 mg/kg q8 hours for 24 hours; randomized crossover design) and the chronic trials evaluated the effects of oral furosemide administration (2 mg/kg and 4 mg/kg q12 hours for 21 days; randomized crossover design). Glycemic parameters were not significantly affected by furosemide administration (pϾ0.05). In Part II, alloxan was used to induce insulinopenic diabetes mellitus. Following stabilization with exogenous insulin therapy, three acute furosemide trials (0 mg/kg (saline), 2 mg/kg, and 6 mg/kg IV q8 hours for 24 hours; randomized crossover design) and two chronic furosemide trials (0 mg/kg (empty capsule) and 2 mg/kg PO q12 hours for 21 days; randomized crossover design) were performed. As in the normal dogs, no significant changes were seen in the assessed glycemic parameters following furosemide administration (pϾ0.05).

In conclusion, furosemide had no effect on glucose tolerance at the doses administered to this group of dogs. This is the first study to evaluate the effects of furosemide on glucose tolerance in dogs, and the results suggest that furosemide can be used in the treatment of diabetic dogs with no adverse effects on glycemic control. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) usually occurs as a sporadic disease in dogs. There is evidence for a genetic contribution to developing the disease in some dogs; the genetic aspects of inherited IDDM have been previously reported in the Keeshond. Though Samoyed dogs are among the many breeds that develop spontaneous diabetes mellitus of undetermined etiology, a familial or genetic predisposition has yet to be reported. This investigation provides evidence for a familial disposition to diabetes mellitus in Samoyed dogs.

Five adult Samoyed dogs from two unrelated litters were diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Two affected full-sibling male dogs from a litter of 9 dogs (Litter A) were raised in the same household. The other three dogs (2 male, 1 female) from an unrelated litter of 6 dogs (Litter B) were raised in a similar geographic area but in different households. Persistent hyperglycemia and glucosuria at the time of initial diagnosis confirmed diabetes mellitus in all dogs. In addition, plasma insulin C-peptide concentrations were determined when possible from insulin treated dogs as an estimate of endogenous insulin production.

Age at the time of diagnosis ranged from 3.5 to 7.8 years (median ϭ 6.0 years). All five dogs demonstrated fasting hyperglycemia ranging from 341 to 711 mg/dl (median ϭ 490), and glucosuria (Ն 2,000 mg/dl), at the time of diagnosis. All 5 dogs initially presented with clinical signs of polyuria and polydipsia. Three of 3 dogs tested (2 from Litter A and 1 from Litter B) had insulin C-peptide concentrations less than 0.05 pmol/ml (reference range 0.17Ϯ 0.01 pmol/ml). Long term administration of an intermediate-acting insulin resolved clinical signs in all dogs.

In conclusion, these results provide evidence for a familial predisposition to adult onset, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in Samoyed dogs. Further analysis of pedigree information, breeding studies, and investigation of additional biochemical and pathologic abnormalities are necessary to fully characterize this finding. In June 1998, the Michigan State University Animal Health Diagnostic Laboratory began running a commercially available (Oxford Laboratories, Oxford MI) canine thyroglobulin autoantibody (TgAA) assay as part of routine thyroid function testing. A retrospective study was done on the first 27,548 laboratory samples to determine some factors related to positive results obtained from the assay. In addition, age of TgAA positive dogs was compared to age of dogs with idiopathic hypothyroidism.

Results indicated that 8.3% of samples were positive (Ͼ200% of negative control). Less than 5% of samples from dogs weighing Ͻ10 kg. were TgAA positive while Ͼ9% of samples from dogs Ͼ10 kg. were positive. Dogs Ͻ2 years of age had few (Ͻ5%) TgAA positive samples; samples from dogs 2 to 6 years of age were positive 9.5 to 12% of the time and samples from dogs older than 6 were positive less often. No sex predilection was found. Over 50% of TgAA positive samples were from dogs Ͻϭ5 years of age while it took until 8 years of age to obtain Ͼ50% of samples from dogs with idiopathic hypothyroidism. This supports the hypothesis that idiopathic hypothyroidism may be a sequelae of autoimmune thyroiditis. Eight breeds with significantly higher ( This study was undertaken to 1) identify clinical signs associated with subclinical thyroiditis (SCThyr; normal T4 and TSH with thyroid hormone antibody (THAA)) and subclinical hypothyroidism (SCHypoT4; normal T4, increased TSH), 2) assess the effect of THAA status on the clinical presentation of hypothyroidism (HypoT4) and 3) evaluate some signs which often initiate thyroid investigation. The lab records of 58,322 cases in which clinicians had checked at least one of 32 pre-printed clinical signs on the request form were reviewed. These were categorized based on T4, TSH and THAA results into: healthy (Norm); antibody positive (ϩve) and negative (Ϫve) HypoT4; SCThyr; ϩve-SCHypoT4 and ϪveSCHypoT4. Chi-square analysis compared rates of each sign to its reference in the Norm group. A p-value of 0.05 inferred statistical significance and odds ratios of Ͼ 1.10 or Ͻ 0.91 arbitrarily inferred biological significance. In the SCThyr group, obesity was more common than in Norm cases, but crusts, dermatitis-moist, dermatitis-erythema, hyper-pigmentation, lichenification, pyoderma, papule and pruritis were under-represented. Lethargy was more frequent in both SCHypoT4 groups but ϩveSCHypoT4 had less pruritis, otitis, pyoderma, crusts, and seizures and more obesity and diarrhea, than Norm dogs. The -veSCHypoT4 group had more hyperpigmentation, seborrhea, crusts, hyperkeratosis, lichenification and acanthosis. Comparison between the two HypoT4 groups indicated more obesity and lethargy in the ϩve group but less abrasions, acanthosis, crusts, dermatitis-moist, dermatitis-erythema, hyperkeratosis, infertility, lichenification, polydipsia, polyuria, pyoderma, pruritis, seborrhea and weight loss. Between the two SCHypoT4 groups there was more obesity, lethargy and diarrhea in the ϩve group but less crusts, otitis, pyoderma, pruritis and seborrhea. In conclusion, subtle differences in clinical presentation between the antibody ϩve and -ve dogs with thyroid disease are limited to higher rates of obesity and lethargy, and fewer cutaneous manifestations in the antibody positive dogs. None of the 32 signs in this study could be used to help identify suspect cases of subclinical thyroiditis. In addition, despite being common initiating signs for thyroid investigation, infertility, otitis and seizures were not overrepresented in any disease group suggesting that there are much more common causes for these signs other than thyroid disease or dysfunction. Summer pasture-associated pulmonary disease (SPAOPD) is a recurrent seasonal disease observed in horses residing on pasture in southeastern region of United States. It is a naturally-acquired progressive, obstructive pulmonary disease of the small airways characterized by coughing and pronounced abdominal lift at the end of exhalation. The clinical signs, laboratory and histopathologic findings were studied in 8 adult horses affected with SPAOPD and compared to 6 adult horses without evidence of respiratory disease. The clinical score was calculated by assessing the nostril flare and abdominal lift. The change in pleural pressure (⌬Ppl) was measured indirectly by an esophageal balloon during tidal breathing. Cytology and bacterial culture were performed on bronchoalveoar fluid (BALF) collected via fiberoptic endoscopy. Light microscopy of pulmonary parenchyma was performed on samples collected via percutaneous lung biopsy and at postmortem from each lung lobe.

The clinical score (CS) for SPAOPD-affected horses (median 5.75) were significantly greater than for normal horses (median 2.0). Cytology of BALF from SPAOPD-affected horses yielded predominantly non-degenerative neutrophils. Histopathologic lesions were identified diffusely throughout the lung lobes and included bronchiolar goblet cell metaplasia, marked accumulation of basophilic mucus and mild peribronchiolar inflammatory infiltrate. Histopathology of percutaneous biopsies compared well with samples collected at post-mortem. The CS was highly correlated to ⌬Ppl; and CS and ⌬Ppl were highly correlated to mucus accumulation in SPAOPD-affected horses. Therefore, clinical scoring is a valid estimation of disease severity; BALF, although variable, was diagnostically useful; and lung biopsy was consistently useful diagnostically. Moreover, lung biopsy procedure was safe as no complications were observed. It has been previously demonstrated that ionized hypocalcemia occurs in cats with urethral obstruction. The purpose of this study was to measure serum PTH concentrations in cats with urethral obstruction to evaluate the parathyroid response to changes in ionized calcium.

Blood was collected from 19 cats with urethral obstruction prior to any therapy. Measurments included iCa 2؉ (mean 1.065 mmol/L, median 1.12, SD 0.155, range 0.71-1.25), PTH (mean 11.0 pmol/L, median 5.3, SD 12.0, range 1.7-41.7), 25 OH Vit D (mean 115 nmol/L, median 101, SD 72.9, range 34-316), pH (mean 7.29, median 7.34, SD 0.12, range 7.07-7.43), K ؉ (mean 5.29 mmol/ L, median 4.90, SD 1.49, range 3.89-8.60), BUN (mean 88 mg/dl, median 37, SD 95, range 20-301), Creatinine (mean 5.5 mg/d, median 1.9, SD 5.9, range 0.6-18.2), Phosphorus (mean 8.2, median 5.5, SD 5.9, range 4.5-24.1), Total Calcium (mean 9.2 mg/dL, median 9.7, SD 1.3, range 6.6-10.7), and albumin (mean 3.6 g/dL, median 3.6, SD 0.3, range 2.8-4.1). Statistically significant inverse correlations were found between ionized calcium and both PTH and phosphorus.

It appears that parathyroid gland secretion of PTH in response to ionized hypocalcemia in cats with urethral obstruction is appropriate and low PTH is not the cause of ionized hypocalcemia in these cats. The pathogenesis of feline hyperthyroidism is not understood. We have attempted to further characterize this endocrinopathy on a molecular basis by investigating the abnormalities of signal transduction at the G protein level. Through previous studies, we have shown that thyroid tissue from hyperthyroid cats have decreased expression of the G-i class of G proteins, classically thought to inhibit cAMP production. The purpose of this study was to develop an in vitro system in which to investigate activation of these G proteins in isolated membranes from hyperthyroid tissue, and to examine differential activation of the G proteins in response to treatment with TSH agonist.

Enriched membrane preparations from euthyroid and hyperthyroid cats were prepared. Activation of G proteins was assessed by measurement of specific binding of a poorly-hydrolyzable GTP analog, GTPg35S that binds to activated G proteins. The amount of binding was measured by 35S scintillation counting. Nonspecific binding was quantified by addition of a 100-fold excess of cold GTPgS under identical experimental conditions.

Feline thyroid membranes were treated with bovine TSH at concentrations ranging from 1-300 mIU/ml. A maximal response of approximately 65% increased GTPgS binding over background was seen at 100 mIU/ml TSH. Mastoparan, a receptor-independent G protein agonist, resulted in a increase of GTPgS binding of 115% over background indicating that it stimulated a population of G proteins not activated by TSH.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated a significant and specific activation of thyroid cell G proteins in response to an appropriate agonist, TSH, in an in vitro system. This system can be used to examine the role of G protein activation in thyroid membranes from hyperthyroid cats and possibly to examine the effect of potential goiterogens in an in vitro system. Both SARD and HAC are well recognized syndromes in dogs. An association between the two has been suggested in the literature and amongst veterinary practitioners. The purpose of this study was to determine prevalence of HAC in dogs diagnosed with SARD at our hospital. For inclusion, dogs must have been diagnosed with SARD between 1/1/1990 and 12/31/1998. Records of each dog were evaluated for: 1) any owner or clinician observations suggestive of HAC: polyuria (PU), polydipsia (PD), polyphagia (PP), or nonpruritic hair loss (NPHL); 2) a serum biochemistry profile and urinalysis (UA) with changes typical of HAC: urine specific gravity (SG) Յ1.020, BUN Յ20mg/dl, or increases in SAP, ALT or cholesterol (CHOL). All dogs with an abnormality consistent with HAC must have undergone at least 1 of 3 screening tests for HAC: ACTH stimulation; low dose dexamethasone; urine cortisol:creatinine. 44 dogs (3-14 yrs old; mean: 8.1 yrs; 30 females) were diagnosed with SARD. 16/44 dogs had at least one abnormality consistent with HAC. 15 dogs were thought to be PU/ PD, 11 PP, 1 had NPHL, 9 had low SG, 10 had decreased BUN. Increases in SAP, ALT & CHOL were documented in 10, 9, and 5 dogs, respectively. 8 of the 16 dogs (18% of 44; 50% of dogs with suspect HAC) had at least one screening test result consistent with the diagnosis of HAC suggesting that owners of dogs with SARD be carefully questioned regarding signs of HAC and that all dogs with SARD be evaluated with at least a serum biochemistry profile and UA.
PANCREATIC ␤ CELLS T. Schermerhorn, M. Noda, K. Sooy*, S. Christakos*, and G.W.G. Sharp. NYSCVM, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY. and the UMDNJ-NJ Medical School, Newark, NJ(*).

body_text.text: Calbindin-D 28K is a 28 kD Ca 2ϩ -binding protein that is expressed in the pancreatic islets of many mammals, including dogs and cats. Since a rise in cytosolic free calcium ([Ca 2ϩ ] i ) is an important stimulus for insulin release, we investigated the role of calbindin in Ca 2ϩ -mediated insulin release. Methods: Two experimental systems were used: 1) pancreatic islets isolated from mice that lack the gene for calbindin production [knockout mice (KO)] and 2) a calbindin overexpression system using a transfected mouse pancreatic ␤ cell line HC-13 cells). Fluorimetry was used to measure cytosolic free calcium ([Ca 2ϩ ] i ) and insulin was measured using a standard RIA. Depending on the experiment, either potassium chloride, which causes insulin release via cell depolarization, or glucose was used as the stimulus for insulin release. Results: Potassium chloride (KCl) caused a larger increase in peak [Ca 2ϩ ] i in islets from KO mice than in control islets from wild type mice (WT) that had normal production of calbindin (1260 nM vs 670 nM, respectively; p Ͻ 0.05). The greater increase in [Ca 2ϩ ] i in KO islets was accompanied by an altered pattern of KCl-induced insulin release. Although the 1st phase of insulin release was the same in both types of islets, the 2nd phase of insulin release was sustained in islets from KO mice relative to WT islets, as measured by the time required for rate of insulin release to fall to 25% of the peak rate (45 min. in KO vs 29 min. in WT; p Ͻ 0.05). In experiments using HC-13 cells, we found that calbindin overexpression lowered the resting [Ca 2ϩ ] i (180 nM vs 215 nM in controls) and markedly inhibited KCl-induced changes in [Ca 2ϩ ] i (225 nM vs 820 nM in controls). Calbindin overexpression also decreased KCl -stimulated insulin release by 80 to 95% from control levels. In another series of experiments, [Ca 2ϩ ] i and insulin release were measured in glucosestimulated islets. In these studies, glucose elicited greater insulin release from KO islets than from WT islets. Even though the glucose-induced rise in [Ca 2ϩ ] i was the same for both KO Fecal occult blood testing may be necessary to detect gastrointestinal hemorrhage, before melena becomes visible. However, dietary contents can influence these tests, so it was the purpose of this study to evaluate various diets in a guaiac based (HemoFEC, Boehringer) and o-tolidine (Hemotest, Bayer) based test kit.

body_text.text: Six cats were fed eight different diets for one week and feces were collected and analyzed always during the last three days. Cats were fed cottage cheese as negative control and cottage cheese with canine blood as positive control. For results see Pepsinogens are unbranched polypeptides that are synthesized in chief cells of the gastric body and fundus. Under acidic conditions pepsinogens autoactivate spontaneously to pepsins. Serum immunoreactive pepsinogens are useful markers for several distinct gastric disorders in human beings and cattle. Pepsinogens have been purified in several species but to our knowledge its purification in horses has not previously been reported. The aim of this work was to purify and partially characterize equine pepsinogens as a prelude to developing immunoassays for quantification of pepsinogens in horse serum.

body_text.text: Mucosa was scraped from the stomach of a freshly slaughtered horse, homogenized, and the homogenate centrifuged. The supernatant was further purified using weak anion exchange on diethylaminoethyl-sepharose (DEAE), strong anion exchange on mono-Q, and size exclusion chromatography on Sephacryl-S100. The N-terminal amino acid sequences of the purified proteins were obtained by the Edman degradation method and the use of a gas phase amino acid sequencer.

body_text.text: Two distinct peaks of equine pepsinogen were identified after weak anion exchange chromatography. Both isoforms migrated as single bands on sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE). The two pepsinogens were labeled equine pepsinogen A (ePG A; migrated furthest towards the anode on agarose gel electrophoresis) and equine pepsinogen C (ePG C) according to their elution profile. The N-terminal amino acid sequence of the first 25 amino acids of ePGA and ePGC are Leu-Ile-Tyr-Lys-Val-Pro-Leu-Val-Lys-Lys-Lys-Ser-Leu-Arg-Gln-Asn-Leu-Arg-Glu-Asn-Gly-Leu-Leu-Glu-Asp and Leu-Ile-Tyr-Lys-Val-Pro-Leu-Val-Lys-Lys-Lys-Ser-Leu-Arg-Gln-Asn-Leu-Arg-Glu-Asn-Gly-Leu-Leu-Ala-Asp, respectively (the only difference between these two isoforms is in position 24). Equine pepsinogens showed good homology with pepsinogens from human beings, pigs, and other species.

body_text.text: In conclusion, the purification method utilized in this work yielded two electrophoretically distinct isoforms of equine pepsinogen with similar molecular weight and N-terminal amino acid sequence compared with the pepsinogens purified from other species. The availability of these pepsinogens will facilitate the development of immunoassays for equine pepsinogens in serum as a diagnostic tool for the diagnosis of gastric disorders in horses. The use of nuclear scintigraphy and the validity of Acetaminophen (AP) absorption in measuring liquid-phase gastric emptying in horses was investigated.
