body_text.text: Twelve experiments were conducted in 6 horses. Technetium-DTPA (10 mCi) and AP (20 mg/kg body weight) were administered in 200 ml of water. Gamma camera images of the stomach and serum samples were obtained over a 4-hr period. Half times of gastric emptying (T 50 ) were determined from right and left lateral images and their geometric mean using power exponential curves. Maximum plasma concentration (C max ), time to C max (T max ), area under the concentration vs time curve (AUC) and the appearance rate constant (K a ) for AP were determined using a parameter estimation program (RStrip). Correlations between T 50 and pharmacokinetic parameters of AP absorption were calculated using Spearman's rank correlation coefficient.

Counts derived from left lateral images showed the best fit to power exponential curves. The strongest and most significant correlations were between T max and T 50 , and between K a and T 50 for the left side.

In conclusion, T 50 is best determined by left lateral imaging. T max and K a are the most useful parameters when using the AP absorption method. The application of 99m Tc-HMPAO labeled white blood cells to support the diagnosis of right dorsal ulcerative colitis (RDC) was studied in two horses with a history and clinical signs consistent with phenylbutazone toxicity. Blood was collected aseptically in heparinized syringes from the patients for in vitro leukocyte radiolabeling. The buffy coat was separated out and radiolabeled with 99m Tc-HMPAO. The radiolabeled blood was re-injected IV and four images of the right and left side of the patient's abdomen were acquired at 4 hours and 20 hours post-injection.

Results of the nuclear study revealed no abnormal findings in the abdomen at the 4 hour post-injection images in either horse. Images obtained 20 hours postinjection revealed a linear uptake of labeled white blood cells in the right cranioventral abdomen in the region of the right dorsal colon in both horses. The radiolableled white blood cell uptake in Horse 1 was more intense than in Horse 2. Horse 1 was euthanatized, and RDC was confirmed at necropsy. Horse 2 recovered with medical management. At this point, the severity of detectable RDC lesions with this technique is unknown. This nuclear imaging study offered a rapid, non-invasive diagnostic tool for identifying right dorsal colon inflammation. These findings not only supported the diagnosis of RDC, but also facilitated appropriate medical management of each horse. The aims of this study were to characterise the morphology and neurochemical expression of the equine enteric nervous system (ENS) using tissue culture and immunohistochemistry, with a view to investigating autonomic neuropathies such as grass sickness.

Intestinal samples were harvested fresh from euthanased horses free from gastrointestinal disease. The tissues were microdissected to prepare both wholemount preparations for immunohistochemistry and explant and dissociated culture systems of the ENS. Immunoreactivities for cell markers and neuropeptides were revealed using a standard indirect immunofluorescence technique. These included: anti-VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide), anti-CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide), anti-D45 (calcium binding protein), anti-PAN and anti-NFM (neurofilaments), anti-GFAP and anti-S100 (glial and Schwann cell markers). Wholemount preparations were very difficult to prepare in the adult equine intestine and positive results were only achieved using the submucous plexuses.

Both explant and dissociated cell ENS culture systems were successful in the horse, but only those derived from the submucous plexus. This is in contrast to small mammal models where enteric neurons have been cultured from both myenteric and submucous plexuses. This reflects the difficulty in accessing the myenteric plexus in the adult horse. Neurons were grown successfully in culture for 5 days and there is the potential to make this period longer. Three main cell types were evident in dissociated culture: neurons, enteric glia and fibroblasts. Neurons appeared to be bedded down in clumps and non-neuronal cells proliferated markedly after 2-3 days in culture. Double labelling experiments revealed that the enteric glial cells are very similar to the Schwann cells of the peripheral nervous system. This is the first report of equine enteric neurons being grown in tissue culture. The difficulties in accessing and harvesting these neurons in the equine intestine mean that further work is necessary in order to produce a repeatable, quantifiable in vitro model. Magnesium (Mg), an important intracellular cation, has numerous physiologic roles, but the most critical ones are associated with production and utilization of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), function of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, and regulation of intracellular calcium. Hypomagnesemia has been reported to be common in critically ill human patients. Hypomagnesemia often accompanies other electrolyte abnormalities. The purpose of this study was to survey a population of 75 horses suffering from gastrointestinal disease to determine the incidence of plasma magnesium abnormalities. A total of 90 horses were evaluated and divided into 5 groups: small intestinal strangulation (nϭ27), large colon torsion (nϭ14), enterits (nϭ15), colitis (nϭ19) and clinically normal horses (nϭ15). Total plasma magnesium was determined using a colorimetric procedure.

Thirty-three horses with gastrointestinal disease (44%) were hypomagnesemic at hospital admission. Hypomagnesemia was present in the following percentages: small intestine strangulation (63%), large colon torsion (14%), enterits (33%) and colitis (47%). Eight of the 75 horses (11%) were hypermagnesemic. All clinically normal horses were normomagnesemic and had electrolytes within the normal ranges. Hypokalemia was present in 30% of hypomagnesemic horses, whereas hypokalemia was present in 20% of normomagnesemic horses with gastrointestinal disease. Hypochloremia occurred in 75% of hypermagnesemic horses, compared with 18% in normomagnesemic horses. These results suggest that Mg abnormalities are important in the critically ill horses suffering from gastrointestinal abnormalities. The prognosis and management of leukemia depend in part on the lineage of the leukemic cells. Immunophenotyping using monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) specific for leukocyte differentiation antigens permits definitive identification of cell lineage. The cells from 3 horses diagnosed with lymphocytic leukemia on the basis of peripheral leukocyte cytology or bone marrow histopathology were studied using a panel of monoclonal antibodies and FACS analysis. All horses were subsequently euthanized, and immunohistochemical staining of neoplastic tissues was performed.

By FACS analysis the cells in all 3 cases were confirmed as leukocytes (EqCD11a/18 ϩ, EqCD44 ϩ). However, based on expression of EqCD13 the cells in one of the horses proved to be myeloid, rather than lymphocytic. The two remaining leukemias were both lymphoid (EqCD13 -, EqWC1 ϩ). One of these neoplasms was poorly differentiated, but likely of B cell origin (MHC IIϩ). The other leukemia was of T cell origin (EqCD2 ϩ, EqCD3ϩ, EqCD5ϩ) and on further evaluation was found to be EqCD4 ϩ/EqCD8 -. In addition, up to 20% of the EqCD4ϩ cells were found to be EqCD3-, a phenotype not previously observed in the horse. This latter observation was confirmed by 2-color flow cytometry. Immunohistochemical staining of neoplastic tissues using the same panel of mAbs permitted visual identification of the distribution of neoplastic cells within affected lymphoid organs.

This study demonstrates the utility of mAbs in combination with FACS analysis and immunohistochemistry in defining the lineage and distribution of leukemic cells in horses. Correlation of immunophenotype with biologic behavior and response to therapy may enhance the management of leukemia in the horse. Antimicrobial peptides exist in the intracellular environment and are critical components of the innate immune response. NK-lysin is a novel antimicrobial peptide that has been identified in porcine intestinal tissue, originating from natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL). Similar peptides have been identified in human NK cells and T lymphocytes. Endogenous antimicrobial killing properties of equine cytotoxic cells have been previously recognized; however, the exact mechanisms of microbial killing remain unknown. The purpose of this investigation was to identify the presence of an NK-lysin homologue in equine NK cells and CTLs, and to determine whether expression of this molecule was related to cell activation.

Lymphocytes were isolated from whole blood using density-gradient centrifugation. Magnetic-bead separation was used for positive selection of CD8ϩ lymphocytes. Cells were stimulated in vitro with the mitogens concanavalin A and phythemagglutinin, and interleukin-2 (IL-2). All cells were washed with 0.1 M PBS and lysed in Trizol reagent. RNA isolation was performed from all populations of cells. Cloning of the cDNA for equine NK-lysin was achieved with RT-PCR using primer pairs selected from the conserved region of porcine and human homologues.

Sequencing analysis revealed that equine NK-lysin shares 87% sequence homology with the porcine peptide. Equine-specific primers revealed constitutive peptide expression in CD8ϩ and CD8-lymphocytes, and in mitogen, and IL-2 stimulated lymphocyte populations. Inducible expression following mitogen and IL-2 stimulation was limited, although expression appeared greater for mitogen stimulated lymphocytes when compared to resting cells.

These data suggest that equine NK-lysin is present in resting and activated lymphocytes. We hypothesize that this peptide is an effector molecule of equine NK cells and CTLs and is a component of the innate immune response. Radiation therapy plays a central role in the management of brain tumors in animals. Conventional treatment protocols vary but typically involve administration of radiotherapy in multiple fractions of 3 to 4 Gy to a total dose of 45 to 50 Gy. A complete treatment course requires multiple anesthetics over periods of 3 to 6 weeks necessitating prolonged hospitalization. Fractionation is required to minimize the damage to normal brain tissue which is also repeatedly exposed with each treatment.

Stereotactic radiation therapy is a technique of providing radiation therapy in one treatment. Cranial computed tomography performed with a stereotactic localizer secured to the skull allows creation of a three dimensional image of the tumor. Using the localizer and the tumor coordinates, radiotherapy is planned and performed by focusing the radiation beam at the tumor while the radiation source rotates in an arc around the tumor. The radiation treatment is applied in three to five arcs with the tumor at the center of each arc. The non-intersecting arcs minimize exposure of normal overlying tissue allowing a larger single treatment dose to be applied (and therefore a lower total dose).

Three dogs were treated with stereotactic radiotherapy using a total dose of 10-15 Gy. A LINAC was used to provide the radiation therapy. Three to five non-intersecting arcs were used in each dog. Two dogs with meningiomas survived 3 1/2 years and 1 year after therapy. The third dog is alive 8 months after therapy. No complications have been observed following use of this technique. Intracranial oligodendrogliomas are a commonly reported neuroectodermal tumor of dogs. The purpose of this study is to report the clinical, imaging, and pathological features of intracranial oligodendrogliomas in 22 dogs.

The medical records of 22 dogs with histopathological confirmation of oligodendroglioma were evaluated retrospectively. Signalment, initial complaint, and results of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis were recorded. Computed tomography (CT) images were evaluated for the presence of hypo-or hyperdense mass lesions both before and after contrast administration. Magnetic resonance (MRI) images were evaluated for the presence of the following characteristics: location, hyperintensity, isointensity and hypointensity of mass lesions, masseffect, edema, ventricular conformation, contrast-enhancement, and axial versus extra-axial appearance.

Eighteen of 22 dogs were brachycephalic (14 of 22 were boxers). Ages ranged from four to 11 years. The primary complaint by the owners was seizures in 21 dogs, and apparent cervical pain in one dog. MRI was done in 14 dogs, and CT in seven dogs; one dog was not imaged. Mass lesions were identified within the following divisions: rostral fossa 17 dogs, middle fossa 2 dogs, and caudal fossa 2 dogs. MRI characteristics were those of intra-axial mass lesions, usually with a mass-effect. Hyperintensity was noted on PD and T2 weighted images, and hypointensity on T1 weighted images. Non-uniform ring-enhancement was identified in nine dogs; poor enhancement in two dogs, and in three dogs the mass did not enhance with contrast. Irregular ring enhancement was identified in two dogs. Appearance on pre-contrast CT images varied from hypodense to hyperdense. Tumors were variably contrast enhancing on CT images. In two dogs the mass failed to show contrast enhancement.

CSF was analyzed in 15 dogs and despite variable results, 10 dogs showed albuminocytological dissociation. Histopathologic diagnosis was oligodendroglioma in all dogs: seven by means of stereotactic CT-guided brain biopsy, and 15 at necropsy. Five dogs had additional neoplasms unrelated to the intracranialoligodendroglioma. Three dogs had metastasis within the ventricular system.

It is concluded from this study that canine intracranial oligodendrogliomas do have some frequently occurring clinical and diagnostic features, however such features are not common to all oligodendrogliomas. Oligodendrogliomas are rarely reported tumors of the feline central nervous system (CNS). The purpose of this report is to describe the clinical, imaging, and pathological characteristics of oligodendrogliomas affecting the caudal fossa of two aged cats. Results of physical and neurological examinations were consistent with a lesion causing dysfunction of the brainstem and cerebellum. Results of a minimum database (complete blood count, serum chemistry panel, urinalysis, thoracic radiographs and abdominal ultrasound) were unremarkable.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain of each cat revealed a contrast-enhancing, heterogeneous space-occupying lesion involving the brainstem, fourth ventricle and cerebellum. The lesion in one cat appeared to comprise two separate and discrete parts, while the lesion in the other cat had poorly defined margins. Hydrocephalus was present in both cats. Cells with characteristics consistent with a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma were identified in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected from each cat. Neuropathological diagnosis was confirmed histologically at necropsy, and was supported by immunocytochemical staining of fresh and formalin fixed tissue.

Results of this report suggest that oligodendroglioma should be included on a differential diagnosis list for cats with clinical signs of brainstem and cerebellar dysfunction, and poorly marginated or multi-focal CNS lesions on MRI. In cats, oligodendrogliomas may have a predilection for the caudal fossa. Furthermore, cytological examination of the CSF may provide useful information in the antemortem diagnosis of oligodendrogliomas of cats. In 1997-98, approximately 434 roadkill or trapped opossums were collected in Florida. Opossums weighed from 0.2 to 4.5 kg (mean 1.9 kg) and were equally divided between genders. Feces and gut scrapings were examined for sporocysts by flotation on Sheather's solution, then intestinal sporocysts were harvested from positive animals. Sporocysts were cleaned, counted, and characterized on the basis of 6 genomic DNA sequences that previously have been shown to distinguish S. neurona from S. falcatula. Isolates were either S. neurona, S. falcatula, or dissimilar to both. The last category included 3 distinct Sarcocystis genotypes (species?).

Approximately 22% of opossums were sporocyst-positive. Counts ranged from 6.4 ϫ 10 4 to 6.3 ϫ 10 7 with median recovery of 5.3 ϫ 10 5 sporocysts/animal. S. neurona was recovered from 4.5% of opossums, S. falcatula from 3%, other Sarcocystis ''species'' from 1.7%, and, in 9.9%, isolates were not characterized (usually because of low recoveries). Only 0.5% of opossums had mixed infections. A lower proportion of opossums were S. neurona-positive in the fall and winter than was the case in the spring and summer. Surprisingly, most S. neurona-positive opossums came from within or close to cities rather than from farms.

This study provides compelling molecular evidence that the opossum is host to multiple Sarcocystis species, including S. neurona, S. falcatula, and several previously unknown species. The 4.5% incidence of S. neurona infection in opossums stands in contrast to the reported high rate of exposure of horses to S. neurona (50% by serology). Additional work is required to elucidate the ways in which sporocysts shed by opossums are acquired by horses. Canine erythrocyte (RBC) survival times range from 86 to 122 days as measured by a variety of RBC labeling techniques. Recently, greyhound RBC survival times measured by in vitro biotinylation were reported to be 53.6 Ϯ 6.5 days as compared to 104.3 Ϯ 2.2 days for non-greyhound control dogs (AJVR, 57(5):739-42, 1996) . An inherently shorter RBC lifespan for greyhounds would suggest that, in spite of their frequent use, greyhounds may not be optimal RBC donors for conditions requiring repeated RBC transfusions. The purpose of this study was to reassess RBC survival in greyhounds using in vivo, instead of in vitro, biotinylation.

RBC survival times were determined in 6 greyhounds and 3 non-greyhounds (2 Labrador Retrievers, 1 mixed breed). Each dog was screened for disease with physical examination, complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, urinalysis, heartworm test, fecal flotation, and serology for Ehrlichia canis, Babesia canis, and Rickettsia rickettsii. Each dog appeared free of disease before use. In vivo biotinylation was done by infusing 30 mg/kg biotin-NHS (150 mg/mL in DMSO) through a jugular catheter at 0.1 mL/min. Blood was collected 12 hrs later and then weekly thereafter to determine the percentage of biotin-labeled RBCs at each time. Each blood sample was washed twice in sample buffer (phosphate buffered saline, 1% bovine serum albumin, 180 mg/dL glucose, 0.025% NaN 3 ) before about 10 8 RBCs were incubated with 25 g avidin-FITC in 750 L sample buffer for 1hr. After the RBCs were washed twice with sample buffer to remove unbound avidin-FITC, the percentage of biotinylated RBCs was determined using a Becton-Dickinson FACS Vantage flow cytometer, evaluating 50,000 RBCs per sample.

A survival curve was generated for each dog by plotting ''% biotinylated RBCs'' vs. ''days'' and calculating a least-squares fitted line over the linear portion of the curve (first 11 weeks, r 2 ϭ 0.94-0.99). RBC survivals, defined by the x-intercept of the best-fit lines, were 95, 99, and 117 days for the 3 nongreyhounds, matching well with reported values. Greyhound RBC survival times ranged from 87 to 109 days, with mean and median of 95 and 90 days, respectively. In this study using in vivo biotinylation, RBC survival times in greyhounds were similar to RBC survivals in non-greyhound dogs. Newer, nonradiometric methods to measure survival of red blood cells and platelets use biotinylation of these blood elements as a kinetic marker. Shortened survivals of red blood cells are reported secondary to antibodies produced against the biotinylated red cells. Serial survivals of biotinylated platelets were performed to determine if a similar antibody against biotinylated platelet survivals could be identified.

Initial control experiments showed a reproducible lifespan of approximately seven days, comparable with published data utilizing other methodologies. Six months after obtaining normal autologous, biotinylated platelet survivals on two dogs, repeat biotin platelet survival showed rapid removal of labeled platelets from the blood. Two hours after infusion none of the labeled platelets were detected by flow cytometric means. The dogs' platelets were evaluated for the presence of an antibody directed against biotinylated platelets. Platelet rich plasma from the two dogs was incubated with either N-hydroxysuccinaimide-biotin (NHS-biotin) 1mg/ml final or, for control purposes, NHS-biotin vehicle (DMSO). Platelet bound antibody was detected with 125 I Staph A, 10ng.

Antibodies directed towards biotinylated platelets were detected based on an increase in 125 I Staph A binding. NHS-biotin or a neoantigen created by platelet bound NHS-biotin elicited an antibody response in these dogs. These data suggest that using NHS-biotin platelet canine kinetic studies has a time limitation set by the immune response. We conclude that to avoid anti-NHS-biotin antibody producing artifactual shortening of measured platelet survivals, serial platelet survivals in the same dog should be designed so that the last measured survival is the normal control. Leukocyte reduction of blood products is a technique used at human blood centers to aid in the prevention of leukocyte induced transfusion reactions. It is considered an important precaution for people who are transfused multiple times. The filters currently used for human blood products generally achieve a 99.9% reduction in the number of white blood cells per unit (450 ml) of blood. The goals of this study were 1) to determine if leukoreduction of canine blood could be effectively achieved using an in line, pre-storage leukoreduction filter, and 2) to determine if the leukoreduced red blood cell product would maintain its viability after 35 days of storage. Use of leukoreduction has not previously been documented in dogs.

Two units of blood were drawn from each dog and filtered with a Sepacell-RS2000 in line filter either immediately at room temperature (6 dogs), or after the blood was cooled for 4 hours to 4ЊC (5 dogs). Filtration efficacy was determined by measurement pre and post filtration leukocyte counts from filtration at the two different temperatures. In vitro viability of the red blood cells filtered at room temperature and stored in Adsol was determined by comparing red blood cell ATP level and percent hemolysis before and after the storage period. In vivo viability of the stored cells was determined using a biotin-streptavidin-phycoerythrin labeling technique and flow cytometry.

Filtration of canine blood immediately post collection versus filtration of blood cooled to 4ЊC, achieved mean reductions in leukocytes of 87% and 99.9% respectively. The mean ATP content was 1.90 mol/g Hb pre-storage and 1.51 mol/g Hb post storage; mean hemolysis was 0.08% pre-storage and 0.32% poststorage. These values are comparable to those obtained in previous studies of canine red blood cells stored for 35 days. The mean in vivo 24 hour survival was 85%, which is acceptable according to previously established transfusion standards.

We conclude that the use of the Sepacell-RS2000 leukoreduction filter does not adversely affect in vitro or in vivo viability of canine red blood cells. It effectively removes leukocytes from blood, and maximal efficiency of filtration was achieved when the blood was cooled to 4ЊC prior to filtration. There is potential for this leukoreduction filter to be beneficial for use in multiply transfused canine patients. Erythrocyte morphology was evaluated in 18 greyhounds, 10 with azotemia (creatinine 1.8-19.6 mg/dl) and 8 nonazotemic, with cutaneous and renal vasculopathy. Wright's stained blood smears were evaluated (minimum of 5 fields) by light microscopy and digital imaging. Erythrocytes were classified per 250 erythrocytes as acanthocytes, microcytes, schizocytes, spherocytes, echinocytes, and keratocytes. Type I echinocytes (crenation) were evaluated as the percent of erythrocytes affected.

The number of azotemic dogs with erythrocyte changes were acanthocytes Ն 5/field ϭ 6, microcytes ϭ 3, schizocytes ϭ 6, spherocytes ϭ 2, keratocytes ϭ 1, and type I echinocytes ϭ 1 with 1-5 %, 2 with 50-60%, and 7 with Ն 80%. The number of nonazotemic dogs with erythrocyte changes were acanthocytes Ն 5/field ϭ 3, microcytes ϭ 1, schizocytes ϭ 3, spherocytes ϭ 1, keratocytes ϭ 0, and type I echinocytes ϭ 4 with 1-5 %, 2 with 50-60%, and 1 with Ն 80%. Rare eccentrocytes were noted in 1 azotemic and 1 nonazotemic dog. The erythrocyte changes were increased in association with azotemia, increased fibrinogen concentrations, and decreased hematocrits. All dogs had acanthocytes present, but the striking feature was the number of notched, pinched, and irregularly spiculated acanthocytes in azotemic and nonazotemic dogs. Occasional very small microcytes, round erythrocyte micro-fragments, were seen in 2 azotemic dogs and 1 nonazotemic dog.

It is currently unknown if the atypical acanthocytosis is due to direct erythrocyte membrane damage from endotoxin/bacterial toxins, secondary to microangiopathic damage, oxidative damage, or a combination of these factors. Decreased serum concentrations of urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine, low urine specific gravity, and enlarged kidneys are common in dogs with portosystemic vascular anomalies (PSVA). These features suggest increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and / or increased water turnover. A prospective study was done to examine the relationship between GFR and renal volume and typical clinicopathologic features of PSVA, before and after surgical attenuation of the anomalous vasculature. Clinical assessments included pre-and post-surgical determinations (CBC, routine serum biochemical analyses, serum bile acids (fasting and postprandial), complete urinalyses, abdominal ultrasound (renal volume determination), per rectal scintigraphy, and GFR). The GFR was estimated by plasma 99m Tc-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid ( 99m Tc-DTPA) clearance before (nϭ21) and after (nϭ12) surgical attenuation of PSVA.

Pre-ligation 99m Tc-DTPA GFR was increased (median 5.64 ml/min/kg, range 3.53-8.49 ml/min/kg, reference range 2.83 to 4.47 ml/min/kg) in 81% of dogs. Post-ligation 99m Tc-DTPA plasma clearance decreased significantly in each of 12 dogs assessed (median % change was Ϫ42%, pϽ 0.001). Pre-ligation renal volume was above the expected size for the left and right kidney in 71% (10/14 dogs) and 69% (11/16) of dogs, respectively. Right renal volume decreased significantly (nϭ5, median % change Ϫ45%, pϭ0.003) following surgical attenuation of PSVA.

These findings document that increased GFR exists in dogs with PSVA and substantiates the previous clinical impression of renomegaly in this disorder. We propose that increased GFR is related to increased renal size, the subnormal serum BUN and creatinine concentrations, and low urine specific gravity in affected dogs. The International Feline Heartworm Disease Council advocates the use of chemoprophylaxis for cats at risk of heartworm (Dirofilaria immitis) infection, because it is unknown which cats and how many cats are at risk, however, published guidelines fail to be universally applicable. Knowledge of regional prevalence of heartworm infection could more accurately guide heartworm prophylactic recommendations for cats. The goal of this study was to determine the prevalence of heartworm infection in a healthy client-owned cat population in lower Michigan.

Serum from 1332 healthy cats was tested for the presence of heartworm antigen using an ELISA test kit. Cats included in the study were greater than 8 months old, clinically healthy, and never on preventive heartworm medication. Samples were obtained from 100 participating private practices throughout lower Michigan during the period of July to December 1998. The heartworm antigen test, which is highly specific for adult female heartworms, was used to establish a definitive diagnosis of heartworm infection. However, due to the nature of feline heartworm infection, this test has a low sensitivity in cats and may underestimate the prevalence of feline dirofilariasis. Nonetheless, the antigen test has significant diagnostic utility via its ability to predict the minimum number of infected cats. The prevalence of infection was determined by the number of antigen positive cats.

In this population, 26 of 1332 cats were positive for heartworm antigen. Therefore, the prevalence of heartworm infection in healthy cats in lower Michigan is 1.9%. Many of the antigen positive cats (80%) were from the southeastern part of the state which closely reflects the concentration of canine heartworm disease in Michigan. These findings suggest that knowledge of the prevalence of regional canine heartworm disease can accurately predict the risk of infection for a local feline population. Establishing the incidence of infectious diseases of horses is essential to giving accurate advice to local owners in development programs. Since brucellosis exists in horses in Central America, investigating the incidence of this zooinotec disease also has humane health importance. Husbandry data, ticks, and serum samples were collected on 497 horses presented at clinics in eight communities. Serum was tested for antibodies to B. caballi and B. equi,, using an ELISA. The Standard Brucellosis Card test was used on site for brucella antibody testing. Serum antibodies to EIAV were tested by Coggin's AGID test.

Of the horses, 36% used for packing, and 41% were used both for packing and riding. Median load carried, six days a week, was 90 kgs. A median of one kg. per day of corn was fed to 70% and leaves of Brosimum alicastrum (Moraceae) were fed to 12 %. The mean and median body score was 2.5 (scale of 1-5). 10% of the horses were emaciated. Fistulous withers (grade 4 back score) occurred in 2.4% of the horses. All horses tested (100%) were positive for Babesia equi and 96% were positive for B. caballi. The high frequency of babesia infection was related to the prevalence of ticks of the genus Boophilus and Amblyoma. Only 3% of horses were positive for EIAV and all of these were from one community. No horses were positive for Brucella abortus. This was true even for horses with fistulous withers.

The absence of brucella positive serum indicates that Brucella abortus is either very rare or absent in this population. The presence of EIAV, even at low incidence, may contribute to the debilitation in some horses. Further, study to identify vector populations is warranted. Widespread hemoparasitism in horses in heavy work, on a low plain of nutrition, contributes to their poor physical condition.

The purpose of this study was to evaluate the relationship between Bartonella spp. and uveitis in cats by assaying aqueous humor from cats with and without uveitis for Bartonella spp. antibodies and for presence of Bartonella spp. DNA by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Bartonella spp. IgM, IgG, and IgA antibodies were measured by ELISA in serum and aqueous humor of 49 client-owned cats with uveitis, 49 healthy shelter cats, and 9 cats experimentally inoculated with either B. henselae or B. clarridgeiae, 454 days after inoculation. Aqueous humor from some cats was assayed for the presence of Bartonella spp. DNA by polymerase chain reaction (PCR; HESKA Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratories, Fort Collins, CO).

Ocular production of Bartonella spp. IgG (C value Ͼ 1) was detected in 7 of 49 cats with uveitis, 0 of 49 healthy shelter cats, and 4 of 9 experimentally inoculated cats. Bartonella spp. IgM C value Ͼ 1 were only detected in cats with uveitis and Bartonella spp. IgM and IgA antibodies were detected in serum of a greater number of cats with uveitis than healthy shelter cats. The organism was detected by PCR in aqueous humor of 3 of 24 cats with uveitis, 1 of 49 healthy shelter cats, and 4 of 9 experimentally inoculated cats.

Results of this study document that Bartonella spp. infect the eyes of cats following natural exposure or experimental inoculation. However, since Bartonella spp. antibodies or organismal DNA can be detected in aqueous humor from cats with and without evidence of uveitis, these test results cannot be used to definitively document uveitis due to ocular bartonellosis. The ability of tissue culture media-propagated equine rotavirus (ERV) to induce clinical signs of rotavirus infection in 9 healthy colostrum-fed foals Ͻ16 days of age was evaluated after administration of 10 4.2 Ϫ10 6.1 FAID50/kg ERV via nasogastric tube (NGT). Four control foals Ͻ16 days of age were challenged with a placebo of tissue culture media (TCM). All dams but one had serum neutralizing anti-rotavirus antibody titers Ͻ1:768 at foaling; 8 dams had titers Յ 1:192. Foals were monitored daily from 3 days prior to challenge to 28 days post challenge with ERV or TCM. Monitoring included physical examination and assignment of a score for fecal consistency (from 0 ϭ normal to 4 ϭ watery). Neutralizing anti-rotavirus antibody titers were assessed in serum samples harvested weekly from dams and foals, in colostrum, and in weekly milk samples. Daily fecal samples were collected from foals for detection of rotavirus antigens via a solid phase semi-quantitative enzyme immunoassay. 1 Mean values for fecal scores for test foals were significantly higher (fecal consistency looser) than those of control foals after challenge. Rotavirus antigen could not be detected in the feces of control foals before or after TCM challenge. All test foals had detectable rotavirus antigen in feces during the first 14 days post challenge. Dams of 6 test foals showed at least a threefold increase in serum neutralizing anti-rotavirus antibody titers to rotavirus 2-3 weeks after their foals were challenged; this pattern was not seen in the dams of control foals. Two test foals experienced a fourfold rise in serum neutralizing anti-rotavirus antibody titers 3-4 weeks following challenge with rotavirus. There was a trend toward detection of more rotavirus antigen in the feces of foals with lower serum neutralizing anti-rotavirus antibody titers. No clinically significant differences were seen between the test and control foals with regards to rectal temperature, heart rate, or body weight after challenge. We conclude that oral challenge with our tissue culture media-propagated rotavirus induces a reproducible model for rotavirus infection in foals Ͻ 16 days of age.

1 Rotazyme II, Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, IL Protein-energy malnutrition occurs in patients with chronic renal failure (CRF) primarily due to loss of appetite. Leptin, a 16-kDa protein recently identified as the ob gene product, is secreted by adipocytes and regulates body adipose mass by affecting food intake and energy expenditure. Leptin has been shown to accumulate in end-stage renal disease in humans and rats and may contribute to uremic anorexia. Plasma immunoreactive leptin was measured by a previously validated radioimmunoassay (Linco Research, St. Louis MO) in 10 healthy cats, 13 cats with naturally occurring CRF and 28 cats with surgically induced renal mass reduction (RMR). Serum creatinine concentrations were significantly higher in 13 cats with naturally occurring CRF compared with 10 healthy cats (3.8 Ϯ 3.0 mg/dl vs 1.4 Ϯ 0.2 mg/dl, pϽ0.05). Serum creatinine concentrations were also significantly higher in 28 cats with RMR compared with 10 healthy cats (3.2 Ϯ 2.1 mg/dl vs 1.4 Ϯ 0.2 mg/dl, pϽ0.05). There were no significant differences in plasma leptin concentration in 17 female cats compared with 11 male cats with RMR (2.5 Ϯ 1.5 ng/ml Human Equivalent (HE) vs 2.1Ϯ 0.9 ng/ml HE, pϭ0.46) indicating that gender is not a major determinant of leptin concentration in cats. Leptin concentrations in 28 cats with RMR were not significantly different than that of the 10 healthy cats (2.3 Ϯ 1.3 ng/ml HE vs 2.4 Ϯ 0.4 ng/ ml HE, p ϭ 0.84). Leptin concentrations in 13 cats with naturally occurring CRF were significantly higher than that of the 10 healthy cats (8.5 Ϯ 7.3 ng/ml HE vs 2.4 Ϯ 0.4 ng/ml HE, pϽ0.05). Furthermore there was a strong positive correlation between plasma leptin and serum creatinine concentration in 13 cats with naturally occurring CRF (R 2 ϭ0.84, pϽ0.0001, leptin ϭ 0.15 ϩ 2.2 creatinine). Gel filtration chromatographic evaluation of plasma from 2 cats with naturally occurring CRF verified that most (81.1, 83.4%) of the observed immunoreactivity was from leptin and not products of leptin degradation or nonspecific crossreactivity of the RIA antisera. Some (13.7, 18.8%) immunoreactivity was found in fractions that would contain proteins of relative molecular weight greater than albumin, possibly leptin bound to a feline form of the soluble leptin receptor. While the mechanism of accumulation of leptin in feline CRF appears to be independent of decrements in glomerular filtration rate, hyperleptinemia could contribute to uremic anorexia and poor nutritional status commonly seen in spontaneous feline CRF. The retina and central nervous system of mammals are highly enriched in long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCPUFA) including arachidonic acid (AA, 20:4n-6) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA, 22:6n-3). Human milk contains DHA and AA at levels high enough for their rapid accumulation in developing nervous tissues. Infant formulas provide 18 carbon precursors of LCPUFA but these appear to be inefficiently converted and the need for LCPUFA supplementation to reflect human milk remains controversial. The objective of this study was to investigate fatty acid (FA) profiles of total milk lipid extracts from dogs with emphasis on their LCPUFA content and compare them with plasma phospholipid (PL) and diet FA. Milk samples were obtained from four nursing, hereditary nephritis carrier female dogs as follows: Dog A, during weeks 1 and 2 of lactation; dog B, during week 2; dog C, during week 1 and 4; and dog D at week 5. In this way preliminary longitudinal data was also obtained in two animals over time. Diets were a mixture of premium canned and dry puppy growth products. Plasma samples were obtained from dog B at week 2 and dog C at week 4. Total lipids were extracted from all samples, phospholipids were fractionated from sera, and FA methyl esters were prepared and subjected to capillary gas chromatography. Total milk fat was determined gravimetrically.

Milk FA profiles closely reflected the diets fed; both fractions are primarily composed of triglycerides. Plasma PL 18:0 and 20:4n-6 was higher and along with 16:0 accounted for approx. 61% of total PL FA consistent with active de novo synthesis and ␦-6 desaturation during PL synthesis. Milk contained approximately 10% total fat and moderate amounts of AA and DHA. Over time, total milk LCPUFA decreased 10%(Dog A, 1 to 2 weeks) and 18%(Dog C, 1-4 weeks) similar to humans. Calculated % AA and DHA in dog milk were approx. 1.8% and 0.07% respectively. By comparison, recommendations for human infant formula based on human milk are 0.3-1.1% AA and 0.25-0.76 % DHA. Levels of AA in canine milk in this preliminary study are moderately higher while those of DHA are markedly lower. What amounts of n-6 and n-3 LCPUFA are necessary for optimal puppy neonatal development requires further study.

There was no significant difference in the plasma vitamin C or retinol concentrations between groups, however mean plasma vitamin E concentration differed significantly between groups following supplementation (S: 75.3 ug/ml vs. control: 44.3 ug/ml), (pϭ0.006) and after days 1 and 2 of exercise. Mean plasma vitamin E decreased significantly in both groups after day 1 of exercise: group S (75.3 ug/ml vs. 61.1 ug/ml), (pϽ0.001) and control group (44.3 ug/ml vs.35.3 ug/ml), (pϭ0.04), however there was no further decrease. Plasma CK activity increased significantly following exercise in both groups (see figure) however there was no significant difference in CK activity at any time between the groups. Supplementation with dietary anti-oxidants increased plasma vitamin E, but not vitamin C concentrations but did not attenuate exercise-induced muscle damage in these sled dogs. Prolonged exercise, food and water deprivation, and acute enterocolitis can all produce substantial depletion of body fluid and electrolyte stores. Treatment of these problems, especially equine colitis, often requires large (and expensive) amounts of intravenous fluids. We recently demonstrated that administration of a mixture of NaCl and KCl, as a hypertonic oral paste, attenuated body weight loss by increasing voluntary water in horses performing 60 km of endurance exercise on a treadmill. Thus, we hypothesized that oral electrolyte pastes would enhance voluntary water intake in dehydrated horses and that the composition of electrolytes would further influence the rehydration process. After overnight dehydration (4-5% body weight loss) was induced by furosemide administration and withholding of water; voluntary water intake and plasma electrolyte concentrations were determined every 6 hours for 36 hours after administration of 3 oral paste doses of NaCl (total dose of 0.5 g/kg), KCl (total dose of 0.5 g/kg), a mixture of NaCl and KCl (total dose of 0.25 g/kg of each salt), or water (no electrolyte control) in 6 horses. Administration of NaCl or a mix of NaCl and KCl resulted in greater (p Ͻ0.01) voluntary water intake and body weight recovery during the first 18 hours of the rehydration period in comparison to KCl or water administration. Although plasma electrolyte concentrations remained within normal reference ranges, sodium and potassium concentrations were greatest with NaCl and KCl treatments, respectively. In addition, no adverse effects of electrolyte administration in the form of hypertonic oral pastes were observed. In conclusion, administration of oral electrolyte pastes improved rehydration of furosemide-dehydrated horses and the degree of rehydration was influenced by composition of the electrolytes administered. Thus, use of oral electrolyte pastes, in combination with intravenous fluid therapy, could reduce the cost of treatment of horses with severe fluid and electrolyte depletion. Healthy and diseased cats were used to begin to evaluate the effects of Feliway, a synthetic facial pheromone, on behavior and food intake of cats caged in The Ohio State University Veterinary Hospital.

Both client-owned cats with lower urinary tract signs and healthy cats provided by hospital staff were studied. 20 Cats were assigned consecutively to exposure to the pheromone or vehicle, which were provided by the manufacturer in spray bottles marked ''A'' or ''B'' so the investigators were blinded to their contents. Cats were placed in a ward cage containing a small cotton towel that had been sprayed with solution A or B 30 minutes previously. Cats were then videotaped for 165 minutes; food intake during the period was measured to the nearest gram. Videotapes were scored at 5-minute intervals for occurrence of any of a catalog of 5 emotional, 6 activity, 3 resting, 4 consumption and 2 elimination behaviors.

No differences between the behavior of healthy and sick cats were identified. For all cats, highly significant positive correlations were found between grooming and rubbing (0.8), walking and rubbing (0.6), food interest and rubbing (0.8), eating and rubbing (0.8), grooming and food interest (0.94), grooming and eating (0.96). Exposure to Feliway resulted in significant ( 2 , pϽ0.05) increases in episodes of grooming food interest and eating. Food intake also was greater (pϭ0.1, Student's t-test) in cats exposed to Feliway (meanϮs.d. 9.8Ϯ17.6 vs. 0.2Ϯ0.6 gm/165 min).

These results suggest that exposure to Feliway may improve food intake of hospitalized cats, and that increased grooming activity could be a useful indicator of feeding behavior. The primary objective of this pilot study was to determine if partial peripheral parenteral nutrition (PPN) improves nitrogen balance (NB), as an indication of protein sparing, in dogs under-going short term nutritional restriction. Treatment effects on serum folate and insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) concentrations were also examined.

Three healthy adult dogs were randomly assigned to treatments in a cross over design. Treatments used were: 5% amino acid (AA), 5% glucose (Glu) solutions, and a control group using an electrolyte (Elec) solution. Solutions were administered intravenously into cephalic or saphenous veins at 60 ml/kg/day for 10 hours/day for 4 days. Serum folate and IGF-I were determined on days 0 and 4; total urine collection was performed on days 3 and 4.

Dogs receiving AA had a positive mean NB (1.38 g) over the last 2 trial days. NB was less negative with Glu (Ϫ8.41g) than with Elec (Ϫ10.08g) infusion. On day 4, serum folate was markedly reduced after AA (35% of day 0 values) but only mildly decreased after Glu (76%) and Elec (78%). IGF-I decreased by day 4 with all treatments, but less with AA (86% of day 0 values) and Glu (80%) than with Elec (73%).

In summary, AA infusion resulted in a positive NB, and Glu infusion appeared to provide some protein sparing compared to Elec. AA infusion decreased serum folate. PPN with AA or Gluc appeared to slightly improve serum IGF-1. In conclusion, these findings suggest that PPN improves NB in healthy dogs undergoing short term caloric restriction, but results need to be confirmed with a larger study. Greyhound trainers believe that thin dogs run faster. This experiment was designed to determine if this was true. Nine racing greyhounds (2-5 years old, 23-33 kg, both sexes) were offered once daily free choice for 30 min a dry diet containing 27% metabolizable energy (ME) protein, 36%ME fat and 27%ME nitrogen free extract for 9 weeks until body weight and food intake had stabilized. Dogs were then randomly assigned to receive either free choice food or 85% of the free choice amount for 9 weeks. Dogs were then crossed over: restricted fed dogs were fed free choice and free choice fed dogs were fed 85% of this free choice amount for 9 weeks. Dogs were weighed weekly and food intake was measured daily. Food intake and body weight stabilized after the first 4 weeks of each diet period. Dogs were exercised twice daily for 15 min in a paddock and raced on an oval sand track over 500 m twice weekly. Race times were measured with a photo-finish camera. Race times, body weights and food intake were compared over the last 5 weeks of each diet period. Total body water was measured by deuterium dilution on a rest day, and blood gases, lactate, CBC and chemistries were measured, before and after racing, during the final (9th) week of each diet period. When food intake was mildly restricted, race times were shorter (32.1Ϯ0.4 vs. 32.5Ϯ0.6 secs; pՅ0.03)), ME intake was less (137Ϯ11 vs. 155Ϯ17 kcal/kg 0.75 ; pՅ0.0001), dogs were lighter (28.2Ϯ2.9 vs. 29.9Ϯ3.3 kg; pՅ0.0001) and there were fewer segmented neutrophils (2194Ϯ794 vs. 2772Ϯ553/L; pՅ0.005). There was no effect on total body water (71Ϯ6 vs. 67Ϯ3%; ␤Յ0.2) or other blood parameters. In conclusion, greyhounds run markedly (0.4 sec or 0.2 m.sec Ϫ1 ) faster over 500 m when food intake is mildly restricted. This is equivalent to 6 m over 500 m. Intraperitoneal (IP) nutrition has been previously reported to successfully maintain dogs. The principal objective of this study was to determine the inflammatory response of the peritoneum to IP administration of nutrient solutions. Twelve healthy adult dogs were given 20% of resting energy requirements via the peritoneal cavity using a once daily, repeat-puncture technique for four days. Four dogs received a 10% dextrose solution, four dogs a 5% amino acid solution, and four dogs a 10% lipid emulsion. The remaining caloric requirements were given orally. On day 1, a baseline diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) was performed. On days 2, 3, and 4, prior to nutrient infusion, a DPL was repeated. The DPL fluid was analysed for total white cell count (TWCC) and differential. Comparisons between groups were made using ANOVA. Twice daily each dog was assessed for abdominal pain, body temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, mucous membrane colour, pulse quality, and capillary refill time.

The mean bodyweight in the dogs receiving amino acids increased significantly (pϽ0.05) due to residual peritoneal fluid. All dogs remained bright and alert, maintained a good appetite, and tolerated the repeat-puncture technique well. There was no evidence of abdominal pain, nor any changes to the cardinal signs. No episodes of sepsis occurred. Mean peritoneal TWCC in dogs given lipid were significantly higher (pϽ0.05) than those given dextrose or amino acids during most days with the exception of baseline. Administration of dextrose, amino acids, and lipid increased the mean TWCC over baseline with the most marked increase occurring in the lipid group. The predominant cell type on each day was the neutrophil. The neutrophils remained non-degenerate over the fiveday period. Large mononuclear cells became activated with numerous intra-cytoplasmic vacuoles, especially in the dogs receiving lipid. Sudan/methylene blue staining of the DPL sediment from dogs receiving the lipid emulsion identified numerous lipid-containing vacuoles in the large mononuclear cells.

It was concluded that a repeat puncture technique for administering peritoneal nutrients was well tolerated. Dextrose, amino acids, and a lipid emulsion produced evidence of peritoneal inflammation with the lipid emulsion associated with the greatest inflammatory response. Recent research has showed that there are two pools of glycogen in human and rodent skeletal muscle. The glycogen molecules in the two pools differ in their protein to carbohydrate ratios. The proglycogen (PG) molecule contains 10% protein and therefore precipitates in perchloric acid (PCA), while the macroglycogen (MG) molecule only contains 0.35% protein, which makes it soluble in PCA. Therefore, extraction of freeze-dried powdered muscle tissue in icecooled PCA allows separation of MG and PG.

The aims of this study were 1) to establish if MG and PG exist in horse muscle; 2) to compare analysis of total glycogen by acid hydrolysis (AC) with total glycogen obtained by adding MG and PG; and 3) to evaluate the reproducibilty of the AC, MG and PG determinations.

Glycogen concentration in muscle biopsies from 44 normal horses were analysed using each of two different methods; AC and MGϩPG determination. There was a strong correlation between total muscle glycogen values obtained by AC and MGϩPG (rϭ0.99). The error of the analytical methods (within biopsy variability) was calculated from duplicate analyses of individual muscle biopsies (nϭ44). The coefficient of variation (CV) was 3.6%, 3.8%, 6.7% and 4.6% for AC, MGϩPG, MG and PG respectively. The between biopsy variabilty (CV), obtained from two repeated biopsies of the m. gluteus medius (nϭ9), was 3.9%, 8.8% and 6.5% for MGϩPG, MG and PG respectively. The average concentration (Ϯsd) of PG in resting horses was 304 (Ϯ43) mmol glucosyl units/ kg dry weight. The corresponding value for MG was 186 (Ϯ54).

Our data showed that MG and PG exist in horse muscle and can be measured reliably in biopsy-sized samples. With this separation technique, it is now possible to study each pool of glycogen and determine how the two glycogen fractions change under conditions of breakdown and resynthesis. In 4 experimental studies, postparturient problems during the 1st 4 wk of lactation were monitored in 36 control cows and 38 experimental cows that were fed a fatty liver-inducing regimen during the dry period. Selected blood and liver parameters were compared in these cows to characterize the degree of fatty liver. Correlation between blood and liver parameters was also evaluated.

Before parturition, blood and liver parameters were similar between the two groups. After parturition in all cows, blood NEFA and liver triacylglycerol concentrations increased and liver glycogen decreased. Compared with control cows, experimental cows had higher concentrations of blood NEFA (1.01 Ϯ 0.08 v.s. 0.50 Ϯ 0.04 mmol/L, P Ͻ 0.001) and lower concentrations of liver lycogen (0.09 Ϯ 0.01 v.s. 0.13 Ϯ 0.01 mmol of glucose/g wet wt of liver, P Ͻ 0.001), and accumulated greater amounts of triacylglycerols in the liver (93.0 Ϯ 7.6 v.s. 32.5 Ϯ 2.7 mg/g wet wt of liver, P Ͻ 0.001) between 1 and 2 wk postpartum. These results indicate that experimental cows developed more severe fatty liver than did control cows. Experimental cows experienced postparturient problems including milk fever (38%), acetonemia (8%), abomasal displacement (8%), mastitis (10%), and foot problems (8%). Whereas 3%, 6% and 3% of control cows suffered from milk fever, mastitis and foot problems, respectively. Results of pooled data indicate that blood NEFA concentrations positively correlated with liver triacylglycerols (r ϭ 0.57, P Ͻ 0.001) and negatively correlated with liver glycogen (r ϭ Ϫ0.26, P Ͻ 0.05). In conclusion, dairy cows that developed fatty liver postpartum are likely to suffer from postparturient problems. In practice, blood NEFA concentrations postpartum can be used as a routine predictor for the development of fatty liver in dairy cows. The presence of telomerase enzyme activity in a body cavity effusion is a sensitive and specific marker for the presence of neoplasia in humans. Previous reports also indicate that telomerase activity can be detected in samples of effusions collected from dogs with neoplasia. The purpose of this study was to determine if telomerase activity is a specific feature of malignant effusions in canine and feline veterinary patients. Effusion samples were collected from client-owned animals presented to the Texas A&M Veterinary Medical Center. Inclusion in the study required that routine fluid analysis, including cytology, be performed, and that a definitive diagnosis be reached through standard diagnostic tests or necropsy. A total of 42 cases were included in the study. In each case, a sample was collected into a serum tube and centrifuged to obtain a cell pellet, which was frozen at Ϫ80ЊC until the telomerase assay could be performed. Storage time for samples had no evident impact on ability to detect telomerase activity. Each sample was assayed in tow independent experiments to determine the presence or absence of telomerase activity using a commercially available kit (Trap-eze kit; Oncor, Inc.). For telomerase negative samples, a further experiment was performed to rule out the presence of an inhibitor of telomerase activity. In no case was significant inhibition of telomerase activity detected.

We compared results of routing cytologic evaluation with results of the telomerase assay, to determine if either test was superior for the identification of neoplasia. We find that the telomerase assay is only marginally more sensitive than cytologic evaluation, and is less specific for the identification of neoplasia in patients with effusions. (Cytology: sensitivity ϭ 36%, specificity ϭ 100%; telomerase activity: sensitivity ϭ 50%, specificity ϭ 79%). The results of this study indicate that although the telomerase assay may constitute a useful adjunctive test, this test alone is not a sufficient basis to conclude whether a neoplastic or benign process underlies the presence of an effusion in veterinary patients. The purpose of this study was to determine if any decrease in antiviral titers due to vaccination or natural exposure occurred in dogs undergoing immunosuppressive chemotherapy for treatment of cancer. This study was intended as a pilot study to determine if further investigation of titer status in cancer patients is warranted. Serum samples were obtained prior to initiation of chemotherapy and again at least two weeks after treatment with an immunosuppressive chemotherapy agent. No dogs were vaccinated between pretreatment and post-treatment sampling times. Canine distemper virus (CDV) antibody titers were determined using a serum neutralization assay. Canine parvovirus (CPV) antibody titers were determined using a hemagglutination inhibition assay.

Pre-and post-treatment serum samples were evaluated from 11 dogs. Diagnoses included lymphoma (nϭ3), mammary carcinoma (nϭ2), and one case each of transitional cell carcinoma, hemangiopericytoma, apocrine gland adenocarcinoma of the anal sac, prostatic carcinoma, nasal carcinoma, and osteosarcoma. Chemotherapy agents administered included doxorubicin, mitoxantrone, cisplatin, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and cytosine arabinoside. Time between pre-and post-treatment samples ranged from 16 to 139 days (median ϭ 66 days, mean ϭ 69 days). Parvovirus titers remained unchanged in eight dogs, increased one-fold dilution in two dogs and decreased from Ͼ1:1024 to 1:512 in one dog. Distemper titers remained unchanged in seven dogs, decreased one-fold dilution in two dogs, and decreased two-fold dilutions in two dogs. No significant associations were found between chemotherapy agent, number of days between sampling times, and tumor type with regard to changes in CDV titers. Decreases in CDV titers were not statistically significant. However, the finding of a two-fold or greater decrease in CDV titers in two dogs followed 36 and 73 days warrants further investigation in a greater number of dogs for a more lengthy study period. Strong epidemiologic evidence exists for an association between the administration of feline inactivated vaccines (primarily feline leukemia and rabies virus vaccines) and subsequent soft tissue sarcoma development at injection sites. Although additional epidemiologic evidence also suggests that postvaccinal sarcomas develop in areas of inflammation at vaccine injection sites, the studies have thus fair failed to identify a specific brand of vaccine responsible for tumor development. Inflammation is considered by many to be a necessary antecedent to tumor production at vaccine sites in cats. All currently available subcutaneously administered rabies vaccines are adjuvanted and produce injection site reactions. A new nonadjuvanted canarypox rabies vector vaccine has recently been approved for use in dogs and cats in the United States. This study evaluated the injection site reactions of five nonadjuvanted feline vaccine combination products, four of which contained the new canarypox rabies vector fraction in a rodent model that has previously been shown to mimic the local inflammatory response as observed in cats after the subcutaneous administration of feline vaccines.
body_text.section: THE EFFECT OF CHEMOTHERAPY ON ANTIBODY

body_text.text: Thirty rats were divided into five groups of six. Each received a sham subcutaneous injection of saline and, on the opposite side, one of five feline vaccine combinations. Group A vaccine contained panleukopenia and calicivirus. Group B contained recombinant rabies with panleukopenia, rhinotracheitis, and calicivirus. Group C contained recombinant rabies with panleukopenia, rhinotracheitis, calicivirus, and a killed nonadjuvanted feline leukemia. Group D contained recombinant rabies, panleukopenia, rhinotracheitis, calicivirus, Chlamydia, and a killed nonadjuvanted feline leukemia. Group E contained recombinant rabies panleukopenia, rhinotracheitis, calicivirus, and Chlamydia. Twenty-one days postinjection the rats were killed and all injection sites were clipped and palpated for the presence of granuloma formation. The skin was tented and skin fold thickness over the injection sites was measured and tissue was removed for histologic evaluation. No evidence of granuloma formation was found on palpation, nor was a significant difference detected in skin fold thickness between vaccine groups or saline controls. Histologic evaluation of injections failed to detect any evidence of injection site inflammatory reactions.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF LOCAL POSTVACCINAL REACTIONS OF

body_text.text: Etoposide is a poorly water soluble anticancer agent, which uses polysorbate 80 in its vehicle. Polysorbate 80 is known to have potent histamine releasing properties in the dog (Masini et al., Agents Actions 16(6):470, 1985) , which has limited the use of Etoposide in veterinary oncology. Histamine release in the dog produces a dose-limiting effect due to hypotension, cutaneous urticaria and pruritus (Ogilvie et al., Am. J. Vet. Res. 49(8):1367 -1370 , 1988 ). These effects have not been sufficiently controlled previously with premedications to allow administration of an effective myelosuppressive dose of Etoposide (Hohenhaus and Matus, J. Vet. Internal Med. 4:239-241, 1990) . A pretreatment regimen was evaluated for use in controlling vehicle-associated clinical signs during Etoposide administration. The regimen consisting of prednisone, prednisolone, diphenhydramine and famotodine was used in a 12 dog study. Approximately 12 hours prior to the first Etoposide dose, animals were premedicated with prednisone (1 mg/kg) orally. Immediately prior to Etoposide administration on the first and second day of dosing, animals were premedicated with diphenhydramine (2 mg/ kg, IM), famotidine (0.5 mg/kg, IV) and prednisolone acetate (1 mg/kg, IM). Immediately prior to Etoposide administration on the third, fourth and fifth day of dosing, animals were premedicated with diphenhydramine (2 mg/kg, IM) and famotidine (0.5 mg/kg, IV).

body_text.section: EVALUATION OF LOCAL POSTVACCINAL REACTIONS OF

body_text.text: This pretreatment regimen allowed repeated continuous intravenous dosing (2 hours) for 5 successive days at doses of 20, 30, 40, or 60 mg Etoposide/m 2 . Dose administration was accomplished by the use of a Walkmed ambulatory pump. The high dose of Etoposide (60 mg/m 2 over 2 hours daily for 5 days) caused lymphopenia (50.3-69.4 % decrease), reticulocytopenia (64.9-88.1 % decrease), slight thrombocytopenia (19.6-25.5 % decrease), and neutropenia (49-54 % decrease). This pretreatment regimen controlled the adverse reactions sufficiently to allow administration of a myelosuppressive dose. The plasma exposure (AUC) of Etoposide increased with dose and there was no significant difference in exposure between the first and last day of dosing indicating that this pretreatment regimen did not interfere with pharmacokinetics. This pretreatment regimen allows increased exposure to water insoluble oncolytic compounds and histamine releasing excipients in the vehicle. The pharmacokinetic disposition of a drug depends to some degree on the duration of time over which the drug is given as well as the total dose. It is likely that different dosing regimes (infusion rates) for the same total dose of drug may result in varied toxicity and efficacy. The purpose of this study was to evaluate doxorubicin pharmacokinetic disposition and toxicoses in a large number of normal and tumor-bearing dogs of varying body weights given a single dose of doxorubicin calculated at varying body weights given at varying infusion durations (10-60 minutes). A single doxorubicin dose (0.75-1.5 mg/ kg; 25-35 mg/m 2 ) was delivered at a concentration of 1 mg/ml in 0.9% saline as a 10-, 15-, 20-, or 60-minute infusion. Plasma samples were collected from each dog over a 3-hour period, centrifuged immediately, and analyzed using previously described methods in our laboratory for doxorubicin pharmacologic analysis.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF LOCAL POSTVACCINAL REACTIONS OF

body_text.text: Fifty-six dogs were evaluated (31 normal, 25 tumor-bearing). For all dogs, infusion rate (mg/m 2 /min) inversely correlated with clearance, Cl (Rϭ Ϫ0.81, pϭ0.0001). Infusion rate positively correlated with the intercept of the distribution phase, A (Rϭ0.62, pϭ0.001), half-life of the elimination phase, t 1/2 (Rϭ0.41, pϭ0.002), area under the plasma concentration versus time curve, AUC (Rϭ0.65, pϭ0.0001), and hematopoietic toxicity (Rϭ0.34, pϭ0.01). As expected, clearance inversely correlated with hematopoietic toxicity (Rϭ Ϫ0.28, pϭ0.04). A faster infusion rate resulted in greater hematopoietic toxicity and a characteristic pharmacokinetic profile. Greater toxicity is likely due to higher and more prolonged doxorubicin levels in blood and bone marrow. The results of this study show the importance of normalizing dosage regimes by infusion rate rather than by infusion duration when considering dose-response phenomena in veterinary patients. Aggressive surgical removal with adequate margins is the treatment of choice for perianal adenocarcinomas in the dog. Recurrent disease is difficult to resect. For inoperable local or regionally confined (lymph node) disease, radiation therapy may be effective in slowing the disease progression but previous reports do not describe long-term survival in these dogs.

body_text.text: Seven dogs with histologically proven recurrent perianal adenocarcinoma with no evidence of enlarged regional lymph nodes (radiographic and ultrasonographic examination) and no evidence of other parenchymal metastases were treated with localized external beam irradiation and evaluated. In all 7 dogs, the recurrent neoplasm was resected and neoplastic cell extension into surgical margins was confirmed. External beam irradiation using a Cesium-137 teletherapy unit was performed in 25-30 fractions of 200-250 cGy each.

body_text.text: Dogs ranged in body size from 7 to 35 kg (mean, 22 kg), age from 9 to 17 years (mean, 11 years), and in breed (2 mixed breed, 5 purebreed). There were 3 male-intact, 2 male-neutered, and 2 female-neutered dogs. All dogs completed the planned teletherapy protocol and were physically examined every 2-3 months thereafter. Thoracic and abdominal radiography with abdominal ultrasonography was performed at each visit.

body_text.text: Regrowth of the perianal neoplasm occurred in 1 of the 7 dogs four months following the completion of the therapy protocol. None of the other 6 dogs had tumor regrowth; however, 5 of the 6 dogs had regional lymph node enlargement and subsequent confirmation of nodal metastatic disease within 11 to 17 months following treatment. The remaining dog died at 10 months with no evidence of local or nodal neoplastic involvement.
