body_text.text: Local regrowth of invasive perianal adenocarcinoma can be effectively managed with irradiation; however, our results strongly suggest concurrent irradiation of regional lymph nodes. A world wide web site was created to enhance instruction associated with the small animal problem solving elective course offered to third year veterinary students. Our goal was to provide students with increased opportunities to improve their clinical problem solving skills.
body_text.section: EVALUATION OF LOCAL POSTVACCINAL REACTIONS OF

body_text.text: Materials for 58 clinical cases were accessible from the course web site (education.vetmed.vt.edu/education/curriculum/VM9144/probhome.htm). Students could view history/physical examination findings, photographs of patients, and results of diagnostic tests such as images of radiographs and cytologic specimens. In addition, radiographs were made available for the students to evaluate. Before class, students were to list problems for each case, including the most likely causes for each problem, interpret results of laboratory tests, and recommend additional diagnostic tests. Students then met as a group to discuss the case(s) with the instructor.

At the end of the course students rated 6 items of the web site on a scale from 1 (not useful) to 6 (very useful). Mean scores of student ratings were: use of e-mail for asking questions (5.51), grades accessible from web site (5.31), having diagnostic test results before class (5.98), availability of diagnostic images (5.75), availability of radiographs for viewing (5.70), and overall rating of the web site (5.64). Students commented that having results of diagnostic tests before class discussions was very important because it allowed them to research all findings and consult their reference texts and class notes prior to making a diagnosis.

We feel that web-based case materials increased opportunities for students to practice their problem solving and diagnostic interpretation skills. Based on the positive response, we plan to continue this format and add additional case materials in the future. Overo coat coloration in the horse is thought to be genetically heterogeneous. The endothelin B receptor mutation responsible for Overo Lethal White Syndrome (OLWS) commonly results in overo white patterning in the coat of heterozygote carriers. The purpose of this study was to determine heterozygote carrier incidence by white patterning phenotype. Carrier incidence was determined by allele-specific PCR in 656 horses of white patterned breeding or phenotype and 49 solid colored horses. Phenotypes were assigned by consensus of two observers.

Heterozygote incidence appeared to divide into four general categories by frequency: Ͼ95% (frame overos, frame blend overos, extremely white calico overos), 36-75% (bald-faced, breeding stock white, calico, medicine hat, toveros), 7-17% (breeding stock Paints, tobiano, sabino overo, splashed white overo), and Ͻ1% (non-frame overo blends, minimal calico overos and solids). Carrier phenotype is most commonly frame overo, but can vary widely in the amount of white patterning. Augmentation of frame patterning occurs in some carriers such as extremely white calico overos. Suppression of frame patterning is less common (breeding stock), as is fusion with another prominent white patterns (tobiano, sabino overo or splashed white overo). The variation in incidence of the OLWS mutation within overo phenotypes is evidence of the genetic diversity of overo patterning and suggests the presence of other genes that affect white patterning. We believe that frame, calico, splashed white and sabino are distinct overo patterns. Other overo and overo blend white patterns are probably produced by combinations of factors to which the OLWS mutation can contribute, but is not essential. Activated coagulation time (ACT) is used to assess the coagulation of whole blood via contact activation. Because ACT testing is simple, inexpensive, and rapid, it is often recommended as an in-clinic hemostatic screen for congenital or acquired disorders involving the intrinsic and/or common coagulation pathways. It is also used to monitor heparinization. Feline ACT reference values have been widely reported as Ͻ65s, but these reports have been based largely on a single study of 22 cats from which samples were collected via jugular catheters.

The primary purpose of this study was to establish feline ACT reference values using jugular venipuncture and direct collection into Becton-Dickinson ACT vacuum tubes. The protocol described on the ACT tube insert was modified such that inspection for clots was first done 45s after blood entered each tube, and subsequently at 10s intervals. Blood for ACTs was collected from 95 apparently healthy cats presented for elective surgery at a private practice. Three samples (S1, S2, S3) were attempted for each cat: S1) pre-sedation (nϭ41); S2) tube 1 of 2 consecutive samples from a single venipuncture of the contra-lateral jugular after sedation with acepromazine/ketamine, IV or IM (nϭ79); and S3) tube 2 post-sedation (nϭ57). Collection success was limited by cat temperament and adequacy of blood flow. Venipuncture quality was rated subjectively on a 3point scale.

Median ACTs were 95s for each sample group, with ranges of 45-245s (S1), 55-185s (S2), and 45-225s (S3). The middle 95% of values ranged inclusively from 55-185s (S1), 65-135s (S2), 45-145s (S3), and 55-165s overall (177 ACTs). There were no statistically significant differences (Wilcoxon Signed Rank tests, non-normal data) between the pre-and post-sedation ACTs (pϭ0.42) or between ACTs for tubes 1 and 2 post-sedation (pϭ0.14). There were no statistically significant relationships between ACTs and venipuncture quality (Spearman rank coefficient ϭ Ϫ0.03) or cat gender (Kruskal-Wallis test, p-values Ͼ 0.05). The 6 ACTs Ͼ165s (185-245s) occurred in 4 cats, but in only 1 cat were values repeatedly Ͼ165s (245, 185, 185s) . No cat had clinical evidence of a hemostatic disorder. With the protocol used, cats with ACTs repeatably Ͼ165s should be further evaluated for hemostatic disorders, though clinical disease may be absent. A 1-tube sampling method appears to be adequate, with or without acepromazine/ketamine sedation. The purpose of this investigation was to determine arterial blood flow characteristics and interobserver variability in the distal thoracic limb of normal horses using angle-corrected pulsed-wave Doppler ultrasonography (PWD). PWD was used on 8 horses to establish reference ranges for peak systolic, end diastolic and mean velocities (MV), resistive and pulsatile indices. Interobserver and patient variability was determined by repeating similar measurements on the same horse weekly for 8 weeks.

The multiple horse study established mean Ϯ std and reference ranges of velocities and indices for five distal thoracic limb arteries. Correlations were moderate to strong in all horses for each arterial site, and gradual decrease in vascular velocities from the proximal to the distal limb was noted. Over time mean velocity was the least variable parameter (PϽ0.05 ANOVA, see table). Horses had blood flow characteristics consistent with either a resistive or non resistive pattern type. The classification was based upon the overall degree of baseline elevation of the diastolic portion of the tracing. The single horse study showed there were no operator effects.

It was concluded that different operators can reliably measure PWD characteristics at any site on the equine distal limb. MV is the most consistent single parameter to monitor in a patient over time. Larger number of horses are needed to see if the resistive/non-resistive categories are consistent over a larger population. If so, it could suggest a fundamental difference in downstream resistance characteristics of forelimb arteries in normal horses. It has been assumed that, for some drugs, disposition may differ between pregnant and nonpregnant animals, which may necessitate a change in dose rate. We hypothesized that volume of distribution may be larger, or clearance faster, for aminoglycoside antibiotics in pregnant mares vs nonpregnant mares, which would result in lower plasma concentration. To examine this hypothesis, we administered gentamicin sulfate to seven Thoroughbred and Quarterhorse mares on two occasions, followed by plasma drug gentamicin assay and pharmacokinetic analysis. The first dose was administered 1-4 weeks before parturition (mean weight 578 kg) and the second dose was administered in the period 1-4 weeks after parturition (mean weight 518 kg). The dose administered at each time was approximately 6.6 mg/kg, IV. Plasma gentamicin concentrations were determined using fluorescence polarization immunoassay and pharmacokinetic analysis was performed using a two-compartment model. The plasma concentration vs time profiles were similar, and total area-under-the-curve was almost identical for mares at late gestation vs early lactation. Mean volume of distribution at steady-state was 0.153 (Ϯ 0.02) and 0.156 (Ϯ0.03) L/kg, systemic clearance was 1.06 (Ϯ 0.17) and 1.11 (Ϯ 0.17) mL/kg/min, and mean elimination half-life was 2.2 and 2.1 hr, for pregnant and nonpregnant mares, respectively. We concluded that there were no differences in drug distribution and clearance between pregnant and nonpregnant mares. Plasma gentamicin was also assayed in plasma of newborn foals after an injection of 6.6 mg/kg to three of the mares within 60 min of parturition. Gentamicin was undetectable in plasma samples from these foals. We conclude that gentamicin distribution does not change in pregnancy, and apparently does not cross the placenta of mares at term. Chloramphenicol has been used for treating a variety of bacterial infections in dogs and cats, but because of decreased availability of some dose forms, there has been interest in substituting florfenicol, which is pharmacologically similar. Florfenicol (Nuflor) is registered for use in cattle, but pharmacokinetics for dogs and cats has not been reported. This study was conducted to determine the disposition of florfenicol in order to examine its potential as a therapeutic agent in dogs and cats. The NCCLS quality control ranges of MIC for florfenicol are 2-8 mcg/ml. Florfenicol 300 mg/ml solution was administered IM and SC to four dogs at a dose of 20 mg/kg, and a 100 mg/ml solution was administered to 6 cats IV, IM, and oral at a dose of 22 mg/kg. Florfenicol plasma concentrations were determined with high pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC). In dogs after IM injection, florfenicol mean peak plasma concentrations were 2.2 mcg/ ml and mean elimination half-life was 4.6 hr. Concentrations were above a MIC of 2.0 mcg/ml for less than 2 hours. After SC administration, florfenicol was absorbed poorly and inconsistently with peak concentrations less than 1.0 mcg/ ml in all dogs. By contrast, the 100 mg/ml solution in cats was absorbed well from both IM and oral routes, with peak concentrations of 19 mcg/ml and 22 mcg/ml, respectively. Absorption was high from both routes (96% and 89% from IM and oral, respectively). IV elimination half-life was 3.75 hr and volume of distribution was 0.6 L/kg. The half-life was 3.4 hr and 4.7 hr for IM and oral dose, respectively. In cats, the 100 mg/ml florfenicol formulation produced concentrations above 2 mcg/ml for 12 hr and 18 hr, after IM, and oral doses, respectively, and concentrations were maintained above an MIC of 8.0 mcg/ml for 10 hr and 6 hr after IM and oral doses, respectively. The objectives of this study were: (1) to compare the SC and IM pharmacokinetics of oxytetracycline approved for IM use (OXY shot LA) with those of another oxytetracycline product approved for SC use (BioMycin); and (2) to compare SC and IM pharmacokinetics of these long-acting oxytetracycline products. Each of the products was administered to 6 cattle IM and SC, using a crossover design, and blood samples were collected at frequent intervals thereafter. Concentrations of oxytetracycline in serum were determined by microbiological assay and pharmacokinetic values were calculated using a model-independent approach.

Irrespective of formulation or route of administration, oxytetracycline was rapidly absorbed and maintained concentrations Ͼ 0.5 g/ml for 72 hours after administration. Based on confidence intervals for differences in mean AUC and C max values, products were bioequivalent whether administered IM or SC. The similarities between IM and SC pharmacokinetics were surprising in light of previous assumptions that IM administration would result in a higher rate of drug absorption.

The purpose of this study was to adapt forced expiratory maneuvers to horses in order to detect lung function changes due to small airway inflammatory disease (SAID) or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Horses were sedated after collection of lung mechanics data including resistance (Rl) and dynamic lung compliance (Cdyn). Forced expiration was induced from total lung capacity by exposure of the horse's airways to a negative pressure reservoir. Flow and volume were computed from the instantaneous changes in pressure in the reservoir yielding forced expiratory flows at 80 to 95 % (FEF 80-95% ) of the forced vital capacity, and other parameters of the forced expiratory flow-volume curve.

Lung function tests were performed in 21 horses (7 controls, 5 SAID, 5 COPD in remission, and 4 COPD in crisis). Rl and Cdyn of COPD horses in crisis were significantly different from control values (PϽ0.05). FEF 80-95% in horses with SAID, and COPD in remission and crisis were significantly lower than in control horses (PϽ0.05). FEF 80% was significantly lower in COPD horses in remission than in horses with SAID (PϽ0.05). FEF 85-95% was significantly lower in COPD horses in crisis than in horses with SAID (PϽ0.05). Forced expiratory flowvolume curves demonstrate flow limitation in horses with SAID and COPD in remission. But flow limitation is more severe in COPD horses in crisis. Tilmicosin has anti-inflammatory activity that reduces the damage to the lung associated with bacterial infections. The use of bacterial infection as a model to study the anti-inflammatory activity of a drug may alter cellular morphology of BALF cells suggesting a mode of drug action. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BALF) cell populations in calves were studied after saline lavage. Cell numbers, recovery, differential cytology and chemotaxis were determined. After 2 treatments (Tx; Tilmicosin 15 mg/kg) or nothing (Control) the calves were re-lavaged and the same parameters determined. Treatment with tilmicosin did not alter the differential cytologic features (PMN control: 27 Ϯ 11; PMN Tx: 34 Ϯ 13; Macophage control: 53 Ϯ 30; Macrophage Tx: 64 Ϯ 12) or the chemotactic index when compared to control (PMN control:2.9 Ϯ 2.1; PMN Tx: 5.5 Ϯ 5.3; Macrophage control: 4.6 Ϯ 6.4; Macrophage Tx: 7.4 Ϯ 10.9). Unlike traditional macrolides (erythromycin), tilmicosin modulates inflammation by mechanisms that do not appear to involve the ability of cells to migrate into the lung associated with mild inflammatory stimuli. The differential cytology did not suggest that apoptosis was a predominant feature of the neutrophil obtained from the lungs of calves treated with tilmicosin. The temporal variations in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) analysis and variations due to separate aliquots and lung sites were studied in 5 horses with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and in 5 horses free of respiratory disease (controls). Horses were stabled in dusty conditions before (five months) and throughout experimental period. Bronchoalveolar lavage were performed as a standard method described in literature. In study 1, BALF were collected from the right lung monthly in February, March and April. In study 2, BALF analyses were performed using 2 incremental instillation of 250 ml of isotonic saline in the same bronchial site during the first monthly evaluation. In study 3, BALF were collected from both lungs and compared. BALF analysis included return volume, total count cells and differential cytologic evaluation. In study 1, COPD affected horses had significantly (p Ͻ 0.05) more neutrophils and epithelial cells, and had lower return volume and lymphocytes counts than control horses. Although not significant, there were individual variations for neutrophils in BALF in COPD affected horses throughout monthly evaluation. In study 2, the second aliquot of BALF obtained from COPD affected horses and from control horses, had signiticant less neutrophils than in the first one. In study 3, no significant difference were found in cytology and cell count from BAL fluid obtained from both lungs, in both COPD affected horses and in control horses. In studies 1, 2 and 3, COPD affected horses had neutrophils percentage Ͼ 10% and the number of neutrophils and the volume return remained significantly different between groups over time. Result of this study suggest that despite temporal effects and variations due to separate aliquots, BAL fluid analysis of COPD affected horses are consistently different from thoses of control horses. This study was funded by Le Groupe de Recherche en Médecine Equine du Québec (GREMEQ) and Le Fonds du Centenaire de la Faculté de Médecine Vétérinaire.

Samples from cats without clinical suspicion of haemobartonellosis (control cats ; n ϭ 137) were submitted as a cohort to a case with suspected haemobartonellosis or were selected from samples for which a complete blood cell count was performed for other reasons. Primers that detect a segment of the 16S rRNA gene common to both sequenced strains (California and Ohio) of H. felis were utilized in either a nested PCR or timed-release PCR. Cytologic evidence of red blood cell infection by H. felis was present in 5 of 66 cats (7.6%) with suspected haemobartonellosis and in o of 137 control cats (0%)

BIBREF9.title: Logistic regression indicated that a blood segmented neutrophil concentration Ͻ2,500 cell/l was the best indicator of gram-negative mastitis, with a sensitivity of 87%, a specificity of 93%, and an overall accuracy of 89% for predicting mastitis type. BIBREF11.title: Bacteremic cows have a pronounced leukopenia (2350 cells/ml) compared to non-bacteremic cows (6400 cells/ml), largely due to neutropenia (150 cells/ml). Creatinine is significantly higher (pϭ0.001) in bacteremic (1.35mg/dl) compared to non-bacteremic cows (1.1mg/dl) though still in the normal range. For comparison of CFU between groups cows were grouped as Ͼ100,000 or Ͻ100,000 CFU/ml on 0hr milk culture. Significant differences in the percent of cows with Ͼ100,000 CFU/ml existed (pϽ0.005). Seventy-four and 38 % of bacteremic and non-bacteremic cows had Ͼ100,000 CFU/ml respectively. Bacteremic cows had significantly fewer DIM (99) compared with non-bacteremic cows
BIBREF11.venue: Previously we reported a substantial proportion of cows with acute coliform mastitis (ACM) were concurrently bacteremic. Classification of cows into severity groups revealed bacteremia with a major pathogen

BIBREF13.title: The objective of this study was to determine whether intravenous glucose infusion alters carbohydrate oxidation (CHOox) or muscle glycogen use in horses during exercise. In random order, 6 horses completed two trials consisting of 90 min of treadmill exercise at 34 Ϯ 1% of peak oxygen uptake

authors.first: Effects Of Glucose Infusion On Substrate Utili-Zation In Horses

BIBREF14.title: CO 2 production, and respiratory exchange ratio (RER) were measured by indirect calorimetry. From these measurements and use of standard equations, rates of CHOox were calculated. Biopsies of middle gluteal muscle for measurement of glycogen concentration were obtained before and after exercise. Plasma glucose was higher (PϽ0.05) in Glu than in Con throughout exercise. Net muscle glycogen utilization was similar in Glu and Con (164 Ϯ 30 and 161 Ϯ 24 mmol/kg dry muscle, respectively). Whereas RER declined as exercise duration increased during both trials, RER was significantly (PϽ0.05) greater in Glu than in Con between 30 and 90 min of exercise. Consequently
BIBREF14.venue: while in the other trial (Con) saline was infused. During exercise

BIBREF15.title: We conclude that glucose infusion in horses does not alter muscle glycogen use during 90 min of low-intensity exercise. However, the increased blood glucose availability in Glu causes CHO oxidation to be maintained above control. Inasmuch as muscle glycogen use was similar in Glu and Con, the higher rate of CHOox in Glu can be attributed to increased utilization of blood glucose. 215 INFLUENCE OF DIETARY ANTI-OXIDANTS ON EXERCISE-INDUCED MUSCLE DAMAGE IN SLED DOGS

BIBREF16.title: 41 dogs were exercised on each of 3 days in teams of up to 16 dogs pulling a sled and musher over snow for 48 miles each day. Two groups of age-, weight-, and sex-matched dogs were used: with the investigators blinded to treatment, a supplemented group (S) (nϭ21) received, in addition to their regular diet, vitamin E (460 iu/day), vitamin C (1 g per day) and ␤-carotene (5 mg/day) for 6 weeks prior to and during exercise; a non-supplemented (control) group, (nϭ20) received the same diet without supplementation. Blood was drawn from the dogs at the beginning of the experiment (A), prior to exercise (B) and following each day of exercise (C, D and E). Plasma was analyzed for vitamin E and C and retinol concentration, and creatine kinase (CK) activity
BIBREF16.venue: Free radical induced damage to skeletal muscle is regarded as an important cause of myopathy during exercise. In order to determine the influence of dietary antioxidants on muscle damage in sled dogs

BIBREF17.title: Numerous studies have investigated hemodynamic changes in the laminitic equine digit, however little is known about the biology of the cellular components of the equine digital vasculature. In this study, we cultured palmar digital vessel endothelial cells (EC), and characterized the expression pattern of 3 mediators important in endo-toxemia-related disease mechanisms: endothelin-1 (ET-1), interleukin-1 beta (IL-1b) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2)

BIBREF18.title: ET-1 mRNA was expressed equally in AEC and VEC; and no change in expression was noted upon LPS exposure. IL-1 message was not detected in either control or LPSexposed AEC or VEC (fidelity of technique was confirmed using LPS-stimulated monocyte mRNA as positive control)
BIBREF18.venue: cell type was documented by LDL uptake, and by cell morphology via light and electron microscopy

BIBREF20.title: After the subcutaneous administration of ceftazidime, the mean elimination half-life was 0.8 hours and the mean serum drug concentration exceeded the MIC for P. aeruginosa for only 4.3 hours. Two dogs had adverse gastrointestinal side effects. After the loading bolus and during continuous infusion of ceftazidime, mean serum drug concentration exceeded 16g/ml (2 times MIC) in all dogs. The mean serum concentration at steady-state was 22g/ml. No adverse effects were observed. Due to the short elimination half-life and observed adverse effects, it was concluded that subcutaneous administration of ceftazidime is likely to be unsatisfactory in the treatment of P. aeruginosa infection in dogs. We predict that administration of ceftazidime as a loading bolus (4.4mg/kg, IV) and continuous infusion (4.1mg/kg/hr, IV), will be effective in the treatment of dogs with P. aeruginosa infections which are resistant to, or in dogs which experience toxicity from, aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones

BIBREF21.title: Two of the thoracic radiographs were interpreted as normal. A diagnosis of ELP was confirmed on histology if there were intra-airway aggregates of lipid-laden macrophages that did not appear to be primarily responding to an insult. All histologic lesions were classified according to size (microscopic, nϭ7; Ͻ1cm, nϭ9; Ն1 cm, nϭ5), location (subpleural, nϭ20; parenchymal, nϭ4; perivascular, nϭ3), distribution (focal, nϭ3; multifocal, nϭ16; diffuse, nϭ1) and lung lobe involvement (1 lobe, nϭ6; Ն2 lobes, nϭ10; unknown, nϭ5)

TABREF34.text: The PMTT revealed that all dogs when Mg depleted (day 28 of the depletion trial), excreted Ͻ 25% of an infused Mg dose compared with the same animals who, when repleted (days 42 and 44), excreted Ͼ 75% of an infused Mg dose (Friedman repeated measures ANOVA on Ranks and Student-Newman-Keuls, pϽ0.05) [see box plot graph]. With respect to serum Mg concentrations, significant decreases were recorded in total serum Mg (1.01Ϯ0.36 mg/dl-normal, 1.48Ϯ0.02) and ionized Mg (0.29 Ϯ 0.07 mg/dl-normal, 0.43Ϯ0.02) by day 7 of the 0.01% (Mg depleted) diet feeding trial. Furthermore, serum Mg concentrations were depressed compared with baseline throughout the depletion trial (Friedman repeated measures ANOVA on Ranks and Dunnnett's, pϽ0.05). Total serum Mg and iMg were correlated strongly on days 7, 21, 28 [depletion trial] (Pearson product moment correlation, pϽ0.001).Thus, parenteral magnesium tolerance testing identified Mg depletion in dogs fed a 0.01% Mg diet. Serum iMg and TMg values became significantly reduced compared to baseline within one week of feeding a 0.01% Mg depleted diet.144 CANINE NEUTROPHIL PHAGOCYTOSIS IS CORRELATED WITH MEMBRANE FLUIDITY. 1 M.K. Whereas glucose induced oscillations in [Ca 2ϩ ] i in WT islets, it did not do so in KO islets. We conclude from these results that calbindin buffers calcium influx and controls the rate of insulin release via regulation of [Ca 2ϩ ] i . Calbindin may have a regulatory role in glucose-induced secretion via its effects on [Ca 2ϩ ] i oscillations. 185 DETECTION OF FECAL OCCULT BLOOD IN CATS FED VAR-IOUS DIETS. S. Puhl Tuffli, and R. The opossum (Didelphis virginiana) is definitive host for Sarcocystis neurona, agent of equine protozoal myeloencephalitis (EPM), a common and potentially debilitating neurologic disease of horses. Because intermediate host(s) of S. neurona are not known, sporocysts for horse challenge can only be acquired from naturally infected opossums.

back_matter.text: This study was designed to evaluate the use of Saccomanno cell transport fluid media in the preservation of cells obtained from canine bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) samples. Our hypothesis was that adding the preservative to the BAL fluid would be beneficial in preserving the samples for future analysis when compared to control samples taken concurrently and maintained without preservative. The Saccomanno fluid is methanol based and is used in human medicine primarily for transport and preservation of bronchial brush samples. This fluid is reported to increases diagnostic cell yield, decrease obscuring mucus, maintain cellular integrity, and limit cellular degeneration when compared to samples prepared with no preservative.BAL samples were collected using standard technique, and were then split into a study group (Saccomanno fluid added) and a control group (no additions). Samples were analyzed (total nucleated cell counts [TNCC] and cytocentrifuge differential [CYTO] counts) immediately following collection and then every 24 hours for 5 days. Comparison of the study (Saccomanno) samples to the control (non-treated) samples found that TNCC decreased daily in all samples but were not different between groups, while on CYTO there were more ruptured cells identified on the non-treated samples when compared to the treated samples, suggesting cellular deterioration of the untreated samples. While additional samples are continuing to be obtained, it appears that Saccomanno cell transport fluid media immediately added to canine bronchoalveolar lavage samples will improve cellular preservation over time when compared to similar samples not maintained in Saccomanno fluid. This should be helpful in maintaining the quality of BAL samples when transported and not processed immediately. Summer pasture-associated obstructive pulmonary disease (SPAOPD) is a recurrent seasonal obstructive pulmonary disease observed in horses residing on pasture the in southeastern region of United States. In order to identify environmental factors associated with the occurrence of SPAOPD in horses residing in Louisiana a population of 21 SPAOPD-affected horses and 8 non-affected horses were studied. The horses were evaluated clinically to determine if there was a correlation between changes in clinical signs and changes in selected climatic factors during the period of 1992 through 1994. The daily assessment included the nostril flare, abdominal lift and respiratory rate. The clinical score was calculated based on the nostril flare and abdominal lift.

Unaffected horses kept at pasture conditions had no appreciable changes in clinical scores throughout the years. The SPAOPD-affected horses kept at pasture had a clear seasonal onset of clinical signs during late spring, especially the month of May. The clinical signs persisted until late autumn, i.e., November. The daily clinical scores and respiratory rates were positively correlated with measurements of temperature (maximum temperature and dew point temperature) in all 21 SPAOPD-affected horses. However, the degree of correlation estimated in this exploratory data suggests that mere fluctuations in daily temperature or dew point temperature are unlikely to be the sole determinants of clinical severity.The seasonal occurrence of SPAOPD and the correlation with elevations in temperature and humidity, both conditions that are conducive to mold growth and increased vegetation, are consistent with the concept that the disease may be due to a hyperresponsiveness to mold spores and/or pollens.

Ovine pulmonary carcinoma (OPC) (jaagsiekte) is a naturally-occurring contagious bronchioalveolar adenocarcinoma most likely related to type D/B-retrovirus infection. OPC is a well-differentiated tumor of alveolar type II or nonciliated bronchiolar (Clara) cells that occasionally metastasizes to regional lymph nodes. Affected sheep are typically adults and present with tachypnea and coughing that worsen with exercise and bilateral nasal discharge. The purpose of this retrospective study was to describe the clinicopathologic and histopathologic findings in 5 cats presented to the Teaching Hospital from 1988-1995 with a proliferative, pulmonary disease resembling OPC. No gender or breed predilections (mean ageϭ9.6 years) were evident. Owner complaints included a 6-10 month history of progressive weight loss and a 2-week to 5.5-month history of lower respiratory signs (dyspnea (3/5), cough (3/5), tachypnea (2/5), wheezing (2/5)). In all cats, clinical signs had improved temporarily with various combinations of antibiotics with corticosteroids, bronchodilators, and diuretics. On physical examination, tachypnea (rangeϭ55-130 BPM) was the most frequent finding. Dyspnea (2/5), harsh lung sounds (2/5), cachexia (3/5), dehydration (2/5), and respiratory stridor with a serous nasal discharge (1/5) also were noted. No significant hematologic or biochemical abnormalities were observed. All cats were FeLV and FIV seronegative. Thoracic radiographs revealed a diffuse interstitial-nodular pattern with multifocal bronchoalveolar infiltrates. Lung aspirate or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid cytologies revealed mild to moderate nonseptic inflammation. Microbial cultures from the deep lung did not yield clinically significant bacterial or fungal growth.Gross and histologic features of lung tissue revealed striking similarities to OPC. Affected lung was pale tan and firm with multifocal white punctate foci scattered over the pleural surface. Lung parenchyma contained multiple unencapsulated, coalescing nodules containing dilated alveolar spaces lined by variably differentiating cuboidal cells resembling type II alveolar cells and columnar bronchiolar cells with patchy fibrosis. Alveolar histiocytosis, lymphocytic interstitial inflammation, and smooth muscle hypertrophy along terminal airways were common features. Hilar lymph node metastasis was found in 1 cat. Electron microscopy of lung tissue (1 cat) revealed a proliferating cell population with features suggestive of alveolar type II epithelial cells. No microbial organisms were identified by special stains.As with OPC, the prognosis for untreated feline pulmonary carcinomatosis (FPC) was poor. Four cats died or were euthanatized due to progressive disease within 4 days of diagnosis; while one cat survived 5 months with symptomatic therapy.
